questions.text: A patient who had a high-grade fever and impaired senses was taken to the emergency room. He was determined to have meningococcal meningitis. Which of the following is the most appropriate empirical therapy option?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Ceftriaxone

Ceftriaxone is the recommended first-line antibiotic for the empirical treatment of meningococcal meningitis. Ceftriaxone is a broad-spectrum antibiotic that is effective against Neisseria meningitidis and provides good coverage against other common bacteria causing meningitis.

  • It has excellent penetration into the central nervous system, making it an appropriate choice for treating meningitis.
  • Piperacillin-tazobactam (option 2) is not typically used as the first-line therapy for meningococcal meningitis. It has broader coverage against Gram-negative bacteria and anaerobes, but it is not as effective against Neisseria meningitidis.
  • Penicillin G (option 3) used to be the drug of choice for treating meningococcal meningitis, but resistance to penicillin has become increasingly common. Ceftriaxone is now preferred due to its broader spectrum and better efficacy.
  • Cotrimoxazole (option 4) is not a recommended first-line therapy for meningococcal meningitis. It may have some activity against Neisseria meningitidis, but other antibiotics like ceftriaxone are more effective and commonly used.




 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition , Page no 1104.

choices.text: Undiagnosed even after 1 week of thorough investigation

questions.text: Which of the following does not include the definition of "pyrexia of unknown origin"?
questions.solution:
The current definition of fever of unknown origin (FUO) does not include undiagnosed after one week of investigation. The criterion "diagnosis uncertain, after 1 week of evaluation" which was previously a part of the definition has been removed.


FUO is currently defined as:
  1. Fever >= 38.3OC (>101OF) on at least two occasions (Option 1)
  2. Duration of >= 3 weeks (Option 2)
  3. No known immunocompromised state (Option 4)
  4. Diagnosis is uncertain after thorough history taking, physical examination, and obligatory investigations.
 
  • Inflammation of Unknown Origin (IUO) is closely related to FUO. It has the same definition, except for the body temperature criterion.
  • IUO is characterized by elevated inflammatory parameters (such as CRP or ESR) on multiple occasions for at least three weeks in an immunocompetent patient with normal body temperature.
  • The causes and workups for IUO are similar to those for FUO.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 145.

questions.text: Which of the following doesn't make up SIRS?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Urine output < 1 ml/kg/hour





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2242.

questions.text: Pick the option that is less likely to be caused by non-typable H. Influenze:
questions.solution:
• Non-typable Haemophilus influenzae is more commonly associated with respiratory tract infections, such as otitis media, exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and puerperal sepsis.
 
  • Meningitis is less likely to be caused by Non typable Haemophilus influenzae among the given options


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1242.

questions.text: The WHO recommends that latent TB should be ruled out in all of the following circumstances, with the exception of which one
questions.solution:
LATENT TB INFECTION: 

State of persistent immune response to stimulation by Mycobacterium tuberculosis antigens without evidence of clinically manifested active TB. 
Latent TB should be ruled out before treatment with TNF-alpha inhibitors, in patients of silicosis and patients undergoing hemodialysis among the provided options. As these conditions can cause reactivation of TB. 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1379.

questions.text: It is uncommon to have relative bradycardia in:
questions.solution:
• Relative bradycardia ( also known as Faget's sign) is uncommon in Staphylococcus infection as compared to given options.
 
  • Typhoid fever, brucellosis, leptospirosis, various drug-induced fevers, and factitious fever all exhibit temperature-pulse dissociation (relative bradycardia).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 944.

questions.text: The cause of "Fever Blister" is
questions.solution:
Fever blisters are caused due to reactivation of latent HSV-1 virus
 
  • Oral lesions of the mouth such as fever blisters or cold sores are usually associated with recurring infection rather than with the first infection.
  • These skin lesions caused by Herpes simplex virus Type-1 (HSV-1) usually occur on the face, particularly the cheeks, chin, around the mouth, or on the forehead. On occasion, lesions may also appear on an infant's buttocks, commonly referred to as a 'napkin rash'.
  • Fever blisters or herpes febrilis is the most typical lesion and happens when the viral infection is reactivated due to elevated body temperature.




Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 27th edition, Page no 459, 463.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old female with a history of fever, joint discomfort, and rash visited the OPD. NSAIDs had been recommended.
After a week, the patient's nose started to look reddish. This was caused by?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Chikungunya

After using NSAIDs for one week, the patient developed a reddish discoloration across their nose, as shown in the image. It is known as Chik sign.
  • The mucocutaneous junction (lip, glans) is the most frequently affected region for fixed drug eruption, followed by the vaginal skin (glans). (Option 4)
  • Based on their medical history, which included chronic joint pain and rash, the most likely diagnosis was pigmentation brought on by Chikungunya. 
  • In cases of Chikungunya, the nose pigmentation is noticeable; this condition has not been noted in cases of any other viral exanthem.


Reference: Fitzpatrick's Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 1369.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions does glucocorticoid use decrease mortality?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Severe typhoid
 
  • In critically ill patients with enteric fever, combining dexamethasone with chloramphenicol resulted in a significantly lower mortality rate than chloramphenicol alone.
 
  • In cerebral malaria, corticosteroids can be used to decrease swelling but can reduce the host immunity response towards the infection as well.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1295.

choices.text: Hypoglycemia, blood sugar level less than 40 mg

questions.text: Which of the following statements about severe malaria is not true?
questions.solution:
Hematocrit more than 15 is the incorrect statement.

All of the following are true about severe malaria except Hematocrit more than 15 as Hematocrit <15 is suggestive of severe malaria.

Malaria with the severe form of Falciparum shows:

  • <15% hematocrit or <50 g/L hemoglobin level and having a parasitemia level of more than 100,000/microL.
  • More than 3 mg/dL (>265 micromol/L) of serum creatinine 
  • plasma glucose level of <40 mg/dL (<2.2 mmol/L).
  • Unarousable coma
  • Acidosis pH < 7.25
  • SBP < 80 mm Hg 
  • Convulsions
  • Jaundice 
  • Pulmonary edema



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1724.

questions.text: When patients are being monitored daily, the tourniquet test is utilised for:
questions.solution:
• The tourniquet test (TT) is a physical examination technique that can identify and stratify dengue disease.
  • Infection with DENV may result in increased capillary permeability, a physiological state that the TT exploits by applying sustained pressure to these small vessels.
  • Positive tourniquet test with greater than 10 petechiae per one square inch.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1640, 1641.

questions.text: Which of the following should be monitored the most closely in a person with dengue hemorrhagic fever?
questions.solution:
• Thrombocytopenia can be seen in Dengue as well.
  • Diagnosis of DHF needs the presence of Rise in Hematocrit of 20% or more i.e. Hemoconcentration.
  • Despite the name, the critical feature that distinguishes DHF from dengue fever is not haemorrhage , but rather plasma leakage resulting from increased vascular permeability.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1643.

questions.text: Which of the following areas of the brain is NOT connected with atrophy due to HIV infection?
questions.solution:
HIV dementia is characterized by 
  • Subcortical dementia, with white matter involvement,
  • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy
  • Demyelination
Immunohistochemistry studies show that the virus is most densely located in the basal ganglia, subcortical regions, and frontal cortex.

Radiographic imaging reveals:
  • Cerebral atrophy and particularly
  • Prominent atrophy of the caudate region.
The cingulate gyrus is not usually involved. 



Reference: Saylor, Deanna et al. “HIV-associated neurocognitive disorder--pathogenesis and prospects for treatment.” Nature reviews. Neurology vol. 12,4 (2016): 234-48. doi:10.1038/nrneurol.2016.27. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4937456/

questions.text: One can observe Warthin Finkeldey cells in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Measles
 
  • Warthin-Finkeldey cells are multinucleated giant cells that are characteristic histopathological findings in measles (also known as rubeola).
  • These cells are formed by the fusion of infected lymphocytes and epithelial cells. They are typically observed in the respiratory epithelium, particularly in the bronchi and bronchioles.





Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 350.

questions.text: Cryoglobulinemia is associated with which of the following
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hepatitis C
 
  • Cryoglobulinemia is a condition characterized by the presence of abnormal proteins called cryoglobulins in the blood. These proteins can precipitate and cause inflammation and damage in blood vessels, leading to various symptoms and complications.
  • The most common type of cryoglobulinemia, known as type II or mixed cryoglobulinemia, is strongly associated with chronic hepatitis C virus (HCV) infection.
  • It is estimated that approximately 80-90% of cases of mixed cryoglobulinemia are associated with HCV.
  • Ovarian cancer, diabetes, and leukemia are not typically associated with cryoglobulinemia. While cryoglobulinemia can be secondary to other underlying conditions or diseases, HCV infection is the most common and well-established association.

Some common extra-articular manifestations associated with Hepatitis C infection:






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2604.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent illnesses is NOT caused on by parvovirus B19?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Roseola infantum

Roseola infantum, also known as sixth disease or exanthema subitum, is not caused by parvovirus B19. It is typically caused by human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6) or, less commonly, human herpesvirus 7 (HHV-7).

On the other hand, parvovirus B19 is associated with the following conditions:
 
  1. Aplastic anemia in sickle cell disease: Parvovirus B19 infection can cause transient aplastic crisis in individuals with underlying hemolytic conditions such as sickle cell disease. It can lead to a temporary shutdown of red blood cell production, resulting in anemia.
  2. Fetal hydrops: Parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to severe complications in the fetus, including fetal hydrops. Fetal hydrops is a condition characterized by abnormal fluid accumulation in two or more fetal compartments, such as the skin, abdomen, or thorax.
  3. Erythema infectiosum (Fifth disease): This is a common childhood illness caused by parvovirus B19. It is characterized by a distinctive rash on the face, giving a "slapped cheek" appearance, followed by a lacy rash on the trunk and limbs.







Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 27th edition, Page no 441, 443, 459.

questions.text: A boy with sickle cell anemia and non-suppurative osteomyelitis appeared. What will be the likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Salmonella

Sickle cell anemia is a genetic blood disorder characterized by the presence of abnormal sickle-shaped red blood cells. Individuals with sickle cell anemia are more susceptible to infections, including osteomyelitis, due to impaired blood flow and compromised immune function.

Among the options provided:
  1. Salmonella: Salmonella is a common cause of osteomyelitis in individuals with sickle cell anemia. Salmonella osteomyelitis tends to affect the long bones, particularly the femur and tibia.
  2. S. aureus (Staphylococcus aureus): While S. aureus is a common cause of osteomyelitis in the general population, it is less frequently associated with osteomyelitis in individuals with sickle cell anemia.
  3. H. influenzae (Haemophilus influenzae): H. influenzae is primarily associated with respiratory tract infections and meningitis. It is not a common causative organism for osteomyelitis.
  4. Enterobacter species: Enterobacter species are not typically associated with osteomyelitis.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1297.

questions.text: During a normal laboratory check, a patient's HBsAg status is discovered to be positive. Other hepatitis serological testing are unremarkable. His liver enzymes are within the normal range, and he exhibits no clinical symptoms. Which of the following options most accurately sums up his diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The above clinical scenario with HBsAg positive and other serological marker negative and with Normal aminotransferase levels points the diagnosis most probably towards Inactive HBV carrier.
 
  • In patients with chronic hepatitis B and normal aminotransferase activity in the absence of HBeAg, serial testing over time is often required to distinguish between inactive carriage and HBeAg-negative chronic hepatitis B with fluctuating virologic and necroinflammatory activity.
 
  • Such patients have IgG anti-HBc in serum; anti-HBs is either undetected or detected at low titer against the opposite subtype specificity of the antigen. These patients may (1) be inactive carriers; (2) have low-grade, mild chronic hepatitis; or (3) have moderate to severe chronic hepatitis with or without cirrhosis.

Serological markers of Hepatitis B:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2576-2578.

questions.text: A male patient is found to have anti-HBe antibody positivity, HBs Ag antigen positivity, and HBe Ag antigen negativity. While SGOT and SGPT are raised to 6 times the upper limit of normal value, HBV DNA copies are detected to be 100,000/ml. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: HBV precore mutant
 
  • The patient has anti-HBe antibody positivity, HBsAg positivity, and HBeAg negativity. These serological markers suggest a transition from the immune tolerant phase to the immune clearance phase of chronic HBV infection. The presence of raised SGOT and SGPT levels indicates liver inflammation.
 
  • The key feature in this case is the detection of HBV DNA copies at 100,000/ml. A precore mutant HBV infection is characterized by the absence of HBeAg production due to a mutation in the precore region of the HBV genome. This leads to a decrease or absence of HBeAg in the serum, despite ongoing viral replication.
 
  • Therefore, the most likely diagnosis in this case is HBV precore mutant infection.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2576.

questions.text: Specify the correct option for Dengue Discharge Protocol:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Return to good appetite

Patient Discharge Guidelines:
  • Fever-free interval of at least 24 hours without the use of antipyretics.
  • Platelet count > 50, 000/mm3
  • Return of appetite
  • Good urine output
  • Platelet count > 50, 000/mm3
  • Minimum of 2 to 3 days following recovery from shock
  • Visible clinical improvement


 
Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 296.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of the below photograph: -
questions.solution:
In the image we can see swelling of Right limb compared to the left, as it's unilateral so it's a case of lymphedema. 
 
  • Lymphedema of the lower extremity initially involves the foot and gradually progresses up the leg so that the entire limb becomes edematous.
  • In the early stages, the edema is soft and pits easily with pressure.
  • Over time, subcutaneous adipose tissue accumulates, the limb enlarges further and loses its normal contour, and the toes appear square.
  • Thickening of the skin is detected by Stemmer’s sign, which is the inability to tent the skin at the base of the toes.
  • Peau d’orange is a term used to describe dimpling of the skin, resembling that of an orange peel, caused by lymphedema.
  • In the chronic stages, the edema no longer pits and the limb acquires a woody texture as the tissues become indurated and fibrotic.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2119.

questions.text: What is cornerstone treatment of dengue fever with warning signs without shock ?
questions.solution:
IV fluids are the mainstay of treatment for a dengue patient who is exhibiting warning signals.
 
Plasma leakage resulting in shock in dengue is the primary pathology.
Therefore, the primary method of treatment is supportive management with continuous infusion of crystalloid IV fluids.


Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 296, 297.

questions.text: What is the most common lung finding in COVID-19?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Diffuse Alveolar Damage
 
  • Diffuse alveolar damage is a type of lung injury that is characterized by widespread inflammation and damage to the alveoli. It is the most common lung finding in COVID-19.
 
  • In COVID-19, the virus can directly damage the alveoli, or it can cause an immune response that leads to damage to the alveoli. The damage to the alveoli can lead to fluid accumulation in the lungs, which can make it difficult to breathe.
 
  • Other lung findings that can be seen in COVID-19 include:
    • Ground-glass opacities
    • Consolidation
    • Pleural effusion


Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 353.

questions.text:
A dengue patient who was admitted hasn't had pyrexia in the past 24 hours and has a healthy appetite. His blood pressure is 110/70 millimeters of mercury. Hematocrit is 44%, TLC is 4K, and platelet count is 34K according to the workup. When he blows his nose, he experiences epistaxis, which has since resolved on its own. What is the best course of action to take next for this patient's care
a. IVF
b. 4 units of platelet-rich plasma
c. Reassurance and observation
d. Plenty of oral fluids
questions.solution:
Reassurance and observation with plenty of oral fluids is the next step in management.

Intravenous fluids should be reduced or discontinued when any of the following signs are present:
• Normal blood pressure, pulse and peripheral perfusion;
• Decrease in hematocrit
• Apyrexia (without the use of antipyretics) for more than 24–48 hours;
• Resolving bowel/abdominal symptoms;
• Improving urine output.

Continuing intravenous fluid therapy beyond the 48 hours of the critical phase will put the patient at risk of pulmonary oedema and other complications such as thrombophlebitis.

Indications for Platelet transfusion: 
  1. Prophylactic platelet transfusion may be given at level of <10,000/cu.mm
  2. Prolonged shock; with coagulopathy and abnormal coagulogram
  3. Spontaneous bleeding manifestations                                                                                                                                                            In case of systemic massive bleeding platelet transfusion may be needed in addition to red cell transfusion.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 296.
National Guidelines for Clinical Management of Dengue Fever 2023, MoHFW, Govt of India. URL: https://ncvbdc.mohfw.gov.in/Doc/National Guidelines for Clinical Management of Dengue Fever 2023.pdf

questions.text:
What are the elements of qSOFA scoring?
A. Heart rate
B. Blood pressure
C. Respiratory rate
D. Mental status
questions.solution:
qSOFA components:
i. Hypotension- systolic BP < 100 mmHg
ii. Altered mental status
iii. Tachypnea- RR > 22/ minute

Each parameter has a score of 1.
A score of more than or equal to 2 criteria suggests a greater risk of a poor outcome.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2246.

questions.text: What statement regarding CORADS is accurate?
questions.solution:
CORADS is a CT based system that is sued to assess the suspicion of pulmonary involvement in COVID -19.

CORADS score of 5 is indicative of typical COVID infection.
 

Findings of COVID-19:

—Bilateral, peripheral & lower zone predominant airspace opacities (GGOs, consolidations) on X - ray.

—Bilateral, sub pleural, peripheral GGOs, airspace consolidations, crazy pavement patterns on CT. 

—Reverse halo/Atoll sign: central area of GGO with surrounding consolidation.






Reference: Prokop, Mathias et al. “CO-RADS: A Categorical CT Assessment Scheme for Patients Suspected of Having COVID-19-Definition and Evaluation.” Radiology vol. 296,2 (2020): E97-E104. doi:10.1148/radiol.2020201473. URL: https://ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7233402/

questions.text: Within 4-6 hours after showing signs of high-grade fever and inspiratory stridor, a kid experiences swallowing difficulties and saliva dribbling. Which of the following needs to be administered in addition to airway management?
questions.solution:
Along with airway management IV Ceftriaxone needs to be given.

The given features are suggestive of acute epiglottitis and it’s treatment has following components:
  • Urgent airway management
  • IV Fluids
  • IV 3rd generation cephalosporin


Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 1487, 1488, 1734, 2203, 2204.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient arrived with skin lesions that are easily ruptureable and flaccid bullae. Suprabasal split was found after a biopsy. What diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
• Using histopathology, an intradermal blister is seen. The basal layer's intercellular edema and loss of intercellular linkages are the initial signs of alteration.
  • Clefts and blisters are created when suprabasal epidermal cells detach from the basal cells.
  • Although being divided from one another and arranged in a row on the blister's floor like tombstones, basal cells are still connected to the basement membrane. Certain acantholytic cells can be found in blister cells.
  • Pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceous, which show a more superficial epidermal cleft, can be distinguished by histopathology.

Histology image of P. vulgaris. 



Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 47.1-47.5, 50.2-50.10.

questions.text: A leprosy patient who is multibacillary and receiving multiple medication therapies exhibits significant rashes on the lesions that are already present. He also displays neurological involvement. What comes next?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Continue ALT and start Steroids.
 
  • Rash or erythema in the existing lesion with nerve involvement suggest Type 1 Lepra reaction. It's a Type 4 Hypersensitivity reaction. ALT must be continue along with steroids as nerve involvement is present.
 
  • Type 1 lepra reactions involve inflammation of existing skin lesions, which become red, painful, and swollen, and may rarely ulcerate. Although new lesions can appear, they are uncommon. This reaction is associated with acute neuritis, including tenderness and loss of sensory and motor function.
 
  • For pain relief, NSAIDs can be added alongside oral steroids. Thalidomide is reserved for severe type 2 lepra reactions, or erythema nodosum leprosum, which involve systemic symptoms such as iritis, orchitis, and new skin lesion eruptions.




Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 28.5, 28,12, 28.16.

questions.text: Upon inspection, a red, painless rash was seen on the left side of the chest in a patient who had been experiencing fever for eight days and breathing difficulties for two days. Treatment entails:
questions.solution:
An eschar is black, necrotic and painless tissue, often observed on the chest and is usually linked to Rickettsial infections.
 
  • Doxycycline is usually the go-to drug for treating Rickettsial infections since the microbes lack cell wall components that makes beta-lactams and cephalosporins ineffective.
 
  • Patients are treated with oral doxycycline (100 mg twice daily for 7–15 days), azithromycin (500 mg for 3 days), or chloramphenicol (500 mg four times daily for 7–15 days).
 
  • Studies have shown Doxycycline in combination with Azithromycin to be more beneficial in reduction of mortality and complications due to Scrub typhus than monotherapy with either of the two drugs.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1436, 1437.

choices.text: Low tidal volume during assisted ventilation prevents acute lung injury
For outcome of goal-oriented management of sepsis patients, monitoring of central venous pressure, hourly urine output and blood pressure is adequate
Intensive blood glucose monitoring and prevention of hyperglycemia improves survival in critically ill patients
The use of drotrecogin-alfa is restricted to severely ill patients with APACHE score > 25

questions.text: All of the following interventions are supported by evidence in terms of the best management of patients with sepsis in the critical care unit, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
• The role of tight control of blood glucose concentration in recovery from critical illness has been addressed in numerous controlled trials.
 
  • Meta analysis of these trials have concluded that use of insulin to lower blood glucose levels to 100-120 mg/dL is potentially harmful and does not improve survival rates.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2246, 2247.

questions.text: Which nerve biopsy helps in diagnosing neuritic leprosy?
questions.solution:
• For individuals with neuritic leprosy, it is usually the radial cutaneous nerve that is selected for biopsy as upper limb nerves are most commonly affected in this form of disease.
  • The sural nerve may also be used but radial cutaneous nerve is the preferred option.
 
  • The superficial sensory branch of the radial nerve is most commonly selected for nerve biopsy in cases of neuritic leprosy.
  • While any affected nerve will reveal the pathology, it is advisable to biopsy a sensory nerve branch rather than a mixed or major nerve trunk.
  • Therefore, despite the ulnar nerve being the most frequently affected peripheral nerve in neuritic leprosy, it is not the ideal choice for biopsy.

Common nerves and sites for biopsy in leprosy include:
  1. The superficial sensory branch of the radial nerve at the wrist
  2. The ulnar cutaneous nerve near the ulnar border at the base of the hand
  3. The sural nerve near the ankle

Note: Nerve biopsy is the gold standard for confirming pure neuritic leprosy.



Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, Page no 28.14.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1385.

questions.text: 2.3 meq/I of hypokalemia develops in a patient taking amphotericin B. What is the necessary K+ supplementation?
questions.solution:
In this case K+ supplementation required is 120-160 mEq over 24 hours.

In case of usual circumstances the total amount of potassium that must be administered daily should not exceed 200 mEq.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 350-352.

questions.text: Grisel syndrome all are true except:
questions.solution:
For grisel syndrome all are true except 4. no need for neurosurgeon

Grisel syndrome is a rare condition characterized by non-traumatic atlantoaxial subluxation (partial dislocation between the first and second cervical vertebrae) following an infection or inflammation in the head and neck region. It is most commonly associated with upper respiratory tract infections, such as pharyngitis or tonsillitis, but can also occur after surgical procedures like tonsillectomy or adenoidectomy.

Causes:
Grisel syndrome is thought to result from laxity of the ligaments that stabilize the atlantoaxial joint, which can be caused by inflammation spreading to this area from nearby infections.

Symptoms:
- Neck pain and stiffness
- Limited or painful neck movement (especially rotation)
- Head tilted to one side (torticollis)
- Swelling or tenderness around the neck
- Neurological symptoms (rare in early stages but can occur if the spinal cord becomes compressed)

Diagnosis:
- Clinical evaluation based on history of recent upper respiratory infections or surgeries
- Imaging studies like X-rays, CT scans, or MRI to confirm atlantoaxial subluxation

Treatment:
- Conservative treatment in mild cases with immobilization of the neck using a cervical collar and anti-inflammatory medications.
- Antibiotics to treat the underlying infection.
- In more severe cases or if neurological symptoms are present, traction or surgery may be required to realign the vertebrae and stabilize the joint.

Early diagnosis and treatment are critical to avoid long-term complications, including permanent neurological damage. Therefore, Early intervention by a Neurosurgeon can be necessary




Reference: Dhingra's Diseases of Ear, Nose and Throat, 8th edition, Page no 507, 508.
Bucak, Abdulkadir et al. “Grisel's Syndrome: A Rare Complication following Adenotonsillectomy.” Case reports in otolaryngology vol. 2014 (2014): 703021. doi:10.1155/2014/703021. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3982280/

questions.text: A patient with Tubercular meningitis was taking ATT regularly. At end of 1 month of regular intake of drugs deterioration in the sensorium is noted in the condition of the patient. Which of the following investigations is not required on emergency evaluation?
questions.solution:
CSF examination in this case is not required in emergency evaluation.
 
  • Blood cultures should be acquired right away when there is a suspicion of bacterial meningitis, and supplementary dexamethasone therapy should also be started.
  • NCCT followed by MRI and LFT will be useful for immediate diagnosis or status of the patient.
  • However CSF analysis will not provide with any new information after 1 month of ATT.


Reference: Davis, Angharad et al. “Treatment of Tuberculous Meningitis and Its Complications in Adults.” Current treatment options in neurology vol. 20,3 5. 28 Feb. 2018, doi:10.1007/s11940-018-0490-9. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5830467/

questions.text: Which of the following statements about staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Predisposed by Varicella infection
 
  • Staphylococcal TSS is associated with the toxic shock syndrome toxin-1 (TSST-1), which binds directly to the MHC II complex and T-cell receptors.
  • This results in a massive increase in cytokines interleukin-2 (IL-2), interferon γ, and tumor necrosis factor (TNF), leading to a cytokine storm. 
  • Staphylococcal TSS is associated with the use of a highly absorbent tampon. 
  • Non menstrual cases are seen in patients with surgical or postpartum wound infections, especially when packing of the wound occurs.
  • Varicella infection (chickenpox) is not a known risk factor for TSS.


Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 27th edition, Page no 206, 207, 217, 218.

questions.text: The core temperature of a child with an infection is increased (>38.5 C), and the child also exhibits tachycardia, hypotension , tachypnea, an elevated leucocyte count, and cardiovascular organ failure. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: All of the above 
 
  • The child is exhibiting symptoms of systemic inflammatory response syndrome (SIRS), sepsis, and septic shock.
  • SIRS is a clinical syndrome characterized by two or more of the following:
    • Temperature > 38.5 °C or < 36 °C
    • Heart rate > 90 beats/minute
    • Respiratory rate > 20 breaths/minute
    • WBC >12,000/µL or < 4,000/µL or > 10% immature (band) forms
  • Sepsis: Occurs when the body's response to an infection damages its own tissues and organs.
  • Septic shock : Severe form of sepsis that results in tissue hypoperfusion and organ dysfunction.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2242, 2247.

questions.text: What is the name of the herpes infection-related geniculate ganglion facial palsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Ramsay hunt syndrome
 
  • Ramsay Hunt syndrome, also called herpes zoster oticus, is a late complication of varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection, that results in inflammation of the geniculate ganglion of the facial nerve (cranial nerve VII).
  • It is characterized by a classic triad of ipsilateral facial paralysis, otalgia, and vesicles in the auditory canal or on the auricle. Pain is the most common presenting symptom.


Trivia- Recently Justin Beiber also suffered from Ramsay Hunt syndrome 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1480.

questions.text: Exception to statements about Pontiac fever is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 2. Pneumonia is most common manifestation
 
  • Legionella pneumophila causes Pontiac fever and Legionnaire's disease.
  • Legionnaire's disease presents with an Influenza-like illness whose symptoms are fever, non-productive cough, and dyspnea and may rarely progress to pneumonia if left untreated, but it is not the most common manifestation.
  • Compared with Legionella pneumonia, Pontiac fever is a milder, self-limited illness that is defined by the absence of pneumonia.
 
  • Diarrhea and encephalopathy are also common.
  • It is often included in the differential diagnosis of atypical pneumonia. Pontiac fever presents with a mild influenza-like illness. 
  • Infection is typically by inhalation of aerosols produced by cooling towers, air conditioners, and showerheads which act as disseminators. 
  • No animal reservoirs exist, no human-to-human transmission occurs, and no carrier state is established. It is an epidemic.
  • Pontiac fever is self-limiting, and antibiotic therapy is not typically needed. Treatment is mainly Supportive.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1253, 1255.

questions.text: Which is the most common subtype of hepatitis B in India?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Ayw
 
  • Serotyping analysis showed that the most common subtype is ayw (44.33%).
  • Classically, HBV strains were distinguished by the presence of two pairs of mutually exclusive serotype determinants 'd'/'y' and 'w'/'r', in the HBsAg along with the main antigenic determinant 'a', which led to the description of 4 serotypes, namely adw, adr, ayw or ayr.
  • Among these, ayw is the most common subtype, in India.


Reference: Ashrafali Mohamed Ismail, Kalaiselvi Sivalingam Puhazhenthi, Jayashree Sivakumar, Chundamanil Eapen Eapen, Rajesh Kannangai, Priya Abraham, Molecular epidemiology and genetic characterization of hepatitis B virus in the Indian subcontinent, International Journal of Infectious Diseases, Volume 20, 2014, doi: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.ijid.2013.12.007.
URL: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1201971214000216

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in case of findings of Basal exudates, infarcts and hydrocephalus observed in brain imaging studies?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Tubercular meningitis 

Tubercular meningitis
  • It is common between 6 months and 4 years of age and usually spread by the hematogenous route.
  • The gelatinous exudate infiltrates the corticomeningeal blood vessels leading to hydrocephalus.

The three stages are-
  1. Prodromal stage
  2. Stage of meningitis
  3. Stage of coma
 
  • CSF study shows reduced sugar level, increased protein level, and lymphocytosis. 
  • Cranial computed tomography (CT) in a case of tubercular meningitis shows basal exudates and hydrocephalus. Intracranial tuberculosis can also manifest as ring-enhancing lesions (tuberculoma), but the basal exudates are the most common and characteristic feature of tubercular meningitis.

Treatment includes antitubercular drugs for 12 months and corticosteroids (to reduce neurologic sequelae).
TB meningitis is the only indication of steroids in TB.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1366.

questions.text: Which of the following best suits what is  'AIDS Related Complex'?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Generalized Lymphadenopathy 
 
  • AIDS Related Complex (ARC): Term used in the past to describe an intermediate stage between HIV infection and full-blown AIDS (Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome).
 
  • ARC was characterized by persistent generalized lymphadenopathy, which means enlarged lymph nodes in various regions of the body.
 
  • As the HIV infection progresses, ARC may evolve into full-blown AIDS, where severe immunosuppression leads to AIDS-associated opportunistic infections (Option 2), AIDS-related cancers (Option 3), and severe HIV infection (Option 4).


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1543.

questions.text: An elderly diabetic male presented with bloody nasal discharge and hemifacial pain on left side with loosening of teeth from upper jaw on the left side. He is a follow-up case of COVID-19. Which of the following test would help in reaching upto a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given case scenario goes in favor of mucormycosis. 
 
  • Nasal swab and subsequent microbiological examination will help in arriving at diagnosis of mucormycosis.
  • It will show broad based aseptate hyphae with obtuse angle branching. 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1682-1684.

questions.text: A known case of chronic liver disease with ascites had a fever, abdominal pain, tenderness and reduced bowel sounds. Ascitic fluid analysis showed >250 polymorphs/cu mm. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario of abdominal distension, fever with ascites, abdominal pain and tenderness with reduced bowel activity and ascitic neutrophil count of > 250 per mm3 is diagnostic of spontaneous bacterial peritonitis. 
 
  • It is an acute infection of ascitic fluid. Most common organism implicated is E.Coli. 
 
  • Diagnosis is by paracentesis and an ascitic fluid neutrophil count of > 250/mm3. 
 
  • Drug of choice for treatment is third generation cephalosporins. 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1054, 1055.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever, jaundice and calf muscle tenderness. On examination, there was conjunctival suffusion and maculopapular eruptions on the trunk.Per abdomen examination revealed tender hepatomegaly. Blood test showed thrombocytopenia and raised bilirubin level. AST and ALT are moderately raised. Kidney function test is normal. Urine microscopy showed hematuria. Most diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical scenario is leptospirosis. 

It is a zoonotic infection caused by Leptospira. It presents with fever with chills, conjunctival effusion, myalgia pronounced in calves, abdomen and back. 

Clinical features:
 
  1. Fever, jaundice, and calf muscle tenderness: Classic triad for severe leptospirosis.
  2. Conjunctival suffusion: Redness of the conjunctiva without exudate is a hallmark of leptospirosis.
  3. Maculopapular eruptions: Commonly seen in leptospirosis.
  4. Tender hepatomegaly: Suggests liver involvement, typical in leptospirosis-related jaundice.
  5. Laboratory findings:
    • Thrombocytopenia: Common in leptospirosis.
    • Raised bilirubin with moderately elevated AST/ALT: Indicates hepatocellular damage, typical in leptospirosis (bilirubin elevation is often disproportionate to liver enzyme levels).
    • Hematuria: Suggests renal involvement, often seen in leptospirosis.

Other options:
 

  1. Dengue Hemorrhagic Fever:

    • Typically presents with fever, thrombocytopenia, and plasma leakage. However, jaundice and calf tenderness are not common, and conjunctival suffusion is not a feature.

  2. Fulminant Hepatitis due to HAV:

    • While jaundice and fever are consistent, fulminant hepatitis due to HAV is characterized by severe liver failure (e.g., coagulopathy, encephalopathy), which is not seen here.

  3. Rickettsial Disease:

    • Rickettsial diseases may cause fever, rash, and thrombocytopenia, but jaundice and conjunctival suffusion are unusual.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1419, 1420.

questions.text: A 28 years old male patient presented with the complaints of fever, jaundice, upper abdominal pain and fatigue since last 2 months. His HBV infection markers were HBsAg positive and IgM anti-HBc antibody positive. What is true?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, presence of HBsAg and IgM anti-HbC goes in favor of acute HBV infection. 

Hepatitis B serological markers:




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 643, 2652-2564.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a mode of spread of abdominal TB?
questions.solution:
• The modes of spread of abdominal TB are through the lymphatic system along with hematogenous spread.
 
  • Close contact with animals having TB is a mode of spread for bovine TB can be transmitted to humans through consumption of contaminated dairy products or close contact with infected animals.
 
  • Feco-oral transmission is not a mode of spread of abdominal TB.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1366.

questions.text: What is the M/C site of Abdominal TB?
questions.solution:
• The most common site of the gastrointestinal TB is ileocecal location (ileocecal TB), followed by jejunum and colon.
 
  • The esophagus, stomach and duodenum are rarely involved.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no

questions.text: Which of the following presents with vesicular lesions?
questions.solution:
Hand-foot-and-mouth disease (HFMD) is an acute viral illness that presents as a vesicular eruption in the mouth, but it can also involve the hands, feet, buttocks, and/or genitalia.
 
  • Hand, Foot, and Mouth Disease (HFMD) is caused by Coxsackievirus A16 (most common) or enterovirus 71. It presents with characteristic vesicular lesions on the hands, feet, and sometimes on the buttocks and mouth. The lesions are typically small, red, and blister-like (vesicular), often appearing after a few days of fever and malaise.

Other options:
 

  1. Roseola (Sixth Disease):

    • Caused by Human herpesvirus 6 (HHV-6), this illness is characterized by a high fever followed by a maculopapular rash, not vesicular lesions.

  2. Dengue:

    • Dengue fever typically presents with maculopapular or petechial rash, not vesicular lesions. The rash can be more severe in cases of dengue hemorrhagic fever.

  3. Zika:

    • Zika virus infection is typically associated with a maculopapular rash (not vesicular), along with other symptoms like fever, conjunctivitis, and joint pain.



Reference: Ananthnarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 483, 497, 498.

questions.text: A diabetic patient cames in the OPD with a lesionin the axilla as shown in the picture below. The lesion shows coral pink fluorescence on wood's lamp examination. Which organism is responsible for the same?
questions.solution:
The lesion shown is Erythrasma - caused by Corynebacterium minutissimum.
  • It shows coral red fluorescence due to liberation of coproporphyrin-3.
  • T. Versicolor caused by Malassezia  species (furfur, globose) shows yellow fluorescence.

Wood lamp appearance of various diseases:




Reference: Rook's Textbook of Dermatology- Volume II, 9th edition, Page no 26.38, 26.41, 26.44.

questions.text: A patient has a history of multiple macular lesions. The histopathological image of the lesion is shown below. Which organism is responsible for the lesion?
questions.solution:
• The characteristic HPE image shows Henderson Patterson body seen in Molluscum contagiosum infection.
  • It is a benign self­ limiting viral infection of epidermal keratinocytes.
  • It leads to pearly white, dome shaped umbilicated papule, generally over the face.
  • It shows Pseudo- koebner's phenomenon - Appearances of morphologically similar lesions along line of trauma (stretching).


Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 367, 733, 964, 1168.

questions.text: Black eschar on the back is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Black Eschar is seen in Scrub typhus aka - Chiggerosis.
  • Causative agent—Orientia tsutsugamushi
  • Vector— Chiggers (Trombiculid mite)
  • Symptoms —Fever, headache, myalgia, generalised /regional Lymphadenopathy.
 
  • Scrub typhus, caused by the bacterium Orientia tsutsugamushi, is characterized by a black eschar at the site of the mite bite, which is a characteristic feature of the disease. This eschar typically appears on the back, chest, or limbs, and is often surrounded by an erythematous halo. The disease is endemic in areas of Asia, Africa, and parts of the Pacific.

Other options:
 

  1. RMSF (Rocky Mountain Spotted Fever):

    • RMSF caused by Rickettsia rickettsii presents with a maculopapular or petechial rash, not a black eschar. Rash often starts on the wrists and ankles and may spread to the palms and soles.

  2. Covid-19:

    • Covid-19 does not typically present with a black eschar. It primarily causes respiratory symptoms, fever, and a wide range of other systemic symptoms, including skin manifestations, but not eschar.

  3. Malaria:

    • Malaria, caused by the Plasmodium species, presents with cyclical fever, chills, and sweating. It does not cause a black eschar.



Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th edition, Page no 415.

questions.text: Not correct about parvovirus B19 infection
questions.solution:
Parvovirus B19 infection is associated with several clinical manifestations, but erosive arthritis is not typically seen in pregnancy.
 

  1. Children - Slapped cheek appearance of rash: Correct. Parvovirus B19 causes fifth disease, which presents as a characteristic slapped cheek rash in children, often accompanied by a lacy rash on the body.

  2. In sickle cell anemia - Aplastic crisis: Correct. Parvovirus B19 can lead to aplastic crisis in individuals with sickle cell anemia by infecting erythroid precursors and halting red blood cell production.

  3. In immunodeficient - Pure red cell aplasia: Correct. In immunocompromised individuals, parvovirus B19 infection can lead to pure red cell aplasia, where only red blood cell production is suppressed.

  4. In pregnancy - Erosive arthritis: Incorrect. While parvovirus B19 infection during pregnancy can lead to fetal hydrops or miscarriage, erosive arthritis is not a typical complication of pregnancy. Erosive arthritis is more often seen in chronic infections or conditions like rheumatoid arthritis, not with parvovirus B19 in pregnancy.


     

Reference: Jawetz, Melnick & Adelberg's Medical Microbiology, 28th edition Page no 460.

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1496.

questions.text: A patient presents with right upper quadrant pain, fatigue and jaundice. The patient is found to be HBsAg +ve and HBeAg +ve. Serum ALT levels are >2 times normal. HBV DNA is >104. USG reveals coarsened hepatic echotexture and no other abnormalities. What treatment should be initiated for this patient?
questions.solution:
• The American Association for the Study of Liver Diseases (AASLD) lays down the guidelines for the management of chronic hepatitis B based on HBeAg status, clinical picture, HBV DNA, and ALT levels.
 
  • The patient with cirrhosis, with no features of decompensation, with HBV DNA levels > 2 x 103 should be treated with oral agents, and not PEG IFN, as it is avoided in patients with cirrhosis, transplantation, or immunosuppressed. (option 1)
 
  • Lamivudine is no longer preferred for the treatment of chronic hepatitis, due to the high rate of drug resistance. (option 3, option 4)


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2566, 2567.

questions.text:
A retroviral patient with CD4 counts CD4 count = 36 cells/mm3 was evaluated with a radiograph which revealed bilateral nodular opacities in the lung fields. Sputum CBNAAT was found to be negative. The patient presents to the clinic with the following lesions on the face and thorax, and is initiated on ART. What is the most probable diagnosis?

1. Disseminated TB infection
2. Dissemination cryptococcus infection
3. Disseminated histoplasmosis
4. Disseminated molluscum contagiosum
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is HIV with disseminated histoplasmosis.
  • Progressive disseminated histoplasmosis(PDH) is seen in immunocompromised patients.
  • Common risk factors are AIDS(CD4+ T-cell count,<200/μL) extremes of age, the administration of immunosuppressive drugs(e.g., prednisone, mycophenolate, calcineurin inhibitors),and use of drugs like methotrexate, anti-TNF-a agents, and other biologic response modifiers for autoimmune disorders. It most commonly involves the lungs and bone marrow.
  • The clinical spectrum of PDH ranges from an acute, rapidly fatal course—with diffuse interstitial or reticulonodular lung infiltrates causing respiratory failure, shock, coagulopathy, and multiorgan failure—to a subacute or chronic course with a focal organ distribution.
  • Common manifestations include fever, weight loss, hepatosplenomegaly, and thrombocytopenia.
  • Other findings may include meningitis or focal brain lesions, ulcerations of the oral mucosa, gastrointestinal ulcerations and bleeding, and adrenal insufficiency. Prompt recognition of this devastating illness is of paramount importance in patients with severe manifestations or with underlying immunosuppression, especially that due to AIDS.

Fig: Intracellular yeasts (arrows) of H. capsulatum in a liver biopsy specimen (hematoxylin and eosin stain) from a patient who developed progressive disseminated histoplasmosis.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1658.

choices.text: Apical segment of right lower lobe consolidation

questions.text: A patient had a fever with a history of cough for the last 12 days. The CXR findings of the patient are as shown. What is the probable diagnosis?

questions.text: 35y old male farmer in south India with history of fever with generalised rash and body ache. On examination patient was found to have a skin lesion ( in fig). What would be the next line of management?

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Scrub Typhus and the image shown is that of an Eschar.
Causative agent is Orientia tsutsugamushi.

Treatment consists of Azithromycin with Doxycycline which is found superior to Doxycycline monotherapy.

questions.text: 25y old male was diagnosed to have Dengue fever. Which of the following is suggestive of Severe disease?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis of severe Dengue-
1. Severe Bleeding
2 Severe organ involvement- AST and ALT >1000, Dengue Encephalopathy, Myocarditis

questions.text: 22y old patient came with three day history of fever with myalgia and headache with retro orbital pain. Patient had maculo papular rash on examination. CBC revealed Bicytopenia. Which of the following is the next appropriate investigation based on above clinical setting?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of dengue fever. Since it has been < 5days of fever, dengue Ns1 is the preferred investigation. If fever >5 days Dengue IgM Elisa is done.

choices.text: Remote Infection with Hep B- Completely recovered

questions.text:
Interpret the serology report.
Hbsag-Neg      Anti Hbs- Neg      hbeag -Neg        Anti Hbc total -Positive        Anti HbC Igm- Negative
questions.solution:
Most likely diagnosis since Anti Hbc Total is only serology which is positive that patient may have had remote infection in the past and is completely recovered,
Anti Hbs - Suggestive of Hep B vaccination.

questions.text: 25y old male came with history of fever, headache and neck stiffness. Patient was evaluated and CSF study showed protein- 65 glucose-24 and white blood cells which are lymphocyte predominant. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The CSF shows- Lymphocyte predominance with low sugar-Suggestive of tubercular meningitis. Other features-Cobweb like appearence, High protein . 

*Extra Edge: 

MTB is first introduced into the host by droplet inhalation infecting the alveolar macrophage. The primary infection localizes in the lung with dissemination to the lymph nodes. At this point in the infectious process, a high degree of bacteremia can seed the entire body. In TBM, the meninges are seeded by MTB and form subependymal collections called Rich foci. These foci can rupture into the subarachnoid space and cause an intense inflammatory response that causes meningitis symptoms. The exudates caused by this response can encase cranial nerves and cause nerve palsies. They can entrap blood vessels, causing vasculitis, and block cerebral spinal fluid (CSF) flow, leading to hydrocephalus, which may be communicating or non-communicating. These immune responses can lead to complications associated with TBM and chronic sequela in patients who recover from TBM.

Tuberculous vasculitis leads to constriction, spasm, thrombosis, and occlusion of intracerebral vessels. This ultimately causes multiple, small, bilateral infarcts, frequently located in the periventricular regions; the basal ganglia, thalamus, and internal capsule are most frequently involved. These infarcts can cause stroke syndromes of the cerebral cortex, basal ganglia, pons, and/or cerebellum.

Reference: 

Slane VH, Unakal CG. Tuberculous Meningitis. [Updated 2024 Sep 2]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK541015/

questions.text: 40y old software engineer in bangalore develops Fever associated with Myalgia and retroorbital pain. On examination he is febrile and has Maculopapular rash. His Tc 2200, Plt- 75000. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of Viral fever with thrombocytopenia with leucopenia in an epidemiological setting ( Bangalore) is suggestive of Dengue fever.
Diagnosis is made by Dengue NS1 and IgM tests.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No: 1640, 1641.

questions.text: 30y old male with history of fever and Myalgia with retro orbital pain for three days. His CBC shows leucopenia and thrombocytopenia. Dengue fever is suspected. Which among the following tests is not useful?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, Dengue IgM Elisa is the least useful as the test becomes positive only after 5 days of fever.
Virus Isolation, Nucleic acid detection and antigen detection is used in early stages of infection for detection of virus.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No: 1644.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair. She is a known case of ovarian cancer. The following finding was noted on examination. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image presented depicts upper eyelid lilac erythema, also known as a heliotrope rash. This clinical presentation, characterized by proximal myopathy and the distinctive heliotrope rash, alongside a history of internal malignancy, suggests a diagnosis of dermatomyositis.

Classic cutaneous signs of dermatomyositis include:

Heliotrope Rash/Eyelid Erythema: This violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids is pathognomonic for dermatomyositis.

V Sign: Confluent macular erythema located over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest.

Shawl Sign: Confluent macular erythema on the upper back and lateral aspects of the arms.

Gottron's Papules: Erythematous papules and plaques found over the extensor surfaces of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints, which are pathognomonic for dermatomyositis.

Gottron's Sign: Erythematous rash over the extensor surfaces of joints such as the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles.

Mechanic's Hands: Characterized by rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmar aspects of the fingers.

Scalp Erythema and Hair Loss

Facial Rash: Confluent erythema in the malar distribution affecting the cheeks, nasal bridge, and nasolabial folds.

Nail Fold Changes.

These signs collectively contribute to the diagnosis and management of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A patient comes to ED with fever and headache. On examination he has neck stiffness. CSF analysis was done and it shows the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis? Opening pressure - Increased Proteins-Mildly increased Glucose-Normal Lymphocytes - Increased.
questions.solution:
The CSF shows mildly raised opening pressure, mildly elevated protein, normal glucose, and a lymphocytic predominance — the classic pattern for viral (aseptic) meningitis. Clinical course is often less fulminant than bacterial meningitis, and patients may improve spontaneously or with supportive care; specific antiviral therapy is used only for certain viruses (e.g., acyclovir for suspected HSV).

Other options — brief:

  1. Bacterial meningitis — usually marked protein rise, low glucose, and neutrophil predominance; presentation is more acute and severe.

  2. Tubercular meningitis — typically shows very high protein, low glucose, and lymphocytic predominance but with more chronic course and often much higher protein/pressure.

  3. Fungal meningitis — seen in immunocompromised hosts; CSF commonly shows high protein and low glucose with lymphocytes, not normal glucose as here.

questions.text: Cryoglobulinemia is associated with
questions.solution:
Cryoglobulinemia is a condition in which abnormal proteins (cryoglobulins) precipitate in the cold, causing vasculitis, purpura, arthralgia, and kidney involvement.

  • Hepatitis C infection: The most common cause of mixed cryoglobulinemia (type II and III). Chronic HCV infection triggers immune complex formation.

  • Ovarian cancer: Not associated with cryoglobulinemia.

  • Diabetes: Not linked to cryoglobulin formation.

  • Leukemia: May rarely cause paraproteinemia, but not typical cryoglobulinemia.

Key point:
If a patient presents with palpable purpura, arthralgia, and renal involvement, always check for hepatitis C.

choices.text: 2 sets of culture samples, 1 aerobic and 1 anaerobic
3 sets of culture samples, 1 aerobic and 2 anaerobic
3 sets of culture samples, 2 aerobic and 1 anaerobic

questions.text: A patient is suspected to have infective endocarditis. What is the correct number of blood culture samples to be collected?
questions.solution:
In suspected infective endocarditis (IE), multiple blood culture sets are required to maximize pathogen detection and differentiate contamination from true bacteremia.

Key points:

  • Number of sets: 3 sets are recommended before starting antibiotics.

  • Aerobic vs Anaerobic bottles:

    • Usually, 1 aerobic and 2 anaerobic bottles per set are collected.

  • Collection sites:

    • From different venipuncture sites to improve yield.

  • Timing:

    • Collected ideally before antibiotics and within first 24 hours.

  • Purpose:

    • To detect fastidious organisms like HACEK group.

questions.text:
Which of the following is incorrectly matched?
A  H Pylori  - Gastric MALT
B  C Psittaci – Ocular MALT
C  Borellia Burgdoferi – Cutaneous MALT
D  C Jejuni – Light chain disease
questions.solution:
• All are correctly matched except Option 4.
  • Campylobacter Jejuni is associated with Alpha Heavy chain disease.
  • MALT -Mucosa Associated Lymphoid Tumor is an extranodal Marginal zone lymphoma most commonly seen in the stomach but also seen in skin, salivary glands, small bowel and synovium.
  • Pathologic feature - Presence of Lymphoepitheilial lesions .Positive for CD 19 CD20 and CD79a and negative for CD5 and CD10.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 849,877.

questions.text: A young male presents with high grade fever, petechia , vomiting, retro orbital pain and myalgia since 4 days is suspected to have dengue hemorrhagic fever. Which of the following investigations is beneficial for the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• In a patient with dengue haemorrhagic fever, presenting four days, following onset of illness NS1 antigen would be the preferred test for diagnosis.
  • In case the patient presents after five days following the onset of symptoms the test of choice would be IgM ELISA.
  • Serological tests, such as IgM ELISA, are performed after day 5 when dengue viruses and antigens are no longer present in the blood due to the appearance of specific antibodies.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker's Textbook of Microbiology, 10th Edition, Page No 501,506,529-530.

questions.text: Which among the following indicates severe COVID?
questions.solution:
• SpO2 < 90% on room air indicates severe COVID.
 
  • According to the clinical guidelines for the management of COVID-19 patients released by the AIIMS/ICMR task force, a respiratory rate of >24/min constitutes moderate COVID, not severe COVID.





Reference: AIIMS/ICMR-COVID-19 National Task Force/ Joint Monitoring Group (Dte.GHS), MoHFW INDIA Clinical Guidance for Management of Adult COVID-19 Patients revised on 14/01/2022. URL: https://covid19dashboard.mohfw.gov.in/pdf/ClinicalGuidanceforManagementofAdultCOVID19Patientsupdatedason05thjan2023.pdf

questions.text: A patient recovered from hepatitis B infection. Which of the following curve represents antibodies seen 4 weeks post-recovery?
questions.solution:
The serological marker identified in the image is the anti-HBs antibody. In typical cases of resolving hepatitis B, HBsAg becomes undetectable 1 to 2 months after the onset of clinical symptoms. Following this, the anti-HBs antibody becomes detectable in the serum.

After infection with the hepatitis B virus (HBV), the first serological marker to increase is HBsAg, which can be detected in the serum within 1 to 12 weeks. It typically becomes undetectable 12 months after the onset of jaundice and rarely persists beyond 6 months. Once HBsAg is no longer detectable, the anti-HBs antibody levels start to rise in the serum and remain detectable indefinitely. The interval between the disappearance of HBsAg and the appearance of anti-HBs antibodies is known as the window period.

HBcAg is found inside the cells and is usually enclosed within an HBsAg coat when present in the serum. Consequently, HBcAg is not typically detectable in the serum of patients with HBV infection, as naked core particles are not present in the bloodstream. However, anti-HBc can be detected in the serum shortly after HBsAg emerges, usually within 1 to 2 weeks. During the window period, anti-HBc may be the only serologic marker that can identify HBV infection.

HBeAg appears shortly after HBsAg and its presence correlates with high levels of viral replication. The presence of anti-HBe is associated with a period of lower infectivity.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2564-2567,2571 table 339-2 .

questions.text: An HIV-positive man presents with a high-grade fever. Examination reveals a positive Kernig's sign. CSF shows reduced glucose, increased protein, and increased leukocytes. A diagnosis of cryptococcal meningitis is made. What is the appropriate management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The appropriate treatment for this patient with cryptococcal meningitis is liposomal amphotericin B (LAMB).
 

  • Cryptococcal meningitis (especially in HIV patients) is a serious opportunistic infection caused by Cryptococcus neoformans.

  • CSF findings: ↓ glucose, ↑ protein, lymphocytic pleocytosis.

  • First-line induction therapy (per IDSA guidelines):

    • Liposomal amphotericin B + Flucytosine for 2 weeks (induction phase).

    • Followed by Fluconazole (high dose) for 8 weeks (consolidation phase).

    • Then maintenance/secondary prophylaxis with fluconazole until immune recovery.

      Incorrect options

  • Voriconazole → not first-line for cryptococcal meningitis (used in aspergillosis).

  • High dose fluconazole with flucytosine → may be used if amphotericin B is not available, but amphotericin B remains preferred for induction.

  • Vancomycin → works against gram-positive bacteria (e.g., MRSA meningitis), not fungi.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, and combing hair. Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids was noted. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of upper eyelid lilac erythema is indicative of heliotrope rash, which, along with clinical signs of proximal myopathy, suggests a diagnosis of dermatomyositis. Dermatomyositis typically shows a preference for proximal muscle involvement over distal muscle involvement.

Classic Cutaneous Signs in Dermatomyositis:

Heliotrope rash/eyelid erythema: Violaceous erythema of the upper eyelids; this sign is pathognomonic for dermatomyositis.
V sign: Confluent macular erythema over the lower anterior neck and upper anterior chest.
Shawl sign: Confluent macular erythema on the upper back and lateral aspects of the arms.
Gottron's papules: Erythematous papules and plaques found on the extensor surfaces of the metacarpophalangeal and interphalangeal joints; also pathognomonic for dermatomyositis.
Gottron's sign: Erythematous rash affecting the extensor surfaces of joints, including the knuckles, elbows, knees, and ankles.
Mechanic's hands: Rough, hyperkeratotic lines on the lateral and palmar aspects of the fingers.
Scalp erythema and hair loss: Involvement of the scalp may also occur.
Facial rash: Confluent erythema in the malar distribution, affecting the cheeks, nasal bridge, and nasolabial folds.
Nail fold changes: Abnormalities in the nail fold area may be present.
Flagellate erythema: Linear erythema on the upper back accompanied by pruritus.
Poikiloderma: A mottled pattern of hyperpigmented and hypopigmented macules with associated telangiectasias.
Cutaneous calcinosis: Accumulation of calcium deposits within the skin.
These clinical features help in the diagnosis and management of dermatomyositis.

questions.text: A patient presented with a fever for 11 days with neck rigidity. A lumbar puncture was done and it showed lymphocytes predominantly, sugar- 50mg, and protein- 3000mg/dl. Gram-staining was negative. Chest X-ray of the patient shows upper lobe involvement with hilar lymph node enlargement. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and CSF findings strongly indicate a diagnosis of tuberculous meningitis.

Tuberculous meningitis, caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, occurs due to the formation of tubercles in the brain parenchyma. This typically arises from the hematogenous spread of the bacteria during a primary infection, or it may result from the rupture of a subependymal tubercle into the subarachnoid space.

Clinical Presentation:
Tuberculous meningitis manifests as a subacute infection, with a longer duration compared to bacterial meningitis.
Ocular nerve palsy is frequently associated due to significant meningeal involvement at the base of the brain.
Patients may also develop hydrocephalus.
CSF Analysis:
The CSF sample typically exhibits pellicle or cobweb-like clots.
Acid-fast bacilli can be optimally isolated from this sample.
Common findings in the CSF include lymphocytic leukocytosis, low glucose concentration, and elevated protein levels.
CSF culture remains the gold standard for definitive diagnosis.

Clinical Triad and Complications:
The classic clinical triad includes fever, headache, and nuchal rigidity, which is characteristic of all types of meningitis.
Nuchal rigidity refers to resistance in the neck during passive flexion and is pathognomonic for meningeal irritation.
Additional signs of meningeal irritation include Kernig's and Brudzinski's signs.
Complications such as raised intracranial pressure (ICP) may present with papilledema, disorientation, or dilated, poorly reactive pupils.
 

Other options:

  • Bacterial meningitis → usually acute (<7 days), neutrophilic predominance, very low glucose, Gram-positive/negative bacteria on stain.

  • Fungal meningitis → slower course, lymphocytic, protein elevated, glucose low, usually immunocompromised.

  • Viral meningitis → usually acute, lymphocytic, normal glucose, mild protein elevation.

questions.text: An infection caused by which of the following organisms does not show Faget sign?
questions.solution:
Faget's sign also known as relative bradycardia is seen when patients exhibit a lower heart rate than anticipated in relation to an increase in body temperature. Normally body temperature influences heart rate such that for each 1°C (1.8°F) rise in temperature, the heart rate typically increases by approximately 15-20 beats per minute.
Relative bradycardia is seen in infections caused by the following organisms.
• Salmonella typhi
• Brucella (brucellosis)
• Francisella tularensis
• Coxiella burnetii (Q fever)
• Leptospira interrogans
• Legionella pneumophila
• Rickettsia spp.
• Orientia tsutsugamushi (scrub typhus)
• Corynebacterium diphtheriae.
• Plasmodium spp. (malaria).
Noninfectious causes include:
• Drug fever
• Beta-blocker use
• Central nervous system lesions
• Malignant lymphoma.

• Factitious fever. Ref- Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition • Page No. 943-44

questions.text: Which of the following does not increase in acute inflammation ?
questions.solution:
Acute phase reactants are classified as positive and negative based on whether their levels increase or decrease in inflammatory states respectively. The levels of APR are primarily regulated by cytokines produced during the inflammatory process, such as interleukin-6 (IL-6). Positive acute phase reactants include -C-reactive protein (CRP)
-Hepcidin
-ferritin
-serum amyloid A (SAA)
-fibrinogen
-haptoglobin

negative acute phase reactants include.
Albumin
transferrin
transthyretin

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition • Page no: 2312

questions.text: A retro positive male presented with cough and breathlessness. On evaluation he has a CD4 count of 110cells/microlitre, serum LDH levels >220 and chest X-ray showed symmetric interstitial infiltrates in the perihilar region. Histopathological findings were as follows. What could be the possible diagnosis
questions.solution:
In the given background of HIV with a CD4 count of less than 200 and chest X-ray showing symmetric interstitial infiltrates in the perihilar region pneumocystis pneumonia is highly likely. This is confirmed by gommori methamine staining of Broncho alveolar lavage which shows crescent-shaped cysts resembling the crushed ping-pong balls. Here the cyst wall of these organisms are stained black. The symptoms of P jiroveci pneumonia (PJP) are nonspecific. PJP in patients with HIV infection tends to run a more subacute indolent course and tends to present much later, often after several weeks of symptoms.
Symptoms of PJP include the following:
Progressive exertional dyspnea (95%)
Fever (>80%)
Nonproductive cough (95%)
Chest discomfort
Weight loss
Chills
Hemoptysis (rare).
Respiratory system examination will reveal tachypnea with minimal crackles / rhonchi
Laboratory investigations show elevated LDH levels >220U/L. The chest radiographic findings may be normal in patients with early mild disease. Diffuse bilateral infiltrates extending from the perihilar region are visible in most patients with P jiroveci pneumonia (PJP). Less-common findings include patchy asymmetric infiltrates, pneumothorax, and pneumatoceles.
On HRCT the typical appearance is patchy areas of ground-glass attenuation with a background of interlobular septal thickening.
Treatment includes Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole . Ref - Harrison Principle of Internal Medicine 20th edition Page 1547-1550

questions.text: A 40 year old female presented with fever , chills and dark coloured urine. On evaluation patient was found to have anemia, jaundice high grade fever and spleenomegaly. She gives a past history of malaria and was treated with Quinine few years ago. Her peripheral smear showed the following findings. Identify the causative organism
questions.solution:
Black water fever is a condition characterized by massive hemolysis after treatment for acute malaria, with clinical symptoms that include hemoglobinuria, anemia, jaundice, and fever. The name of the syndrome relates to the presence of dark urine noted in affected patients. Blackwater fever, rare, yet dangerous,complication of malaria. It occurs almost exclusively with infection from the parasite Plasmodium falciparum.
On peripheral smear Falciparum malaria shows a very high percentage of RBCs containing ring forms. This high-level parasitemia is more often seen in Plasmodium falciparum infection than in infection by other plasmodia. The gametocytes of P. falciparum are crescent-shaped or "banana-shaped" whereas those of the other plasmodia are spherical.Ref- harrison Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 1724-1730

choices.text: Plasmodium vivax is the causative organism and Artesunate is the treatment
Plasmodium falciparum is the causative organism and Artesunate used for treatment
Plasmodium ovale is the causative organism and treatment in Artesunate
Plasmodium malariae is the causative organism and chloroquine is used for treatment

questions.text: At what CD4 count dose HIV associated dementia occur in retropositive individuals?
questions.solution:
The likelihood of developing HIV associated dementia increases when absolute CD4 lymphocyte count is <200 cells/ microlitre.
Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10e • Page no. 520, 521, 522

questions.text: A of pulmonary tuberculosis came to the OPD with complaints of fever, cough, and breathing difficulty. The consultant ordered and chest x-ray, which showed Monod sign. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with a past history of tuberculosis with an X-ray showing Monod's sign is suggestive of aspergilloma. The gas/air surrounding a mobile fungal ball or mycetoma (usually an aspergilloma) in an already-existing lung cavity is referred to as the Monod sign.
Aspergilloma or fungal ball is a late manifestation of chronic cavitary pulmonary aspergillosis (CPA) caused by Aspergillus species. A fungal ball is formed within the pulmonary cavity of CPA by the peeled-off inner layer of the cavity.Ref-Grainger and Allison Radiology 7th edition Page 262

questions.text: A 60 year old retro positive male with a CD4 count of 100 cells/cu.mm, presents with a 5-day history of cough and high-grade fever without chills and rigors. Chest X-ray shows no abnormality. ABG done shows PaOz <70 mmHg or with an arterial-alveolar (a-A) gradient >35 mmHg. Which of the following drugs is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
A CD4 count of < 200 and background history of fever with cough would Indicate Pneumocystis jirovecii infection. Clinical features include fever and nonproductive cough. Chest X-ray could be normal or have bilateral infiltrates. The treatment of PCP is with cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole).
For patients with a PaOz <70 mmHg or with an arterial-alveolar (a-A) gradient >35 mmHg, adjunct glucocorticoid therapy should be used in addition to cotrimoxazole.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition • Page 1547-1550, 1269, 1068, 1519

questions.text: What is the Chest X ray given below suggestive of?
questions.solution: The given X ray is suggestive of Miliary TB. It is a disseminated form of PTB that occurs when organism draining through lymphatics enter the venous blood and circulate back to the lung. It can result from progressive primary disease, reactivation of latent foci and iatrogenic exposure. CXR- faint reticulonodular pattern distributed uniformly throughout the lung. Ref- Robbins and Cotran 9th edition Page 376,672

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures. His CT head reveals multiple parenchymal cysts. Which of the following is not a part of the immediate management in the next 24 hours?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with neurocysticercosis (multiple parenchymal cysts on CT and seizures).

  • Immediate management in the first 24 hours focuses on:

    • Antiepileptics: To control seizures.

    • Steroids: To reduce inflammation caused by dying parasites or cyst degeneration.

    • Anti-edema treatment (e.g., mannitol or osmotic agents): To control raised intracranial pressure if present.

  • Antiparasitic drugs (e.g., albendazole, praziquantel) are not given immediately in acute symptomatic patients with seizures or significant edema because killing cysts can worsen inflammation and cerebral edema. They are started later once the patient is stabilized.


Reference
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition - Page No 1643
Paniker's Textbook of Medical Parasitology 8th edition - Page 126

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with the following lesions that started 2 days after he developed a fever. On examination, there are generalized vesicular eruptions over the trunk. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
*Chickenpox (Varicella)*

Chickenpox, also known as varicella, is caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV). Most infections occur in children under the age of 5, though older children and adults can also be affected. The characteristic rash develops in 3-5 successive crops and is polymorphic, meaning lesions at different stages can appear at the same time in different areas. Within 2-4 days, the lesions form a dry crust, leaving shallow pink depressions that heal without scarring, provided no secondary infections occur.
