  • Pulmonary stenosis (PS), is generally not associated with rheumatic heart disease. PS is more commonly a congenital heart defect, meaning it is present from birth, rather than a consequence of rheumatic fever. It is a common finding in Noonan syndrome.

Valve abnormalities commonly seen in rheumatic heart disease (RHD):





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2004.

questions.text: What is the best noninvasive test to determine the myocardium's viability?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. PET-CT
 
  • For the evaluation of myocardial viability in patients with ischemic cardiomyopathy, myocardial perfusion imaging (with SPECT or PET) is usually combined with metabolic imaging (i.e., fluorodeoxyglucose [FDG] PET).
  • In hospital settings lacking access to PET scanning, thallium-201 SPECT imaging is an excellent alternative.
  • FDG PET is also used in the evaluation of myocardial and vascular inflammation and in patients with suspected infective endocarditis.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1834, 1835.

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient comes into your clinic complaining of chest pain that has lasted the last 24 hours and has been accompanied by perspiration and diaphoresis. The ECG results are as follows. It is 150/90 mm Hg. Which of the following is not recommended for this patient's management?
questions.solution:
This is a typical case of ST-elevation MI (STEMI).
Since the patient has come to the hospital 24 hours after the onset of symptoms, there will be no benefit from thrombolysis.

Treatment algorithm for STEMI (ACC/AHA):





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2058.

questions.text: A patient who was presented to the emergency department had the following ECG recorded: What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Atrial fibrillation
 
  • AF is diagnosed by electrocardiogram (ECG), either by 12-lead standard ECG or limited lead ambulatory monitor ECG, with findings of lack of organized atrial activity (no P wave), with an irregular ventricular response.
 
  • Characterized by no observable P waves and a fluctuating RR interval, erratic QRS response.
 
  • The lack of coordinated atrial activity and the irregularly irregular ventricular response define the ECG in AF.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1903, 1904.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is not recommended for the treatment of the disease seen in the ECG below?
questions.solution:
• The ECG displays baseline variation and no P waves. Atrial Fibrillation exhibits this.
  • Except for adenosine, which is used in PSVT, Rest all of these medications are utilized in AF. 
  • Acute rate control can be achieved with beta blockers and/or the calcium channel blockers verapamil and diltiazem administered either intravenously or orally, as warranted by the urgency of the clinical situation.
  • Digoxin has been used for many years for rate control, particularly in patients susceptible to congestive heart failure, because it lacks the negative inotropic effect seen in calcium channel blockers and beta blockers.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1905.

questions.text: Breathlessness and shock were detected in a patient who had suffered a steering wheel injury to the right side of the chest. How can cardiac tamponade and tension pneumothorax be distinguished from one another?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Breath sounds
 
  • Cardiac Tamponade: Breath sounds are normal.
  • Tension Pneumothorax: Breath sounds are absent on the side of Pneumothorax.


Difference between Cardiac tamponade vs Tension Pneumothorax vs Massive Hemothorax: 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2021, 2200.

questions.text: Which of the following is not useful in monitoring cardiac output?
questions.solution:
Central venous catheter alone is not useful for measuring cardiac output.
 
  • Cardiac output is measured by the Fick method or the thermodilution technique.
  • The Fick method uses oxygen as the indicator substance and is based on the principle that the amount of a substance taken up or released by an organ (oxygen consumption) is equal to the product of its blood flow (cardiac output) and the difference in the concentration of the substance in the arterial and venous circulation (arterial-venous oxygen difference).
  • Cardiac output can also be determined with a pulmonary artery catheter and echocardiography. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1861.

questions.text: ECG is conducted after the patient reports having recent onset breathlessness. The electrocardiogram (ECG) is presented below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• ECG shows- narrow complex tachycardia with irregular rhythm. Since P waves are seen, it rules out AF.
 
  • Different morphologies of P waves in ECG rules out sinus arrhythmia. All the above said features confirm MAT.
 
  • Absence of chest pain and significant ST elevations rules out acute myocardial infarction.
 
  • Multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) is a cardiac arrhythmia caused by multiple sites of competing atrial activity. It is characterized by an irregular atrial rate greater than 100 beats per minute (bpm). Atrial activity is well organized, with at least 3 morphologically distinct P waves, irregular P-P intervals, and an isoelectric baseline between the P waves.
 
  • MAT is commonly seen in COPD patients. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1901, 1902.

questions.text: A patient arrives with a history of palpitations that started suddenly. The ECG displayed a narrow complex tachycardia with a rate of 160 BPM but no "P" waves. His BP is 96/68 mm Hg. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution:
Carotid sinus massage must be done as the next step
 
  • Clinically, the rapid nature of the palpitations and narrow complex tachycardia without obvious P Waves points to the possibility of atrioventricular re-entrant tachycardia (AVRT), the most prevalent type of SVT.
 
  • Patient is clinically stable with a systolic BP > 90 mm of Hg. Therefore, cardioversion or defibrillation are not required.
 
  • The best next step in management will be a carotid sinus massage (or any other vagal maneuver), as these can stop roughly 10–20% of AVNRTs.
  • Adenosine is still preferred over beta-blockers as a treatment for failed vagal maneuvers in patients with hemodynamic stability.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1893, 1899.

questions.text: Loud S1 in mitral stenosis is absent in all of the following except:
questions.solution:
Loud S1 is present in Mild MS.
 
  • In the initial stages of the condition, the first heart sound (S1) is frequently accentuated.
  • Loud S1 in MS is independent of MS severity.
  • The anterior mitral valve leaflet's distance to return to its annular plane, leaflet mobility, left ventricular contractility, and the PR interval all affect S1 intensity.

Causes of loud S1 include:
  • Tachycardia
  • Increased AV flow
  • Prolonged AV flow
  • Short PR interval

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1991, 1992.

questions.text: An intern saw a hypertensive patient's blood pressure readings in the right arm to be 180/100 mm Hg and the left arm to be 130/90 mm Hg during a regular follow-up. He also has an early diastolic murmur in right 2nd intercostal space. Which of the following conditions has the least chance of being connected to these findings?
questions.solution:
Coarctation of aorta, Takayasu arteritis and aortic dissection can cause mid-diastolic murmur but aortic stenosis causes systolic murmur.

Causes of EDM
 
Aortic Regurgitation Backflow of blood from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole due to an incompetent aortic valve. High-pitched decrescendo murmur best heard at the left sternal border. Associated with bounding pulses and wide pulse pressure.
Pulmonic Regurgitation Backflow of blood from the pulmonary artery into the right ventricle due to pulmonary valve insufficiency. Low-pitched decrescendo murmur best heard at the upper left sternal border.
Ventricular Septal Defect (VSD) Left-to-right shunt increases flow across the mitral valve, creating a diastolic murmur. Increased flow due to the shunt leads to turbulent flow during diastole.
Tricuspid Regurgitation Backflow of blood from the right ventricle to the right atrium during diastole due to a faulty tricuspid valve. Early diastolic murmur best heard at the lower left sternal border, accentuated with inspiration.
Aortic Root Dilatation Dilatation of the aortic root causes aortic regurgitation, leading to backflow of blood into the left ventricle. Murmur caused by regurgitant flow through the aortic valve.
Pulmonary Hypertension Increased pressure in the pulmonary artery causes pulmonic regurgitation. Diastolic murmur due to increased backflow through the pulmonic valve.
 
Causes of Unequal BP- 
Coarctation of aorta
Takayasu arteritis
 Aortic dissection



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1981.

questions.text: What is the following ECG's diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This is a classical ECG showing Ventricular Bigeminy as distinct 2 morphologies of QRS complex could be seen.
     
  • In Ventricular bigeminy, every alternate QRS is a PVC.
  • It is seen in digoxin toxicity.

Electrical alternans would have variable amplitude of qRS but not as distinct 2 morphologies. Here's an image given below:




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1917.

questions.text: Which of the following is a treatment option for heart failure in alternative medicine?
questions.solution:
• Terminalia arjuna is comparable to nitroglycerine in that it helps to relax the coronary arteries and thus, increase blood flow and oxygen supply. This, in turn, results in an increase in exercise capacity and relief from angina pains.
     
  • Additionally, Terminalia arjuna has antioxidant and anti-inflammatory properties that help protect the heart from damage. It may also help to regulate cholesterol levels and reduce the risk of atherosclerosis which is another factor contributing to angina and other forms of heart disease.
 
  • Patients with ischemic cardiomyopathy showed significant symptomatic relief in coronary heart failure from NYHA class III to class I.
 
  • Ultimately, the ingestion of Terminalia arjuna may have effects similar to those obtained when using nitroglycerine for the relief of angina and increasing exercise capacity.



Reference: Dwivedi, S, and R Jauhari. “Beneficial effects of Terminalia arjuna in coronary artery disease.” Indian heart journal vol. 49,5 (1997): 507-10. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/9505018/

choices.text: 9L arrived at the blood bank for platelet apheresis for the first time. He had circumoral numbness and paresthesias during

questions.text:
A young donor with a platelet count of 1.9L arrived at the blood bank for platelet apheresis for the first time. He had circumoral numbness and paresthesias during
the course of the donation. But his vital signs are still steady. Tachycardia with ST-T alterations was seen on the ECG. What is the cause of his symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Clinical signs of paresthesias, circumoral numbness, and an ECG with tachycardia and ST-T alterations are strongly suggestive of Hypocalcemia brought on by a protracted citrated blood transfusion.
 
  • Citrate chelates calcium and suppresses the coagulation cascade, which is why it is frequently used to anticoagulate blood components.
 
  • Multiple quick transfusions can cause hypocalcemia, which shows up as circumoral numbness and/or tingling in the fingers and toes.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 358.

questions.text: Which scientific principle is the basis for thermodilution method used in measurement of cardiac output by Pulmonary Catheter?
questions.solution:
• The Stewart-Hamilton equation is the foundational element of the thermodilution technique applied to measure cardiac output using a pulmonary catheter.
 
  • The indicator dilution technique has become the de-facto clinical standard for measuring cardiac output due to its simplicity and extensive past usage in multiple contexts.

 
  • This technique requires injecting a known quantity of a substance into a peripheral vein and then monitoring the alteration of its concentration in repeat arterial sampling. 



Reference: Argueta, Erwin E MD*; Paniagua, David MD†. Thermodilution Cardiac Output: A Concept Over 250 Years in the Making. Cardiology in Review 27(3):p 138-144, May/June 2019. | DOI: 10.1097/CRD.0000000000000223. URL: https://journals.lww.com/cardiologyinreview/fulltext/2019/05000/thermodilution_cardiac_output__a_concept_over_250.5.aspx

questions.text: Cardiomegaly was discovered in a woman who had cold intolerance and hoarseness of voice. What investigation needs to be done to determine the cause?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is of dysphagia lusoria, i.e. hoarsness of voice due to RLN compression by enlarged left ventricle. 
  • Echocardiography is a noninvasive imaging test that uses sound waves to produce images of the heart and its surrounding structures.
  • It is useful in detecting enlargements of the heart, which is an indicator of cardiomegaly. With echocardiography, doctors can evaluate the size and shape of the heart and the thickness of the heart walls.
  • It can detect any obstructions in the blood flow, changes in the heart valves, and other abnormalities.
  • The images can then help in determining the underlying cause of cardiomegaly and in creating an effective treatment plan.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1832, 1833.

questions.text: Midsystolic click is heard in a female. Pathology seen in mitral valve is:
questions.solution:
• It appears that the clinical signs indicated in the question point to Mitral Valve Prolapse Syndrome (MVP).In the event of an inspection of the cells and tissues, a myxomatous degeneration and the falling back of the mitral valve are likely results to be seen in Mitral Valve Prolapse Syndrome.
 
  • Mitral valve prolapse syndrome is a condition in which the mitral valve, which separates the upper and lower chambers of the heart, bulges abnormally into the left atrium. It is the most common form of heart valve disorder.

 
  • Symptoms of mitral valve prolapse range from no symptoms to a wide variety of uncomfortable symptoms and can include chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, and fatigue. Other common symptoms may include dizziness, fainting, anxiety, dry cough, and significant fatigue.
  • Patients may also suffer from a palpitation when the mitral valve fails to close properly and a murmur may be heard. In some cases, mitral valve prolapse can cause a leak in the valve, leading to even greater issues such as heart arrhythmia and congestive heart failure.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2000.

questions.text: Streptokinase and warfarin are given to a patient who has transmural thrombi. After which further testing should thrombolysis be stopped?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Pericardial Effusion
 
  • Fibrinolytics and anticoagulants can be continued in case of pericarditis, however, once significant pericardial effusion develops after MI, fibrinolytics should be discontinued.
  • The risk of post MI pericardial effusion is not increased with the use of fibrinolytic agents, heparin, aspirin and other antiplatelet agents.
  • In contrast, a pericardial effusion occurring in the setting of MI is an indication to discontinue anticoagulation and fibrinolytics.
  • As soon as pericardial effusion is established by echocardiography, emergency percutaneous pericardiocentesis should be performed at 20 +/- 6 h after thrombolytic therapy was started.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2056, 2020.
Renkin J, de Bruyne B, Benit E, Joris JM, Carlier M, Col J. Cardiac tamponade early after thrombolysis for acute myocardial infarction: a rare but not reported hemorrhagic complication. J Am Coll Cardiol. 1991 Jan;17(1):280-5. doi: 10.1016/0735-1097(91)90739-v. PMID: 1898952. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/1898952/

questions.text: Determine the diagnosis based on the ECG below:
questions.solution:
• The ECG seen above is often observed in a 2:1 heart block, a kind of second-degree "fixed ratio" AV nodal block.
 
  • It develops when every other P wave is NOT followed by a QRS complex because the P wave is not passed by the AV node to reach the ventricles.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1881, 1883, 1924.

questions.text: Continuous murmur cannot be heard in:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. VSD with aortic regurgitation
 
  • A continuous murmur is predicated on a pressure gradient that persists between two cardiac chambers or blood vessels across systole and diastole. The murmurs typically begin in systole, envelop the second heart sound (S2), and continue through some portion of diastole.
 
  • The classic example of a continuous murmur is that associated with a PDA, which usually is heard in the second or third interspace at a slight distance from the sternal border.
 
  • Other causes of a continuous murmur include a ruptured sinus of Valsalva aneurysm with creation of an aortic–right atrial or right ventricular fistula, a coronary or great vessel arteriovenous fistula, and an arteriovenous fistula constructed to provide dialysis access.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1822.

questions.text: A P wave greater than _____ indicates a persistent right atrial overload.
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. 2.5 mm 
 
  • Right atria chronic overload or acute overload is indicated by P wave of more than 2.5 mm.
  • The electrical signal for atrial depolarization originates at the sinus node and then spreads from the right to the left atrium, resulting in a downward and left-pointing vector in the electrocardiogram (ECG).
  • This vector is recorded in leads I and aVR as positive and negative, respectively. Normal p wave is less than 2.5mm in lead II. If it is more than 2.5, this indicate right atrial overload.


Reference: Douedi S, Douedi H. P wave. [Updated 2023 Jul 24]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK551635/

questions.text: Pick the option that is not a major criteria in acute rheumatic fever?
questions.solution:
According to Modified Jones criteria, Major criteria include- Polyarthritis, myocarditis, subcutaneous nodules, erythema Nodosum and Sydenham's chorea. While Polyarthalgia comes in minor criteria in Low risk population.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2769.

questions.text: A 52-year-old diabetic man with palpitations arrives at the AIIMS emergency department. Systolic blood pressure was 70 mm Hg at the time of assessment. His ECG was recorded in an emergency and is shown below. What is the management's next most important step?
questions.solution:
• The ECG is showing narrow complex tachycardia with absent P-waves with regular R-R interval. The patient is likely to be having paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).
 
  • Since the patient is in shock with hypotension, electrical cardioversion is the immediate treatment of choice.
 
  • Drug of choice for PSVT is Adenosine but it is to be used in hemodynamically stable patients.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1898, 1899.

questions.text: A 76-year-old male patient who has been experiencing retrosternal chest pain for six hours comes to the AIIMS emergency room. The next EKG was recorded. What is going to be your main line of management?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows STEMI and onset of symptom is 6 hours so PCI is the best possible intervention.
PCI could be done upto 24 hours. Ideal door to balloon time is 90 minutes.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2058, 2059.

choices.text: Cardiac apex is displaced laterally to left

questions.text: About isolated aortic stenosis, all of the following is accurate except for:
questions.solution:
• Pulsus bisferiens is seen in a patient of AS along with AR and is rare in isolated AS.
  • The cardiac apex is usually displaced to left because of Left ventricular hypertrophy.
 

Causes of Pulsus Bisferiens:

  1. Aortic regurgitation (AR)
  2. Aortic regurgitation with aortic stenosis (AR+AS)
  3. Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1818, 1981.

Acute ischemic stroke within 3 hours of onset

questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Sustained BP >185/110 mm Hg despite treatment.

questions.text: A 40 years old female presented with acute onset shortness of breath. She has a history of nephrotic syndrome 1 year back and recent prolonged air travel. She has a BP of 90/60 mm Hg, heart rate of 115 per minute and sinus tachycardia on ECG. A 2-D echocardiogram revealed dilation of right ventricle with bulging of the interventricular septum to the left. What will be the primary treatment modality?
questions.solution:
• Diagnosis is DVT leading to Pulmonary thromboembolism. This is a case of High risk PTE as the patient is Hypotensive and 2D- Echo shows RV dyskinesia.
  • It needs immediate thrombolysis by IV Tissue plasminogen activator for treatment since the patient is unstable.

Risk stratification and treatment is summarised below: 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2098, 2100.

choices.text: Patient should be asked to take normal breaths
The cuff pressure should be increased to 20 mm over systolic pressure
The cuff should be slowly deflated until the first Korotkoff sound is heard only during expiration

questions.text: A patient with possible cardiac tamponade arrives at the emergency department of the AIIMS. All of the following measures should be observed while taking BP EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
The cuff is slowly deflated and the paradoxical pulse is recorded from the point when first Korotkoff sound is heard only during expiration to when it is heard in both expiration and inspiration. Rest statements are true.
 
  • Pulsus paradoxus refers to a fall in systolic pressure >10 mmHg with inspiration. Pulsus paradoxus is measured by noting the difference between the systolic pressure at which the Korotkoff sounds are first heard (during expiration) and the systolic pressure at which the Korotkoff sounds are heard with each heartbeat, independent of the respiratory phase.
 
  • Between these two pressures, the Korotkoff sounds are heard only intermittently and during expiration. The cuff pressure must be decreased slowly to appreciate the finding.
 
  • The patient must also breathe normally during the recording.

Pulsus paradoxus is seen in patients with:
 
  1. Pericardial tamponade
  2. Massive pulmonary embolism
  3. Hemorrhagic shock
  4. Severe obstructive lung disease
  5. Tension pneumothorax.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1818.

questions.text: A female patient, age 41, visits the emergency room of AIIMS with complaints of agitation, palpitations, excessive sweating, and a sense of impending doom. To rule out biological causes in an emergency, the following test should be performed:
questions.solution:
The presentation of this patient is suggestive of panic attack.

  • Before diagnosing a panic attack, we must rule out organic (medical) causes of anxiety. All the investigations listed above are important to rule out organic causes.
  • Although anemia can also present with panic attacks, Hemoglobin need not be done as an emergency investigation.
  • The most important investigation to be done here is ECG.
  • Hypoglycemia can be ruled out by asking a history of diabetes mellitus.


Organic causes of Anxiety:

  1. Hypoglycemia
  2. Hyperthyroidism
  3. Pheochromocytoma
  4. Cardiac- Angina/MI/MVP




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1888, 1892.

questions.text: For which of the following is Left bundle branch block (LBBB) on ECG least likely to develop?
questions.solution:
LBBB occurs when normal electrical activity in His-Purkinje system is interrupted.
It occurs in patients with underlying heart disease and may be associated with progressive conducting system disease.

Causes of LBBB:

• Structural heart diseases
• Primary disease of cardiac electrical and Coronary artery disease conduction system
• Dilated cardiomyopathies
• Long standing hypertension leading to aortic root dilation
• Hyperkalemia



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 349, 350, 1896, 1897.

questions.text: The heart's phase of minimal motion during cardiac imaging is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Mid diastole

During mid diastole, the heart is in a relaxed state, and the ventricles are filling with blood. This phase is characterized by minimal motion of the heart, making it an optimal time for cardiac imaging procedures such as echocardiography or cardiac magnetic resonance imaging (MRI).
 
  • Late systole (Option 1) refers to the end of the contraction phase of the cardiac cycle.
  • Mid systole (Option 2) is the middle of the contraction phase when the heart is actively pumping blood.
  • Late diastole (Option 3) refers to the end of the diastole phase just before the next contraction begins.



Reference: Otton, James M et al. “Defining the mid-diastolic imaging period for cardiac CT - lessons from tissue Doppler echocardiography.” BMC medical imaging vol. 13 5. 1 Feb. 2013, doi:10.1186/1471-2342-13-5. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3570333/

questions.text: Following waves in ECG are seen in
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hypokalemia
 
  • U waves are small deflections that can appear on an electrocardiogram (ECG) following the T wave and before the next P wave.
  • U waves are often prominent and can be seen in leads V2 to V4 on the ECG.
  • U waves can be seen in certain conditions such as hypokalemia (low potassium levels), which is the most common cause.
  • Hyponatremia (low sodium levels) and hypercalcemia (high calcium levels), do not typically cause U waves in an ECG.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1830, 1831.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is an automatic implantable cardioverter defibrillator (AICD) implant used for?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: All of the given options in 1,2,3 are Indications of ICD according to American College of Cardiology/American Heart Rhythm Society (ACC/AHRS).





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1911, 1914, 1916, 1925.

questions.text: The myocardial stunning pattern does not correspond to the ECG. The diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is: Takotsubo cardiomyopathy
  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as "broken heart syndrome" or "stress-induced cardiomyopathy," is a condition characterized by a sudden weakening of the heart muscle. It often occurs following a stressful or emotional event.
 
  • One of the distinguishing features of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy is that the pattern of myocardial stunning or dysfunction does not correspond to the typical distribution of coronary arteries, meaning that the area of myocardial dysfunction is not directly related to a specific blockage or ischemia in the coronary arteries.
 
  • On the other hand, restrictive cardiomyopathy (option 2) is characterized by impaired filling of the ventricles due to stiffness or fibrosis of the heart muscle, and it is not typically associated with myocardial stunning.
 
  • Brugada cardiomyopathy (option 3) refers to Brugada syndrome, an inherited arrhythmia disorder that primarily affects the electrical conduction system of the heart, causing abnormal ECG patterns and an increased risk of life-threatening arrhythmias. It is not directly associated with myocardial stunning. ECG pattern if Brugada syndrome is is known as the "Brugada pattern" or "Brugada sign." It is typically observed in the right precordial leads (V1 to V3) most commonly as ST elevation.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1966.

questions.text: An alternative drug to epinephrine for treating cardiac arrest is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Amiodarone. Amiodarone is an alternative drug that can be used in the treatment of cardiac arrest.

It is administered during advanced cardiac life support (ACLS) as a substitute for or in combination with epinephrine. It can be particularly useful in certain situations, such as VF or pVT, where the effectiveness of epinephrine may be limited.

Apart from Epinephrine, Amiodarone and Lignocaine are other two drugs recommended by AHA for the treatment of Adult Cardiac arrest. Rest other drugs are NOT recommended.

ACLS algorithm:
  • Step 1: Assess responsiveness Determine if the patient is responsive and shout for help.
  • Step 2: Activate emergency response system Activate the emergency response system or ask someone to do it.
  • Step 3: Check for a pulse Assess for the presence of a pulse. If absent or not palpable within 10 seconds, proceed to the next step.
  • Step 4: Start high-quality CPR Begin high-quality CPR with a compression-to-ventilation ratio of 30:2 for adult patients. Ensure adequate depth and rate of compressions with minimal interruptions.
  • Step 5: Attach and analyze a defibrillator Attach an automated external defibrillator (AED) or manual defibrillator to the patient and analyze the rhythm.
  • Step 6: Deliver defibrillation If a shockable rhythm (ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia) is detected, deliver a single shock and immediately resume CPR.
  • Step 7: Perform rhythm checks After 2 minutes of CPR, assess the rhythm to determine if it is shockable or non-shockable.
  • Step 8: Administer medications Administer medications as indicated based on the rhythm and protocol. Epinephrine is typically given every 3-5 minutes. Additionally, consider administering vasopressin as an alternative vasopressor to one dose of epinephrine.
  • Step 9: Continue cycles of CPR and rhythm assessments Perform cycles of CPR with rhythm checks every 2 minutes. Follow the specific guidelines for rhythm interpretation, shock delivery, and medication administration.
  • Step 10: Consider advanced airway management If feasible and in accordance with local protocols, consider advanced airway management such as endotracheal intubation or supraglottic airway placement.
  • Step 11: Post-resuscitation care After return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC), provide post-resuscitation care, including monitoring, optimizing oxygenation and ventilation, treating underlying causes, and transferring the patient to an appropriate care setting.





Reference: Adult Cardiac Arrest algorithm, American Heart Association (AHA) 2020 guidelines. URL: https://cpr.heart.org/en/resuscitation-science/cpr-and-ecc-guidelines/algorithms

questions.text: ABPI rises artificially in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Arteriosclerosis calcified arteries

Artificially high ABI readings (>1.4) can be caused by media sclerosis and calcifcation of the arterial wall, causing vessel incompressibility and a falsely elevated ABI






Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1001.

questions.text: Other than MI, what are the causes of myocardial shock?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: All of the above

Myocardial shock, also known as cardiogenic shock, is a severe condition characterized by inadequate circulation of blood due to the heart's inability to pump effectively. While acute myocardial infarction (MI) is a common cause of myocardial shock, other conditions can also lead to this condition.
  1. Acute mitral regurgitation: Severe acute mitral regurgitation can result in a sudden increase in left ventricular volume and pressure overload. This can lead to a decrease in cardiac output and ultimately result in myocardial shock.
  2. Ventricular septal rupture: Ventricular septal rupture is a complication that can occur after an MI. It involves a rupture in the septum that separates the ventricles of the heart. This condition leads to a significant shunting of blood between the ventricles, compromising cardiac output and causing myocardial shock.
  3. Isolated right ventricular shock: Isolated right ventricular shock refers to a condition where the right ventricle fails to pump blood effectively. It can occur due to various causes, such as right ventricular infarction, severe pulmonary embolism, or right heart failure. In this condition, there is a decrease in systemic cardiac output, resulting in myocardial shock.
Therefore, all of the listed options can contribute to the development of myocardial shock by compromising the heart's ability to pump blood effectively.



Reference: Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th edition, Page no 1148.

questions.text: Where is Mobitz type 2 second degree AV block not seen?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Cushing syndrome
 Mobitz type 2 second degree AV block is due to- 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1882.

choices.text: Occurs due to rapid filling of the ventricles during atrial systole

questions.text: The assertions about the third heart sound (S3) that follow are all accurate, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
S3 is a low-pitched sound (25–50Hz) which is heard in early diastole, following the second heart sound.
 
  • The third heart sound (S3) occurs during the rapid filling phase of ventricular diastole. It can be a normal finding in children, adolescents, and young adults; however, in older patients, it signifies heart failure.
  • A left-sided S3 is a low-pitched sound best heard over the LV apex. A right-sided S3 is usually better heard over the lower left sternal border and becomes louder with inspiration.
  • A left-sided S3 in patients with chronic heart failure is predictive of cardiovascular morbidity and mortality. Interestingly, an S3 is equally prevalent among heart failure patients with preserved and reduced LV ejection fraction.
  • S3 is also heard in those states in which left heart handles increased load of blood volume like in ASD and VSD.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1820.

questions.text: In ACLS, which drug other than epinephrine can be given following ventricular fibrillation after cardiac arrest?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Amiodarone

Here is a simplified ACLS flowchart:
  1. Assess Responsiveness and Activate Emergency Response:
    • Check for responsiveness of the patient.
    • Activate the emergency response system, call for help, and obtain necessary equipment.
  2. Assess Airway, Breathing, and Circulation (ABCs):
    • Open the airway and check for breathing.
    • Check for the presence of a pulse.
    • If the patient is unresponsive, not breathing, or pulseless, start CPR immediately.
  3. Basic Life Support (BLS):
    • Perform high-quality chest compressions.
    • Provide rescue breaths (ventilation) using a bag-mask device or advanced airway as appropriate.
    • Minimize interruptions in chest compressions.
  4. Attach Monitor and Assess Rhythm:
    • Attach a cardiac monitor/defibrillator to assess the patient's cardiac rhythm.
    • Identify shockable rhythms (ventricular fibrillation or pulseless ventricular tachycardia).
  5. Defibrillation:
    • Deliver a shock using a defibrillator (if indicated) followed by immediate chest compressions.
  6. Advanced Cardiovascular Life Support:
    • Administer epinephrine promptly after the first shock.
    • Continue cycles of CPR (compressions and ventilations).
    • Assess the rhythm after each cycle of CPR.
    • Consider advanced airway management (endotracheal intubation) and capnography monitoring.
  7. Medications and Interventions:
    • Administer antiarrhythmic medications (such as amiodarone or lidocaine) if the patient remains in a shockable rhythm.
    • Treat specific causes of cardiac arrest if identified (e.g., treat reversible causes like hypoxia, hypovolemia, hypothermia, etc.).
    • Consider advanced interventions like transcutaneous pacing, intraosseous access, or central venous access as needed.
  8. Post-Cardiac Arrest Care:
    • Optimize ventilation and oxygenation.
    • Maintain hemodynamic stability.
    • Treat hypotension with fluids or vasopressors as necessary.
    • Targeted temperature management (hypothermia protocol) may be considered in selected patients.






Reference: Adult Cardiac Arrest algorithm, American Heart Association (AHA) 2020 guidelines. URL: https://cpr.heart.org/en/resuscitation-science/cpr-and-ecc-guidelines/algorithms

questions.text: A young asymptomatic female is observed to have a Mid systolic Click on routine examination. Valves are likely to show:
questions.solution:
• It appears that the clinical signs indicated in the question point to Mitral Valve Prolapse Syndrome (MVP).In the event of an inspection of the cells and tissues, a myxomatous degeneration and the falling back of the mitral valve are likely results to be seen in Mitral Valve Prolapse Syndrome.
 
  • Mitral valve prolapse syndrome is a condition in which the mitral valve, which separates the upper and lower chambers of the heart, bulges abnormally into the left atrium. It is the most common form of heart valve disorder.
 
  • Symptoms of mitral valve prolapse range from no symptoms to a wide variety of uncomfortable symptoms and can include chest pain, palpitations, shortness of breath, and fatigue. Other common symptoms may include dizziness, fainting, anxiety, dry cough, and significant fatigue.
 
  • Patients may also suffer from a palpitation when the mitral valve fails to close properly and a murmur may be heard. In some cases, mitral valve prolapse can cause mitral regurgitation  in the valve, leading to even greater issues such as heart arrhythmia and congestive heart failure.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2000.

questions.text: Beck's Triad can be observed in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Cardiac tamponade

Beck's triad consists of three classic signs seen in cardiac tamponade, which is a condition characterized by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space:
  1. Hypotension: Low blood pressure due to reduced cardiac output.
  2. Muffled heart sounds: Distant, muffled, or soft heart sounds heard on auscultation.
  3. Jugular venous distention: Distended jugular veins in the neck due to increased venous pressure.
While the other options (constrictive pericarditis, right ventricular myocardial infarction, and restrictive cardiomyopathy) may have similar manifestations, they are not specifically associated with Beck's triad.

Physiology:
  • The fall in arterial blood pressure results from pericardial fluid accumulation inside the pericardial sac, which decreases the maximum size of the ventricles. This limits diastolic expansion (filling) which results in a lower EDV (End Diastolic Volume) which reduces stroke volume, a major determinant of systolic blood pressure.
  • The rising central venous pressure is evidenced by distended jugular veins while in a non-supine position. It is caused by reduced diastolic filling of the right ventricle, due to pressure from the adjacent expanding pericardial sac. This results in a backup of fluid into the veins draining into the heart, most notably, the jugular veins. In severe hypovolemia, the neck veins may not be distended.
  • The suppressed heart sounds occur due to the muffling effects of the fluid surrounding the heart.

Clinical use: Although the full triad is present only in a minority of cases of acute cardiac tamponade, presence of the triad is considered pathognomonic for the condition.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2021.

questions.text: Which of these conditions is most frequently associated with accelerated idioventricular rhythm (AIVR)?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Myocardial Reperfusion
 
  • Three or more ventricular beats at a rate slower than 100 beats/min are termed an AIVR.
  • Automaticity is the likely mechanism, although in some rare cases, a reentrant circuit utilizing diseased myocardium can cause AIVR.
  • Idioventricular rhythms are common during acute MI and may emerge during sinus bradycardia.
  • This rhythm is also common in patients with cardiomyopathies or sleep apnea. It can also be idiopathic, often emerging when the sinus rate slows during sleep.
  • Treatment: Atropine may be administered to increase the sinus rates if hemodynamic instability is a concern.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1917.

questions.text: Pick the antihypertensive drug avoided in patients with high serum uric acid levels.
questions.solution:
Hydrochlorothiazide increases uric acid levels.
 
  • Mechanism: first, the thiazide enters the proximal tubule cell, and then is exchanged with uric acid, driving the reabsorption of urate.
 
  • Long-term use of higher dose thiazides in hypertension has caused rise in blood urate level.
 
  • It tends to raise blood uric acid level by competing with its proximal tubular secretion as well as by increasing reabsorption in PT that occurs as a consequence of reduced e.c.f. volume.


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 627, 632.

questions.text: Water-hammer pulse is seen in:
questions.solution:
Water hammer pulse is a characteristic of aortic regurgitation (AR) which is a condition that occurs when the aortic valve does not close completely.

  • This allows for blood to leak backwards from the aorta into the left ventricle during diastole. This abnormality in the flow of blood is what causes the water hammer pulse in aortic regurgitation.
  • The pulse may be observed as a rapid alternating rise and fall of the arterial waveform in response to each heart beat. It has a snapping or palpable nature to it and is most often seen in the carotid artery.
  • It is typically accompanied by a loud radiated sound (“machinery murmur”) heard over the lower left sternal border during systole.
  • Water hammer pulse occurs due to a sudden and dramatic increase in diastolic blood pressure- caused by the regurgitated blood.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1988.

questions.text: Where is Pulmonary plethora seen in?
questions.solution:
Pulmonary plethora is a condition in which there is increased pulmonary blood flow, often caused by an abnormal opening in the heart.

  • This can result in enlarged central and peripheral pulmonary arteries and veins in all areas of the lungs.
  • Common causes of pulmonary plethora without cyanosis (blue skin discoloration) are partial anomalous pulmonary venous drainage and large left-to-right shunts due to certain types of congenital heart defects like ASD, VSD, and PDA.
  • On the other hand, the most common cause of pulmonary plethora with cyanosis is total anomalous pulmonary venous drainage (TAPVC).
  • In this condition, the venous blood from the lungs flows directly into the systemic circulation without passing through the left atrium and left ventricle. This can cause cyanosis due to increased oxygen levels in the venous blood, which is not fully oxygenated.
  • In rest all pulmonary oligemia is seen


 

Reference: Essential Pediatrics by OP Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 423, 424.

questions.text: Name the machine.
questions.solution:
The given machine is an Automated external defibrillator (AED).
  • This specialised medical tool is frequently used to determine if ventricular fibrillation or fast ventricular tachycardia is present or absent.
  • It decides whether to deliver an electrical shock directly to the heart without the need for operator interaction (fibrillation).


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 8th edition, Page no 2877, 3186.

questions.text: Name the cause for A 20 years old man with hypertension has following CXR finding with aortic shadow as below.
questions.solution:
• The image shows the figure of 3 sign which is seen in the Coarctation of the aorta. It is formed by pre-stenotic dilatation of the aortic arch and left subclavian, indentation at the coarctation site, and post-stenotic dilatation of the descending aorta.
 
  • Coarctation of the aorta refers to the luminal narrowing of a short section of the aorta typically at the site of insertion of the ductus arteriosus. The narrowing of the aorta is thought to occur due to the presence of excessive integrations of ductal tissue around the aortic isthmus.
  • This condition typically presents in teenage or adult patients with seemingly unexplained hypertension and they are at increased risk of additional micro- and macrovascular complications.
  • Individuals with coarctation of the aorta may display symptoms including headaches, nosebleeds, pale skin, tiredness, fainting, and chest pain.
  • Treatment options for Coarctation of the aorta may include medical therapy, balloon angioplasty, or even open surgical aortic reconstruction.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2015.
Essential Pediatrics by OP Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 428, 429.

questions.text: A 24-year-old lady presented with abdominal pain and was treated with some medication. 3 hours post-treatment with this medication - the lady developed palpitations and respiratory distress. Vitals were stable and ECG is shown below. Treatment?
questions.solution:
Torsade de pointes is the suspected diagnosis based on the patients' ECG.
 
Long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that result in Torsade de pointes can be effectively treated and prevented with IV MgSO4.
 
  • Defibrillation should be started right away if the patient is unstable.

    The ECG presented indicates wide QRS complex tachycardia with varying QRS amplitudes, suggesting torsades de pointes. Since the patient is hemodynamically stable, the preferred treatment is intravenous MgSO.

  • Polymorphic ventricular tachycardia (VT) is characterized by continuously changing QRS morphology. When it occurs in individuals with congenital or acquired QT interval prolongation, it is known as torsades de pointes. Patients may experience near-syncope, syncope, or cardiac arrest.
  • IV MgSO is very effective for both treating and preventing recurrence of long QT-related ventricular ectopic beats that can trigger torsades de pointes.
  • If magnesium treatment is ineffective, an infusion of isoproterenol or pacing at a rate of 100-120 depolarizations per minute generally suppresses VT recurrences. In cases where the patient is hemodynamically unstable, immediate defibrillation is necessary.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1911, 1923, 1924.

questions.text: As per the ECG shown below, what will be the next step in the case of A 34-year-old with h/o of palpitations who came to emergency with a pulse rate of 156/min and with a BP=70/40 mm Hg. Emergency has tried initial vagal manoeuvre and adenosine to which the rhythm is refractory. ?
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows narrow QRS complex regular tachycardia with absent p waves which is suggestive of AVRT. 

Since the patient in the given question is hemodynamically unstable, the next step of management would be to deliver synchronized DC cardioversion.  


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1895, 1898.

choices.text: Assertion and reason is true, reason is the correct explanation of assertion
Assertion and reason is true, reason is not explanation for assertion
Assertion is false but reason is true

questions.text:
Assertion: Early intubation is needed in massive stroke patient 
Reason: Chances of development of sleep apnea in massive stroke patients is more
questions.solution:
• Sleep apnea, especially OSAP, is warranted in cases of low GCS (coma, in this case), which occurs in almost 40 to 70% cases of stroke.
  • But sleep apnea is not prevented or treated by early intubation.
 
  • The need for early intubation in patients of stroke is to prevent aspiration and provide an airway.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2205, 2206, 3337.

questions.text: Choose which is not a radiographic finding seen in CHF?
questions.solution:
• Focal oligemia is not a radiological sign of left heart failure; rather, it is associated with pulmonary embolism and is referred to as Westermark's sign. 
 
  • This condition is characterized by a hyperlucent area in the lung with reduced vascularity due to oligemia. It results from a disruption of circulation caused by an embolus, leading to the absence of visible pulmonary vasculature in the affected area on an X-ray.

Radiological features of Left heart failure:
 
  • Cardiomegaly- Refers to the enlargement of the cardiac silhouette, indicated by an increased cardiothoracic ratio.
  • Upper lobe pulmonary venous congestion, characterized by cephalization of vessels, and interstitial edema is present.
  • Kerley B lines appear as horizontal lines in the peripheral regions of the lower posterior lung fields, as illustrated below.


Reference: Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 6th edition, Page no 374, 375.

questions.text: What is the next step in management for a 70-year-old unstable male with h/o HTN and DM who acquired the following rhythm with a B.P. of 90/60 mmHg and a weak pulse
questions.solution:
ECG shows uniform narrow QRS complex tachycardia suggestive of PSVT.
 
  • DC cardioversion is a procedure used to treat abnormal heart rhythms. It involves the application of a direct electrical current to the heart through paddles or electrodes placed on the chest wall.
  • This electrical current causes the heart to reset its rhythm to normal, which is why it is used in the case of wide QRS monomorphic ventricular tachycardia.
  • Since the patient is clinically unstable, with a blood pressure (BP) of 90/60 mmHg, it is imperative that the immediate treatment is DC cardioversion to restore normal rhythm and prevent further harm.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1919.

questions.text: What is the most likely diagnosis in the ECG shown below. The patient complains of palpitation and dizziness
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows narrow QRS complex tachycardia with absent p waves and irregularly spaced R-R intervals, diagnostic of Atrial fibrillation.
 
  • Option 2- PSVT will have regularly spaced R-R interval with narrow QRS complex tachycardia and absent p waves.
  • Option 3- 2nd degree heart block will be characterized by progressively increasing PR interval followed by missing of a QRS complex.
  • Option 4- MI will produce significant elevation of ST segment with reciprocal changes in opposite leads.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1903, 1904.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with heart failure and is scheduled for a heart transplant. His RFT is erratic and his Hb is 6 gm%. The patient received transfusion with two units of whole blood. He experiences acute respiratory distress and fever four hours later. He has high MAP and hypoxemia. Which are the most effective investigations in this case

i. Chest X-ray
ii. Brain Natriuretic Peptide (BNP) level
iii. Absolute neutrophil count
iv. Leucocyte antibodies
v. Platelets
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. i, ii (Chest X ray & BNP levels)
 
  • The clinical scenario describes an elderly patient with heart failure who experiences severe respiratory distress, hypoxia, tachycardia, and elevated mean arterial pressure after a blood transfusion. The most likely diagnosis is transfusion-associated circulatory overload (TACO). Recommended investigations for suspected TACO include a chest X-ray and BNP levels.
 
  • A chest X-ray in TACO may reveal bilateral and predominantly alveolar infiltrates, while BNP levels are typically elevated due to volume overload. It’s important to note that anti-leukocyte antibodies are found in transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI), not in TACO patients.
 
  • TACO is primarily a clinical diagnosis, suspected in any patient who develops acute respiratory distress or hypertension during a transfusion or within six hours after it ends. Risk factors for TACO include older age, pre-existing fluid overload, cardiac dysfunction, renal dysfunction, and the transfusion of large blood volumes.
 
  • Management of TACO involves stopping the transfusion and administering oxygen and diuretics.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 895.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements about TACOTransfusion-associated circulatory overload) is correct?
(i) Chest X-ray showing congestion
(ii) Fever
(iii) Dyspnea
(iv) Hypotension
(v) BNP <200pg/ml
questions.solution:
Statements (i) and (iii) are correct for TACO.

  • Evidence of acute or worsening pulmonary edema (CXR shows vascular congestion, pleural effusion etc.) and dyspnea are seen in TACO(Transfusion-associated circulatory overload)
  • BNP<200 pg/mL, Fever, and Hypotension are commonly seen in TRALI (Transfusion-associated Acute Lung Injury), not TACO.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 895.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient is dizzy and has had palpitations for two hours. When being admitted, SBP was 70 mmHg. A quick ECG reveals narrow complex tachycardia. Which statement about how this case should be handled is accurate?
questions.solution:
From the information in the question, most probable diagnosis is PSVT.
 
  • In case of hemodynamically unstable patient, QRS synchronous Direct Current Cardioversion should be done.
  • Paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia is characterised by bursts of faster-than-normal heart rate.
  • Most prevalent from the second to the fourth decade of life Women > Men ( in case of AVNRT )

Most of the time it's tolerated well, however in older people it may cause:

i. Angina
ii. Pulmonary edema
iii. Hypotension
iv. Syncope



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1894, 1898.

questions.text: Patient of middle age has had chest pain for the last three hours. Trop T = 14 ng/dl, patient's ECG demonstrates ST segment depression and T wave inversion. Vitals remain constant. Which course of treatment is recommended for this patient
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from NSTEMI (Non-ST elevation MI). Aspirin with heparin can be used for the initial treatment for this patient. PCI is done in critically unstable and high risk patients. 

Acute coronary syndrome is divided into two main groups: 

1. ST-segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI)
2. Non-ST-Elevation Acute Coronary Syndrome (NSTE-ACS)

NSTE-ACS is further categorized into:

- NSTEMI (where myocyte necrosis is present and cardiac troponins are elevated)
- Unstable Angina (where myocyte necrosis is absent and cardiac troponins are not elevated)

The diagnosis of NSTE-ACS relies on the following criteria:

- Severe chest discomfort accompanied by at least one of these three features:
  - Occurrence at rest or with minimal exertion, lasting more than 10 minutes
  - Recent onset
  - Crescendo pattern

Additionally, the ECG may show:
- ST segment depression
- T wave inversion
- Elevated cardiac troponins in the case of NSTEMI.

Management of NSTE-ACS:
 
  • To alleviate pain and discomfort, the initial treatment includes bed rest, nitrates, beta blockers, and inhaled oxygen (administered only if arterial oxygen saturation is below 90%).
  • Antithrombotic therapy involves both antiplatelet and anticoagulant medications:
- Dual Antiplatelet Therapy (DAPT): Aspirin (162-325 mg) plus one ADP receptor inhibitor (Ticagrelor, Clopidogrel, or Prasugrel).
- Anticoagulation: Options include Enoxaparin, unfractionated heparin, Fondaparinux, or Bivalirudin.
 
  • An early invasive strategy is recommended for stabilized patients at high risk for coronary events (based on TIMI, GRACE, or HEART scores). This includes diagnostic coronary angiography within 2-72 hours of presentation, followed by revascularization (either percutaneous coronary intervention or coronary artery bypass grafting).


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2047, 2051.

questions.text: 65-year-old man experiencing palpitations and a sudden, excruciating discomfort. What are the best cardiac indicators with a high sensitivity and specificity at two hours after myocardial injury?
questions.solution:
• Best cardiac marker/markers with high sensitivity and specificity 2-4 hours post myocardial injury is Troponin T.
 
  • It is used in the given case because it rises very fast post attack and is very specific for myocardial infarction, unlike CK MB which may also rise in case of muscle injury.

Other options take time to reach a significant value.







Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2055.

choices.text: Non-cardiovascular death is more in HFrEF 30-40% as compared to HFpEF 15%
ACE inhibitors leads to angioedema in 1% cases and dry cough in 10-15% cases
5yr mortality in heart failure is around 50% regardless of EF or type of heart failure
In elderly atrial fibrillation is common and constitutes quarter of stroke cases

questions.text: In relation to cardiac failure, which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Option 1– In Heart Failure with preserved Ejection Fraction (HFpEF), majority of deaths in this group occurs due to non-cardiovascular causes.  In Heart Failure with reduced Ejection Fraction (HFrEF), majority of deaths arise due to cardiovascular causes.

Option 2– ACE inhibitors cause cough and angioedema because they inhibit the degradation of Bradykinin which can cause cough and angioedema.

Option 3– Overall 5 year mortality rate in heart failure is around 50% regardless of EF and type of heart failure (HFpEF or HFrEF).

Option 4– In elderly patients, AF is responsible for around 25% of strokes.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1903, 1931, 1932.

questions.text: A 63-year-old hypertensive patient who was also experiencing diaphoresis presented. He exhibits uneven pulses in both arms upon inspection. ECG showed non-specific ST-T changes. Which of the following imaging studies is most helpful in this situation?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Aortic Dissection.
The clinical presentation and ECG revealing nonspecific ST-T changes strongly suggest aortic dissection. Given the patient’s hemodynamic instability, the next best investigation is a transesophageal echocardiogram.

Aortic Dissection:

Aortic dissection occurs when a tear or flap develops in the intima of the aorta, allowing blood to track into the aortic tissues and split the medial layer.

Predisposing Factors:
- Age
- Hypertension
- Marfan syndrome
- Pregnancy
- Other connective tissue disorders (e.g., Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, giant cell arteritis, systemic lupus erythematosus)
- Coarctation of the aorta
- Turner or Noonan syndromes
- Iatrogenic factors (e.g., aortic cannulation)

Clinical Features:
  • The hallmark presentation of aortic dissection is severe tearing pain between the shoulder blades, often accompanied by diaphoresis. Additional symptoms may include syncope, weakness, and dyspnea.
  • Physical examination may reveal hypertension or hypotension, loss of pulses, signs of aortic regurgitation, pulmonary edema, or neurological deficits. Unequal pulses or blood pressure in the limbs may indicate alterations in blood flow between the true and false lumens.
 
  • An endoscopic transducer is inserted into the esophagus during a typical transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE), a type of ultrasonography that provides a generally better view of the major vessels and posterior cardiac structures than the transthoracic method (TTE).
  • To evaluate cardiac and aortic structures, TOE is most frequently utilised in the fields of anesthesiology, cardiology, and critical care.
 
  • IOC in hemodynamically unstable patient: TEE
  • IOC in hemodynamically stable patient: CT angiography



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2104, 2105.

questions.text: The 'a' wave in JVP means:
questions.solution:
• The 'a' wave seen in jugular venous pulse reflects right atrial contraction before the first heart sound (S1). It can be prominent in those with reduced right ventricular compliance.
  • Additionally, a cannon-type 'a' wave can occur when right atrial contraction is taking place against a closed tricuspid valve in atrioventricular (AV) dissociation. In a wide complex tachycardia, the presence of a cannon a wave can identify the rhythm as being of ventricular origin.
 
  • In atrial fibrillation, this wave is not present.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1817.

questions.text: A 60 year old man was brought to ER in unconscious state. He is a known case of COPD with fever for last 3 days. Based on the ECG provided below, what is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Presence of narrow QRS tachycardia, P-waves of different morphologies along with history of COPD suggests it to be Multifocal Atrial Tachycardia (MAT).
 
  • When an ECG shows a narrow complex tachycardia with an irregular rhythm, this suggests that the heart is beating faster than normal, with a characteristically altered electrical pattern. The presence of P waves, however, indicates that this is not atrial fibrillation, as P waves are not seen in atrial fibrillation.
 
  • Morphological variations in the P waves are highly suggestive of multifocal atrial tachycardia (MAT) which is characterized by multiple P wave morphologies (>= 3 types) rather than one consistent morphology.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1901, 1902.

questions.text:
A patient, 45 years old, complains of chest trouble. An angiogram was performed, and the results showed blocked left circumflex artery. After the stenting, the patient was started on 75 mg of aspirin, 20 mg of atorvastatin, and 50 mg of metoprolol.
Which of the following statements about the patient's future care is true?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Add P2Y12 Inhibitor.
 
  • After the stenting, the patient was started on the following medications:
    • 75 mg of aspirin (standard antiplatelet therapy).
    • 20 mg of atorvastatin (statin to lower cholesterol).
    • 50 mg of metoprolol (beta-blocker to manage blood pressure and heart rate).
 
  • The patient's future care requires the addition of a P2Y12 inhibitor to complete the dual antiplatelet therapy (DAPT) after coronary stenting.
  • The most common P2Y12 inhibitors used for MI are clopidogrel, prasugrel, and ticagrelor.
  • DAPT should be continued for at least 1 year post stenting to prevent stent thrombosis. After DAPT treatment for said duration, Aspirin should be continued lifelong.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2049, 2050.
Magnani, Giulia, and Marco Valgimigli. “Dual Antiplatelet Therapy After Drug-eluting Stent Implantation.” Interventional cardiology (London, England) vol. 11,1 (2016): 51-53. doi:10.15420/icr.2015:17:2. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5808681/

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman who had forearm claudication, temporary visual loss, and stomach pain presented. Her femoral pulses were likewise feeble. Retinal haemorrhages were also visible on fundus. What diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Takayasu arteritis is often referred to as Martorell syndrome, occlusive thromboaortopathy, and Pulseless disease.

Clinical traits: Limb numbness or discomfort, forearm claudications, lightheadedness or wooziness, difficulty focusing, eyesight issues.
Blood pressure is high, different BP in two limbs.

Vessel involvement and corresponding clinical manifestation in Takayasu arteritis: 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2811, 2813.

questions.text: A labourer went to the emergency room complaining of dizziness and extreme fatigue. When the doctor took his medical history, he revealed that he had been working in a hot environment; the temperature that day was 42°C. He had no sign of dehydration. All of the symptoms listed below could have been present, with the exception of :
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Sweating
 
  • The clinical scenario described in a patient who shows no signs of dehydration and has a body temperature of 42oC strongly indicates heatstroke, which is characterized by the absence of sweating.
  • Heatstroke, also known as thermic fever or heat hyperpyrexia, occurs due to a malfunction in the hypothalamus's heat regulation center, leading to inadequate cutaneous circulation and sweating. Contributing factors include high temperatures, elevated humidity, minor infections, advanced age, lack of acclimatization, and alcoholism.

Heatstroke can be classified into two types: 

1. Exertion-induced heatstroke: which affects individuals who experience prolonged exposure to or engage in strenuous physical activity in high temperatures, often without proper training. 

2. Sedentary heatstroke: which primarily impacts the elderly or those with health issues, whose cardiovascular systems struggle to manage the stress of a hot environment, resulting in a rise in body temperature.
 
  • Patients typically exhibit signs of shock, presenting with sudden collapse and loss of consciousness. Common vital sign abnormalities include tachypnea, tachycardia, hypotension, and a widened pulse pressure.
  • Additional specific symptoms may include rapid Kussmaul breathing, lack of sweating accompanied by dry, hot skin, delirium, coma, convulsions, rhabdomyolysis, and multi-organ failure.




Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine and Toxicology by KS Narayan Reddy, 33rd edition, Page no 319.

choices.text: Propranolol is given initially to treat hypertension
Can present as Hypertension alone, sometime with abdominal pain and vomiting.

questions.text: Out of the following, which is a false statement regarding Pheochromocytoma?
questions.solution:
Propranolol is not the preferred drug for HTN control in pheochromocytoma.
 
  • The most popular drug used to treat patients before pheochromocytoma excision is phenoxybenzamine, a non-selective alpha blocker.
  • Alpha blockers are given initially to manage hypertension followed by Beta blockers like propranolol which is given only after adequate alpha blockade has been achieved.
  • If beta blockers are given initially without alpha blockade, it will lead to unopposed alpha stimulation of catecholamines leading to hypertensive crisis.

Pheochromocytoma Overview

Definition:
Pheochromocytoma is a tumor that secretes catecholamines, arising from the chromaffin cells of the adrenal medulla. It can occur sporadically or as part of hereditary syndromes.

Hereditary Syndromes:
  • Hereditary pheochromocytomas are associated with conditions such as:
  • MEN 2 (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2)
  • Familial Paraganglioma Syndrome
  • Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) Syndrome
  • Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1)

Clinical Features:
The condition typically presents with a classic triad of:
  1. Intermittent headaches
  2. Palpitations
  3. Profuse sweating

Patients may also experience:
  • Hypertension
  • Anxiety
  • Panic attacks
  • Nausea
  • Abdominal pain
  • Weight loss
  • Weakness

Symptoms can be triggered by:
  • Surgery
  • Pregnancy
  • Changes in position
  • Exercise
  • Certain medications (e.g., metoclopramide, tricyclic antidepressants)

Investigations:
1. Biochemical Screening: Measurement of urinary and plasma catecholamines and metanephrines.
2. MRI: Preferred for tumor localization due to less risk of precipitating hypertensive episodes compared to CT scans.
3. Other Imaging: Techniques like MIBG scintigraphy, DOPA-PET, or FDG-PET scans can help identify the primary tumor and detect extra-adrenal tumors and metastases.

Treatment:
  • Surgical Resection: The definitive treatment for pheochromocytoma.
  • Preoperative Management: Hypertension is managed with alpha-blockers, followed by beta-blockers.
  • Postoperative Care: Lifelong yearly follow-ups are recommended to monitor for recurrence or complications.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2976.

questions.text: Patient with a history of recurring, 3-minute episodes of retrosternal chest discomfort that responded to sublingual nitrate. Presenting with chest pain in emergency. He has hypercholesterolemia, diabetes, and HTN. He is taking metformin, lovastatin, aspirin, and atenolol. ECG displays a Flat T wave and LVH. What will be the next step?
questions.solution:
The current clinical situation points to a diagnosis of Unstable angina.

Acute coronary syndrome is divided into two main groups: 

1. ST-segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction (STEMI)
2. Non-ST-Elevation Acute Coronary Syndrome (NSTE-ACS)

NSTE-ACS is further categorized into:

- NSTEMI (where myocyte necrosis is present and cardiac troponins are elevated)
- Unstable Angina (where myocyte necrosis is absent and cardiac troponins are not elevated)

The diagnosis of NSTE-ACS relies on the following criteria:

- Severe chest discomfort accompanied by at least one of these three features:
  - Occurrence at rest or with minimal exertion, lasting more than 10 minutes
  - Recent onset
  - Crescendo pattern

Additionally, the ECG may show:
- ST segment depression
- T wave inversion
- Elevated cardiac troponins in the case of NSTEMI.

Management of NSTE-ACS:
 
  • To alleviate pain and discomfort, the initial treatment includes bed rest, nitrates, beta blockers, and inhaled oxygen (administered only if arterial oxygen saturation is below 90%).
  • Antithrombotic therapy involves both antiplatelet and anticoagulant medications:
- Dual Antiplatelet Therapy (DAPT): Aspirin (162-325 mg) plus one ADP receptor inhibitor (Ticagrelor, Clopidogrel, or Prasugrel).
- Anticoagulation: Options include Enoxaparin, unfractionated heparin, Fondaparinux, or Bivalirudin.
 
  • An early invasive strategy is recommended for stabilized patients at high risk for coronary events (based on TIMI, GRACE, or HEART scores). This includes diagnostic coronary angiography within 2-72 hours of presentation, followed by revascularization (either percutaneous coronary intervention or coronary artery bypass grafting).
 
  • Many LMWHs, including dalteparin, enoxaparin etc have been examined in unstable angina. Nadroparin decreased the risk of ischemic events in a small open study when compared to aspirin alone or a combination of aspirin and conventional heparin.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2047, 2051.

questions.text: A patient went to the emergency room complaining of severe chest pain. He experienced a syncope episode with a brief loss of consciousness. The patient was diaphoretic and had obvious signs of instability. Uneven bilateral pulses were present. Tachycardia with non-specific ST-T alterations was seen on the ECG. Which of the following studies will serve as a roadmap for future management?
questions.solution:
This is a case of Aortic Dissection.
The clinical presentation and ECG revealing nonspecific ST-T changes strongly suggest aortic dissection. Given the patient’s hemodynamic instability, the next best investigation is a transesophageal echocardiogram.

Aortic Dissection:

Aortic dissection occurs when a tear or flap develops in the intima of the aorta, allowing blood to track into the aortic tissues and split the medial layer.

Predisposing Factors:
- Age
- Hypertension
- Marfan syndrome
- Pregnancy
- Other connective tissue disorders (e.g., Ehlers-Danlos syndrome, giant cell arteritis, systemic lupus erythematosus)
- Coarctation of the aorta
- Turner or Noonan syndromes
- Iatrogenic factors (e.g., aortic cannulation)

Clinical Features:
  • The hallmark presentation of aortic dissection is severe tearing pain between the shoulder blades, often accompanied by diaphoresis. Additional symptoms may include syncope, weakness, and dyspnea.
  • Physical examination may reveal hypertension or hypotension, loss of pulses, signs of aortic regurgitation, pulmonary edema, or neurological deficits. Unequal pulses or blood pressure in the limbs may indicate alterations in blood flow between the true and false lumens.
 
  • An endoscopic transducer is inserted into the esophagus during a typical transesophageal echocardiogram (TEE), a type of ultrasonography that provides a generally better view of the major vessels and posterior cardiac structures than the transthoracic method (TTE).
  • To evaluate cardiac and aortic structures, TOE is most frequently utilised in the fields of anesthesiology, cardiology, and critical care.
 
  • IOC in hemodynamically unstable patient: TEE
  • IOC in hemodynamically stable patient: CT angiography



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2104, 2105.

questions.text: ESRD and pedal edema were detected in a patient with hypertension. The patient is reduced urine output. Investigations revealed that the serum creatinine level was 1.9 mg/dl. Which antihypertensive medication from the list below should be administered to this patient to treat their hypertension?
questions.solution:
#Controversial question 

The antihypertensive that can be given in this case is chlorthalidone. The patient in this case is having renal insufficiency but there is no proteinuria mentioned in the question stem. So among the given options, the thiazide diuretic chlorthalidone can be administered as antihypertensive in this patient.

Management of hypertension in chronic kidney disease(CKD):
 
  • ACE inhibitors or ARBs are considered the first-line drugs in patients with proteinuria.
  • These agents effectively reduce blood pressure, proteinuria and prevent kidney decline. Calcium channel blockers can be added if necessary.

For patients who do not have proteinuria, there is no established first-line therapy. One or two of the following drugs can be used:
  1. Thiazides/thiazide-like diuretics
  2. ACE inhibitors or ARBs
  3. Calcium channel blockers
  • In patients presenting with fluid retention or fluid overload, thiazide diuretics such as chlorthalidone and hydrochlorothiazide are recommended for management.
  • In CKD stages 1 to 3 (GFR thiazides are recommended, while loop diuretics such as bumetanide, furosemide are used in stages 4-5 (GFR < 30ml/min).


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 530, 610.
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 516.

questions.text:
The patient has a history of mononeuritis multiplex, polymyalgia rheumatica, jaw claudication, headache, and giant cell arteritis.
What should the initial course of treatment be?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Prednisolone.

The patient is presenting with symptoms of giant cell arteritis (GCA), which is an inflammatory disease of the arteries. 

GCA can cause a number of symptoms, including:
  • Headache
  • Jaw claudication (pain in the jaw when chewing)
  • Polymyalgia rheumatica (pain and stiffness in the shoulders and hips)
  • Mononeuritis multiplex (inflammation of multiple nerves)
  • Amarausis fugax 
The initial course of treatment for GCA is high-dose prednisolone. It is especially important to start prednisolone as soon as GCA is suspected, due to the risk of vision loss by ophthalmic artery involvement.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2811, 2812.

questions.text: What should not be given to a patient with NSTEMI?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Streptokinase.
 
  • NSTEMI (Non-ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction) is a type of heart attack with partial blockage of a coronary artery,but the blockage does not cause the ST segment of the ECG to rise.
  • Treatment for NSTEMI includes aspirin, clopidogrel, and prasugrel. These medications help to prevent blood clots from forming and blocking the coronary arteries
  • Streptokinase, a thrombolytic medication used to dissolve existing blood clots, should not be given to a patient with NSTEMI as it can increase the risk of bleeding and thrombus may embolise to distant small vessels and can cause blockage.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2048-2051.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is inhaled nitric oxide used?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Pulmonary hypertension

NO increases cGMP levels in vascular smooth muscle, which acts as a vasodilator and relaxes other smooth muscle. Inhaling NO increases blood flow to the areas of the lung exposed to it and lowers pulmonary vascular resistance.
Uses: 
  • Therapeutic: The FDA has only approved chronic pulmonary neonatal hypertension as the use of inhaled NO. 
  • Diagnostic: Inhaled NO can be utilized during cardiac catheterization to assess the ability of patients with heart failure and newborns with congenital heart disease to dilate their blood vessels in the lungs. It can also be used to calculate the diffusion capacity (DL) across the alveolar-capillary unit.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2124-2128.

questions.text: An emotionally disturbed middle-aged man in good health was having a disagreement with his brother when he suddenly felt chest pain and fainted. He was pronounced dead when he was taken to the hospital. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Takotsubo cardiomyopathy, also known as the apical ballooning syndrome or stress-induced cardiomyopathy, is a form of heart failure that is becoming more recognized around the world.
  • It is characterized by global ventricular dilation with basal contraction, and primarily affects older women following intense emotional or physical stress.
  • Symptoms may include pulmonary edema, chest pain, and hypotensive states and ECG changes that mimic an acute infarction.
  • The left ventricular impairment usually resolves within a few weeks, however it is considered to be a reversible condition.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 102, 1966.
Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th edition, Page no 1590.
