choices.text: Urinary Sodium and potassium increases, Urinary calcium increases
Urinary Sodium and potassium increased, Urinary calcium decreases
Urinary Sodium and calcium increases, Urinary potassium decreases
Urinary Potassium and calcium increases, Urinary sodium decreases

questions.text: Thiazides are prescribed to a 35-year-old male to treat his primary hypertension. What would be his urinary sodium, potassium, and calcium levels after taking the medication?
questions.solution:
Thiazide diuretics, commonly used to treat hypertension, have specific effects on urinary sodium, potassium, and calcium levels due to their mechanism of action on the nephron.

Mechanism of action:

  1. Sodium: Thiazides inhibit the sodium-chloride (Na+Cl-)symporter in the DCT (distal convoluted tubule), leading to increased excretion of sodium (natriuresis).
  2. Potassium: As sodium excretion increases, more sodium is delivered to the collecting duct. This stimulates RAAS- and aldosterone enhances sodium reabsorption in exchange for potassium secretion, leading to increased potassium excretion and urinary potassium (kaliuresis).
  3. Calcium: Thiazides reduce urinary calcium excretion by enhancing calcium reabsorption in the distal convoluted tubule.
Hence, expected urinary changes
 
  • Urinary Sodium: Increased (Natriuresis)
  • Potassium: Increased(Kaliuresis)
  • Calcium: Decreased
Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 628, 629.

questions.text: Which test is considered to be the gold standard for myocarditis diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Endomyocardial biopsy
 
  • The gold standard for determining the cause of myocarditis and providing a conclusive diagnosis is an endomyocardial biopsy.
  • Endomyocardial biopsy is indicated when a new presentation of heart failure is accompanied by conduction blocks or ventricular tachyarrhythmias, which suggest possible etiologies of noninfectious inflammatory causes that warrant aggressive immunosuppression, such as sarcoidosis or giant cell myocarditis.
  • The indications, yield, and benefit of endomyocardial biopsy for evaluation of myocarditis or new-onset cardiomyopathy are not well established.
  • MRI is the best option because non-invasive inquiry is recommended in the current scenario.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1930, 1932, 1959.

choices.text: NOAC ( New oral Anticoagulants) are used in atrial fibrillation and mitral stenosis
Patients with ischemic stroke due to Atrial Fibrilation can be started on anticoagulation

questions.text: <strong>Consider the following statements in AF patients:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. 2, 3 are correct

Novel Oral Anticoagulants (NOACs), also referred to as direct oral anticoagulants, comprise a new category of anticoagulants that includes the oral thrombin inhibitor dabigatran and oral factor Xa inhibitors such as rivaroxaban, apixaban, and edoxaban. These medications are user-friendly, provide reliable anticoagulation, and do not necessitate dosage adjustments based on blood testing. Compared to warfarin, they have a lower risk of intracranial hemorrhage and serve as alternatives for patients with atrial fibrillation.
 
  • Statement 1: NOACs are not recommended for treating moderate to severe mitral stenosis (MS) due to limited clinical evidence regarding their efficacy and safety in this condition. Warfarin is the preferred anticoagulant for patients with mitral stenosis and mechanical prosthetic valves.
  • Statement 2: NOACs are contraindicated in individuals with prosthetic mechanical heart valves because of insufficient evidence. Warfarin is given in such cases. 
  • Statement 3: For patients experiencing ischemic stroke due to atrial fibrillation, anticoagulation with either warfarin or NOACs is recommended. In cases of small or moderate-sized infarcts without intracranial bleeding, warfarin can be initiated shortly (after 24 hours) following admission, as the risk of transitioning to hemorrhagic stroke is minimal. NOACs can be started after 48 hours due to their quicker anticoagulant effects.
  • Statement 4: Beta blockers and CCBs are first line drugs used to achieve rate control in AF.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 935, 1905-1907.

choices.text: Aortic valve balloon dilation to prevent further worsening

questions.text: An 11-minute workout is being performed by a 50-year-old man with aortic stenosis as per Bruce's protocol. Fatigue forced the end of the exercise. At rest, his peak systolic gradient across the aortic valve was 60 mmHg. What kind of care is ideal for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Aortic valve replacement

The patient in question has asymptomatic aortic stenosis but develops symptoms on exercise (abnormal/positive exercise test). Also the presence of mean pressure gradient of 60 mm Hg puts this patient into the category of  Severe Aortic Stenosis. Since the patient in question has 'Very Severe AS' and 'Abnormal Stress Testing' he should be considered for surgical intervention in the form of Aortic Valve Replacement (AVR).

Management of Aortic Stenosis is summarised below:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1982, 1983.

choices.text: Sudden unexpected cardiac death with symptoms of ischemia
New regional wall motion abnormally with raised cardiac biomarkers
Three times increase in troponin levels are required for coronary artery bypass grafting
Reinfarction can be diagnosed if increased troponin levels by 5-7% in serial samples

questions.text: Which of the following statement is incorrect regarding Myocardial Infarction?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Three times increase in troponin levels are required for coronary artery bypass grafting.
 
  • Coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG) is a surgical procedure that is used to improve blood flow to the heart. It is not typically performed based on troponin levels. 
  • Troponin levels are used to diagnose a heart attack, but they are not used to determine whether or not a patient needs CABG.
Other options:

Option 1: Sudden unexpected cardiac death with symptoms of ischemia is consistent with a myocardial infarction.
Option 2: New regional wall motion abnormality with raised cardiac biomarkers is indicative of myocardial infarction and is one of the criteria for its diagnosis.
Option 4: Reinfarction can be diagnosed if there is an increase in troponin levels by 5-7% in serial samples, suggesting a recurrent myocardial infarction.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2033, 2045, 2057.

questions.text: A young male patient is admitted with triglycerides of 140 mg/dl and LDL cholesterol of 600 mg/dl. What would a physical examination likely reveal?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Tendon xanthomas.
 
  • The clinical presentation of elevated serum LDL (low-density lipoprotein) and elevated serum cholesterol points to a diagnosis of familial hypercholesterolemia (type IIa hyperlipoproteinemia). This is an inherited disorder due to defects in LDL receptors.
  • Tendon xanthomas: Yellowish nodules that form on tendons (such as the Achilles tendon), caused by the deposition of cholesterol and other lipids in the tendons.
  • Elevated triglycerides and LDL cholesterol in the patient contribute to tendon xanthomas.
  • The patient's young age is a risk factor for developing tendon xanthomas.

Other options:
 
  • Planar xanthomas: Flat, yellowish patches that form on the skin.
  • Lipemia retinalis: Condition in which the retina (the light-sensitive tissue at the back of the eye) becomes cloudy due to the accumulation of lipids. 
  • Tuberoeruptive xanthomas: small, yellowish nodules that form on the skin, especially the face and back.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3139, 3141.

choices.text: Late enhancement on Gadolinium: MRI suggests scar
Akinetic area does not benefit from reperfusion
Low dose dobutamine may be used to detect hibernating myocardium
Rest reinjection thallium is used to detect hibernating myocardium

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true?
questions.solution:
• The contractile function of hibernating myocardium can be completely restored after reperfusion. It is a reversible state of contractile dysfunction observed in the course of chronic ischemia associated with reduction of coronary blood flow without major evidence of irreversible myocardial damage (viable myocardium).
 
  • Ischemia may also manifest as delayed contractility of a segment (Akinetic segment). Ischemia is a dynamic condition, and if sufficient blood flow is restored in time, either through a decrease in metabolic demand (as when a stress test ends) or through reperfusion, contractility of the affected segment can recover rapidly.

 
  • Persistence or increasing severity of the wall motion abnormality after the initial insult implies that the tissue is becoming nonfunctional (i.e., not metabolically active or hibernating) or nonviable (infarcted). Akinetic myocardial segments do not thicken at all, and dyskinetic segments bulge paradoxically outward in systole, thus implying that no functioning myocardium is present

 
  • Any improvement in wall motion abnormality by at least one grade in two or more segments during stress echocardiography with Dobutamine is likely to signify viability (either stunned or hibernating myocardium).

 
  • Viable myocardium can be revealed by raising blood levels of thallium by reinjection of a small dose (1 to 2 mCi) of thallium at rest. Thus, in some patients, thallium reinjection is necessary to identify viable myocardium when there are irreversible defects on stress-redistribution images.



Reference: Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th edition, Page no 195, 196, 262.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is made worse by prostaglandin E infusion?
questions.solution:
Obstructive TAPVC is worsened by prostaglandin E infusion.
 
  • Deterioration of the clinical status after starting prostaglandin E1 usually indicates the presence of rare congenital cardiac defects associated with pulmonary venous or left atrial obstruction

These include:
  • Transposition of the great arteries associated with restrictive atrial shunting.
  • Ductal independent lesions
  • Total anomalous pulmonary venous connection (TAPVc)
  • Truncus arteriosus
  • Anomalous origin of the left main coronary artery from the pulmonary artery


Reference: Essential Pediatrics by OP Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 423, 424, 429.

choices.text: It involves acral parts of the fingers
Migratory thrombophlebitis is seen only in Raynaud's phenomenon
Drugs acting by inhibiting the beta receptors in blood vessels also play a role
Emotional stress may also precipitate Raynaud's phenomenon

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Raynaud's phenomenon?
questions.solution:
All of the following are true regarding Raynaud's phenomenon except:
Option 2: Migratory thrombophlebitis is seen only in Raynaud's phenomenon

Migratory thrombophlebitis is seen in following conditions:
    • Raynaud's phenomenon
    • Buerger's disease
    • Malignancies
 
  • Raynaud's phenomenon is characterized by episodic vasoconstriction in the fingers and toes (acral region), sometimes also affecting the tip of the nose and earlobes.
  • Attacks are reversible, and can be triggered by a decrease in temperature, as well as emotional stress and vibration.
  • Attacks typically start with pallor of the fingers, followed by cyanosis of variable duration. Hyperemia ensues spontaneously or with rewarming of the digit.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2778.

questions.text: Which of the following examinations is useful in determining the site of a misplaced implant in a patient with an implanted cardiac pacemaker (defibrillator)?
questions.solution:
In a patient with  implanted cardiac pacemaker (defibrillator), the investigation useful to know the position of the misplaced implant is X-ray
 
  • Lead dislodgement maybe radiographically visible or it maybe a micro dislodgement, where there is no radiographic change in position, but there is significant increase in pacing threshold or decline in electrogram amplitude.

A plain radiograph/X-Ray is the modality of choice to determine the location of implantable cardioverter defibrillator. 
  • CXR allows visualization of ICD leads and the generator with its position relative to the heart. It can also detect if there are any complications such as Lead dislodgement or migration.
  • CT scan or Fluoroscopy is used if detained analysis of the pacemaker is required, however CXR is the most effective way and the first line investigation to locate an ICD.


Hence, Best method to know the position and integrity of ICD is plain radiograph.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1914.

questions.text: In cases of haemorrhage, the shock index (HR/SBP) can be used to assess the level of bleeding. Which of the following best describes a serious PPH?
questions.solution:
0.9-1.1 is most indicative for significant PPH.

Shock index of more than 0.9 is a sign of tissue hypoperfusion.
 
  • The shock index (SI) is defined as the HR/systolic blood pressure (SBP) with a normal SI being 0.5–0.7.
  • An elevated SI (>0.9) has been proposed to be a more sensitive indicator of transfusion requirement and of patients with critical bleeding among those with hypovolemic (hemorrhagic) shock than either HR or BP alone.
  • The SI may also identify patients at risk for postintubation hypotension.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2238.

questions.text: Which grade does a patient who has hypertension under clinical treatment belong to?
questions.solution:
Above patient falls under ASA 2.
 
  • In a patient with mild systemic disease (no functional limitation) ASA grade is 2.
  • So, ASA grade in hypertensive patient whose BP is controlled, is 2.


Anesthesiologists (ASA) Physical Status (PS) Classification System: 





Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page no 987.

questions.text: Which part of the body is used to check the proper arterial supply using a modified Allen's test?
questions.solution:
Modified Allen's test is for checking the proper arterial supply at the wrist.
 
  • Modified Allen's test is used to know the integrity of palmar arch (patency of radial and ulnar arteritis).
  • A normal Modified Allen’s test or Barbeau test confirming dual blood supply to the hand from the radial and ulnar arteries is recommended prior to access at this site.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1860.

questions.text: What is the most commonly used solution for cardioplegic arrest?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Potassium solution.
 
  • Cardioplegic arrest is a technique used to stop the heart during surgery. It is done by injecting a solution into the coronary arteries that stops the heart from beating.
  • The most commonly used solution for cardioplegic arrest is a potassium solution.
  • Potassium solution causes temporary arrest of the heart's electrical activity, leading to reversible cardiac arrest.
  • Stopping the heart's contractions allows surgeons to work on a motionless and bloodless heart during the procedure.
  • To provide a motionless field for the surgeon, the heart is arrested in diastole by the administration of a potassium enriched cardioplegia solution. Cessation of myocardial electromechanical activity is the single most important step in reducing the heart’s metabolism.
  • Potassium-induced arrest alone reduces the heart’s myocardial oxygen consumption by 90%.



Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th Edition, Page no 1759.

questions.text: Symptoms of a 50-year-old male patient include palpitations, dizziness, and weariness. The ECG strip displays the image below. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Ventricular premature complex.

The ECG strip displays a premature ventricular beat (VPC), originating from the ventricles.
VPCs are frequent and typically not harmful, but they may indicate underlying heart conditions like heart disease or cardiomyopathy.

Criteria of ECG for ventricular premature complex (VPC):
  • Premature beat that originates in the ventricles.
  • QRS complex is wider than 0.12 seconds.
  • There is no P wave preceding the QRS complex.
  • The QRS complex is usually bizarre in appearance.
  • The T wave is usually inverted.
  • The VPC may be followed by a compensatory pause


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1915-1917.

questions.text: A patient with palpitations is brought to the emergency room. The following image can be seen on the ECG recording. What medication is preferred to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Lignocaine
 
  • The ECG shows a regular rhythm with a wide QRS complex, indicating ventricular tachycardia (VT).
  • VT is a serious arrhythmia requiring immediate treatment.
  • In a hemodynamically stable patient amiodarone, lidocaine, and procainamide can be used to treat the condition
  • Preferred medication: Lignocaine
  • In hemodynamically unstable patients, electrical cardioversion is done.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1913.

questions.text: A patient has syncope, palpitations, and hypotension all of a sudden. The patient's ECG displays the picture below. What medical intervention does the patient require?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: DC cardioversion.
 
  • In the given ECG, the presence of narrow-complex regular tachycardia and P-waves occurring after QRS complexes, known as retro P waves or pseudo-r' waves, (especially prominent in lead V1) point to a diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT).
  • Electrical cardioversion is done if the patient is hemodynamically unstable (as in this case scenairo where the patient has hypotension and syncope) or if PSVT does not response to any of the other methods mentioned above.
Management includes:
  • Vagal maneuvers    
  • Intravenous Adenosine
  • Intravenous β blockers (esmolol, metoprolol)
  • Intravenous non-DHP calcium channel blockers (verapamil, diltiazem)
  • Electrical cardioversion (if hemodynamically unstable or unresponsive to other methods)



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1898, 1899.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Pulsus Bigeminus is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Compensatory pause is absent.
 
  • Pulsus bigeminus is characterized by an irregular rhythm with every other beat occurring prematurely, resulting in a paired (coupled) beat. 
  • The premature beat is followed by a compensatory pause, which is a brief pause before the next regular heartbeat. 
  • This compensatory pause is a key feature that helps distinguish pulsus bigeminus from other irregular rhythms.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1818, 1819, 1915.

questions.text: Rytand's murmur appears in:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: A-V Block.
  • Rytand's murmur is a diastolic murmur that is heard in patients with complete atrioventricular (A-V) block.
  • It is a mid-late blowing diastolic murmur heard occasionally in patients with complete atrioventricular heart block. Best heard at the apex, and often confused with mitral stenosis (no opening snap).






Reference: An auricular diastolic murmur with heart block in elderly patients, David A. Rytand, American Heart Journal, Volume 32, Issue 5, 1946, Pages 579-598, ISSN 0002-8703, https://doi.org/10.1016/0002-8703(46)90667-9.
(https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/0002870346906679)

questions.text: The sign of Auenbrugger is seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Percardial Effusion.
 
  • Auenbrugger's sign, also known as "Percussion Dullness," is a physical sign seen in patients with pericardial effusion. It can be seen as a bulge in the epigastrium.
  • It is caused by the accumulation of fluid around the heart, leading to upward and leftward displacement of the heart, which can be felt by palpating the chest wall.
  • Constrictive pericarditis may cause a similar sign called Kussmaul's sign.



Reference: Rastogi, Vaibhav et al. “Abdominal Physical Signs of Inspection and Medical Eponyms.” Clinical medicine & research vol. 17,3-4 (2019): 115-126. doi:10.3121/cmr.2019.1420. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6886890/

choices.text: Characterised by pleuritic chest pain, leukocytosis and elevated ESR

questions.text: Which statement concerning the Dressler syndrome is false?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Steroids from the mainstay of treatment.
 
  • Dressler syndrome, also known as post–myocardial infarction syndrome, Dressler syndrome usually occurs 1 to 8 weeks after infarction
  • Clinically, patients with Dressler syndrome have malaise, fever, pericardial discomfort, leukocytosis, an elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR), and a pericardial effusion.
  • The cause of post-MI syndrome s not clearly established, although detection of antibodies to cardiac tissue suggests an immunopathologic process.
  • Treatment is with Aspirin, 650 mg as often as every 4 hours, may be effective. Glucocorticosteroids and NSAIDs are best avoided in patients with Dressler syndrome within 4 weeks of STEMI because of their potential to impair infarct healing, cause ventricular rupture, and increase coronary vascular resistance


Reference: Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th edition, Page no 1163.

questions.text: What is the sequence of color changes in Raynaud's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: White - Blue - Red
 
  • Raynaud's syndrome occurs due to peripheral vasospasm, and it is more common in the upper extremities. It may occur due to exposure to various stimuli, including cold temperatures, tobacco, or emotional stress, and certain occupational groups, such as those who use vibrating tools, or it can be secondary to scleroderma, systemic lupus erythematosus, Sjogren's syndrome, and antiphospholipid syndrome.
  • The sequence of color changes typically starts with pallor (white) due to decreased blood flow to the extremities.
  • This is followed by cyanosis (blue) as the lack of oxygen causes the skin to turn blue.
  • Finally, as the blood flow returns, the affected areas may turn red due to reactive hyperemia, a rebound increase in blood flow.
  • Therefore, the correct sequence of color changes in Raynaud's disease is White - Blue - Red.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2778.

questions.text: Where do we see the Epsilon wave?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Arrhythmogenic right ventricular dysplasia 
 
  • The epsilon wave is a characteristic finding seen in the ECG of a patient with arrhythmogenic right ventricular cardiomyopathy.
  • It is a small positive deflection buried at the end of the QRS complex.
  • The sinus rhythm ECG suggests the disease in >85% of patients, most often showing T-wave inversions in V1–V3.
  • Delayed activation of the right ventricle may cause a widened QRS (>110 ms) in the right precordial leads (V1–V3) and a prolonged S-wave upstroke in those leads and, occasionally, a notched deflection at the end of the QRS known as an epsilon wave.

Image showing Epsilon wave seen in ARVD: 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1921.

questions.text: For patients with Congestive Heart Failure and an ejection fraction of <40 percent i, which is the treatment of choice?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: ACE-I+ Beta Blocker
 
  • Heart failure is termed HFrEF when the EF is below 40%. The pharmacological management of HfrEF includes two broad categories of drugs:


Combining ACE-I with Beta blocker will have mortality benefit more than other combinations given in options.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1941, 1942.

questions.text: In which of the following is the Duroziez's sign seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Aortic Regurgitation
 
  • Duroziez's sign is heard over the femoral artery.
  • It is elicited by partially compressing the femoral artery with a stethoscope.
  • The sign is associated with a to-and-fro murmur.
  • Duroziez's sign is indicative of aortic regurgitation.

Peripheral signs of Aortic Regurgitation:  




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1988.

questions.text: In which of the following is the Vitum's sign seen?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Tricuspid Regurgitation

questions.text: Where do we see Carvallo's Sign representing a Diastolic Murmur that increases on inspiration?

  • Carvallo's sign disappears in RV failure.

questions.text: The target BP must be below which value before thrombolysis can be done in ischemic stroke?
questions.solution:

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke:

questions.text: What is the likely cause of Aneurysmal rupture in case of a patient with suspected subarachnoid haemorrhage presents with blood isolated in the fourth ventricle on a CT scan?
questions.solution:
The correct Option is 1: Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery Aneurysm 
 
  • The fourth ventricle is located in the brainstem, and blood isolated in this area on a CT scan indicates bleeding in that region.
  • The Posterior Inferior Cerebellar Artery (PICA) is a branch of the vertebral artery, and aneurysms in this artery can cause subarachnoid hemorrhage with blood isolated in the fourth ventricle.
  • Posterior inferior cerebellar artery (PICA) - the largest branch of vertebral artery. It supplies the lateral part of the medulla, the cerebellar hemisphere, and the choroid plexus of the fourth ventricle.



Vertebral artery branches:

questions.text: Which of the following is the best marker to look for in athletes with acute STEMI?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Troponin T/I
 
  • Troponin T and Troponin I are cardiac-specific biomarkers that are released into the bloodstream when there is damage to the heart muscle, such as in acute STEMI.
  • They are highly sensitive and specific indicators of myocardial injury, and their levels rise within a few hours after the onset of a heart attack.
  • Troponin T/I levels are widely used in clinical practice to diagnose acute myocardial infarction (AMI) and to assess its severity in athletes and non-athletes alike.
  • CK levels, CRP and LDH may be falsely elevated in professional athletes due to skeletal muscle damage that occurs. So, it can't be used as a marker for myocardial injury.



Reference: Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th edition, Page no 1116, 1184

questions.text: The initial treatment of acute, life-threatening cardiogenic Pulmonary edema involves all of the following, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Digoxin
 
  • Cardiogenic pulmonary edema: Accumulation of fluid in the lungs due to heart failure.
  • The initial treatment aims to relieve the acute symptoms and improve the patient's condition rapidly.
  • Digoxin is not typically used in the initial treatment of acute, life-threatening cardiogenic pulmonary edema due to its slower onset of action.
Management of Acute Cardiogenic Pulmonary Edema:

questions.text: Which of the following conditions has the lowest likelihood of being linked to infectious endocarditis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Small ASD
 
  • Infective endocarditis: Infection of the inner lining of the heart chambers and heart valves, usually caused by bacteria or fungi.
  • It is most commonly associated with abnormalities that cause turbulent blood flow or damage to the endocardium, which can provide a favorable environment for bacterial attachment and colonization.
  • The risk of infective endocarditis is relatively lower for small ASDs compared to larger defects or conditions involving heart valves.
  • As the gradient is less in ASD thus turbulence doesn't take place and thus Infective Endocarditis doesn't usually happen. 
  • Other conditions like small ventricular septal defects (VSDs), mild mitral regurgitation (MR), and mild mitral stenosis (MS) may still present some risk, depending on their severity and structural abnormalities.


Reference: Braunwald's Heart Disease: A Textbook of Cardiovascular Medicine, 11th edition, Page no 1486.

questions.text: Identify the statement which is true about 'Gregg' effect:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Increased coronary flow improves LV systolic performance 
 
  • Gregg effect: Increased coronary flow improves LV (left ventricular) systolic performance by enhancing oxygen and nutrient delivery to the heart muscle, aiding better contraction and preventing heart failure.
Treatment options to increase coronary blood flow:
  • Angioplasty: Opens narrowed/blocked coronary arteries.
  • Stent placement: Keeps coronary arteries open after angioplasty.
  • Coronary artery bypass grafting: Creates a new blood supply to the heart.



Reference: Salavastru, C I, and R Cârmaciu. “The role of the Gregg phenomenon in cardiac performance.” Romanian journal of physiology : physiological sciences vol. 35,3-4 (1998): 253-7. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11061325/

questions.text: A 52 year old patient with diabetes presented with palpitation. On examination the BP was 128/78 mmHg. The ECG of the patient is given below. What is the next step in the management?
questions.solution:
• The given ECG shows narrow complex tachycardia with absent P waves and regular rhythm suggestive of PSVT.
  • Adenosine is the drug of choice in hemodynamically stable patients. (Synchronised Cardioversion if unstable). It's used for the acute termination of PSVT. It works by briefly blocking conduction in the atrioventricular (AV) node, which can interrupt the reentrant circuit responsible for the tachycardia.

questions.text: What is the cause of the following murmur?
questions.solution:
The given image is representative of the phonocardiogram (PCG) tracing obtained in a patient. The murmur represented is a holosystolic murmur i.e. lying between the first and second heart sounds, with equal intensities of S1 and S2.
The murmur of mitral regurgitation is often described as a holosystolic, high-pitched, “blowing murmur” which is loudest at the apex and radiates towards the axilla.

questions.text: ECG of a patient is given. Which of the following can lead to the ECG changes shown below?
questions.solution:
The ECG of this patient reveals tall, symmetrically peaked T waves. Based on the options, the patient is likely being managed with antihypertensives.
The finding of peaked/ tall T waves can be due to hyperkalemia, and in this patient it is likely to be medication-induced, the likely culprit being spironolactone.
Spironolactone is a potassium Sparing Diuretic. It is a competitive inhibitor of the mineralocorticoid receptor in the late distal tubule and collecting duct of kidneys. as a result, Spironolactone Promotes sodium diuresis but maintains body potassium levels.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 348.

questions.text: A 51-year old female presented with palpitation, chest discomfort and fatigue. Auscultation reveals a mid-diastolic murmur. The JVP tracing shows large ‘a’ waves. The patient most likely will have?
questions.solution:
The patient with a mid-diastolic murmur and giant ‘a’ waves has a valvular heart lesion - tricuspid stenosis which is the cause of the patient’s difficulty in breathing.
The patient most likely has tricuspid stenosis.

questions.text: A female patient presents with restlessness, palpitations and tremors. BP is recorded to be 180/110 along with tachycardia. On examination there is a neck swelling. She is a known case of asthma. ECG shows A-Fib. Which drug is used next in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
A female asthmatic patient with a neck swelling and symptoms of restlessness, palpitations and tremors with increased blood pressure and heart rate, showing atrial fibrillation on ECG has multiple issues:
  • Asthma
  • Hyperthyroidism as indicated by the neck swelling, restlessness, palpitations, tremors, increased heart rate and BP (with a high index of suspicion for thyroid storm/ crisis, particularly if the patient has hyperpyrexia or is agitated)
  • Atrial fibrillation - precipitated by the thyrotoxicosis
The first step in the management of atrial fibrillation, despite the cause, is to control the ventricular response. Beta-adrenergic blockers, calcium channel blockers and digoxin are effective agents. 
In patients with severe asthma in whom beta blockers are contraindicated, rate control can be achieved with calcium channel blockers such as diltiazem.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2942.

questions.text: A 75y old man with history of chest pain since two days radiating to left arm. Trop- Positive. The resident told the intern to treat the patient as NSTEMI. Which of the following drugs will not be given in NSTEMI?
questions.solution:
Tenectplase is fibrinolytic. It is contraindicated in NSTEMI.
Drugs used in NTSEMI-Aspirin, Clopidogrel, Statin, Ace Inhibitors, Beta Blockers, nitrates and heparin.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, page. No- 2048, 2050.

questions.text: 50y old male was diagnosed to have Cardiac failure. Which among the following will delay the progression of heart failure in this man?
questions.solution:
ACE inhibitors are used in Heart failure as they prevent progression of disease and prevent Cardiac Remodelling.

*Extra Edge: 

Left ventricular (LV) remodeling (ie, enlargement and functional deterioration occurring over time) is among the main mechanisms of progression in heart failure (HF). LV dilatation and dysfunction are major negative prognostic markers in patients with HF. Treatments that are effective in limiting or even reversing this process can be expected to provide clinical benefit. Changes in LV dimensions rather than in ejection fraction should be used to monitor remodeling. Ejection fraction can be influenced by transient loading conditions and by agents that stimulate contractility at the expense of increased oxygen demand, whereas dimensional changes probably reflect structural modifications occurring in the myocardium. The neurohormonal antagonists that have been demonstrated to reduce mortality and morbidity in HF (angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors [ACE], beta-blockers, angiotensin receptor blockers, and aldosterone antagonists) are also able to inhibit or reverse remodeling. In reverse remodeling, beta-blockers appear to be superior to the other classes of drugs, with a stronger correlation between dose and effect, but it must be remembered that they have been tested as an addition to background therapy that may include ACE inhibitors. 

Reference: Frigerio M, Roubina E. Drugs for left ventricular remodeling in heart failure. Am J Cardiol. 2005 Dec 19;96(12A):10L-18L. doi: 10.1016/j.amjcard.2005.09.060. Epub 2005 Oct 5. PMID: 16399088.

questions.text: A male patient presents to the emergency department after a car crash. On examination, his BP was 80/40mmHg and pulses were feeble, neck veins distended, and heart sounds were muffled. Which of the following changes will you expect in the jvp of this patient?
questions.solution:
Patient scenario:

  • Male, post-trauma

  • Hypotension (80/40 mmHg)

  • Feeble pulses

  • Distended neck veins

  • Muffled heart sounds

**This is Beck’s triad → classic for cardiac tamponade.

JVP changes in cardiac tamponade:

  • Prominent X descent (atrial relaxation)

  • Absent Y descent (impaired ventricular filling due to pericardial pressure) 

  • Other findings: Kussmaul sign (JVP rises on inspiration), tachycardia, hypotension

Other options:

  • Cannon A waves → seen in AV dissociation

  • Absent A wave → seen in atrial fibrillation

questions.text: In a patient with NSTEMI, all the following can be used for treatment except?
questions.solution:
Streptokinase is not used in the management of NSTEMI (Non-ST Segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction). It is a fibrin nonspecific plasminogen activator primarily utilized as a fibrinolytic agent in the treatment of STEMI (ST Segment Elevation Myocardial Infarction).

Key Differences in Management:
STEMI:

Typically caused by plaque rupture leading to the formation of an occluding thrombus.
Fibrinolytic therapy is indicated as it can restore blood flow by dissolving the clot.
NSTEMI:

Can arise from stable, non-occluding plaques, which may still allow some blood flow.
Fibrinolytic therapy is contraindicated as it may cause rupture of the stable plaque, potentially worsening the situation.
Classification of Acute Coronary Syndrome:
1. Unstable Angina
2. NSTEMI
3. STEMI
Treatment of NSTEMI:
Admission: To a specialized cardiac unit for monitoring and management.
Oxygen: Inhaled oxygen if hypoxia is present.
Bed Rest: Continuous ECG monitoring.
Cardiac Biomarkers: Regular monitoring for troponin levels.
Medications:
Nitrates: For chest pain relief.
Beta-Blockers: To reduce myocardial oxygen demand.
Antiplatelet Agents: Such as aspirin, clopidogrel, or prasugrel to prevent further clot formation.
This approach ensures that NSTEMI is managed effectively without the unnecessary risks associated with fibrinolytic therapy.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient with a history of tuberculosis presents with dyspnea on exertion. On examination, it is noted that the JVP rises during inspiration. A chest radiograph of the patient is given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of a patient with a history of tuberculosis, now showing positive Kussmaul's sign and pericardial calcification on chest radiography, suggests a diagnosis of constrictive pericarditis.

Constrictive pericarditis is a chronic condition that develops as a result of the healing of acute fibrinous pericarditis or the absorption of chronic pericardial effusion. In developing countries, tuberculosis is the most common cause, whereas in developed countries, it often follows viral pericarditis, cardiac surgery, mediastinal radiation, or is associated with autoimmune conditions such as rheumatoid arthritis and systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

The primary abnormality in constrictive pericarditis is the inability of the ventricles to fill properly due to a rigid and thickened pericardium. Unlike cardiac tamponade, where restriction is uniform throughout diastole, in constrictive pericarditis, ventricular filling occurs normally in the early part of diastole but abruptly ceases when the elastic limit of the pericardium is reached.

In the jugular venous pressure (JVP) curve, the Y-descent is prominent in constrictive pericarditis, reflecting the rapid early filling of the ventricles. A sudden cessation of ventricular filling and the resulting increase in pressure is represented as the square root sign on the JVP curve.

questions.text: In an elderly male experiencing recurrent fainting episodes, the electrocardiogram shows P waves at a rate of 75 beats per minute and qRS complexes at a rate of 35 bpm. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient is an elderly male with recurrent fainting (syncope), and ECG shows P waves at 75 bpm but QRS complexes at 35 bpm, indicating a transient or intermittent complete heart block.

  • Stokes-Adams syndrome is a clinical diagnosis characterized by sudden, transient syncope due to intermittent complete heart block or other severe bradyarrhythmias.

  • It typically occurs in the elderly and may be associated with second-degree or complete AV block.

Other options:

  • First-degree AV block: PR interval prolonged, but all impulses conducted; does not cause syncope.

  • Second-degree AV block: Conduction failure of some P waves; may cause symptoms but Stokes-Adams is the clinical manifestation of such high-grade AV blocks.

  • Electrical alternans: Alternating QRS amplitude; usually due to pericardial effusion, not syncope.

Key point:

Recurrent syncope with slow ventricular rate in elderly → Stokes-Adams syndrome, usually due to high-grade AV block.

questions.text: A male patient comes with acute chest pain for the past one hour. ECG shows ST segment elevation in the leads II, III and aVF. What is the most appropriate intervention?
questions.solution:
The patient has acute chest pain and ST-segment elevation in leads II, III, and aVF, which indicates an inferior wall ST-elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI).

  • Most appropriate intervention: Primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI, i.e., angioplasty)

    • Preferred if available within 120 minutes of first medical contact.

    • It restores coronary blood flow and reduces mortality and complications. 

Other options — brief:

  1. Dabigatran: Oral anticoagulant; used for atrial fibrillation or venous thromboembolism, not acute STEMI.

  2. Streptokinase: Thrombolytic therapy; alternative if PCI is not available within the recommended window.

  3. Beta blockers: Can be used as adjunct therapy, but do not restore coronary blood flow acutely.

Key point:

Primary PCI (angioplasty) is the treatment of choice for acute STEMI, especially within the first few hours.

questions.text: A 50 year old man was brought to the emergency with chest discomfort and palpitations on evaluation patient was unconscious, diaphoretic with a pulse of 158bpm BP 80/40mmhg ecg showed narrow complex tachycardia what is the next best step in management
questions.solution:
As the given patient with PSVT is hemodynamically unstable the next line of management would be synchronised cardioversion.

PSVT is a narrow QRS complex tachycardia with sudden onset and termination. They mainly present with dizziness and palpitations.

When the patient is hemodynamically stable:
Carotid sinus massage can be done. It is avoided if carotid bruit is present and if a prior history of stroke is seen
Valsalva maneuver is done if the patient is cooperative
Intravenous adenosine is useful in most cases. However, its usage is contraindicated in patients with prior cardiac transplantation. It.can aggravate bronchospasm and atrial fibrillation, hence, it must be used with great caution in such patients.
Intravenous calcium channel blockers such as verapamil or diltiazem and beta-blockers are helpful but can cause hypotension.

When the patient is hemodynamically unstable, i.e., hypotension with unconsciousness or respiratory distress, QRS-synchronous direct current cardioversion is done.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1895-1898.

choices.text: Echo showing RA RV diastolic collapse during expiration

questions.text: A 45 year old male presented with breathlessness and chest pain following a viral illness. On examination patient had a pulse rate of 110bpm BP of 100/60 on auscultation normal vesicular breath sounds were present with no added sounds which of the following is not seen in this condition.
questions.solution:
• The given image shows water bottle sign seen in massive pericardial effusion following a viral illness.
  • Clinical features include Becks triad that is muffled heart sounds, hypotension, jugular venous distension.
  • Other physical exam findings unique to pericardial effusion include the Ewart sign, characterized by dullness to percussion at the base of the left inferior scapular border, tubular breath sounds, and egophony.
  • Patients with pericardial effusion demonstrate Pulsus paradoxus that is drop in systolic blood pressure of more than 10 mm Hg during inspiration. This drop occurs because the expanding right ventricle collapses the left ventricle, causing the interventricular septum to bow and compress the left heart, leading to decreased filling, reduced stroke volume, and lower systolic blood pressure.
  • Several tests can help evaluate a suspected pericardial effusion. On a chest radiograph The heart may appear boot-shaped in the presence of significant, chronic effusion or a "water bottle sign" may be seen.
  • ECG findings be normal or have non-specific ST-segment changes for small effusions. The ECG may demonstrate electrical alternans for large effusions or tamponade, which is a specific but not sensitive finding.
  • On echocardiogram Right atrial free-wall collapse or inversion during systole, right ventricular free-wall collapse during diastole, increased septal bowing into the left ventricle during inspiration and the right ventricle during exhalation may be seen.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2019-2020.

questions.text: A 60 year old male presents with chest pain, palpitations since the past 1 hour. On evaluation his ECG is as follows. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The given ECG is suggestive on posteroinferior wall MI. It shows ST elevation in inferior leads and ST depression in leads V1 V2 V3.
  • The ECG findings of an acute posterior wall MI include the following:
  • ST segment depression (not elevation) in the septal and anterior precordial leads (V1-V4). This occurs because these ECG leads will see the MI backwards; the leads are placed anteriorly, but the myocardial injury is posterior.
  • A R/S wave ratio greater than 1 in leads V1 or V2.
  • ST elevation in the posterior leads of a posterior ECG (leads V7-V9). Suspicion for a posterior MI must remain high, especially if inferior ST segment elevation is also present.
  • Posterior wall MI is typically caused by occlusion of the circumflex artery or the posterior descending artery, which supplies the posterior aspect of the heart.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2053-2055.

questions.text: Which of the following is a rare cause of bilateral pedal edema
questions.solution:
• Lower extremity edema is the accumulation of fluid in the tissues of the legs, leading to swelling. It can result from various conditions affecting the circulatory, lymphatic, or renal systems.
  • Bilateral pedal edema is usually caused due to fluid retention or decreased serum albumin levels.
  • In Chronic venous insufficiency veins in the legs do not efficiently return blood to the heart, leading to pooling of blood and fluid leakage into surrounding tissues.
  • However, this edema is usually unilateral depending on the limb that is affected.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 275-78.

questions.text: OHA of choice in a diabetic with echo showing reduced ejection fraction
questions.solution:
• Dapagliflozin, which is a sodium-glucose transporter-2 (SGLT-2) inhibitor used for diabetes has been recently approved for use in patients with heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and is the preferred drug in this patients with diabetes and heart failure.
  • Dapagliflozin works by inhibiting the sodium-glucose co-transporter-2 (SGLT-2) in the proximal renal tubules resulting in reduced reabsorption and increased urinary excretion of glucose.
  • Dapagliflozin acts as a diuretic and natriuretic by reducing sodium and volume load, causing intravascular contraction.
Other beneficial effects of dapagliflozin
(1) Blood pressure reduction.
(2) weight loss

Reference: Katzung Basic and Clinical Pharmacology, 14th Edition, Page No 261 ,763.

choices.text: Rare finding in a morphologically, normal heart
Treated with intravenous digoxin to control ventricular rate
Should be treated with cardioversion in all cases
This arrhythmia is seen in holiday heart syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the arrhythmia in the following ECG?
questions.solution:
• The following ECG, is that of atrial fibrillation.
  • Cardioversion, whether electrical or pharmacological, is not always appropriate for every patient with AF.
  • The decision to perform cardioversion depends on several factors, including the duration of the AF episode, the presence of underlying heart disease, the patient's symptoms, and the risk of thromboembolism.
  • In some cases, rate control and anticoagulation may be the preferred treatment
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 1903 , 1907-1908.

questions.text: Which of the following are true about subclinical myocarditis?A.PalpitationsB. Elevated proBNP, TroponinsC. Regional wall motion abnormalities in 2D echoD. ECG suggestive of myocarditisE.Low LVEF on 2D echo
questions.solution:
A patient is diagnosed with possible subclinical acute myocarditis when there is a typical syndrome but without any cardiac symptoms such as palpitations. Biomarkers of cardiac injury are elevated (statement 2), ECG is abnormal (statement 4), and there is a reduced LV ejection fraction (statement 5) and regional wall motion abnormality on 2D echo (statement 3).

Probable acute myocarditis is diagnosed when the aforementioned criteria are accompanied by cardiac symptoms such as palpitations, shortness of breath, and chest pain. When there are signs of pericarditis along with elevated CK-MB or troponins and regional wall motion abnormalities, the term myopericarditis or perimyocarditis is used.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1959,1960 .

questions.text: During which phase of the cardiac cycle is an AR murmur likely to be heard?
questions.solution:
Aortic regurgitation (AR) murmurs are most commonly heard during ventricular diastole. In patients with chronic AR, auscultation reveals a high-pitched, decrescendo diastolic murmur, best heard at the left sternal border in the third intercostal space. In mild AR, the murmur is brief, but as the condition worsens, the murmur lengthens and can eventually become holodiastolic. When AR is caused by primary valvular disease, the murmur is typically louder along the left sternal border. However, if the murmur is more prominent along the right sternal border, it suggests that AR is due to an aneurysmal dilation of the aortic root.

Auscultatory findings in AR are accentuated by maneuvers like handgrip, which increases systemic vascular resistance and left ventricular afterload.

Heart murmurs heard during systole include:
- Aortic and pulmonic stenosis: ejection systolic murmur
- Chronic mitral and tricuspid regurgitation: holosystolic murmur
- Mitral valve prolapse: midsystolic click followed by a late systolic murmur
- Ventricular septal defect: holosystolic murmur

Heart murmurs heard during diastole include:
- Aortic regurgitation: early diastolic, decrescendo murmur
- Mitral stenosis: opening snap followed by a mid-to-late diastolic murmur


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1988 .

questions.text: Identify the given ECG
questions.solution:
The given ECG shows broad QRS tachycardia with changing QRS morphology with every beat. The most likely diagnosis in this case is polymorphic ventricular tachycardia or Torsades de pointes.

The causes of torsades de pointes include congenital long QT syndrome, electrolyte abnormalities (hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, and hypocalcemia), certain drugs, cardiac conditions like myocardial infarction and myocarditis, and endocrine disorders like hypothyroidism and pheochromocytoma.


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1919,1920,1923,1924 .

questions.text:
Order in which the following heart sounds are heard from superior to inferior on the left side chest wall?
A. Pulmonary
B. Aortic
C. Mitral
questions.solution:
The order of heart sounds as they are heard on the left chest wall from superior to inferior is as follows:

1. Pulmonary — second intercostal space

2. Aortic — can be auscultated in the neoaortic area or the Erb‘s point, in the third intercostal space


3. Mitral — fifth intercostal space

The following picture shows the areas of auscultation:

1. Aortic area, second right intercostal space: this area is primarily used for auscultation of the aortic valve. The murmurs heard best here are those of aortic stenosis, aortic regurgitation, and hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

2. Pulmonic area, second left intercostal space: this area is primarily used for the auscultation of the pulmonic valve.


3. Erb‘s point, third left intercostal space: this area lies close to both the semilunar valves.

Pathologies of both aortic and pulmonic valves can be heard at this point. Murmurs in this region are more audible if the patient leans forward.

4. Tricuspid area, fourth left intercostal space: murmurs of tricuspid stenosis and tricuspid regurgitation, and ventricular septal defects are heard in this area.

5. Mitral area, fifth left intercostal space in the midclavicular line: murmurs of mitral stenosis, mitral regurgitation, and mitral valve prolapse are heard here.


Reference: Hutchinson’s Clinical Methods, 24th Edition, Page no 200-202 .

choices.text: Which of the following defects can be seen in this patient?

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with bilateral pitting pedal edema, and abdominal distension. On examination, he had ascites and auscultation revealed an S3. Which of the following defects can be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
• Chronic smoker → predisposed to cor pulmonale / right heart failure.

  • Findings:

    • Bilateral pitting pedal edema

    • Ascites

    • S3 (right ventricular S3 possible in volume overload)

  • These features are classic for right-sided heart failure, which is often associated with tricuspid regurgitation.

  • Other options:

    • Aortic stenosis / Aortic regurgitation → left-sided valvular lesions, cause dyspnea, angina, syncope, pulmonary edema, not isolated ascites/edema.

    • Mitral regurgitation → also a left-sided lesion, causes pulmonary congestion more than peripheral edema/ascites.

questions.text: A patient presents with dyspnea and distended neck veins that increase on inspiration. There is no murmur. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Definition: A condition characterized by thickened, fibrotic, and often calcified pericardium that restricts the diastolic filling of the heart.

Common Causes:
Infectious: Tuberculosis and viral infections (most prevalent in developing countries).
Non-infectious: Cardiac surgery, radiation therapy, connective tissue diseases, uremia, neoplasms, and idiopathic cases.

Clinical Presentation:
Symptoms:
Dyspnea (difficulty breathing)
Orthopnea (shortness of breath when lying flat)
Fatigue
Ascites (fluid accumulation in the abdominal cavity)

Signs:
Kussmaul's sign: Distended neck veins that increase on inspiration, indicating impaired filling of the heart.
Auscultation findings: Distant heart sounds and possibly a pericardial knock at the cardiac apex, which occurs due to the abrupt cessation of ventricular filling.
Summary:
Patients with constrictive pericarditis often present with symptoms indicative of heart failure, and the physical exam reveals characteristic signs like Kussmaul's sign. Recognizing these features can lead to timely diagnosis and management.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs reduce mortality in a patient with heart failure?
questions.solution:
Metoprolol is a beta-blocker that has been shown to reduce mortality in patients with heart failure.

Role of Beta-Blockers in Heart Failure:
Mortality Reduction: Beta-blockers can significantly prolong survival in patients with heart failure.
Symptom Improvement: They help in alleviating symptoms and improving the quality of life.
Arrhythmia Prevention: These medications also play a crucial role in preventing arrhythmias.
Ejection Fraction Improvement: Beta-blockers contribute to improving left ventricular ejection fraction, particularly in chronic heart failure cases.

Classes of Drugs That Reduce Mortality in Heart Failure:
1. ACE Inhibitors: Commonly used to manage heart failure and reduce mortality.
2. Angiotensin Receptor Blockers (ARBs): Serve a similar role to ACE inhibitors.
3. Angiotensin Receptor Neprilysin Inhibitor (ARNI): A newer class that combines the effects of 4. ARBs with neprilysin inhibition.
4. Beta-Blockers: Essential for long-term management and mortality reduction.
5. Mineralocorticoid Receptor Antagonists:
Spironolactone
Eplerenone
6. Hydralazine + Isosorbide Dinitrate: Often used in specific patient populations, particularly those who are African American.
These medications are pivotal in the comprehensive management of heart failure, aimed at improving patient outcomes and reducing mortality.

questions.text: A young male presents with altered sensorium, headache, seizures and blurred vision. On evaluation he had a BP of 220/140mmhg. Which of the following is the drug of choice
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hypertensive emergency / hypertensive crisis i.e BP> 160/110 mmhg with target organ damage. Intravenous labetall is the drug of choice for controlling BP in a hypertensive crisis. It is effective, has a rapid onset of action, and has a good safety profile.
Labetalol is a nonselective ( blocker and vascular a blocker. It should be avoided in patients with asthma and congestive heart failure due to bronchoconstriction. Ref- Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition • Page no: 3335-3338

questions.text: Which of the following disorders has an impaired thermoregulatory mechanism?
questions.solution:
Heat stroke is a severe heat disorder that occurs when the body's thermoregulatory mechanism fails. Heat stroke is likely to occur when the body temperature rises to 106-108 °F (normal 98.6 °F). Common vital sign abnormalities include tachypnea, various tachycardias, hypotension, a widened pulse pressure and absence of sweating.
Signs of heat stroke include : hot, dry skin, dilated pupils, and a rectal temperature > 106°F.
Management Before cooling is initiated, endotracheal intubation and continuous core-temperature monitoring should be considered.
Hypoglycemia is a frequent finding and can be managed by glucose infusion. In case of hypotension Since peripheral vasoconstriction delays heat dissipation, repeated administration of discrete boluses of isotonic crystalloid for hypotension is preferable to the administration of α-adrenergic agonists. Evaporative cooling is frequently the most practical and effective technique. Cool water (15°C [60°F]) is sprayed on the exposed skin while fans direct continuous airflow over the moistened skin. Cold packs applied to the neck, axillae, and groin are useful cooling adjuncts. Immersion cooling in ice-cold water is an alternative option but can induce peripheral vasoconstriction. Other methods are less efficacious and rarely indicated, include IV infusion of cold fluids and cold irrigation of the bladder or gastrointestinal tract. Ref: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition • Page no: 3637

questions.text: Which of the following arteries is being palpated in the given image?
questions.solution: Anterior Tibial Artery is palpated Anteriorly midway between the medial and lateral malleoli, lateral to the EHL tendon, against the lower end of the tibia.Ref- Hutchinson Clinical methods 24th edition Page 24

questions.text: Among troponin, myoglobin, LDH, CK-MB which is the third cardiac marker to rise following a myocardial infarction?
questions.solution: In an acute myocardial infarction Myoglobin is the earliest to rise followed by CK-MB, troponin and then LDH. Ref- Harrison Prinicple of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 2055

questions.text: In which of the following conditions brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) is lower than expected?
questions.solution:
Brain natriuretic peptide (BNP) are stopped in the ventricular myocytes and are released from these cells when there is distension of the respective chambers because of fluid overload. BNP levels are lower than expected in obesity due to increased BNP clearance by adipocytes. Conditions that cause increases in BNP include.
Congestive heart failure (CHF)
Septic shock
Right or Left ventricular dysfunction, without acute CHF
Coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation Acute respiratory distress syndrome
Acute pulmonary embolism
Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease with
cor
pulmonale
Renal failure
Liver cirrhosis
Subarachnoid hemorrhage, ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke
Hyperthyroidism.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition • Page 275, 276, 2124

questions.text: A 65 year old female was brought the emergency room with chest pain, diaphoresis and had hypotension on evaluation with the following ecg. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
"The given ECG is suggestive on posteroinferior wall MI. It shows ST elevation in inferior leads and ST depression in leads V1 V2 V3.
The ECG findings of an acute posterior wall MI include the following:

ST segment depression (not elevation) in the septal and anterior precordial leads (V1-V4). This occurs because these ECG leads will see the MI backwards; the leads are placed anteriorly, but the myocardial injury is posterior.
A R/S wave ratio greater than 1 in leads V1 or V2.
ST elevation in the posterior leads of a posterior ECG (leads V7-V9). Suspicion for a posterior MI must remain high, especially if inferior ST segment elevation is also present.
Posterior wall MI is typically caused by occlusion of the circumflex artery or the posterior descending artery, which supplies the posterior aspect of the heart.
Davidson's Principles and Practice of Medicine, 23rd edition • Page no. 497

choices.text: Below is his ECG. What is the next step in management?

questions.text: 30y old male was brought to the ED . His HR- 200 BP- 70/40. Below is his ECG. What is the next step in management?
questions.solution: ECG shows narrow QRS complexes without P wave suggestive of Paroxysmal Supraventricular tachycardia. As the patient is Hemodynamically unstable next step is DC cardioversion. Below is algorithmic management of Narrow complex tachycardia. Ref - Harrison's principles of internal medicine page 21st edition page no 1899 fig249-6

choices.text: 4th Intercostal space 1cm medial to mid clavicular line

questions.text: What is the landmark for auscultation of Mitral area?
questions.solution: The auscultatory area for Mitral valve corresponds to the apex of the heart at the 5th intercostal space in the midclavicular line. Ref- Macleod clinical examination 14th edition Page 54.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of Beck's triad?
questions.solution: Becks triad - Hypotension + Muffled heart sounds + Elevated JVP ( distended neck veins) with prominent x descent and absent y descent is suggestive of Cardiac Tamponade. Other features- Tachycardia, Pericardial rub, Pulsus Paradoxus. ECG- Reduced voltage+ electrical alterans. ECHO- Swinging heart sign. Ref- Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 2021-2022

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presents to the OPD with bilateral swelling of lower limbs. On examination, there is elevated JVP, hepatomegaly, and ascites. What is your provisional diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with bilateral lower limb edema, elevated jugular venous pressure (JVP), hepatomegaly, and ascites, which are classic signs of right-sided heart failure.

  • These features indicate fluid overload due to impaired cardiac function, leading to systemic venous congestion.

Other options:

  • Hepatic failure: May cause ascites and hepatomegaly but JVP is usually not elevated, and peripheral edema is less pronounced early.

  • Brain injury: Does not cause peripheral edema, hepatomegaly, or ascites.

  • Renal failure: Can cause edema and ascites, but elevated JVP and hepatomegaly are less specific, and history of oliguria or abnormal renal labs would be expected.



Reference :
Current Medical Diagnosis and Treatment - 2019 - Page no. 415

questions.text: A patient presents with a pansystolic murmur and features of carditis. Echocardiography showed mitral regurgitation. Which of the following is the most common manifestation of this condition?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with pansystolic murmur, carditis, and mitral regurgitation, suggesting acute rheumatic fever (ARF).

  • Among the major manifestations of ARF, arthritis (migratory polyarthritis of large joints) is the most common.

Other options:

  • Erythema marginatum: Rare, pink non-pruritic rash.

  • Subcutaneous nodules: Rare, firm, painless nodules over extensor surfaces.

  • Chorea (Sydenham’s chorea): Occurs in some patients, usually later and more in females.





Reference
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition - Page no: 2528

questions.text: Which electrolyte abnormality has to be considered in a patient with the following ECG?
questions.solution:
Torsades de pointes, a polymorphic ventricular tachycardia, is seen on the traditional ECG.
This kind of rhythm is frequently linked to hypokalemia and hypomagnesemia.

Torsades de pointes, or "twisting of the points," is a condition in which the QRS complex appears polymorphic due to its twisting around the baseline. One prominent characteristic is an ECG with prolonged QT interval, which is caused by an uneven cardiac repolarization delay.

Other factors that can result in Torsades de-pointes include:
  • Anti-arrhythmic medications in Classes I and III
  • Bradycardia
  • Acute myocardial infarction or ischemia




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1925.

choices.text: 5 °C, and some spots can be noted over the fundus. CBC showed a leukocyte count of 20,000/ cu mm. Blood has been sent for culture. infective Endocarditis is suspected. How many minor Duke's Criteria are satisfied for the diagnosis?

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presents with a fever. He is an intravenous drug user. On examination, a temperature of 38.5 °C, and some spots can be noted over the fundus. CBC showed a leukocyte count of 20,000/ cu mm. Blood has been sent for culture. infective Endocarditis is suspected. How many minor Duke's Criteria are satisfied for the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Duke’s Minor Criteria present in this patient:

  1. Predisposing factor – IV drug use 

  2. Fever ≥38°C – 38.5°C 

  3. Vascular phenomenon – Roth spots (fundus spots) 

Thus, 3 minor criteria are satisfied.

This aligns with Duke’s criteria for infective endocarditis.


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition 3859-3861

questions.text: A 60-year-old male with an acute ischemic stroke is undergoing thrombolysis with IV alteplase. He currently weighs 80 kg. What is the appropriate dose of alteplase to be given to this patient?
questions.solution:
• IV alteplase (tPA) dosing for acute ischemic stroke: 0.9 mg/kg (maximum 90 mg).

  • Administration: 10% of the total dose is given as an initial IV bolus over 1 minute, and the remaining 90% is infused over 1 hour.

Calculation for this patient:

  • Patient weight = 80 kg

  • Total dose = 0.9 × 80 = 72 mg

  • Initial bolus (10%) = 10% of 72 mg = 7.2 mg, which is rounded to 8 mg for practical administration.

  • Remaining 90% = 64 mg infused over 1 hour.



Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page no 3334-3335,3337-3338

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient came with complaints of breathlessness that worsens on exertion and fatiguability for a few months. She gives a history of radiotherapy for carcinoma breast 6 months back. On examination, bilateral lower limb pitting edema, ascites, hepatomegaly, and Kussmaul's sign were present. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with right-sided heart failure signs: bilateral lower limb edema, ascites, hepatomegaly, and Kussmaul's sign (rise in JVP on inspiration).

  • History of radiotherapy for breast cancer is a known cause of fibrosis of the myocardium, leading to restrictive cardiomyopathy (RCM).

  • In RCM, diastolic dysfunction predominates, while systolic function is usually preserved.

Other options:

  • Dilated cardiomyopathy: Characterized by ventricular dilation and systolic dysfunction; usually presents with both right and left heart failure.

  • Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy: Usually presents with exertional dyspnea, syncope, or sudden death; asymmetric septal hypertrophy is typical.

  • Takotsubo cardiomyopathy: Acute, stress-induced, mainly mimics acute coronary syndrome; usually reversible and primarily affects the left ventricle apex.



Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1791-1792

questions.text: An elderly obese man was brought to casualty with complaints of severe chest pain for the last two hours. He has also had profuse sweating, pain in the left arm, nausea, and one episode of vomiting. On examination, his pulse rate is 58 per minute and blood pressure is 90/60 mm of Hg. ECG was done and it shows the following finding. Cardiac biomarker showed elevated troponin levels. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Elderly obese man with:

    • Severe chest pain

    • Left arm radiation

    • Sweating, nausea, vomiting

    • Bradycardia (HR = 58 bpm)

    • Hypotension (BP = 90/60 mmHg)

These are classic signs of acute myocardial infarction, especially inferior wall MI, which may involve the right ventricle — leading to bradycardia and hypotension due to vagal stimulation and decreased cardiac output.

ECG Findings:

  • ST elevation in leads II, III, and aVF
    → These are inferior leads.

  • Reciprocal ST depression in aVL
    → Supports diagnosis of inferior MI.

    Biomarker:

  • Elevated Troponin confirms myocardial injury.

    Coronary Artery Involved:

  • Most common cause of inferior MI:

    • Right Coronary Artery (RCA) occlusion, particularly the posterior descending artery (PDA) branch.

      Why other options are incorrect:

  • 1. Pericarditis:

    • Diffuse ST elevation (not localized to II, III, aVF)

    • No reciprocal depression

    • Pain is positional and pleuritic (not radiating to arm)

  • 2. Anterior wall MI:

    • ST elevation would be in V1–V4, not II, III, aVF.

  • 4. Posterior wall MI:

    • May show ST depression in V1–V3 and tall R waves.

    • Would not show elevation in inferior leads unless it's a posteroinferior MI, but the leads mentioned here are classic for inferior MI.


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1841-1842

questions.text: What is the diagnosis if the axis is on the mark "?” from the diagram shown below?
questions.solution:
The image displays right axis deviation since the cardiac axis is greater than +100 degrees.

The mean QRS axis, or mean depolarization vector direction, is represented by the cardiac axis. The typical adult QRS axis is oriented to the left and downward, between -30 and +100 degrees.

As can be seen in the figure below, the lead aVF is positioned at +90 degrees. AVF would have the largest R wave amplitude if the cardiac axis was also at +90 degrees, since it would be facing the same direction as the lead aVF.

If the axis of mean is:

* A left axis deviation greater than -30 degrees

* A right axis deviation greater than +100 degrees

* Extreme axis deviation lies between -90 and +180 degrees.

Causes of axis deviation:
Right Axis Deviation (RAD) Left Axis Deviation (LAD)
Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH) Left ventricular hypertrophy (LVH)
Pulmonary embolism Left anterior fascicular block (LAFB)
Chronic lung disease (e.g., COPD) Inferior wall myocardial infarction
Lateral wall myocardial infarction Wolff-Parkinson-White (WPW) – Right-sided pathway
Left posterior fascicular block (LPFB) Aortic stenosis
Normal in children and tall thin adults Hypertension with LV strain
Congenital heart disease (e.g., ASD, TOF) WPW – Left-sided pathway
Sodium channel blocker toxicity Obesity, pregnancy (mechanical shift)


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1676

questions.text: Identify the rhythm in the following ECG rhythm strip.
questions.solution:
In Normal Sinus Rhythm (NSR), the following features are seen on an ECG rhythm strip:

Feature Normal Sinus Rhythm
Rate 60–100 bpm
Rhythm Regular
P wave before each QRS Yes
P wave morphology Uniform, upright in lead II
PR interval Normal (120–200 ms)
QRS complex Narrow (<120 ms)

Other options: 

  • Atrial fibrillation – irregularly irregular rhythm, no distinct P waves, variable ventricular response.

  • AV block – implies conduction delay or block, not a rhythm type.

  • Atrial flutter – "sawtooth" flutter waves, regular atrial activity (~300 bpm), typically with a fixed ventricular conduction (e.g., 2:1 or 4:1).


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1675

questions.text: An intern observed that a patient was unresponsive, and an ECG which was performed urgently showed an arrhythmia as below. DC shock was delivered but the arrhythmia persisted and the patient is still unresponsive. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
• The ECG described shows ventricular fibrillation (VF) – a shockable rhythm and a medical emergency.

  • The patient is unresponsive, and DC shock (defibrillation) was already delivered but VF persists.

  • According to Advanced Cardiac Life Support (ACLS) guidelines, if the first shock fails, you should:

    ACLS algorithm for persistent VF/pulseless VT:

  1. Start CPR immediately (high-quality chest compressions)

  2. Give 1 mg Epinephrine IV every 3–5 minutes (but only after starting CPR)

  3. Continue CPR for 2 minutes, then reassess rhythm and pulse

  4. If VF persists, deliver additional unsynchronized shocks and consider antiarrhythmics (e.g., amiodarone)

    Why not the other options?

  • Synchronized cardioversion – used for hemodynamically unstable but conscious patients with tachyarrhythmias (e.g., SVT, VT with pulse), not VF.

  • Deliver another DC shock – only after 2 minutes of CPR and drug administration.

  • 1 mg epinephrine IV – correct but after initiating CPR.

    Key Point:

CPR is always the first step after failed defibrillation in a pulseless VF patient.



Reference: Millers anesthesia 9th edition page no 2729,2739

questions.text: Tall and tented T waves, wide QRS, and absent P wave are features of:
questions.solution:
ECG features of hyperkalemia (progressive changes):

  • Tall, peaked (tented) T waves – earliest sign

  • Flattened or absent P waves

  • Widened QRS complexes

  • Prolonged PR interval

  • Eventually sine-wave pattern, leading to ventricular fibrillation or asystole if not corrected

    Why the other options are incorrect:

  • 1. Ventricular ectopic
    → Shows wide QRS with abnormal morphology, but P waves are often absent or dissociated, and T waves are not tall/tented.

  • 2. Acute MI
    → May have ST elevation, Q waves, and hyperacute T waves, but these are usually localized, not generalized like in hyperkalemia.

  • 3. Bundle branch block
    → Causes wide QRS, but P waves are present, and T waves vary based on the block type, not typically tented.

    Clinical tip:

In any patient with renal failure or on potassium-sparing drugs (e.g., spironolactone, ACE inhibitors), always check potassium if these ECG changes appear.


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 310-311

choices.text: Confusion and elevated blood urea nitrogen > 7 mmol/L
Systolic BP < 100 mm Hg and Diastolic BP < 60 mm Hg

questions.text: Which of the following does not include a CURB-65 score?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Systolic BP < 100 mm Hg and Diastolic BP < 60 mm Hg

The CURB-65 score is a clinical prediction rule used to assess the severity of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and determine the need for hospitalization. It consists of five criteria, each representing a specific factor associated with increased mortality in CAP.

The components of the CURB-65 score are as follows: (Each has a score of 1)
  1. Confusion (C)
  2. Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) > 7 mmol/L (U)
  3. Respiratory Rate > 30/min (R)
  4. Systolic Blood Pressure ≤ 90 mm Hg or Diastolic Blood Pressure ≤ 60 mm Hg (B)
  5. Age ≥ 65 years (65)
The score ranges from 0 to 5, with higher scores indicating greater severity.

Interpretation of the score:
    • 0 or 1: Low severity, generally suitable for outpatient treatment.
    • 2: Moderate severity, consider the need for hospitalization based on clinical judgment.
    • 3 or more: High severity, strongly consider hospitalization and intensive care admission
 
  • Consider additional factors: While the CURB-65 score provides a useful initial assessment, clinical judgment should also consider other relevant factors, such as comorbidities, functional status, social support, and ability to tolerate oral intake.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1012.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true for obstructive sleep apnea syndrome.
questions.solution:
Obstructive sleep apnea-hypopnea syndrome(OSAHS) occurs in around 1-4% of middle-aged males and is about half as common in women i.e Males are more commonly affected as compared to females.
Other options are correct.
 
  • Definition: OSA is defined on the basis of nocturnal and daytime symptoms as well as sleep study findings. Diagnosis requires the patient to have:
  1. either symptoms of nocturnal breathing disturbances (snoring, snorting, gasping, or breathing pauses during sleep) or daytime sleepiness or fatigue that occurs despite sufficient opportunity to sleep and is unexplained by other medical problems; and
  2. five or more episodes of obstructive apnea or hypopnea per hour of sleep (the apnea-hypopnea index [AHI], calculated as the number of episodes divided by the number of hours of sleep) documented during a sleep study.
  • OSA also may be diagnosed in the absence of symptoms if the AHI is ≥15 episodes/h. Each episode of apnea or hypopnea represents a reduction in breathing for at least 10 s and commonly results in a ≥3% drop in oxygen saturation or a brain cortical arousal.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2205, 2206.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male is found to have chronic, productive cough associated with clubbing. Crackles and wheeze were heard during auscultation. Which investigation will be most helpful in confirming the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. HRCT
 
  • The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Bronchiectasis.
  • HRCT (High-Resolution Computed Tomography): HRCT is the gold standard for diagnosing bronchiectasis, which is a likely cause of chronic productive cough and clubbing

DIAGNOSIS: 
  • The diagnosis usually is based on presentation with a persistent chronic cough and sputum production accompanied by consistent radiographic features. Although chest radiographs lack sensitivity, the presence of “tram tracks” indicating dilated airways is consistent with bronchiectasis.
