  • Chest CT is more specific for bronchiectasis and is the imaging modality of choice for confirming the diagnosis.
  • CT findings include airway dilation (detected as parallel “tram tracks” or as the “signet-ring sign”—a cross-sectional area of the airway with a diameter at least 1.5 times that of the adjacent vessel), lack of bronchial tapering (including the presence of tubular structures within 1 cm from the pleural surface), bronchial wall thickening in dilated airways, inspissated secretions (e.g., the “tree-in-bud” pattern), or cysts emanating from the bronchial wall (especially pronounced in cystic bronchiectasis).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2174.

questions.text: A woman in her 70s had an influenza illness but resisted getting the vaccine. After contracting pneumonia, she passed away within 5 days. What  of the following organisms cause post-influenza pneumonia most frequently?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Staphylococcus aureus
 
  • Following an influenza illness, secondary bacterial pneumonia is a common complication, and Staphylococcus aureus is one of the predominant bacteria associated with this condition. Influenza infection weakens the respiratory tract, making it more susceptible to bacterial invasion. Staphylococcus aureus is a bacterium that can cause severe pneumonia, particularly in individuals with underlying health conditions or weakened immune systems.
  • Legionella pneumophila, a bacterium responsible for Legionnaires' disease, can also cause pneumonia. However, it is not typically associated with post-influenza pneumonia.
  • Measles and cytomegalovirus (CMV) are viral infections that can lead to pneumonia but are not commonly seen as direct complications following influenza.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1011, 1519.

choices.text: Early appearance of honey combing on CT
Males are affected more commonly than female

questions.text: Pick the statement that is correct regarding non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP):
questions.solution:
• NSIP is a form of interstitial lung disease that typically has a better prognosis compared to other types, such as usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP).
  • Early appearance of honeycombing is more characteristic of UIP.
  • Males are not necessarily more commonly affected than females in NSIP, and NSIP is not specifically common in the elderly age group; it can affect a wide age range

Different types of ILD are summarised below: 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2190, 2193, 2194.

questions.text: Choose the pulmonary symptom that is NOT correctly matched with the corresponding non-pulmonary association:
questions.solution:
1. Cyanosis-Anxiety is the wrong match
 
  • Cyanosis is seen in hypoxemic respiratory disorders that result in >5 g of deoxygenated hemoglobin/dL. It is NOT seen in Anxiety or Panic attacks.
 
  • Option 2: Wheezing and rhonchi can occur in CHF with congestion of the bronchial mucosa and sometimes lead to a misdiagnosis (and inappropriate treatment) of asthma or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).
 
  • Option 3: Tachypnea occurs in metabolic acidosis as a compensatory mechanism to promote CO2 washout.
 
  • Option 4: Chest pain is the most common symptom of Acute pericarditis. The pain of acute pericarditis is often severe, retrosternal and/or left precordial, and referred to the neck, arms, or left shoulder.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1937, 2019, 2132, 3115.

choices.text: Diagnosis can be made on the basis of history
CT scan is the investigation of choice
It is a type I hypersensitivity reaction

questions.text: A man who has a history of exposure to pigeon excrement is experiencing bilateral crepitations in the base of the lungs as well as symptoms of pneumonitis. Which statement about this condition is accurate?
questions.solution:
The given case fits the description of Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis. 
Amongst the given options - option (2) is best answer. 

Hypersensitivity Pneumonitis 
 
It is a chronic lung inflammatory illness that affects the alveolar walls and terminal airways in a susceptible host and is brought on by repeated inhalation of a range of organic substances.

Common types and causative agents are: 
1. Farmer's lungs.  --   Moldy hay --- Thermophilic actinomycetes(Putative antigen)
2. Bird Fancier's lungs -- Various birds --- Protein in avian feces (Putative antigen)
3. Cheese Workers' lungs -- Moldy cheese --- Penicillium

Surprisingly, cigarette smoking has been known to decrease its incidence. 

Pathogenesis:
Its both an immune complex­ mediated reaction (Type III) and cell-mediated hypersensitivity (Type IV) reaction.

Clinical Presentation:
It can manifest as acute, subacute, or chronic disease.
  • Acute:  Symptoms including coughing, fever, chills, and dyspnea may appear 6 to 8 hours after antigen exposure. If there is no further exposure to the antigen, the symptoms often go away in a few days.
  • Subacute: The subacute type frequently develops slowly over a few weeks and is characterized by coughing and dyspnea. If left untreated, it can proceed to cyanosis and severe dyspnea, which necessitates hospitalization.
  • Chronic: In its later stages, the chronic type of HP may be clinically indistinguishable from pulmonary fibrosis. Cough, weight loss, lethargy, and a progressive increase in dyspnea are among the symptoms. Physical examination may demonstrate digital clubbing and inspiratory crackles.

Diagnosis:
  • A combination of CT findings, history of exposure, BAL lymphocytosis and histopathology is used to know the likelihood of HSP (Hence, option 1 is incorrect - diagnosis is not based only on clinical history) 
  • CT in particular HRCT Chest is considered the investigation of choice. (option 2)

CT findings:
  • Acute HP appears with diffuse "ground-glass" infiltrates a reticulonodular pattern, or confluent alveolar opacification.
  • In subacute disease, centrilobular nodules and "ground-glass" changes predominate.
  • In chronic HP, changes include emphysema and interstitial fibrosis; honeycombing and subpleural linear opacities are common.


X ray findings:
They are not characteristic and can occur in other diseases as well. (hence, option 3 is incorrect).
They include-
1. B/L lungs have numerous tiny, poorly defined opacities (5 mm), sometimes sparing the apices and bases.
2. Ground-glass opacities, which can be patchy or diffuse.
3. Pattern of fine reticulation.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2160, 2161.

questions.text: How is a tension pneumothorax immediately managed?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Insert needle in 2nd intercostal space
 
  • In the case of a tension pneumothorax, the immediate management involves the insertion of a needle or catheter into the affected side of the chest to relieve the pressure buildup.
  • This procedure, known as needle decompression or needle thoracostomy, is typically performed in the 2nd intercostal space along the midclavicular line. It is done to rapidly release the trapped air and relieve the tension within the pleural space.
  • Once the initial needle decompression is performed, it is typically followed by the placement of a chest tube (tube thoracostomy) in the 5th intercostal space to allow for continued drainage and re-expansion of the lung.



NOTE- Previously, needle insertion was done @2nd ICS but nowadays, maximum literature recommend Needle thoracostomy @ 5th ICS in mid-axillary line through triangle of safety. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2200.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 374.

questions.text: A 5 kilogramme, 65 cm-long baby who is 10 months old has a cough and cold. He was discovered to have a respiratory rate of 48 breaths per minute with no cyanosis, retraction, or grunting. There is no previous history of seizures. Which statement regarding this child is accurate?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: No pneumonia, only cough and cold
 
  • As the child is between 2 and 12 months, the cut-off for tachypnea- which in turn directly means Pneumonia, is 50/min.
  • In this case, the child is not tachypneic and cannot be said to be having Pneumonia.
  • The child also doesn't have any danger signs.



Classification of Fast breathing/ Tachypnea:
  • <2 months: >60 breaths/min
  • 2-11 months: > 50 breaths/min
  • 12-59 months: > 40 breaths/min


Reference: Essential Pediatrics by OP Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 380.

questions.text: A newborn with a displaced mediastinum to the right and an enlarged left upper lung lobe is experiencing respiratory difficulties. Which diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Congenital lobar emphysema
  • Congenital lobar emphysema is a rare congenital condition characterized by overinflation and hyperexpansion of one or more lobes of the lung.
  • It is typically caused by the narrowing or obstruction of the bronchus leading to the affected lobe, resulting in air trapping and overinflation of the lung segment or lobe. This can lead to displacement of the mediastinum towards the opposite side and compression of the unaffected lung.
  • The scenario mentions a displaced mediastinum to the right and an enlarged left upper lung lobe. This finding is consistent with the clinical presentation of congenital lobar emphysema. The respiratory difficulties experienced by the newborn can be attributed to the compression of the unaffected lung and the associated ventilation-perfusion mismatch.
  • While the other conditions listed in the options (Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency, pneumonia, and cystic fibrosis) can also present with respiratory difficulties, the specific features described in the scenario, such as the displaced mediastinum and enlarged left upper lung lobe, are more characteristic of congenital lobar emphysema.






Reference: Demir, Omer Faruk et al. “Congenital lobar emphysema: diagnosis and treatment options.” International journal of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease vol. 14 921-928. 1 May. 2019, doi:10.2147/COPD.S170581. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6507121/

questions.text: Chronic sinusitis, nasopharyngeal ulcers, cavitary lung nodules, and renal failure are all present in a 65-year-old male adult patient. What should the next diagnostic step be?
questions.solution:
This is a classical description of Granulomatosis with Polyangitis a.k.a Wegener's Granulomatosis.
  • cANCA levels are required for diagnosis.
 
  • GPA is characterized by glomerulonephritis and granulomatous vasculitis of the upper and lower respiratory tracts.
 
  • Additionally, disseminated vasculitis in varying degrees that affects both small arteries and veins may manifest.
ANCA Memorizing trick:- 
PCM- p-ANCA- Churg's Strauss, Microscopic polyangitis 
c-ANCA- Wegener's 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2806, 2807.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male patient was seen with a history of back discomfort, which was worse in the morning and was helped by taking a warm bath. What is the most likely next finding in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The clinical scenario in the above question with morning stiffness is character­istic of spondyloarthropathy, like AS.
  • The initial symptom is pain that can be either sharp or dull, insidious in onset, felt deep in the lower lumbar or gluteal region, and accompanied by low-back morning stiffness of up to a few hours’ duration that improves with activity and returns following inactivity.
 
  • Such patients also commonly have  decreased chest wall expansion. 
  • Chest expansion is measured as the difference between maximal inspiration and maximal forced expiration at the levels of either the fourth intercostal space or the xiphisternum, with the patient’s hands resting on or just behind the head. Normal chest expansion is ≥2.5 cm. The value is less than 2.5 cm in SpA.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2793.

questions.text: What causes infertility in Kartagener's syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Sperm motility is said to be lost or reduced in asthenozoospermia.
  • As a primary ciliary condition, Kartagener's syndrome causes aberrant or decreased motility in sperms (Asthenozoospermia).
  • Asthenozoospermia is the cause of infertility in people with Kartagener's syndrome.



Reference: Mishra, Mayank et al. “Kartagener's syndrome: A case series.” Lung India : official organ of Indian Chest Society vol. 29,4 (2012): 366-9. doi:10.4103/0970-2113.102831.URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3519024/

questions.text: The most vital factor in the "Pneumonia Severity Scale" is:
questions.solution:
• Age is one of the most important factors in assessing the risk of fatality among adults from the Pneumonia Severity Index (PSI). It is well established that the older a patient is, the higher the risk of fatality.
 
  • Other important factors assessed by the PSI include the presence of other medical conditions, laboratory findings, and the patient’s vital signs.
 
  • However, age is the most reliable predictor of the potential severity of a pneumonia case, and is therefore the most important factor when assessing risk.

Pneumonia Severity Index (PSI):




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1012.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient reports postural changes along with dyspnea and a productive cough. The patient had smoked for 20 pack-years in the past. Additionally, the patient has a recent history of binge drinking. The chest X-ray is displayed below. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
Clinical features with history of smoking & binge drinking (increases risk of aspiration) and chest X-ray findings showing cavitation & necrosis are suggestive of lung abscess.

Most common cause of primary lung abscess is anaerobes. So, Next step in management is Intravenous clindamycin and fluids.
 
  • Primary lung abscesses is thought to originate when chiefly anaerobic bacteria (as well as microaerophilic streptococci) in the gingival crevices are aspirated into the lung parenchyma in a susceptible host.
  • Thus, patients who develop primary lung abscesses usually carry an overwhelming burden of aspirated material or are unable to clear the bacterial load.
  • Pneumonitis develops initially (exacerbated in part by tissue damage caused by gastric acid); then, over a period of 7–14 days, the anaerobic bacteria produce parenchymal necrosis and cavitation whose extent depends on the host–pathogen interaction. Anaerobes are thought to produce more extensive tissue necrosis in polymicrobial infections in which virulence factors of the various bacteria can act synergistically to cause more significant tissue destruction.

For primary lung abscesses, the recommended regimens are:

(1) Clindamycin (600 mg IV three times daily; then, with the disappearance of fever and clinical improvement, 300 mg PO four times daily) or
(2) an IV-administered β-lactam/β- lactamase combination, followed—once the patient’s condition is stable—by orally administered amoxicillin-clavulanate. 

This therapy should be continued until imaging demonstrates that the lung abscess has cleared or regressed to a small scar. Treatment duration may range from 3–4 weeks to as long as 14 weeks



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1020-1022.

choices.text: Signs and symptoms usually subsides within 3-4 weeks of onset
Supportive care is the mainstay of treatment
Steroids have a doubtful role in the management

questions.text: Which of these is false about Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury (TRALI)?
questions.solution:
In TRALI (Transfusion Related Acute Lung Injury), symptoms tend to resolve within 3-4 days from the onset - not 3-4 weeks as given in option 1 - hence it is a false statement. 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 894.

choices.text: Flail chest due to fracture of ribs 5, 6, 7 & 8

questions.text: A 12-year-old boy who was injured in a bike accident is brought to the emergency room complaining of coughing, dyspnea, and chest pain. At the time of evaluation, the patient's blood pressure was 130/80 mm Hg, his heart rate was 88 beats per minute, and his respiration rate was 22 beats per minute. On auscultation, there was less air entry and no breath sounds on one side. An oximeter reading of 98% indicates saturation. Below is an X-ray of the chest. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
In the image above, we can see Hyperlucent left lung field with collapsed lung near the left heart border.

  • Pneumothorax is suspected because the surrounding hemithorax is found to be more translucent than usual with absence of broncho-vascular markings.
  • The central, non deviated location of the trachea is another indication that there is a pneumothorax with collapse.
  • When air leaves from the lung, it collapses. The area between the lung and the chest wall that is external to the lung is then filled with air.
  • The diagnosis is made by physical examination showing an enlarged hemithorax with no breath sounds, hyperresonance to percussion, and shift of the mediastinum to the contralateral side.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2200.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 373, 374.

questions.text: Polysomnography contains all of the following tests except:
questions.solution:
• The PSG monitors many body functions, including ECG, EMG, EOG, EEG. Depending upon the clinical scenario other functions such as sPO2/SaO2, esophageal pH too can be measured. 
  • However, pCO2 measurement would require an invasive ABG (causing pain) resulting in disruption of sleep and is not performed.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2206, 2207.

choices.text: Aspiration of 20-30 mL of contents with pH <2.5 is required
Fungal infection is the most common cause of pneumonia
Posterior segment of the right upper lobe is most commonly affected in the recumbent position
Aspiration is responsible for 5-15% of community acquired pneumonia

questions.text: About aspiration pneumonia, all of the following are true, barring:
questions.solution:
Aspiration pneumonia is an infectious pulmonary condition triggered by entering bacteria-rich oropharyngeal fluids into the lower respiratory tract. The aspirated fluid may contain oropharyngeal secretions, particulate matter, or gastric content.

Most common causative organisms of Aspiration Pneumonia are Oral anaerobes and gram negative enteric bacteria.
 
  • Option 1: Aspiration pneumonia is more likely to occur when pH of the aspirated fluid is less than 2.5 and the volume of aspirate is greater than 0.3 mL/kg of body weight (20-25 mL in adults).
 
  • Option 3: In supine positions, the posterior segments of the right upper lobe and the right apical segment of the lower lobe are the areas most likely affected. In the standing and sitting positions, the basal segments of the lower lobes, particularly of the right lower lobe, are usually affected.
 
  • Option 4: The incidence of aspiration pneumonia among patients with CAP ranges between 5% and 15% in the US, United Kingdom, and Korea.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1010, 1011.
Jordi Almirall et al., Aspiration pneumonia: A renewed perspective and practical approach, Respiratory Medicine, Volume 185, 2021. doi: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.rmed.2021.106485. URL: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S0954611121001918

choices.text: Massive hemoptysis is bleeding >400 ml in 24 hours
CT chest is the next step in management
In an unstable patient, rigid bronchoscopy is done to identify the lesion

questions.text: What statement concerning hemoptysis is false?
questions.solution:
CT chest is the first investigation done that is a false statement for massive hemoptysis.
 
  • "Massive hemoptysis may be characterized as greater than 400 ml blood loss from the lungs in 24 hours (OR) >150 ml at a time.”
  • In 90% of cases, the bronchial circulation is the cause of massive hemoptysis.
  • The following step in the examination of hemoptysis should be a conventional chest radiograph for the majority of individuals.
  • If the cause of bleeding cannot be determined on plain film, a CT of the chest should be acquired. When these examinations are unrevealing, bronchoscopy should be taken into consideration. An 8.5-mm or bigger rigid bronchoscope is required.
  • As most large-volume hemoptysis results from an airway lesion, the location of the bleeding can be determined by either a chest x-ray or bronchoscopy.
  • Next step in management should be to secure the airway followed by identification of bleeding site. 

Approach to the management of Hemoptysis: 





 Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 270, 271.

questions.text: Which drug from the list below can be administered to people with primary pulmonary hypertension?
questions.solution:
Bosentan can be given in patients of primary pulmonary hypertension.

  • Bosentan is a FDA approved non-specific antagonist of endothelin receptors (ERA) of both ET-A & ET-B. 
 
  • ERAs prevent ET-1 from attaching to either endothelin receptor A (ET-A) or receptor B(ET-B). Vasoconstriction is mediated by ET-A receptors on the smooth muscle cells of the pulmonary artery. ET-B receptors are found on endothelial cells in the normal pulmonary vasculature, and they were found to mediate vasodilation by the synthesis of prostacyclin and nitric oxide as well as the clearance of ET-I.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2129.

questions.text: A 36-year-old overweight prominent smoker was snoring and had hypertension. Five apnea/hyperpnea events occurred during each hour of the sleep test. He was prescribed anti-hypertensives and told to give up smoking. What will be in the next line of action?
questions.solution:
The clinical presentation of an obese, hypertensive patient with 5 AHI episodes/hour and snoring episodes is suggestive of Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA).

Management of OSA: 
 
  • A comprehensive approach to the management of OSA is needed to reduce risk factors and comorbidities. The clinician should seek to identify and address lifestyle and behavioral factors as well as comorbidities that may be exacerbating OSA. As appropriate, treatment should aim to reduce weight; optimize sleep duration (7–9 h); regulate sleep schedules (with similar bedtimes and wake times across the week).
 
  • However, CPAP is the treatment of choice. CPAP is the standard medical therapy with the highest level of evidence for efficacy. Delivered through a nasal or nasal-oral mask, CPAP works as a mechanical splint to hold the airway open, thus maintaining airway patency during sleep.
 
  • Upper airway surgery for OSA is less efficacious than CPAP and is mostly reserved for the treatment of patients who snore, have mild OSA, or cannot tolerate CPAP. Uvulopalatopharyngoplasty (removal of the uvula and the margin of the soft palate) is the most commonly performed surgery for OSA


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2208, 2209.

choices.text: Pneumonia affecting medial zone of right middle lobe
Pneumonia affecting superior zone of right lower lobe
Pneumonia of anterior zone of right middle lobe

questions.text: A patient presents with cough and fever. On X-ray examination, a homogenous opacity silhouetting the right heart border with ill-defined lateral margins is seen. What would be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The cardiac silhouette on the right side of the lung with an ill-defined lateral border is indicative of pneumonia affecting the medial zone of the right middle lobe.
  • Cardiac silhouettes are be beneficial in identifying the location of pulmonary abnormalities, since all parts of the cardiac silhouette, including the heart border, ascending and descending aorta, aortic knob, and hemidiaphragm, are located adjacent to a certain area of the lung.


Image showing Pneumonia of Medial part of RML



Reference: Grainger & Alison's Diagnostic Radiology,7th edition, Page no 34.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1010.

questions.text: Which of the following will you hear on auscultation in a patient with post-tuberculosis bronchiectasis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Both early and late inspiratory crackles
 
  • Post-tuberculous bronchiectasis typically only affects one lung and causes coarse, biphasic crackles.
  • It is typical to hear late inspiratory fine crackles in people with CHF, COPD, or pneumonia.
  • As a result of pulmonary edema, bibasilar crepitations are heard (indicative of fluid overload).
  • There is a sound of tubular breathing during a consolidation.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2174.

questions.text: An individual with probable TB has had a pleural tap. All of the following tests should be done on the pleural fluid, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
• The most important diagnostic tests in pleural fluid specimen in a patient with suspected TB are GeneXpert (PCR) and ADA levels.
 
  • Total Protein levels and LDH levels are required to differentiate between Transudative and Exudative effusion according to Light's Criteria. So doing a pleural fluid Albumin level separately will not be very useful. Total protein estimation should be done instead.
 
  • The pleural fluid is an exudate with predominantly small lymphocytes. The diagnosis is established by demonstrating high levels of TB markers in the pleural fluid (adenosine deaminase >40 IU/L or interferon γ >140 pg/mL). CBNAAT or Gene Xpert is the diagnostic investigation of choice in TB pleural effusion. Alternatively, the diagnosis can be established by culture of the pleural fluid, needle biopsy of the pleura, or thoracoscopy.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1368, 2198, 2199.

choices.text: Non-invasive ventilation with continuous positive airway pressure

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman with bronchial asthma who has been previously diagnosed presented to the emergency department of AIIMS complaining of severe dyspnea, diaphoresis, and wheezing. Upon examination, you discover that the patient is aware and has a heart rate of 144 beats per minute, a respiratory rate of 30 breaths per minute, and a blood pressure of 96/64 mm Hg. A blood gas examination of the arterial circulation revealed a pH of 7.3, pO2 of 50 mm Hg, and pCO2 of 70 mm Hg. patient shows no improvement on O2 therapy with nasal prongs. What should be the next line of management ?
questions.solution:
Non-invasive ventilation with continuous positive airway pressure should be followed next in managing Acute exacerbation of Asthma not improving on conventional O2 therapy.
  • The patient here has respiratory acidosis with elevated PaCO2. So, the best management strategy for these patients is assisted ventilation with CPAP to promote CO2 washout and correct acidosis.
  • Endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation are employed when other less invasive maneuvers have failed.
 
  • Noninvasive positive-pressure ventilation to assist with respiratory exhaustion is used to prevent a need for intubation, and helium-oxygen mixtures may be used to decrease the work of breathing.
  • Mechanical ventilation may be difficult in patients with status asthmaticus due to high positive pressures in the setting of high resistance to airflow due to airway obstruction. Most patients with asthma attacks present with hypocapnia due to a high respiratory rate. Normal or near-normal PaCO2 in a patient with asthma in respiratory distress should raise concerns of impending respiratory failure and need for mechanical ventilation.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2158.

choices.text: Before performing the ABG, syringe should be loaded with 0.3 cc of heparin
A different site should be tried if modified Allen’s test is negative

questions.text: You are instructed to conduct an ABG on a patient by a second-year PG resident. All of the following regarding an ABG are true, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Before performing the ABG, syringe should be loaded with 0.3 cc of heparin.
Syringe should be flushed with heparin and not loaded.
 
  • Normal pH, HCO3, and PCO2 levels may not indicate absence of an acid-base imbalance: This statement is true. While normal values of pH, bicarbonate (HCO3), and partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2) may suggest a balanced acid-base state, they do not guarantee the absence of an acid-base imbalance. There are different types of acid-base disorders, such as respiratory acidosis/alkalosis and metabolic acidosis/alkalosis, which can exist even with normal pH, HCO3, and PCO2 values. Additional parameters and the evaluation of compensatory mechanisms are required to make an accurate assessment of acid-base balance.
  • A different site should be tried if modified Allen's test is negative: This statement is true. The modified Allen's test is performed to assess collateral circulation in the hand before arterial puncture. If the modified Allen's test is negative (indicating inadequate collateral circulation), it is recommended to try a different arterial site for blood sampling to avoid potential complications, such as hand ischemia.
  • Radial artery is the preferred site: This statement is true. The radial artery is commonly preferred for arterial blood gas (ABG) sampling due to its accessibility and lower risk of complications compared to other sites. It is easily palpable and provides a relatively comfortable experience for patients.
ABG Steps-
    1. Heparin rinse
    2. Modified Allen’s test performed
    3. Wrist extension
    4. Needle pierced at 45 degrees angle




Reference: Trulock EP III. Arterial Blood Gases. In: Walker HK, Hall WD, Hurst JW, editors. Clinical Methods: The History, Physical, and Laboratory Examinations. 3rd edition. Boston: Butterworths; 1990. Chapter 49. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK371/

WHO Guidelines on Drawing Blood: Best Practices in Phlebotomy. Geneva: World Health Organization; 2010. Annex I, Modified Allen test. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK138652/

questions.text: With pCO2-30, pO2-115, [HCO3-]- 20 and pH-7.45 revealed in an arterial blood gas analysis, the patient is likely dealing with:
questions.solution:
• The pH of 7.45 is at the upper limit of normal signifying a trend toward Alkalosis. 
  • pCO2 is low (less than 35) at 30 - suggesting the cause for Respiratory alkalosis. 
  • Alveolar hyperventilation decreases Paco2 and increases the HCO3−/ Paco2 ratio, thus increasing pH. Non-bicarbonate cellular buffers respond by consuming HCO3−. Hypocapnia develops when a sufficiently strong ventilatory stimulus causes CO2 output in the lungs to exceed its metabolic production by tissues. Plasma pH and [HCO3−] appear to vary proportionately with Paco2 over a range from 40–15 mmHg.

Summary of Acid-Base disorders: 


Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 368.

choices.text: Occurrence in patients with old cavitary lesions

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis?
questions.solution:
Recurrent pneumonia is NOT seen in ABPA
 
  • Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) is a fungal infection of the lung due to a hypersensitivity reaction to antigens of Aspergillus fumigatus after colonization into the airways.
  • Predominantly it affects patients with bronchial asthma and those having cystic fibrosis.
  • It characteristically presents with bronchospasm, pulmonary infiltrates, eosinophilia, and immunologic evidence of allergy to the antigens of Aspergillus species.
  • It does not cause pneumonia.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2165, 2166.

questions.text: For very severe COPD, the following is the GOLD criteria :
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Fev1/Fvc <70 and Fev1 <30 

GOLD Criteria for severity of Airflow obstruction in COPD:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2182.

questions.text: Which conditions may not benefit from oxygen therapy?
questions.solution:
• The interstitial lung diseases (ILDs) are characterised by scarring and fibrosis of lung tissue with varying degrees of hypoxaemia. Common symptoms include severe cough and dyspnea.
  • Despite recent advances in pharmacotherapy, many patients with ILD have limited treatment options.
  • Oxygen therapy is commonly prescribed for people with ILD, with the aim of reducing breathlessness and increasing physical capacity through improved gas exchange. Despite its frequent use there is a lack of evidence supporting the effectiveness of oxygen therapy in ILD.
  • Supplemental oxygen users with pulmonary fibrosis perceive greater dyspnea than oxygen non-users.
  • Many systematic reviews showed no effects of oxygen therapy on dyspnea during exercise in ILD, although exercise capacity was increased.



Reference: Oxygen therapy for interstitial lung disease: a systematic review, Emily C. Bell, Narelle S. Cox, Nicole Goh, Ian Glaspole, Glen P. Westall, Alice Watson, Anne E. Holland, European Respiratory Review Mar 2017, 26 (143) 160080; DOI: 10.1183/16000617.0080-2016. URL: https://err.ersjournals.com/content/26/143/160080

questions.text: A patient is seen with the following values: pH 7.5, pCO2 28mmHg, and 16 meQ/L of HCO3. Which of the subsequent options best sums up the compensating mechanism?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Metabolic Acidosis
 
  • A patient with pH 7.5 with pCO2 of 28 mmHg [Normal: 35-45] suggests that the patient is having Respiratory alkalosis.
 
  • Compensation for the same would be done via Metabolic acidosis (the patient is having low HCO3 16 suggesting metabolic compensation has started).
  • Hence, the Correct answer is option (4) - Metabolic Acidosis.
Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same


Please note - The question is asking about the compensating mechanism - not the primary acid-base abnormality.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text: An anxious 29-year-old woman appears with a four-month history of increasing dyspnea and exercise intolerance. Her FEV1/FVC is 86% and FVC is 90%. DLCO is 50% of expected. After exercise, oxygen saturation was seen to fall from 92% to 86%. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
• Primary pulmonary hypertension is an idiopathic condition wherein a young adult develops sudden progressive dyspnea and exercise intolerance over a few months due to narrowing of Pulmonary arteries resulting in PAH.
  • This is due to a genetic mutation in BMPR 2 gene.
 
  • In PAH, an isolated reduction in diffusing capacity of the lungs for carbon monoxide (DLCO) is a classic finding.

  • The right heart catheterisation (RHC) remains the gold standard test to both establish the diagnosis of PH and guide selection of appropriate medical therapy.

The hemodynamic criteria for diagnosing PH requires:
  1. mPAP >20 mmHg
  2. pulmonary artery wedge pressure (PAWP) (or left ventricular end-diastolic pressure [LVEDP]) ≤15 mmHg or >15 mmHg, respectively
  3. PVR ≥3.0 Wood units (WU)


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2123, 2124.

questions.text: A truck driver reported having a dry cough and fever for the previous four weeks. He also details a prior weight loss of roughly 10 kg. Reticulonodular infiltrates are visible on the X-ray on both sides. The following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Truck driver - Dry cough and persistent fever with H/o significant weight loss suggests immuno deficiency - important to R/o HIV. This is most likely infective then. Out of the other given options, The questions specifically tells Reticulonodular infiltrates on CXR which suggests Pneumocystis carinii Pneumonia (PCP) by ruling out other TB and Pneumococcal Pneumonia.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1566.

choices.text: Start IV fluids after insertion of wide bore IV line

questions.text: A 20 years old boy following an RTA presented with respiratory distress and hypotension. He has subcutaneous emphysema and no air entry on the right side. Choose the next best step in management of this patient:
questions.solution:
The next best step in management should be Needle decompression/ thoracostomy @ 5th ICS through the triangle of safety. Previously it was done @2nd ICS at mid-clavicular line.

Management of spontaneous pneumothorax involves a two-step process:
  1. Emptying the air from the chest cavity: This is accomplished by inserting a large bore needle (usually 16 or 18 gauge) into the 5th intercostal space in the midaxillary line (point above the armpit). The patient will usually be in a sitting position and the needle is attached to a syringe or connected to a sterile drainage system. The needle should be inserted slowly and gently with steady pressure to allow for controlled drainage.
  2. Preventing further air from entering the chest cavity: Once the air has been emptied from the chest cavity, it is important to close off the opening in the chest wall to prevent more air from entering. This can be accomplished with a small steel clamp or a suture. The patient will then be monitored for a few days to ensure the pneumothorax has fully resolved.
Definitive management of Tension Pneumothorax is Tube thoracostomy (ICD insertion) @ 5th ICS in the mid-axillary line through triangle of safety.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 374.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2200.

questions.text: What Child Pugh class should a kid with a serum bilirubin level of 2.5 mg/dL, a S. albumin level below 3, and an INR of 2, no ascites and encephalopathy be placed in?
questions.solution:
The Child Pugh class for a patient with a serum bilirubin of 2.5 mg/dl, serum albumin of less than 3g/dl and an INR of 2, with no Ascites and Encephalopathy is CTP B. This score indicates moderate disease severity with a five-year survival rate of about 55%.

Child-Turcotte-Pugh (CTP) score:



In this question:
 
Parameter Value Score
Sr. Bilirubin (mg/dl) 2.5 2
Sr. Albumin (mg/dl) <3 3
INR 2 2
Ascites None 1
Encephalopathy None 1
TOTAL score= 9

A score of 9 belongs to CTP Class B (7-9)



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2552.

questions.text: A gentleman 24 years of age with h/o of hemophilia and the current bleeding episode was treated with two units of FFP since cryoprecipitate and factor VIII concentrate are unavailable. 2 hours post-transfusion revealed B/L crepitations and Xray chest showed B/L infiltrates. JVP is normal, BP is slightly decreased. What's the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the above scenario - the patient developed new-onset respiratory distress, and B/L Crepitations within 2 hours of FFP transfusion. This is most likely due to TRALI.
 
  • Given that TRALI frequently occurs with plasma components, especially following FFP/Platelets and the JVP is normal with slightly decreased -the diagnosis is likely to be TRALI. (option 1).
  • TRALI usually occurs within six hours after the transfusion and is accompanied by a new ALI (acute lung injury) ± hemodynamic compromise. The management is supportive.
 
  • Since the patient is young, free of cardio-renal disease, and has a normal JVP, and low BP, it is unlikely that they have TACO. In TACO, patients frequently have hypertension and high JVP.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 891, 894.

questions.text: A person admitted to the cardiac failure ward for heart transplant also has a compromised renal function. 6hrs post blood transfusion developed chest tightness, dyspnoea, BP=160/94 mm Hg, and elevated JVP. What is the probable Dx?
questions.solution:
The probable diagnosis in the above scenario is TACO i.e. Transfusion associated Circulatory overload. The respiratory distress, elevated blood pressure, compromised renal function, and elevated JVP point all point towards TACO. 

Transfusion Associated Circulatory Overload(TACO)

Etiopathogenesis
An increase in hydrostatic pressure due to an increase in pulmonary blood volume (due to transfusion) and central venous pressure results in fluid extravasation into the alveolar space leading to pulmonary edema/hypoxia/respiratory distress.

Clinical Features
1. Characterized by respiratory distress, hypoxia, B/L Rales Along with Hypertension/elevated JVP. 
2. Does not have a fever, ejection fraction is reduced, and CXR shows B/L infiltrate. 

Management
1. Supportive
2. Diuretics
 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 891, 895.

questions.text: A 65 year old patient is treated in ICU for Acute exacerbation of COPD. Which of the following is false regarding management?
questions.solution:
Incorrect statement is 1. Non-invasive ventilation is not indicated

Non-invasive mechanical ventilation is preferred for patients with acute respiratory failure, as it improves gas exchange, reduces work of breathing and the need for intubation, and can lower hospitalization duration and improve survival.

  • Systemic corticosteroids (Option 4) have been found to improve lung function and reduce recovery time and duration of hospitalization, but treatments should not exceed 5-7 days.
  • Antibiotics, when indicated, can reduce early relapse, treatment failure and hospitalization duration, but should not exceed 5-7 days.
  • Methylxanthines are not recommended due to potential side effects.
  • Supplemental O2 therapy should be provided enough to maintain a target SpO2 of 88-92%.
  • Short-acting inhaled beta-agonists, often in combination with anticholinergics, are recommended as the initial bronchodilators for treatment of an acute exacerbation of COPD. (Option 3)



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2189.

questions.text: A patient with hypoxemia was brought to the emergency room. It was discovered that the alveolar-arterial gradient (A-a gradient) was normal. Which of the following is the most likely cause
questions.solution:
Alveolar - arterial O2 gradient is the difference in pO2 between alveoli and blood in arteries. 
In hypoventilation, there is no defect in oxygenation of blood. Hence [A -a] gradient remains normal.


Among the given options:
 
  • Option 1: Right to Left Shunt—arterial O2 decreases and gradient increases.
  • Option 3: V/Q mismatch - Here the lung is ventilated properly but is not perfused well. As a result, arterial blood doesn’t get oxygenated properly and hence gradient is increased.
  • Option 4: Hyaline Membrane Disease - The process of diffusion of gases is affected here, so oxygenation of blood doesn’t take place properly and so gradient is increased.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2133, 2136, 2137.

questions.text: A CT chest scan was performed on a 45-year-old patient who had a two-year history of mucopurulent cough. The CT scan is given below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the information given in the question and CT scan finding, most probable diagnosis is Bronchiectasis.

Bronchiectasis is  irreversible dilatation of the bronchial tree.

Signs of Bronchiectasis on CT:
 
  • Tram Track sign: Thickened and parallel walls of cylindrical bronchiectasis
  • Signet ring sign :Dilated bronchus and accompanying pulmonary artery
  • String of pearls sign: Intermittent narrowed and dilated segment to the affected bronchus when viewed in long axis
  • Bunch of grapes sign: Closely apposed dilated bronchi may look like multiple adjacent thin walled cysts which mimic the appearance of a bunch of grapes.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2174, 2175.

questions.text:
When would you accept a COVID-19 patient who is 75 years old to a facility that specialises in COVID care?
a. Presence of chest discomfort
b. SpO2 < 93% in room air
c. RR of 25/min
d. Presence of serious co-morbidities
Options :
questions.solution:
COVID 19 cases are hospitalized only if they fall in the moderate or severe category:

Moderate:
Pneumonia with no sign of severe disease
RR 15 to 30/min, SpO2 90 -94%
Severe :
Respiratory rate > 30min, SpO2 <90% on room air






Reference: CLINICAL GUIDANCE FOR MANAGEMENT OF ADULT COVID-19 PATIENTS, AIIMS/ ICMR-COVID-19 National Task Force/Joint Monitoring Group (Dte.GHS), Ministry of Health & Family Welfare, Government of India (2021 guidelines). URL: https://dghs.gov.in/WriteReadData/Orders/202104231216553337715COVIDManagementAlgorithm_22Apr21.pdf

questions.text: 40-year-old smoker presents with chronic cough, dyspnea, and chest pain for the past two years. His HRCT chest is displayed below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In the given image Water Lily sign is seen. The diagnosis is lung hydatid cyst. Hydatid cysts are caused by the parasite Echinococcus granulosus (EG) possessing cystic lesions. Echinococcal cysts most frequently develop in the liver, then in the lungs.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1793, 1794.

questions.text:
A vaso-reactivity test was negative in a patient with grade II pulmonary artery hypertension.
Which of the following is the best course of treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
• Based on vaso - reactive test., If positive (inhaled Nitric Oxide cause PAH < 10 mm Hg with BP and CO normal), Ca2+ channel blockers are used.
 
  • If negative, endothelin antagonists (Bosentan, Ambrisentan) are preferred. Drugs like prostacyclin analogues and PDE - 5 inhibitors (Sildenafil) are also used in advanced cases.


Treatment strategy overview for patients with newly diagnosed pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH):



Low- or intermediate (Int)-risk patients are initiated on combination oral therapy, which generally includes an endothelin receptor antagonist and phosphodiesterase type 5 inhibitor.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2128.

questions.text: Having a fever and severe abdominal pain for the previous four days, a 35-year-old man arrived at the emergency department. The abdomen's X-ray is shown below. Which diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
The given x ray shows Gas Under Diaphragm. It is seen in the following conditions:

1. Hollow viscous perforation
2. Penetrating injury in abdomen
3. Pneumoperitoneum in laparoscopic surgeries 


The gut wall's integrity is lost in perforated hollow viscus, which leads to enteric contents leaking out. Gastrointestinal wall perforation and full-thickness disruption are caused by direct trauma or tissue ischemia and necrosis.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 137.

questions.text: A patient's ABG reveals pH of 7.12, HCO3 of 28, and PCO2 of 50 mm Hg. What is the patient's acid-base disorder?
questions.solution:
This statement is saying that a pH level of 7.12, which is indicative of acidosis, and a partial carbon dioxide pressure (PCO) of 50 m Hg, which is higher than the normal range from 35 to 45 m Hg, suggests that a patient is experiencing respiratory acidosis. Additionally, this statement is noting that the level of bicarbonate (HCO;) is 28 mmol/L, which is higher than the normal range from 18-24 mmol/L and implies that the kidneys are compensating for this respiratory acidosis by maintaining the level of HCO; so that the patient can maintain an appropriate pH balance. In summary, this statement is saying that the patient is experiencing respiratory acidosis with a renal compensation.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text:
A patient has had a fever, nocturnal cough, shortness of breath, and wheezing for four weeks.
Absolute eosinophil count is greater than 5000. Miliary Pattern is shown on a chest X-ray. What medical diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Tropical Pulmonary Eosinophilia.
 
  • TPE is a hypersensitivity reaction to filarial parasites, Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi, transmitted through mosquito bites causing lymphatic filariasis.
  • Symptoms: Chronic cough, wheezing, and shortness of breath, often exacerbated at night (nocturnal).
  • Peripheral eosinophilia with an absolute eosinophil count > 5000 is a typical finding in TPE.


Other options :
 
  • Bronchial asthma can cause respiratory symptoms but lacks the miliary pattern and marked eosinophilia typical of TPE.
  • Miliary tuberculosis is a consideration but the marked eosinophilia and absence of other typical tuberculosis features make this option less likely.
  • Hypersensitivity pneumonitis can cause eosinophilia but is characterized by inflammation due to allergen exposure and lacks the miliary pattern and marked eosinophilia typical of TPE.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1781.

choices.text: Admit in ICU and a manage without Invasive mechanical ventilation
Admit in ICU and manage with Invasive mechanical ventilation
Consider hospital admission in non ICU setting

questions.text: Male, age 68, coughing and producing sputum. Bronchial breath noises were audible during auscultation. No confusion. BP 110/70mm Hg, RR 20/min, and Urea 44. What action should be taken next?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Consider hospital admission in non ICU setting.

The CURB-65 score is a clinical score that is used to assess the severity of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). The score is based on the following factors:
  • Confusion
  • Urea level (>7 mmol/L)
  • Respiratory rate (>20 breaths/min)
  • Blood pressure (<90 mmHg systolic or <60 mmHg diastolic)
  • Age (>65 years)

 
  • The patient in the question has urea levels >7 mmol/ L and is aged >65. His CURB-65 score is 2, which indicates moderate CAP, therefore the treatment should be admission in a non-ICU setting.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1012.

questions.text: Which are the drugs used in the treatment of severe COVID-19 infection in children?
questions.solution:
Steroids - Steroids should only be used in severe and critically ill COVID-19 cases who are hospitalized and under tight monitoring. Steroids should be given at the proper time, in the proper dose, and for the proper period.
 

  • Moderate COVID: Corticosteroids are not required in all children with moderate illness; they may be administered in rapidly progressive disease 
  • Remdesivir (an emergency use authorization drug) is NOT recommended in children
  • There is lack of sufficient evidence on safety and efficacy with respect to Remdesivir in children below 18 years of age.



Reference: Comprehensive Guidelines  for Management of COVID-19  in CHILDREN and ADOLESCENTS (below 18 years), Directorate General of Health Services,Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, Government of India guidelines (2022). URL: https://dghs.gov.in/WriteReadData/Orders/202201201058557928169DteGHSComprehensiveGuidelinesforManagementofCOVID19inCHILDRENandADOLESCENTS_revised17January22_2021hrs.pdf

questions.text:
A patient has been admitted to the emergency room with a possible acid-base disorder. Which of the following is most likely to help with the diagnosis?
(i) pH of arterial blood
(ii) pH of venous blood
(iii) pO2 of venous blood
(iv) pCO2 of venous blood
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. (i), (ii). Arterial and Venous pH can be used to identify acid-base disorders.

Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis is considered the gold standard for evaluating oxygen and acid-base status. Venous blood gas (VBG) analysis is increasingly being adopted as an alternative to ABG, as the difference in pH between VBG and ABG is clinically insignificant (with arterial pH generally 0.03 higher than venous pH), rendering venous pH values acceptable. 

Other options:  
 
  • Option 3: The pO2 values exhibit a notable difference, as arterial pO2 (normal 95 mmHg) is usually 55 mmHg higher than venous pO2 (normal 40 mmHg), which makes venous pO2 values unacceptable.  
  • Option 4: Venous pCO2 (normal range 41 to 51 mmHg) values show a significant discrepancy from arterial pCO2 (normal range 35 to 45 mmHg), varying by 5 to 15 mmHg, thus rendering venous pCO2 values unacceptable.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 360.

Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology.14th edition, Page no 1085.

choices.text: Start TB treatment first 2 weeks later ART
Start ART first and later merge with ATT

questions.text: A patient tested positive for both tuberculosis and HIV. Which of the following is the next best management step?
questions.solution:
Due to immunological suppression, HIV infection increases the likelihood that a new M. tuberculosis infection will develop into TB illness quickly. Start TB treatment first, followed by ART as soon as possible after starting TB treatment within the first 8 weeks of treatment.
 
  • HIV-positive TB patients with profound immunosuppression (e.g., CD4+ < 50/μl) should receive ART within the first two weeks of initiating TB treatment.
  • Initiation of ART and/or anti-TB therapy may be associated with clinical deterioration due to immune reconstitution inflammatory syndrome (IRIS) reactions which is caused the viral proteins. These are most common in patients initiating both treatments at the same time, may occur as early as 1 week after initiation of ART therapy, and are seen more frequently in patients with advanced HIV disease.
 
  • For these reasons it is recommended that initiation of ART be delayed in antiretroviral-naïve patients with CD4 counts >50 cells/μL until 2–4 weeks following the initiation of treatment for TB.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1546, 1567.

questions.text: A Flow-volume loop is shown in the image below. What kind of obstruction does it represent?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Fixed Central airway obstruction 


FLOW  VOLUME LOOPS:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2135.

choices.text: Percentage of oxygen bound to hemoglobin in venous blood
Central venous oxygen saturation can be used

questions.text: Which of the following statements about mixed venous oxygen saturation is untrue?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Can be measured by pulse oximetry.
 
  • Pulse oximetry is a noninvasive method of measuring oxygen saturation in arterial blood.
  • Mixed venous oxygen saturation (SVO2) cannot be measured by pulse oximetry because it measures oxygen saturation in arterial blood.
  • Mixed venous oxygen saturation ( SvO2 ) is the O2 saturation of blood at the proximal pulmonary artery. It has been a frequently monitored variable in critically ill patients, since it reflects the average O2 saturation of the blood returning from the body to the right heart, weighted by the respective regional blood flows.
  • The measurement of venous O2 saturation can be performed intermittently by co-oximetry of blood sampled from the distal tip of a pulmonary artery catheter (SvO2) or a central venous catheter (SCVO2).
  • Central venous oxygen saturation (ScvO2) can be used as an alternative to assess tissue oxygenation.
  • SvO2 is commonly measured using a Swan-Ganz catheter inserted into the pulmonary artery.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1305-1307.

questions.text: Which of the following bleeding conditions shows an elevated aPTT with a normal PT?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: SLE.
 
  • Systemic Lupus Erythematosus (SLE) is an autoimmune disease that can affect various parts of the body, including the blood.
  • In SLE, the aPTT is often prolonged due to the presence of lupus anticoagulant, which is an antiphospholipid antibody that interferes with the clotting process and leads to a tendency for increased bleeding. 
  • However, the PT remains normal because lupus anticoagulant does not affect the extrinsic pathway, which is measured by PT.

  • Cirrhosis → Prolonged PT and aPTT (due to decreased synthesis of coagulation factors).
  • SVC obstruction → Does not cause aPTT/PT abnormalities; it leads to venous congestion.
  • SLE → Lupus anticoagulant (LA) prolongs aPTT due to interference with phospholipid-dependent coagulation tests. However, paradoxically, LA is associated with thrombosis rather than bleeding.
  • Hypothyroidism → Can cause mildly prolonged aPTT due to decreased factor production, but it is not a primary cause of isolated aPTT prolongation.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 456, 2741, 2749.

questions.text: Which of the given statements is incorrect regarding Assist control ventilation?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Can cause respiratory acidosis.
 
  • Assist control ventilation (ACV) is a mechanical ventilation mode providing a set tidal volume (VT) to the patient.
  • It allows patients to trigger breaths at their own respiratory rate, promoting spontaneous breathing (option 3).
  • This mode ensures the patient receives a minimum VT while allowing them to breathe spontaneously.
  • ACV aims to maintain adequate ventilation and prevent respiratory acidosis (not cause it) by ensuring proper CO2 exhalation and balanced pH. 
  • An increase in tidal volume can help improve ventilation and decrease PCO2 in patients with inadequate alveolar ventilation (option 2).
  • Increasing the FiO2 can help increase the oxygen saturation in the patient's blood (option 4).


Reference: Mora Carpio, Andres L. and Jorge I. Mora. “Assist-Control Ventilation.” StatPearls, StatPearls Publishing, 24 April 2023. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28722886/

Mora Carpio AL, Mora JI. Assist-Control Ventilation. [Updated 2023 Apr 24]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441856/

questions.text: What is correct about a pneumothorax?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Decreased Chest Expansion.
 
  • Pneumothorax is a condition where air accumulates in the pleural space, causing partial or complete collapse of the lung.
  • A characteristic sign of a pneumothorax is decreased chest expansion on the affected side due to the collapsed lung's limited ability to expand during breathing.
  • Other signs include:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2200.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 373, 374.

questions.text: What results in tropical pulmonary eosinophilia?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Occult filariasis.
 
  • TPE is a hypersensitivity reaction to filarial parasites, Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi, transmitted through mosquito bites causing lymphatic filariasis.
  • Symptoms : Chronic cough, wheezing, and shortness of breath, often exacerbated at night (nocturnal).
  • Peripheral eosinophilia with an absolute eosinophil count > 5000 is a typical finding in TPE.
  • Treatment involves using diethylcarbamazine (DEC) to eliminate the microfilariae.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1781.

questions.text: Patients with severe kyphoscoliosis who get abnormal results on their preoperative pulmonary function tests include:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Increased RV/TLC
 
  • Patients with severe kyphoscoliosis often have restrictive lung disease due to the impaired movement of the chest wall and decreased lung expansion.
  • Kyphoscoliosisis a ventilation defect due to Chest wall abnormality. In such cases, RV remains unchanged, whereas TLC is unchanged or slightly reduced leading to an Normal to increased RV/TLC ratio on pulmonary function tests.
  • Rest all other options are false





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2137, 2138.

questions.text: Which of the following tests will confirm the diagnosis in a patient with asthmatic clinical symptoms?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Diurnal variation in PEF > 10 Percent
 
  • Asthma is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by airway inflammation and narrowing, leading to breathing difficulties.
  • Specific finding in asthma: Diurnal variation in PEF >10%, with lower values in the morning due to increased airway inflammation.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2154, 2155.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about chronic bronchitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Predominant symptom is Dyspnea
 
  • Chronic bronchitis is a type of COPD with airway inflammation and narrowing, leading to symptoms like cough, sputum production, dyspnea, wheezing, and chest tightness.
  • The predominant symptom in chronic bronchitis is a productive cough lasting at least three months per year for two consecutive years.
  • "Blue Bloaters" (Option 2) is a term used for chronic bronchitis patients with cyanosis and peripheral edema due to low oxygen levels in the blood. Pink Puffers is referred to patients with Emphysema.
  • DLCO (diffusing capacity of the lung for carbon monoxide) is  NORMAL or reduced in chronic bronchitis due to impaired oxygen transfer. (Option 3)
  • Patients with chronic bronchitis are not typically obese (Option 4); they are more likely to experience weight loss due to their breathing difficulties and reduced appetite. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2133, 2180, 2185.

questions.text: Daytime sleepiness and an apnea-hypopnea index (AHI) greater than ________ are symptoms of Obstructive Sleep Apnea (OSA).
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: >5
 
  • Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) is diagnosed if the patient has either symptoms of nocturnal breathing disturbances or daytime sleepiness, and ≥ 5 episodes of obstructive apnea or hypopnea per hour of sleep.
 
  • This is known as the apnea-hypopnea index, and is calculated as: number of episodes ÷ number of hours of sleep.
 
  • Each such episode should last for at least 10 seconds, resulting in ≥ 3% drop in oxygen saturation or a brain cortical arousal. OSA is diagnosed by overnight polysomnogram (PSG)


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2205.

questions.text: Which of the following is the patient's primary disorder in case of a patient was admitted to the casualty with hysteria and anxiety. Estimation of arterial plasma showed PH of 7.53; HCO3 of 18 meq and PCO2 of 27 mm Hg.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Respiratory alkalosis
 
  • pH of 7.53= Alkalosis (higher than normal range of 7.35 to 7.45).
  • HCO3 of 18 = Alkalosis (higher than normal range of 22 to 26 meq).
  • PCO2 of 27= ↓ CO2 levels in blood  (lower than normal range of 35 to 45 mm Hg).
  • These findings collectively indicate respiratory alkalosis, which is caused by a decrease in the partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2) due to hyperventilation.
  • The patient's hysteria and anxiety likely triggered hyperventilation, leading to respiratory alkalosis.
  • Hyperventilation leads to excessive CO2 elimination, raising the blood pH.


Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text: Which diagnosis is suggested by Bilateral upper lobe bronchiectasis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Cystic Fibrosis
 
  • Bilateral upper lobe bronchiectasis strongly suggests cystic fibrosis.
  • Cystic fibrosis is a genetic disorder affecting the respiratory and digestive systems.
  • The condition leads to the production of thick, sticky mucus to build up in the lungs and other organs. This can lead to infections, inflammation, and damage to the lungs.
  • Bronchiectasis is characterized by permanently widened and thickened airways, making mucus clearance difficult.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2174, 2176.
Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 472.

questions.text: What is Brock's Syndrome ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Middle Lobe Bronchiectasis
 
  • Brock's syndrome, also known as Middle Lobe Syndrome, is a condition that affects the middle lobe of the lungs (other lobes are not affected).
  • It is characterized by the presence of bronchiectasis, which is a permanent dilation of the bronchi. This can lead to recurrent infections, inflammation, and damage to the lungs.
  • Symptoms: Chronic cough, sputum production, and recurrent respiratory infections.



Reference: Kunal, Shekhar et al. “Middle lobe syndrome: an intriguing presentation of tracheobronchial amyloidosis.” BMJ case reports vol. 2017 bcr2017219480. 22 May. 2017, doi:10.1136/bcr-2017-219480. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5753675/

questions.text: What is seen with Bronchiectasis Sicca?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Tuberculosis 
 
  • Bronchiectasis Sicca is a term used to describe a specific type of bronchiectasis that presents with dry, non-productive cough without significant sputum production.
  • The term "sicca" comes from Latin, meaning dry. In this condition, the characteristic bronchial dilation and airway damage are present, but the typical symptom of excessive sputum production is not observed.
  • Kartagener syndrome is a specific type of primary ciliary dyskinesia, which can be associated with bronchiectasis but is not the same as bronchiectasis sicca.



Reference: Butler, Marcus W., and Michael P. Keane. “Bronchitis, Bronchiectasis.” Infectious Diseases(2017): 243–250.e2. doi:10.1016/B978-0-7020-6285-8.00027-7. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7150028/

choices.text: Contralateral mediastinal nodes are a contraindication to surgical resection
Single Agent Chemotherapy is preferred for patients> 70 years with advanced disease
Squamous Cell Carcinoma is the most common NSCCL amongst Asian population
Gefitinib is most effective for female smokers with adenocarcinoma on histology

questions.text: The following descriptions of non-small cell lung cancer (NSCCL) are all accurate, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Gefitinib is most effective for female smokers with adenocarcinoma on histology 
 
  • Gefitinib is an epidermal growth factor receptor (EGFR) tyrosine kinase inhibitor used in the treatment of NSCLC with specific EGFR mutations.
  • It has shown significant efficacy in patients with EGFR mutations, particularly in those with exon 19 deletions or exon 21 L858R mutations.
  • EGFR mutations are more common in Asian populations and in non-smokers or light smokers and have adenocarcinoma histology, but it is not limited to female smokers.
  • Gefitinib is more effective in patients with EGFR mutations, regardless of gender or smoking history.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 595, 600, 606, 607.

questions.text: A patient who was given a bronchiectasis diagnosis five years ago appears with proteinuria and edema on the legs. His kidneys will most likely reveal one of the following:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Amyloid Nephropathy
 
  • Amyloid nephropathy: Kidney damage and dysfunction caused by amyloid protein deposition..
  • It can present with proteinuria and edema due to impaired kidney function and fluid retention.
  • Bronchiectasis is a chronic lung condition, and in some cases, it can be associated with systemic amyloidosis, leading to amyloid deposition in various organs, including the kidneys.
Other options:
  • Minimal change disease (MCD): Glomerulonephritis with minimal glomerular changes, often in young individuals with allergies.
  • Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN): Severe form of glomerulonephritis, leads to rapid kidney failure. Associated with infections, autoimmune diseases, and medications.
  • Crescentic glomerulonephritis: Type of RPGN with crescent-shaped structures in glomeruli, causing kidney damage.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 878, 2345.

questions.text: An elderly patient with long presentation of hypertension attended Emergency department with the complaints of acute onset of breathlessness, anxiety and sweating. It was noticed that the patient was not taking anti-hypertensives regularly. On examination, respiratory rate was 20 breaths/minute. X-ray chest was done as shown below. Next step in managing such a case:
questions.solution:
The given case scenario along with CXR points towards acute cardiogenic pulmonary edema due to hypertension. Hence, the next best step in management will be administration of intravenous nitroglycerin in order to decrease blood pressure. 
  • Common causes include acute severe hypertension, acute myocardial infarction, or exacerbation of chronic heart failure.
  • Precipitating factors may involve medication non-compliance, excessive salt intake, or tachyarrhythmias.
 
  • The condition typically presents with severe dyspnea, pink frothy sputum, diaphoresis, and cyanosis.
  • On auscultation, rales and rhonchi are heard across all lung fields.
  • A chest X-ray reveals increased interstitial markings, vascular redistribution, and alveolar edema in a butterfly pattern, with cardiomegaly potentially present in chronic heart failure cases.
 
  • Management includes diuretics, nitrates, and morphine to reduce preload.
  • Nitroglycerin and isosorbide dinitrate, with their rapid onset of action, can be administered sublingually or intravenously if pulmonary edema persists and hypotension is absent.
  • Oxygen therapy is advised to maintain saturation above 92%.
  • If oxygen saturation remains inadequate, positive-pressure ventilation through a face mask or endotracheal intubation is necessary.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 355, 1930-1936.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is not used for mucociliary clearance?
questions.solution:
Saccharide clearance test, gamma scintigraphy and charcoal test can be used for examination of mucociliary clearance.
 

  • Saccharide test: This test is used to assess mucociliary clearance, as it involves the administration of a saccharide solution and then measuring the time it takes for it to be cleared from the airway.

  • CXR (Chest X-ray): While not the primary method, a chest X-ray may be used to assess for structural abnormalities or conditions that could affect mucociliary clearance (e.g., chronic lung diseases). It is not a direct test for mucociliary clearance but can provide useful context.

  • Scintigraphy: This is a specialized imaging test that is used to directly assess mucociliary clearance. It involves the use of a radioactive tracer that is inhaled and its movement in the airways is tracked over time.

  • Electron microscopy: This technique is used for examining the ultrastructure of cells and tissues at very high magnification but is not used for directly assessing mucociliary clearance. It can be useful in diagnosing conditions like primary ciliary dyskinesia, but it is not a test for mucociliary clearance itself.

Thus, electron microscopy is not used for assessing mucociliary clearance.



Reference: Cumming's Otorhinolaryngology: Head and Neck Surgery, 6th edition, Page no 54, 55.

questions.text:
A 50-year old man who is a chronic smoker has a cough with hemoptysis. He complains of shooting pain in the right arm. The patient is noted to have ptosis. Chest X-Ray findings are as shown. What is the diagnosis?

1. SVC syndrome
2. Pancoast tumor
3. Thyroid cancer
4. Aspergilloma
questions.solution:
A chronic smoker with hemoptysis, ptosis, and unilateral pain in the arm with CXR revealing a right upper lobe mass likely has a Pancoast tumor/ superior sulcus tumor. 
  • The central or endobronchial growth of the tumor is responsible for the cough and hemoptysis and suggests a diagnosis of lung cancer.
  • Superior sulcus tumors represent a distinctive subset of stage III disease. These tumors arise in the apex of the lung and may invade the second and third ribs, the brachial plexus, the subclavian vessels, the stellate ganglion, and adjacent vertebral bodies.
  • They also may be associated with Pancoast syndrome, characterized by pain that may arise in the shoulder or chest wall or radiate to the neck. Pain characteristically radiates to the ulnar surface of the hand.
  • Horner’s syndrome (enophthalmos, ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis) due to invasion of the paravertebral sympathetic chain may be present as well. Patients with these tumors should undergo the same staging procedures as all patients with stage II and III NSCLC.
  • Neoadjuvant chemotherapy or combined chemoradiotherapy followed by surgery is reserved for those without N2 involvement.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 606.

questions.text: 72y old male known case of COPD is brought to the ER with dyspnoea. On examination, Spo2 -80% RA ,Patient has tachypnoea and is using accessory muscles of respiration. He appears confused. What is the most likely acid base abnormality that can be seen in this patient.?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Type II respiratory failure seen in COPD patients.
Type II respiratory failure causes
Respiratory acidosis. Ph <7.35 Pco2 >45.
The Co2 retention in this patient can cause altered sensorium resulting in Metabolic Encephalopathy.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No: 359, 361.

questions.text: 68y old man comes to the OPD with history of fever and cough. On examination -Coarse crepts+. CXR - B/L infiltrates. Which scoring system will you use to manage this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history is suggestive of Community Acquired Pneumonia.
Scoring system used in Pneumonia is CURB -65 -
  • Confusion Urea >17mg/dl
  • Respiratory rate >30
  • SBP <90 or DBP<60
  • Age >65
0-Outpatient treatment 1or 2- In patient and non ICU >2 - ICU admission.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No: 1012, 1014.

questions.text: The triad of Situs inversus totalis, chronic sinusitis and bronchiectasis indicates the diagnosis of?
questions.solution:
Kartagener syndrome is a primary ciliary dyskinesia (PCD) subtype characterized by the classic triad:

  • Situs inversus totalis → mirror-image reversal of thoracic and abdominal organs

  • Chronic sinusitis → due to impaired mucociliary clearance

  • Bronchiectasis → recurrent respiratory infections leading to permanent airway dilation

Key points:

  • Genetics: Usually autosomal recessive

  • Pathophysiology: Defective dynein arms in cilia, causing impaired motility

  • Other syndromes:

    • Cystic fibrosis: Thick mucus secretions, chronic lung infections, pancreatic insufficiency, but not associated with situs inversus

    • Young syndrome: Obstructive azoospermia with bronchiectasis

    • Churg-Strauss syndrome: Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis

questions.text: A patient presents to the outpatient department (OPD) with wheezing and shortness of bread On examsination she is found to have low forced expiratory volume in 1 second (FEVT) and low FEVI FVC ratio. Patients with which of the following other conditions present similarly?
questions.solution:
The patient shows:

  • Wheezing, shortness of breath

  • Low FEV and low FEV/FVC ratio → indicates obstructive pattern

Reasoning:

  1. Obstructive lung diseases → FEV ↓, FEV/FVC ↓

    • Examples: Asthma, COPD, bronchiectasis

  2. Restrictive lung diseases (ILD, IPF, silicosis) → FEV ↓ but FEV/FVC ratio normal or increased

  • Interstitial Lung Disease: Restrictive → FEV/FVC normal or ↑

  • Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis: Restrictive → FEV/FVC normal or ↑

  • Silicosis: Restrictive → FEV/FVC normal or ↑

  • Asthma: Obstructive → FEV ↓, FEV/FVC ↓

questions.text: A male patient, a chronic smoker, presents with persistent productive cough, yellow in color and clubbing. On examination, his cough increases with postural changes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• worsening with postural changes.

  • These features are classic for bronchiectasis, a chronic condition characterized by permanent dilation of bronchi due to repeated infections or airway damage.

  • Postural cough increase (postural drainage) occurs because secretions accumulate in dilated bronchi and are mobilized with position changes.

Other options — 

  • Pneumonia: Usually acute, with fever, chills, pleuritic pain, not chronic productive cough or clubbing.

  • Lung carcinoma: May present with chronic cough, hemoptysis, weight loss, but productive cough with postural variation is unusual; clubbing can occur but less commonly.

  • Asthma: Characterized by episodic wheezing, dyspnea, and cough, usually non-productive; clubbing is rare.

questions.text: A patient with a known history of lung cancer presents with darkening of the creases in their palms and soles. Which of the following hormones might be the underlying cause of this condition?
questions.solution:
• The patient has hyperpigmentation of palmar and plantar creases in the context of lung cancer, which suggests a paraneoplastic endocrine effect.

  • Mechanism: Some tumors, especially small cell lung carcinoma, can produce adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) or pro-opiomelanocortin (POMC) derivatives, leading to excess melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH) activity.

  • MSH stimulates melanocytes to produce melanin, resulting in diffuse or localized hyperpigmentation.

  • Other options:

    • Melanin: Pigment itself, not a hormone; cannot cause new pigmentation.

    • Neuropeptide Y: Regulates appetite and cardiovascular function; not related to pigmentation.

    • C-peptide: Byproduct of insulin synthesis; unrelated to skin pigmentation.

questions.text: A 60-year-old bedridden patient develops acute onset dyspnea and chest pain. A CT pulmonary angiography was done. Which of the following investigations is considered the investigation of choice in this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
The patient is bedridden, with acute dyspnea and chest pain, raising suspicion for pulmonary embolism (PE).

  • CT pulmonary angiography (CTPA): Already done; it confirms PE.

  • To identify the source of thrombus, the investigation of choice is duplex ultrasound of the lower limbs.
