    • Detects deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which is the most common source of emboli causing PE. 

Other options — brief:

  1. Echocardiography: Can detect right heart strain or intracardiac thrombus; supportive but not primary for DVT detection.

  2. MR Angiogram: Rarely used; more expensive and less accessible.

  3. Coagulogram: Evaluates coagulation status but does not localize thrombus.

Key point:

In a patient with PE, duplex ultrasound of the lower limbs is the investigation of choice to identify the thrombus source.

questions.text: A patient in suspected to have transudative type of pleural effusion. Which of the following plestral Rant fiendings would not be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient is diagnosed with a transudative pleural effusion. High fibrin levels in pleural fluid are typically associated with exudative pleural effusions, not transudative ones. Fibrin is a protein involved in the clotting process, and elevated fibrin levels indicate increased vascular permeability and protein leakage into the pleural space, signaling an exudative process.

To differentiate between transudative and exudative pleural effusions, Light's criteria can be utilized. Exudative effusions will meet at least one of the following criteria:

Pleural fluid protein/serum protein ratio > 0.5
Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH ratio > 0.6
Pleural fluid LDH levels exceeding two-thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum LDH.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male is admitted to the hospital with complains of fever and cough since 4 days. He is oriented to time, place, and person. His respiratory rate is 35/min, BP is 130/90 and serum urea is found to be within normal limits. What is the CURB-65 score in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient, likely diagnosed with pneumonia, has a CURB-65 score of 1 (due to a respiratory rate greater than 30 breaths per minute). The recommended management for this patient is with a respiratory fluoroquinolone, such as moxifloxacin, in the inpatient non-ICU setting.

The CURB-65 criteria help evaluate pneumonia severity, consisting of five variables, each worth one point:

Confusion
Blood Urea Nitrogen (BUN) > 7 mmol/L
Respiratory rate ? 30/min
Systolic blood pressure ? 90 mmHg or diastolic ? 60 mmHg
Age ? 65 years
Management based on CURB-65 scores:

0 points: Treat as an outpatient
1 to 2 points: Admit to the hospital (non-ICU)
? 3 points: Consider ICU admission

questions.text: A woman underwent surgery for a fracture of the femur shaft. She has been on a cast for a month. Since yesterday, she developed sudden onset of breathlessness and chest pain. Her chest examination is normal. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has risk factors for venous thromboembolism (VTE):

  • Recent femur fracture surgery

  • Immobilization in a cast

She presents with sudden onset breathlessness and chest pain, which are classic features of pulmonary thromboembolism (PTE).

  • Chest examination may be normal, especially in small or moderate emboli.

Other options — brief:
2. Deep venous thrombosis (DVT): May be asymptomatic or present with leg swelling, pain, and redness; does not cause sudden breathlessness unless embolized.
3. Pneumothorax: Usually presents with decreased breath sounds and hyperresonance on examination.
4. Pneumonitis: Develops gradually, not sudden; associated with cough, fever, and crepitations.

Key point:

Sudden respiratory symptoms after lower limb immobilization → Pulmonary thromboembolism is the most probable diagnosis.

questions.text: A woman with mitral stenosis experiences sudden-onset respiratory difficulty, limb oedema, and abdominal distension. What is the likely clinical diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A patient with mitral stenosis develops sudden respiratory difficulty, limb edema, and abdominal distension, which are classic features of acute pulmonary edema due to left atrial pressure overload.

Key points:

  • Mitral stenosis:

    • Obstructs blood flow from the left atrium to the left ventricle.

    • Leads to elevated left atrial pressure, pulmonary venous congestion, and eventually pulmonary edema.

  • Symptoms of pulmonary edema:

    • Dyspnea, orthopnea, paroxysmal nocturnal dyspnea

    • Peripheral edema, ascites (in severe cases)

  • Other options:

    • Pulmonary embolism: Sudden dyspnea, pleuritic pain, but limb edema and ascites are uncommon.

    • Cerebral embolism: Neurological deficits, not respiratory distress.

    • Paradoxical embolism: Usually leads to stroke or systemic embolism, not pulmonary edema.

choices.text: Apnea is due to fall in O2

questions.text: 40y old male came with history of increased day time sleepiness associated with repeated awakening from night at sleeping associated with snoring. All the following are true except?
questions.solution:
• The given history is suggestive of Obstructive Sleep Apnoea.
  • Pharygeal muscles tone decreases during sleeping thus causing partial obstruction.
  • All the other statements are correct with respect to Obstruvtive sleep Apnoea syndrome.





Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2203-2206.

questions.text: A female presented with excessive daytime sleepiness and impaired concentration and memory for one year. On examination, the BMI was 43 kg/m2 and BP was 170/98 mmHg. ABG was done in awake state and the findings are given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?PaO.: 70 mmHgPaCO,: 53 mmHgHCO3: 33 mmHg
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of an obese patient experiencing daytime sleepiness and hypercapnia on arterial blood gas (ABG) suggests obesity hypoventilation syndrome (OHS). OHS arises due to factors such as increased work of breathing, respiratory muscle impairment due to the added load, and a decreased central ventilatory response to hypoxemia and hypercapnia. The diagnosis of OHS requires the following criteria:

- A BMI of ? 30 kg/m2
- A PaCO2 of ? 45 mmHg, indicating daytime alveolar hypoventilation
- Evidence of sleep-disordered breathing, often due to obstructive sleep apnea (OSA)

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) (option A) is diagnosed if the patient exhibits either symptoms of nocturnal breathing disturbances or daytime sleepiness, with 5 or more episodes of obstructive apnea or hypopnea per hour of sleep. Each episode should last at least 10 seconds, leading to a >3% drop in oxygen saturation or brain cortical arousal. OSA is diagnosed using an overnight polysomnogram (PSG), which measures breathing, oxygenation, body position, cardiac rhythm, sleep stages, and snoring intensity. The presence of waking hypoxemia or hypercarbia in a patient with OSA indicates the possibility of underlying cardiopulmonary disease or OHS.

Central sleep apnea (CSA) (option D) is caused by an increased sensitivity to PCO2, resulting in an unstable breathing pattern characterized by periods of hyperventilation alternating with apnea. A prolonged circulation delay between the pulmonary capillaries and carotid chemoreceptors also contributes to CSA, often seen in patients with heart failure. These patients may present with Cheyne-Stokes breathing.

Narcolepsy (option C) presents with difficulty in maintaining wakefulness and disrupted nocturnal sleep. However, unlike sleep apnea, patients with narcolepsy typically feel well-rested upon awakening but become tired throughout the day. A distinguishing feature of narcolepsy is cataplexy—sudden muscle weakness without loss of consciousness, usually triggered by strong emotions.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 209,2203-2206 .

questions.text: A chronic cigarette smoker now joined a construction company. His pulmonary function test results are given below. What is the most likely diagnosis for this patient?Initial lung volumes were:FEV1 – 0.9LFVC – 1.9LFEV1/FVC – 0.4After bronchodilation:FEV1 – 1.9LFVC – 3.9LFEV1/FVC – 0.4
questions.solution:
In the provided clinical scenario, the FEV1/FVC ratio is less than 0.7, indicating an obstructive lung disease. After bronchodilator administration, the FEV1 increased from 0.9 L to 1.9 L, an improvement of more than 12%, suggesting reversibility. Therefore, the most likely diagnosis is an obstructive pulmonary disease with bronchodilator reversibility.

In obstructive pulmonary diseases, the FEV1/FVC ratio is reduced to less than 0.7, and the FEV1 is also reduced to less than 80% of the predicted value. Reversibility is defined as an increase in FEV1 of at least 12% and an absolute increase of 200 mL, measured at least 15 minutes after administering a ?2-agonist. Examples of obstructive pulmonary diseases include COPD, asthma, and bronchiectasis.

In contrast, restrictive pulmonary diseases present with a normal or increased FEV1/FVC ratio (greater than 0.7) and reductions in both FEV1 and FVC. Examples of restrictive pulmonary diseases include asbestosis, sarcoidosis, and idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis.


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2131,2132,2154,2182 .

questions.text: A patient in emergency has the following lab parameters: creatinine 1.5 and BUN 45. The chest x-ray is shown below. In gram staining and culture, only rhinovirus was Isolated. The patient is shifted to ICU. What is the treatment of choice in this patient?
questions.solution:
The chest radiograph is suggestive of pneumonia. Since this patient requires treatment in an ICU setting, the drugs of choice would be ceftriaxone plus azithromycin.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1012-1014.

questions.text: Which of the following is a cause of exudative pleural effusion?
questions.solution:
Rheumatoid arthritis is indeed a cause of exudative pleural effusion.

Pleural Effusion
Pleural effusion is the pathological accumulation of fluid in the pleural space, which can occur due to two main mechanisms:

Excess Fluid Formation: This can arise from interstitial lung fluid, fluid from the parietal pleura, or the peritoneal cavity.
Decreased Fluid Removal: This happens when lymphatics fail to adequately drain the fluid.

Differentiating Between Transudative and Exudative Pleural Effusions
Light's criteria are used to differentiate between transudative and exudative pleural effusions. For a pleural effusion to be classified as exudative, it must meet at least one of the following criteria:

1. Pleural Fluid Protein / Serum Protein > 0.5
2. Pleural Fluid LDH / Serum LDH > 0.6
3. Pleural Fluid LDH is more than two-thirds of the upper limit of normal for serum.
Clinical Implications
Exudative pleural effusions are often associated with inflammatory processes, infections, malignancies, or autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis. Identifying the type of pleural effusion can guide further diagnostic and therapeutic interventions.

questions.text: Hamman sign is seen in:
questions.solution:
Hamman's sign can be elicited in cases of pneumomediastinum. This sign is characterized by a crunching or clicking sound that is synchronous with the heartbeat, best heard when the patient is in the left lateral decubitus position.

Pneumomediastinum refers to the presence of air or gas in the mediastinum, often resulting from:

Alveolar rupture or perforation.
Rupture of the esophagus, trachea, or bronchi.
Air dissection from the neck or abdomen into the mediastinum.
Clinical Features:
Substernal chest pain that can radiate to the neck and arms.
Subcutaneous emphysema over the suprasternal notch.
Hamman's sign: A key finding in which a crunching sound is heard on auscultation.



Diagnostic and Management Approach:
Chest X-ray confirms the diagnosis of pneumomediastinum.
Treatment:
Generally, no specific treatment is required, as the air is usually reabsorbed.
High-concentration oxygen can speed up the absorption of mediastinal air.
If mediastinal structures are compressed, needle aspiration may be performed.

questions.text: Ground-glass appearance on HRCT is seen in which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Silicosis, when assessed with HRCT, typically demonstrates a ground-glass appearance.

This condition arises from the inhalation of crystalline silicon dioxide (silica), commonly seen in workers involved in sandblasting or rock mining. Upon inhalation, macrophages phagocytose the silica particles, leading to the activation and release of inflammatory mediators such as IL-1 and IL-8, which subsequently recruit fibroblasts.

Microscopic examination reveals coalescent nodules composed of whorled collagen fibers, encircled by a peripheral zone of silica-laden macrophages. The HRCT findings may also include a characteristic "crazy paving" pattern, which is attributed to interlobular septal thickening alongside a background of ground-glass opacity.

choices.text: 8mg%, and a positive HIV test. Which of the following organisms is responsible?

questions.text: A 70-year-old patient with a history of smoking presents with high-grade fever, cough, confusion, and diarrhea. Chest X-ray shows bilateral infiltrates in bilateral lower lung fields. On sputum gram stain, no organisms were detected. Laboratory results reveal Na: 126mEq/L, AST:62, ALT:56, RBS: 112 mg/dl, serum bilirubin of 0.8mg%, and a positive HIV test. Which of the following organisms is responsible?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario described, involving a patient with HIV infection, hyponatremia, and a negative sputum gram stain, is suggestive of Legionnaire's disease, which is caused by Legionella pneumophila.

This bacterium is typically found in lakes, streams, and various water bodies. Infection primarily occurs through the inhalation of aerosols generated by contaminated sources such as air conditioners, humidifiers, and nebulizers.

Certain risk factors can increase the severity of the infection, including smoking, advanced age, and immunosuppression, as seen in this patient. The disease may manifest as a severe, rapidly progressing illness characterized by high fever, chills, hypoxia, diarrhea, and delirium. Chest X-rays commonly reveal patchy, often multilobar consolidation, and pleural effusion may also be present. Initial laboratory findings can include leukocytosis or leukopenia, thrombocytopenia, hyponatremia, elevated liver enzymes, and renal dysfunction.

A milder clinical syndrome known as Pontiac fever can occur, which is generally self-limiting and presents with mild symptoms such as fever, myalgia, and headache.

Microscopic examination of sputum samples typically shows numerous leukocytes without any identifiable organisms. Gram staining of sterile sites, such as pleural fluid and lung tissue, may reveal faint gram-negative bacilli; these bacteria require a counterstain of basic fuchsin, as safranin stains them poorly. Legionella are a group of fastidious, aerobic gram-negative bacteria that can be cultured on buffered charcoal yeast extract (BCYE) agar.

Diagnosis can be confirmed using direct fluorescent antibody tests and BCYE culture specimens. Additionally, urine antigen tests and molecular assays may also be employed.

The preferred antibiotics for treatment are macrolides and quinolones, which are effective as monotherapy. Alternatively, doxycycline may also be used. However, beta-lactams, monobactams, and aminoglycosides are not considered effective against this organism. The recommended duration of therapy is 10-14 days for immunocompetent hosts and up to 3 weeks for immunosuppressed patients.

questions.text: A 5-year-old child presented with recurrent respiratory infections with thickened sputum. Chest X-ray showed bronchial wall thickening. He has been suffering from steatorrhea since birth. Which of the following is the first differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 5-year-old child with:

  • Recurrent respiratory infections + thick sputum → due to inspissated secretions and chronic infections.

  • Bronchial wall thickening on X-ray → suggests bronchiectasis.

  • Steatorrhea since birth → due to exocrine pancreatic insufficiency.

This classic triad points to Cystic Fibrosis, an autosomal recessive disorder (CFTR gene mutation, chromosome 7).

Cystic Fibrosis – Summary

Genetics

  • Autosomal recessive

  • CFTR mutation (Chromosome 7), most common = ΔF508

  • Defective chloride channel → thick secretions

Clinical Features

  • Respiratory: recurrent infections (Staph, Pseudomonas), bronchiectasis, nasal polyps, clubbing

  • Gastrointestinal: pancreatic insufficiency, steatorrhea, malabsorption, meconium ileus (newborn)

  • Hepatic: biliary cirrhosis, portal hypertension

  • Reproductive: male infertility (absent vas deferens), female subfertility

  • Electrolytes: hyponatremia, hypochloremic metabolic alkalosis



Why not the others?

  • Hyaline membrane disease → occurs in preterm neonates, not in a 5-year-old.

  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency → causes early emphysema and liver disease, not steatorrhea since birth.

  • Malabsorption syndrome → explains steatorrhea, but does not explain recurrent respiratory infections with thick sputum.

choices.text: Negative skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray
Positive skin tuberculin test and positive chest X-ray
Positive skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray
Negative skin tuberculin test and negative chest X-ray

questions.text: A 65-year-old male presented with unexplained fever and prolonged respiratory distress despite appropriate treatment. A diagnosis of cryptic tuberculosis was made. Which of the following is the correct statement related to this condition?
questions.solution:
The accurate statement regarding cryptic tuberculosis is that it is characterized by a negative skin tuberculin test and a negative chest X-ray.

Overview of Cryptic Tuberculosis:
Cryptic disseminated tuberculosis pertains to patients with disseminated TB who exhibit less typical abnormalities on chest radiographs, which may include normal findings or non-miliary patterns. This form of tuberculosis has an insidious onset, primarily affecting middle-aged and elderly individuals. Key features include:

Absence of localizing signs: Patients often do not present with specific symptoms that indicate a particular site of infection.
Lack of choroidal tubercles: There are typically no ocular manifestations of tuberculosis.
Normal chest X-rays: This can lead to challenges in diagnosis, as conventional imaging may not show the expected abnormalities.
Negative tuberculin skin test: The test frequently yields false negatives in these cases, complicating the diagnostic process.

Influence of Underlying Conditions:
The presence of underlying health issues such as HIV infection, chronic renal disease, diabetes, immunosuppression, and endocrine disorders can modify the typical presentation of tuberculosis. This variation often results in delayed diagnoses or overlooked cases of cryptic tuberculosis. Hence, maintaining a high level of clinical suspicion and conducting thorough evaluations is crucial for at-risk populations.

questions.text: An elderly male on bed rest for many months presented with breathlessness and chest pain. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is indicative of acute pulmonary embolism (PE), most likely stemming from deep vein thrombosis (DVT). The patient's immobility significantly increases the risk of developing DVT, which can subsequently lead to PE. The principal imaging test for diagnosis is a pulmonary angiogram.

Clinical Presentation:
Patients typically present with:
Sudden onset of dyspnea
Syncope
Chest pain
Hypotension

Investigations:
1. CT of the Chest with Intravenous Contrast (CT Pulmonary Angiogram): This is the primary imaging modality for diagnosing PE. It not only visualizes the pulmonary arteries but also assesses the heart's chambers and helps identify alternative diagnoses such as emphysema, pulmonary fibrosis, or pulmonary masses.

2.Lung Scanning: This serves as a second-line diagnostic test for patients who cannot tolerate intravenous contrast. A perfusion scan defect indicates absent or reduced blood flow.

3. Electrocardiogram (ECG): In acute PE, ECG changes may reveal the classic S1Q3T3 pattern, suggestive of right ventricular strain and ischemia, characterized by:
A prominent S wave in lead I
A Q wave in lead III
An inverted T wave in lead III
While this sign is specific, it is not sensitive for diagnosing PE.

4. Echocardiography: This imaging tool is generally not reliable for diagnosing PE, as many patients present with normal echocardiograms. However, echocardiography can help detect other conditions that may mimic PE, such as acute myocardial infarction, pericardial tamponade, and aortic dissection. One indirect finding on echocardiography is McConnell's sign, which refers to the hypokinesis of the right ventricular free wall while the right ventricular apex maintains hyperkinetic or normal motion.

Treatment:
The management of acute PE primarily involves anticoagulation therapy, which may include:

Parenteral anticoagulants: Unfractionated heparin, low molecular weight heparin, or fondaparinux, often used with bridging to warfarin.
Transitioning to oral anticoagulants: Direct thrombin inhibitors such as dabigatran or anti-Xa agents like rivaroxaban or apixaban, followed by maintenance therapy.
Timely diagnosis and appropriate management are crucial for improving patient outcomes in cases of acute pulmonary embolism.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of smoking a pack of cigarettes for the past 15 years presents with hemoptysis. Chest X-ray shows a 3cm upper lobe mass near the apex of the lung, What is the next best step for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
• This patient is a chronic smoker with hemoptysis and an apical lung mass → highly suspicious for lung cancer.

  • The next best step depends on the location of the lesion:

    • Central lesion (near hilum/large bronchi): Bronchoscopy with biopsy is preferred.

    • Peripheral lesion (outer lung fields, including apical/upper lobe mass): CT-guided percutaneous biopsy is the investigation of choice.

  • Other options:

    • Sputum cytology → may detect central squamous cell carcinoma but has low sensitivity.

    • Sputum for AFB → indicated if tuberculosis is suspected, but here smoking + apical mass strongly suggest malignancy.

    • Bronchoscopy → less useful for peripheral/apical lesions.

choices.text: Supplemental oxygen is indicated in patients with resting 02 saturation of ?90 or ?92% with signs of PAH or right heart failure.
Patients with dependent edema, P-pulmonale on ECG, or hematocrit value >56% with Pa02 value between 56-59 mm will benefit from oxygen therapy
benefits of oxygen therapy are directly proportional to the duration of oxygen administration

questions.text:
A 70-year-old male patient is being treated for chronic obstructive pulmonary disease and comes for follow-up. He is tachypneic with a resting oxygen saturation of 88%.
Which of the following statement regarding oxygen therapy is false?
questions.solution:
COPD is a disease state characterized by chronic airflow obstruction. It includes emphysema, chronic bronchitis, and small airway disease. Supplemental oxygen is indicated in patients with resting 02 saturation of ?88% or ?89% with signs of pulmonary arterial hypertension or right heart failure. It has been proven to prolong survival and the benefits are directly proportional to the duration of oxygen administration (hours per day).
Studies did not show significant benefits in patients with moderate hypoxemia.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition • Page no. 2180, 2182, 2185,
2186, 2187,2188, 2189

questions.text: A male patient with history of chronic smoking presents with productive cough and clubbing. He aslo gives history of cough with postural changes. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of bronchiectasis. It refers to an irreversible airway dilation in either focal or diffuse manner. Types- tubular, Cystic, Varicose, Traction bronchiectasis. HRCT- Signet ring sign, tree in bud pattern, Tram track sign. Ref- Harrsion Principles of Internal Medicine 20 th edition Page 1983-1985

questions.text: Interpret the ABG findings pH 7.3 pCO2 50 Hco3 24
questions.solution: pH being <7.35 is suggestive of acidosis and pco2 being >40 is suggestive of a respiratory cause of acidosis. Ref- Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 359

questions.text: A patient with chronic heart failure has a type of breathing pattern given below. What is the abnormality shown here?
questions.solution:
The image is showing Cheyne Stokes breathing. It is charecterised by waxing and wanning hyperventilation seperated by periods of apnea. This is seen in patients at high altitude and in patients with heart failure and brain injury.
Ganong's Review Of Medical Physiology, 26th Edition • Page no 655

questions.text: A 60 year old male was admitted in veiw of fracture neck of femur . on post op day three he developed sudden onset breathlessness and chest pain on inspiration. On evaluation had a pulse of 127 bpm and BP of 110/80mmhg. His chest X-ray is as shown below. Identify the finding
questions.solution:
X-ray findings in acute pulmonary embolism.
(1) Westermark sign: A sharp cut-off of pulmonary vessels with distal hypoperfusion in a segmental distribution within the lung. This is a rare but specific finding for acute PE. (2) Hampton's hump: A shallow, hump-shaped opacity on CXR in the periphery of the lung. This is a rare and nonspecific finding.
(3) Palla's sign: An enlargement of the right descending pulmonary artery. This is a useful radiographic finding for the early detection of acute pulmonary embolism.
(4) Fleishner sign: An enlargement of the central pulmonary artery. Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition • Page 2094, 2098-2100

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presents with daytime sleepiness, impaired concentration, and impaired memory. On examination, her BMI is 43 kg/m2, blood pressure is 170/100 mm of Hg. Her awake arterial blood gas analysis shows bicarbonate - 33 mEq/L, PaCO2 - 53 mmHg, PaO2 - 70 mmHg. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient has obesity (BMI 43), daytime sleepiness, cognitive impairment, hypertension, and ABG showing chronic hypercapnia (PaCO2 53 mmHg), hypoxemia (PaO2 70 mmHg), and elevated bicarbonate (33 mEq/L).

  • These are classic features of obesity hypoventilation syndrome, also known as Pickwickian syndrome, which involves hypoventilation during wakefulness in obese patients.

Other options:

  • Narcolepsy: Characterized by excessive daytime sleepiness, cataplexy, but ABG is typically normal; no hypercapnia.

  • Central sleep apnea: Caused by loss of central respiratory drive; ABG may show intermittent hypercapnia but usually not associated with obesity.

  • Obstructive sleep apnea: Usually causes nocturnal hypoxemia, intermittent apneas; daytime hypercapnia develops only in severe or chronic cases.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition - Page 2012.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient presents with difficulty in breathing and dizziness. He has been undergoing treatment for lung cancer. On examination, breath sounds were reduced over the left inferior-scapular region. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient has dyspnea, dizziness, and reduced breath sounds over a specific region, which are classic signs of pleural effusion.

  • In a patient with lung cancer, malignant pleural effusion is a common complication.

  • Other supporting features may include dullness to percussion and decreased tactile fremitus on the affected side.

Other options:

  • Constrictive pericarditis: Presents with Kussmaul sign, pericardial knock, not localized reduced breath sounds.

  • Cardiac tamponade: Shows Beck’s triad (hypotension, muffled heart sounds, raised JVP), not focal reduced breath sounds.

  • Pneumothorax: Causes hyperresonant percussion and absent breath sounds; usually sudden onset.


Reference
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition - Page no. 1844

questions.text: An elderly male patient who is a known case of COPD, hypertension, and diabetes mellitus visits the OPD to review his medications. Which of the following criteria should be followed by the physician during the review?
questions.solution:
• Beers criteria provide a guideline for potentially inappropriate medications in elderly patients.

  • They help clinicians review and adjust medications in older adults, especially those with comorbidities like COPD, hypertension, and diabetes, to reduce adverse drug reactions.

Other options:

  • Duke's criteria: Used for infective endocarditis diagnosis.

  • Jones criteria: Used for diagnosis of rheumatic fever.

  • Light criteria: Used to differentiate exudative vs transudative pleural effusions.



Reference
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 13th Edition - Page no: 38

questions.text: A 45-year-old man had severe hypothyroidism. His arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis shows very low pO2 and high pCO2 levels. Which of the following types of respiratory failure is likely to be present in him?
questions.solution:
• Type 2 respiratory failure is characterized by hypercapnia (PaCO > 50 mmHg) and hypoxemia (PaO < 60 mmHg).

  • Severe hypothyroidism can lead to hypoventilation due to reduced respiratory drive and weakened respiratory muscles, resulting in CO retention.

  • This pattern corresponds to Type 2 (hypercapnic) respiratory failure.

Other options:

  • Type 1: Hypoxemia without hypercapnia; typical of ARDS or pneumonia.

  • Type 3: Perioperative respiratory failure; not commonly classified separately in ABG terms.

  • Type 4: Due to shock-related hypoperfusion, not hypoventilation.



Reference
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition - Page no 2026

questions.text: What percentage of increase in FEV1/ FVC ratio represents the minimum change required to demonstrate the reversibility of obstruction after administration of bronchodilators in bronchial asthma? FEV1 - Forced expiratory volume in the first minute FVC - Forced vital capacity
questions.solution:
• Reversibility testing in asthma assesses improvement in airflow obstruction after bronchodilator administration.

  • According to guidelines, a significant bronchodilator response is defined as an increase in FEV or FVC by 0.12, that is, ≥12% and ≥200 mL from baseline.

  • This demonstrates reversible airway obstruction, characteristic of asthma.


Reference
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition - page 1963

questions.text: A 60-year-old male presented with shortness of breath. He is a known case of COPD and has had similar episodes in the past, which required hospitalization. The classification according to GOLD's criteria was moderate COPD. What are the likely PFT values of the patient considering this classification?
questions.solution:
• GOLD classification for COPD severity is based on post-bronchodilator FEV1:

    • Mild (GOLD 1): FEV1 ≥ 80% predicted

    • Moderate (GOLD 2): FEV1 50–79% predicted

    • Severe (GOLD 3): FEV1 30–49% predicted

    • Very severe (GOLD 4): FEV1 < 30% predicted

  • In COPD, the FEV1/FVC ratio is always <0.7 post-bronchodilator, indicating airflow obstruction.

So, a patient with moderate COPD (GOLD 2) will have:

  • FEV1/FVC < 0.7

  • FEV1 50–80% predicted



Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1991

questions.text: A 60-year-old bedridden patient develops acute onset dyspnea and chest pain. A CT pulmonary angiography was done. Which screening test will be useful to determine the etiology of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
• The patient is bedridden and presents with acute dyspnea and chest pain, which raises high suspicion for pulmonary embolism (PE).

  • D-dimer is a fibrin degradation product elevated in thromboembolic events and is used as a screening test.

  • A negative D-dimer in a low-to-moderate risk patient can effectively rule out PE, while a positive result warrants imaging (like CT pulmonary angiography) for confirmation.

Other options:

  • MR Angiogram: Not first-line for PE; used in specific cases or when CT is contraindicated.

  • Echocardiography: Can show right heart strain but cannot reliably diagnose PE.

  • Coagulogram: Evaluates clotting function but does not diagnose thromboembolism.



Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page no 2091-2097

choices.text: 24, pCO2 - 60 mm Hg, pO252 mmHg, and HCO3 - 27 mmol/L. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with a history of COPD presents with sudden onset increased shortness of breath. His ABG analysis reveals pH - 7.24, pCO2 - 60 mm Hg, pO252 mmHg, and HCO3 - 27 mmol/L. What is the most appropriate treatment for this patient?
questions.solution:
Interpretation of ABG

  • pH = 7.24 → Acidotic

  • pCO = 60 mmHg → Elevated → Respiratory acidosis

  • HCO = 27 mmol/L → Mild compensation

  • pO = 52 mmHg → Hypoxemia

This pattern is classic for acute on chronic type II respiratory failure in a known COPD patient.

Rationale:

  • This patient has acute respiratory acidosis superimposed on chronic CO retention due to COPD.

  • NIPPV (e.g., BiPAP) is first-line treatment for COPD exacerbation with hypercapnia and acidosis (pH < 7.35 but > 7.25).

  • It improves oxygenation, reduces CO, offloads the respiratory muscles, and reduces the need for intubation.

    Why not the others?

  • Endotracheal intubation (Option 2) and IPPV (Option 3) are reserved for:

    • Respiratory arrest

    • Severe acidosis (pH < 7.25 and worsening)

    • Hemodynamic instability

    • Decreased consciousness

  • Lung volume reduction surgery (Option 4) is elective for stable patients with severe emphysema, not for acute exacerbations.


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1991,1996

questions.text: A 72-year-old man presented with weight loss, decreased appetite, and iron deficiency anemia. Chest X-ray was done and given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The phrase "cannon ball metastases" refers to multiple, well-circumscribed, round opacities seen on a chest X-ray, typically scattered throughout both lung fields. This appearance is highly characteristic of hematogenous metastases to the lungs.

Key clinical and radiological clues:

  • Elderly male with weight loss, anorexia, and iron deficiency anemia suggests a malignancy, possibly gastrointestinal or genitourinary in origin.

  • Chest X-ray shows cannon ball lesions → classic for lung metastases.

  • Most common primary cancers causing cannon ball metastases:

    • Renal cell carcinoma

    • Choriocarcinoma

    • Colorectal cancer

    • Prostate cancer

      Why other options are less likely:

  • Bronchogenic carcinoma: Typically presents as a single spiculated mass or hilar lesion, not multiple round nodules.

  • Miliary tuberculosis: Shows innumerable, uniformly sized tiny nodules (<2 mm) spread throughout the lungs — described as a "millet seed" appearance, not cannon ball.

  • Mesothelioma: Usually presents as pleural thickening or mass, not discrete round pulmonary nodules.

    Summary:

Cannon ball metastases on CXR with a background of weight loss and anemia in an elderly patient strongly indicate lung metastasis from an extrapulmonary primary.



Reference: Graigner and Allison's Diagnostic Radiology 6th edition page no 338

questions.text: A 55-year-old construction factory worker presents with dyspnoea. He has been working in this industry for the past 25 years. Which is the most specific malignancy that we can expect in this patient?
questions.solution:
A 55-year-old construction factory worker with dyspnoea and long-term occupational exposure strongly suggests asbestos exposure.

Why Malignant Mesothelioma?

  • Asbestos exposure (common in construction, insulation, shipbuilding) is the most specific risk factor for malignant mesothelioma.

  • Mesothelioma arises from the pleural lining, not lung parenchyma.

  • Presents with dyspnoea, chest pain, pleural effusion, and pleural thickening.

  • Latency period between exposure and cancer onset: 20–40 years.

    Other Options:

  • Squamous cell carcinoma, adenocarcinoma, and small cell carcinoma are all linked to smoking more than occupational exposure.

  • These are primary lung carcinomas, but not specific to asbestos exposure.
    Takeaway:

  • Asbestos → Mesothelioma is a highly specific association.

  • Thus, the most specific malignancy in this patient is: Malignant mesothelioma.

Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1978

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient comes to your clinic with 8-month history of shortness of breath and non-productive cough. He has smoked half a pack of cigarettes for the past 30 years. On physical examination, clubbing is seen and fine crackles are heard on both sides during inspiration. You perform pulmonary function tests and it shows an FVC of 78% and FEV1/FVC ratio of 92%. You request a CT scan of the chest. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This case describes classic features of pulmonary fibrosis (especially idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis or IPF):

Clinical Features:

  • Chronic non-productive cough

  • Progressive dyspnea

  • Clubbing

  • Fine inspiratory crackles ("Velcro crackles")

  • History of smoking (a risk factor)

    Pulmonary Function Test (PFT) Findings:

FVC = 78% → Reduced (restrictive pattern)

  • FEV1/FVC = 92% → Normal or increased, which is typical of restrictive lung disease

Restrictive patterns = ↓ FVC, normal or ↑ FEV1/FVC

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Bronchial asthma → Obstructive disease; expect ↓ FEV1, ↓ FEV1/FVC ratio (<70%), not restrictive.

  • Pulmonary tuberculosis → Can cause cavitary lesions, hemoptysis, night sweats, and constitutional symptoms; not primarily associated with chronic fibrosis and clubbing unless very advanced.

  • Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) → Also obstructive; expect ↓ FEV1/FVC ratio, typically <70%.

On High-Resolution CT (HRCT), the typical findings include:

  • Reticular opacities (a net-like pattern)

  • Honeycombing: clustered cystic air spaces, typically in subpleural and basal areas

  • Traction bronchiectasis: dilated airways due to fibrotic pull

  • Basal and peripheral predominance

  • Absence of ground-glass opacities in typical cases (but may be seen in acute exacerbations)


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1999

questions.text: What is the most commonly seen pattern in chest CT of patients affected with COVID-19?
questions.solution:
The most prevalent pattern in chest CT scans of COVID-19 patients is ground glass opacity (GGO).

Typical CT Scan Features in COVID-19:

  1. Ground glass opacities (GGO) – Most common finding

  2. Consolidation – Especially in advanced stages

  3. Air bronchograms – May accompany consolidation

  4. Thickened interlobular septa – Adds to a reticular pattern

  5. Intralobular lines (crazy paving pattern) – GGO + septal thickening

  6. Reverse halo sign – Central GGO surrounded by denser consolidation

    Summary:

  • Ground-glass opacity is the hallmark radiological finding in COVID-19.

  • Most commonly bilateral, peripheral, and lower lobe predominant.

  • Other features like consolidation and crazy paving may be seen but are less common than isolated GGO in early or mild disease.



Reference Online Resource https://www.ncbi.nim.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7585632/

questions.text: A patient was admitted to the ICU 48 hours after the fracture of the femur. The saturation of oxygen in the rebreathing unit was 100% but his Sp02 remained at 60%. The patient is in a state of confusion. Chest radiograph showed lung fields to be clear. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
FAT EMBOLISM

  • Timeline:

    • Occurs typically 24–72 hours after long bone fracture (e.g., femur)

    • Here, the patient presented 48 hours post-fracture, fitting perfectly

  • Clinical features (classic triad):

    • Hypoxemia (SpO low despite 100% oxygen delivery)

    • Neurological signs (e.g., confusion)

    • Petechial rash (may be subtle or absent early)

  • Radiological findings:

    • Chest X-ray is often normal or shows mild interstitial infiltrates initially

    • No evidence of infiltrates helps rule out ARDS

  • Key finding:

    • Saturation discrepancy: High PaO in ventilator/rebreather, but low SpO in patient — suggests a diffusion defect due to fat microemboli in pulmonary capillaries

      Why others are incorrect:

  • ARDS: Would show bilateral infiltrates on CXR and occurs from systemic inflammation

  • Occult pneumothorax: Would usually show respiratory distress and radiographic signs (deep sulcus, etc.)

  • Pulmonary embolism: Can cause hypoxia, but usually not this early post-fracture and would show signs of vascular compromise (e.g., wedge infarct or perfusion mismatch)

 

Major and Minor Criteria for Fat Embolism Syndrome (FES) — based on Gurd's criteria, the most commonly used diagnostic framework:

Major Criteria:

  • Respiratory insufficiency
    (e.g., hypoxia, dyspnea, tachypnea, low PaO)

  • Cerebral signs not due to other causes
    (e.g., confusion, agitation, seizures, coma)

  • Petechial rash
    (typically on chest, axilla, conjunctivae)

    Minor Criteria:

  • Tachycardia (HR >110/min)

  • Fever (>38.5°C)

  • Retinal changes (fat/lipid in retina, hemorrhages)

  • Fat in urine

  • Sudden hematocrit or platelet drop

  • High ESR

  • Fat globules in sputum

    Diagnostic Threshold (Gurd’s Criteria):

  • Diagnosis = At least 1 Major + 4 Minor criteria


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page no 1911,2031

questions.text: A resident is evaluating a patient, who presented with acute onset of chest pain and dyspnea, for pulmonary embolism. Which of the following imaging test should be performed to confirm this diagnosis?
questions.solution:
1. CT pulmonary angiography

  • Gold standard imaging test for pulmonary embolism in most clinical settings.

  • Provides direct visualization of thrombus in pulmonary arteries.

  • Rapid, widely available, highly sensitive and specific.

  1. Ventilation-perfusion (V/Q) scan

  • Used when CTPA is contraindicated (e.g., contrast allergy, renal failure, pregnancy in some cases).

  • A normal V/Q scan can effectively exclude PE.

  1. Doppler echocardiography

  • Helpful in detecting right heart strain or right ventricular dysfunction due to PE.

  • Useful in unstable patients who cannot undergo CTPA, but not confirmatory for PE.

  1. MR pulmonary angiography

  • Can visualize pulmonary vessels but is not routinely used due to limited availability, longer acquisition time, and less sensitivity compared to CTPA.



Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 1912

questions.text: Which one of the following can be used as a substitute for a liver biopsy to detect fibrosis in order to avoid a liver biopsy?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Serum hyaluronic acid and laminin
 
  • Serum hyaluronic acid and laminin are biomarkers that can provide information about liver fibrosis, which is scarring of the liver tissue.
  • Elevated levels of these biomarkers are associated with liver fibrosis, indicating potential liver damage.
  • However, these are non-specific biomarkers and should not be used as reliable tests for detecting fibrosis. Fibroscan is a better non-invasive test to detect Hepatic fibrosis.
 
  • Although the other options (SGOT and SGPT, serum ALP and GGT, unconjugated and conjugated bilirubin) are also liver function tests, they do not specifically evaluate liver fibrosis or provide a comprehensive assessment of liver health without the need for a biopsy.






Reference: Yamada’s Textbook of Gastroenterology, 6th edition, Page no 2952.

questions.text: Pick the drug is not active against Hepatitis B.
questions.solution:
Zidovudine(AZT) is active against HIV. However, it is not active against Hepatitis B.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2595.

questions.text: Pick the option that is diagnostic of acute hepatitis B infection.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: IgM anti-HbC
 
  • During acute hepatitis B infection, IgM antibodies against the hepatitis B core antigen (anti-HBc) are typically detectable.
 
  • IgM anti-HBc is an important marker of recent or ongoing infection and is used to confirm acute hepatitis B infection. It indicates an active immune response to the hepatitis B virus.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2565, 2576.

questions.text: Both HbsAg and HbeAg seropositivity was discovered in a nurse. She is afflicted with:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Acute infectious hepatitis B

The nurse has recently acquired hepatitis B infection. The presence of both HBsAg and HBeAg seropositivity is commonly seen during the acute phase of hepatitis B infection when the virus is actively replicating. In this case, the nurse is likely experiencing an acute infectious episode of hepatitis B.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2565, 2576.

questions.text: Between peritoneum and which of the following is the Le-Veen shunt in ascites done?
questions.solution:
The LeVeen shunt a.k.a Peritoneovenous shunt designed for ascites management due to CLD.

One end of the tube is inserted into the peritoneal cavity while the other end is subcutaneously tunneled to the neck, where its inserted into the IJV and fed into the SVC.




Reference: LeVeen, H H. “The LeVeen shunt.” Annual review of medicine vol. 36 (1985): 453-69. doi:10.1146/annurev.me.36.020185.002321. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/3888061/

questions.text:
Serology profile done for a patient is mentioned below. What is the likely cause of the abnormal findings:
HbsAg-Non-reactive
HBV DNA-Undetectable
HbeAg-Non-reactive
IgG Anti-HbC-Reactive
questions.solution:
State of recovery from chronic hepatitis

It is evident from the aforementioned serology profile that the patient either has a remote past of Hepatitis B infection or is a low-level Hepatitis B carrier.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2576.

questions.text: 2 hours after eating at a restaurant, a young male experienced 5 episodes of loose stools. He is afebrile and slightly dehydrated. What is the next course of action?
questions.solution:
The patient in the hypothetical clinical situation is mildly dehydrated and experiencing diarrhea.

Replacement of lost fluid and electrolytes is crucial for all types of diarrhoea. Fluid replacement with ORS is adequate in cases of mild diarrhea. 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 301, 302.

questions.text: A patient arrived with ascites. Ascitic fluid analysis was done and found to have a SAAG greater than 1.1. Which of the following is not a cause?
questions.solution:
In tubercular peritonitis, Serum-Ascites Albumin Gradient (SAAG) is <1.1gm/dL.
 
  • The SAAG is effective for separating ascites resulting from portal hypertension from ascites without portal hypertension.
  • The SAAG corresponds with the hepatic venous pressure gradient and represents the pressure within the hepatic sinusoids.
  • The SAAG is determined by deducting the serum albumin level from the ascitic albumin concentration, and it is unaffected by diuresis.
  • A SAAG <1. g/dL indicates that the ascites is not related to portal hypertension, as in tuberculous peritonitis, peritoneal carcinomatosis, or pancreatic ascites.
 
SAAG \(\geq\) 1.1 g/dl SAAG < 1.1 g/dl
• Liver cirrhosis • Malignancy
• Fulminant hepatic failure • Peritoneal carcinomatosis
• Liver metastases • Nephropathy
• Budd-Chiari syndrome • Malnutrition
• Portal Vein Thrombosis • Protein-losing enteropathy
• Veno-occlusive Disease • Tuberculous peritonitis
• Myxedema • Pancreatic ascites
• Cardiac Failure • Serositis
• Constrictive Pericarditis • Secondary peritonitis
• Pulmonary Hypertension



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 322, 323, 2631, 2632.

questions.text: The most common presentation of immunoproliferative small intestinal disease is:
questions.solution:
• IPSID, also known as Mediterranean Lymphoma, is a chronic inflammatory disorder of the small intestine caused by infection with the bacteria Campylobacter jejuni. It is most commonly seen in patients of Middle Eastern, North African and Central Asian origin.
 
  • The most prominent feature of this disorder is malabsorption. This can lead to diarrhea, weight loss, abdominal pain and loss of appetite.
 
  • Other symptoms that may be seen with IPSID include fever, anemia, and an enlarged spleen.
 
  • Patients with this condition will often require lifelong antibiotic treatment to control the infection and may also need nutritional supplementation to ensure proper nutrition.


Reference: Martin, I G, and M I Aldoori. “Immunoproliferative small intestinal disease: Mediterranean lymphoma and alpha heavy chain disease.” The British journal of surgery vol. 81,1 (1994): 20-4. doi:10.1002/bjs.1800810107. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/8313111/

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2459.

questions.text:
A patient with hematemesis was examined, and his blood pressure was 90/60 mmHg and his heart rate was 120. There was also splenomegaly.
What is the most probable cause of bleeding?
questions.solution:
Portal hypertension is a condition in which the pressure in the portal vein (the primary vein that carries blood from the intestines, pancreas, spleen, and stomach to the liver) is abnormally high.

Splenomegaly (enlarged spleen) and massive bleeding due to rupture of gastric varices leading to hypotension and tachycardia (rapid heart rate) are symptoms often seen in patients with portal hypertension. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2625.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is best for determining whether an individual has intestinal malabsorption?
questions.solution:
• The D-Xylose absorption test, which examines Xylose absorption in the intestinal villi and can differentiate between Intestinal and Pancreatic malabsorption, is the most effective test for diagnosing Intestinal Malabsorption
 
  • Urinary D-xylose Test: The urinary D-xylose test for carbohydrate absorption provides a measure of proximal small-bowel absorptive function. d-Xylose, a pentose, is absorbed almost exclusively in the proximal small intestine and is excreted in the urine. The d-xylose test is usually performed by administering 25 g of d-xylose and collecting urine for 5 h. An abnormal test (excretion of <4.5 g) primarily reflects duodenal/jejunal mucosal disease.
 
  • For pancreatic malabsorption,we use the NBT-PABA and serum amylase assays.
  • Although, the gold standard for intestinal malabsorption is considered as faecal fat estimation, D-Xylose absorption is the best test.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2468.

questions.text: The right upper quadrant of the abdomen is full in a 40-year-old obese woman. Her medical history is significant for both hyperlipidemia and Type 2 diabetes mellitus. Which of the following diagnoses is the most likely one that a liver biopsy would point to?
questions.solution:
Non alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH) is used to describe clinical features of liver injury, such as elevated transaminases.

Commonly associated abnormalities are: -
a. Type 2 diabetes
b. Obesity, primarily central obesity)
c. Dyslipidemia
d. Hypertension



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2622.

questions.text: Progressive jaundice was detected in a patient who was 50 years old. LFT revealed SGOT-50, SGPT-65, alkaline phosphatase-550 IU, direct and total serum bilirubin levels of 4.8% and 6.7% respectively. On clinical examination GB was non palpable. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
Most probable diagnosis is Jaundice due to choledocholithiasis.
 
  • High Conjugated (Direct) bilirubin and increased alkaline phosphatase levels point towards post hepatic obstruction as seen in case of choledocholithiasis.
 
  • Serum bilirubin levels > 20 mg/dL should suggest the possibility of neoplastic obstruction, which is not seen in this case.
 
  • Moreover, According to Courvoisier's law, GB is palpable in Malignant Obstructive jaundice (Periampullary CA) whereas it is non palpable in Choledocholithiasis, due to repeated inflammation and fibrosis.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2553, 2554, 2557

choices.text: Negative nasogastric aspirate does not exclude variceal bleed
Nasogastric tube insertion can provoke variceal bleeding

questions.text: A 60-year-old man with alcoholic liver disease and a history of hematemesis presented to emergency. Which of the following statements about his management is false?
questions.solution:
NG tube insertion DO NOT provoke variceal bleed. Rather, it should be done to prevent aspiration in patients with acute variceal bleed. NG tube aspirate do not necessarily contain variceal bleed.
 
  • Treatment for esophageal varices as a complication of portal hypertension is divided into two main categories: (1) primary prophylaxis and (2) prevention of rebleeding once there has been an initial variceal hemorrhage.
 
  • Upper GI endoscopies are recommended at diagnosis of compensated cirrhosis and then every 2 years if the liver disease is active or every 3 years if inactive (alcohol cessation, viral hepatitis eradication). Endoscopy is also recommended at the time of hepatic decompensation.
 
  • The use of vasoconstricting agents, usually somatostatin or octreotide, has been shown to improve initial bleeding control and reduce transfusion requirements and all-cause mortality.
 
  • Balloon tamponade (Sengstaken-Blakemore tube or Minnesota tube) can be used in patients who need stabilization prior to endoscopic therapy or as a bridge to transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS) after endoscopic failure


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2630.

choices.text: 8 mg/dL (direct = 18.6 mg/dL) in the serum, respectively. What plausible diagnosis is there?
Acute hepatitis E superimposed on chronic liver failure due to hepatitis B
Fulminant hepatitis due to hepatitis B infection
Acute hepatitis E with chronic hepatitis A
Fulminant hepatitis due to hepatitis E infection

questions.text:
A pregnant woman of 27 years old arrives with severe jaundice and decreased sensory function. The patient is found to be severely icteric, unresponsive to orders, and the pelvic ultrasound shows an intrauterine foetal demise. The values of AST and ALT are 1063 and 28.8 mg/dL (direct = 18.6 mg/dL) in the serum, respectively. What plausible diagnosis is there? 
Viral indicators are: 
Anti-HAV lgG Reactive
Anti-HAV lgM Nonreactive
HbSAg Nonreactive
Anti-HbSAg Nonreactive
Anti-HBc lgM Nonreactive
Anti-HBc lgG Reactive
Anti-HCV lgG Nonreactive
Anti-HEV lgM Reactive
Anti-HEV lgG Nonreactive
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is Fulminant hepatitis due to hepatitis E infection.
 
  • From the markers mentioned, it can be concluded that the patient is previously infected and immune to hepatitis A and hepatitis B. Since the IgM for hepatitis E is positive, the patient is suffering from Acute fulminant hepatitis E. This is common in pregnant women.
 
  • Hepatitis E causes fatal fulminant hepatitis in upto 20% cases in pregnant women.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2574, 2578.

questions.text: A 76-year-old man with abdominal pain, a binge drinking episode, shock, and a blood pressure of 70/50 mm Hg and a heart rate of 115 beats per minute arrives at the emergency room. The patient has an oxygen saturation level of 70 mm Hg. The amount of serum creatinine was 2.4 mg/dl and BUN 30 mg/dl. The patient's transaminases were elevated. Based on the CT scan below, what is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Alcohol binge is a common cause of acute pancreatitis. Here the CT scan showing blurry margins of the pancreas is confirming the diagnosis.

Since vitals are unstable and end organ damage is developing as S. Cr is 2.4mg/dL and BUN is 30 mg/dl, therefore it is Severe Acute Pancreatitis. 

Markers for Severe acute Pancreatitis:

questions.text: Which of the following is not an effective tool for malabsorption research?

  • The 14 C-triolein and trioctanoin breath test is used for fat malabsorption.

questions.text: Most common cause of chronic pancreatitis is:
questions.solution:
Chronic alcohol abuse is a major risk factor for developing chronic pancreatitis. Prolonged alcohol intake leads to pancreatic injury and inflammation, eventually resulting in the development of chronic pancreatitis.
 
  • Other causes of chronic pancreatitis include long-standing pancreatic calculi (option 2) that obstruct the pancreatic duct, pancreatic divisum (option 3), a congenital anatomical variation of the pancreatic ducts, and gallbladder stones (option 4), which can cause recurrent episodes of acute pancreatitis but are less commonly associated with chronic pancreatitis.
 
  • A common mnemonic used to remember the causes of chronic pancreatitis is
  • TIGAR-O: Toxic-metabolic, Idiopathic, Genetic, Autoimmune, Recurrent and severe acute pancreatitis and Obstructive
Most common cause of Acute pancreatitis is GB stone. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2665.

choices.text: Jaundice less than 7 days before development of encephalopathy

questions.text: A 5 year old presented with acute liver failure. He has no history of Acetaminophen intake. Which of the following requirements does not fall under the purview of the King's College requirements for liver transplantation?
questions.solution:
The King’s college criteria for Acute Liver Failure stipulate that if acetaminophen is involved, the patient must have a PH level of less than 7.30, or a prothrombin time of over 100 seconds (INR of over 6.5). Additionally, the patient must have a serum creatinine value of over 3.4 mg/dl (300 mmol/l) if encephalopathy is present.

In cases where acetaminophen is not involved, the patient must have a prothrombin time over 100 seconds (INR over 6.5), or 3 of the following: age less than 10 years or over 40 years, non-A/non-B hepatitis, drug-induced, or idiosyncratic reactions, duration of jaundice before onset of encephalopathy over 7 days, prothrombin time over 50 seconds (INR 3.5) and a serum bilirubin of over 17.6 mg/dl (300 mmol).

King’s College Criteria for Liver transplantation in Acetaminophen and Non-Acetaminophen induced Acute Liver Failure: 





Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1195.

questions.text: Which of the following will you not do in a patient having massive hematemesis
questions.solution:
Platelet transfusion is NOT done in case of active variceal bleeding unless definite coagulopathy is documented. It is indicated only when Platelet count is < 50,000/microL or in patients with evidence of micro vascular bleeding.
 
  • Bleeding Esophageal Varices: The most frequent location for variceal haemorrhage is the lower oesophagus. The risk of bleeding of esophageal varices increases above 12 mm of Hg. It is a medical emergency. Those who have severe bleeding should be admitted to the intensive care unit.
 
  • Management Blood transfusions, colloids, and plasma expanders should all be used to reduce the blood volume. Rectify coagulopathy: Vitamin K (10 mg intravenously) is given, but fresh-frozen plasma must also be given to correct a coagulopathy (FFP). Esophageal balloon tamponade (Sengstaken-Blakemore tube): Four lumens are present in modified Sengstaken-Blakemore (old Sengstaken-Blakemore tube contains 3 tubes). One for esophageal balloon dilation, one for stomach aspiration, one for gastric balloon dilation, and one for esophageal aspiration.
 
  • Pharmacotherapy:  Somatostatin and octreotide, which are long-acting analogues of the hormone, are effective. Previously used vasopressin is also useful, but nitroglycerin must be administered in addition to it to prevent constriction of the coronary vessels. Terlipressin has recently become widely used to stop bleeding.
 
  • Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic stent shunts (TIPSS) is an intrahepatic shunt done as definitive management of Esophageal varices. Urgent Endoscopy is also indicated. Studies have demonstrated that a lower rate of rebleeding and shorter length of hospital stay when endoscopy was performed within 24 hours of admission.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1203.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition, Page no 274.

questions.text: What will be the colour of the iv cannula used in a patient with diarrhea and severe dehydration presenting in OPD, for rapid infusion of fluid?
questions.solution:
The 16 G grey cannula has a larger bore, which increases the flow rate. Hence, it is used for quick fluid replacement.

questions.text: Hypothyroidism is now evident in the patient with h/o DM, and she is not gaining weight. What has to be done in terms of additional diagnostic research
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Anti TPO antibodies
 
  • Hashimoto thyroiditis is an autoimmune disorder in which the body's immune system attacks the thyroid gland, causing inflammation and damage to the thyroid cells.
  • This destruction and damage leads to a decrease in the production of thyroid hormones.
  • It is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in areas where iodine is not deficient.
  • It is more commonly found in women than in men. It is associated with the presence of autoantibodies against thyroglobulin and thyroid peroxidase (TPO), and there is a genetic component linked to the genes CTLA4 and PTPN22.
  • Histologically, the thyroid gland shows a mononuclear infiltrate, atrophic thyroid follicles and Hurthle cells.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2933, 2934.

questions.text: Which test distinguishes between organic d/s and functional disorder of Bowel?
questions.solution:
Stool Calprotectin is a marker used to differentiate between IBS and IBD.

  • It is a protein released into the stool by white blood cells when inflammation is present in the intestinal wall. It is elevated in IBD due to the inflammatory process.
  • It is usually normal in IBS, but can occasionally be mildly elevated due to certain food triggers.
  • Fecal calprotectin and lactoferrin levels have been used to distinguish IBD from irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), to assess whether CD is active, and to detect postoperative recurrence of CD.
  • Fecal calprotectin is a more sensitive marker of ileocolonic or colonic inflammation rather than isolated ileal inflammation.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2477.

questions.text: From the options given below, identify the one which is not a feature of the MELD score:
questions.solution:
Albumin among the following is not a component of MELD score.

MELD stands for model for end stage liver disease. MELD score is calculated using serum bilirubin, serum creatinine, and International normalised ratio (INR).

COMPONENTS OF MELD SCORE: [Mnemonic- C.B.I]
  1. Creatinine
  2. Bilirubin and
  3. INR (PT)
It may also include Sodium levels which is known as MELD-Na score.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2635, 2636.

questions.text:
40 yr female presents with abdominal pain and gross distension. Vitals are stable. P/A findings shows presence of dullness in flanks ?

i. Minimum amount of fluid should be 1500ml to show shifting dullness in flanks
ii. Minimum amount of fluid should be 500ml to show shifting dullness in flanks
iii. USG can detect minimum < 100ml
iv. USG can detect minimum > 500ml
v. Most common cause is cirrhosis
questions.solution:
• Minimal amount of fluid present to demonstrate shifting dullness is 500ml, for horse shoe shaped dullness is 1000 ml and for fluid thrill is 1500 ml.
 
  • USG is the most sensitive modality to detect ascites for it can detect minimum of 100 ml of ascitic fluid. 
  • Abdominal ultrasonography can detect as little as 100 mL of ascitic fluid, hepatosplenomegaly, a nodular liver, or a mass.
 
  • Most common cause of Ascites is DCLD due to Liver Cirrhosis. Cirrhosis accounts for 84% of cases of ascites.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 322, 323.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient was admitted with severe ascites and had an abdominal paracentesis. The fluid is clear, cell-free under a microscope, and contains ascitic albumin levels of 1.2 g/dl and ascitic protein level of 2.1 g/dl. Serum albumin levels is 3.5 g/dl. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The etiology is Late Budd Chiari syndrome.

SAAG = S. albumin - Ascitic fluid albumin = 3.5-1.2= 2.3 gm%.

Causes of SAAG > 1.1% with Ascitic protein < 2.5% are:
  • Cirrhosis
  • Late Budd-Chiari syndrome
  • Massive liver metastases





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 323.

questions.text:
A 40-year-old male patient who had a history of smoking enters the OPD at AIIMS with fever, tiredness, jaundice, and yellow urine and faeces. He had grown wary of smoking cigarettes over the last few days. On inspection, scleral icterus was discovered. LFT are
Total Bilirubin 18.5
Direct Bilirubin 7.5
SGOT 723
SGPT 812
What investigations will you send for ruling out acute viral hepatitis?
questions.solution:
Anti-HAV, HBsAg, IgM antiBc, Anti-HCV investigations are done to detect the presence of the hepatitis viruses that cause acute viral hepatitis.

We mainly test for Hepatitis A, B and C. Hepatitis D and E are rarely tested.
 
  • The anti-HAV antibody test is done to detect the presence of the Hepatitis A virus, which is transmitted by direct contact with infected material such as food or water that has been contaminated with the virus.
 
  • Hepatitis E is not tested routinely as majority of patients who acquire HEV infection spontaneously resolves or clears the virus. ALF is more likely in Pregnant, malnourished and patients with previous history of Liver disease.
 
  • The HBsAg test is used to detect the presence of the hepatitis B virus, which is typically spread through contact with bodily fluids of an infected person.
 
  • The IgM anti-HBC test is used to detect the presence of Hepatitis C, which is most often spread through contact with the blood of an infected person.
 
  • The Anti-HCV test is done to detect the presence of the hepatitis C virus, which is transmitted through contact with infected blood or other bodily fluids.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 74-77, 2562-2568.

questions.text:
A 68-year-old female patient with atrial fibrillation and mitral stenosis was diagnosed.
No thrombus is shown on the ECHO. Which of the following prevents stroke the best in feature?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Oral warfarin
 
  • Irregular heartbeats (atrial fibrillation) and narrowing of the mitral valve (mitral stenosis) can cause blood clots, posing a stroke risk.
  • Both conditions increase the risk of blood clot formation in the heart, which can potentially travel to the brain and cause a stroke.
  • In the absence of a thrombus on ECHO, the patient is at risk for developing a blood clot in the heart.
  • Oral Warfarin has been shown to be effective in preventing strokes in patients with atrial fibrillation and mitral stenosis.

Anticoagulation in atrial fibrillation:
Anticoagulation is indicated for patients with mitral stenosis, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, previous history of stroke. In nonvalvular atrial fibrillation, the risk of stroke and the need for anticoagulation is assessed with the CHA2DS2-VASc score.

Anticoagulants that can be used include:
  • Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
  • Antithrombin inhibitor - Dabigatran
  • Factor Xa inhibitors - Rivaroxaban, Apixaban, and Edoxaban
 
  • In AF patients with rheumatic mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves, the anticoagulant of choice is warfarin. The newer anticoagulants are not yet tested for rheumatic heart disease.
  • Warfarin is a less compliant drug because it requires routine PT/INR monitoring for dose adjustments and has many drug interactions. The newer oral anticoagulants are easy to use and do not require PT/INR monitoring for dose adjustments.



Anticoagulation in A. fib Trick- 
Valvular pathology- Warfarin
No valvular pathology- NOACs 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1906.

questions.text: Which of the following salivary glands is the source of deep plunging ranula?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Sublingual gland.
 
  • A ranula is a type of mucous retention cyst in the floor of the mouth.
  • It results from the obstruction of salivary gland ducts, causing the accumulation of saliva.
  • Deep plunging ranulas are a specific type of ranula that are located in the submandibular space.
  • They are caused by a leakage of saliva from the sublingual gland into the submandibular space.
  • The sublingual gland, located under the tongue, can lead to deep plunging ranulas when its saliva leaks into the submandibular space.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 833, 834.

questions.text: The Zollinger-Ellison syndrome is not diagnosed using which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Gastrin stimulation test.
 
  • Zollinger-Ellison syndrome (ZES) causes excessive production of gastrin, a hormone that stimulates stomach acid production. This can lead to ulcers in the stomach and duodenum.
  • Gastrin stimulation test is not used for ZES diagnosis due to potential false-positive results in conditions like chronic kidney disease.

The diagnosis of ZES is made using a combination of tests, including:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2453, 2454.

questions.text:
Which class of antibodies is most frequently linked to autoimmune pancreatitis?
1. IgG1
2. IgG2
3. IgG3
4. IgG4
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: IgG4
 
  • Autoimmune pancreatitis is associated with the class of antibodies known as IgG4.
  • IgG4-related disease is characterized by inflammation and fibrosis due to infiltration of tissues by IgG4-positive plasma cells.
  • Elevated levels of IgG4 antibodies are commonly observed in autoimmune pancreatitis (AIP1) and serve as an important diagnostic marker for the disease.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2664, 2666.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about osmotic diarrhoea is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Osmol gap < 50
 
  • Osmotic diarrhea is caused by osmotically active solutes in the stool, leading to watery diarrhea.
  • The osmolar gap, which measures the difference between stool and plasma osmolality, is typically greater than 50 in osmotic diarrhea.
  • Stool osmotic gap is calculated as 290 mOsm/kg − 2 × (stool Na + stool K). 290 mOsm/kg is the presumed stool osmolality, and the measured concentration of sodium and potassium cations is doubled to account for the corresponding anions which must be present.
  • The characteristic features of osmotic diarrhea:
    • Watery diarrhea. The stool is typically watery with a volume of >1 L/day.
    • Osmolar gap > 50.
    • Stool does not contain blood, pus, or mucus.
    • Stool does not contain blood, pus, or mucus.
    • Diarrhea stops after fasting. If the patient fasts, the diarrhea will stop, as there will be no food in the intestine to cause the osmotic effect.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 303.

questions.text: All stomach conditions are premalignant, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Hiatus Hernia
 
  • Hiatus hernia is not considered premalignant.
  • It is a condition where a portion of the stomach protrudes through the diaphragm into the chest cavity.
  • While hiatus hernia can cause symptoms like acid reflux, it is not directly associated with an increased risk of malignancy or cancer development in the same way that conditions like atrophic gastritis or pernicious anemia are.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 629, 630.

choices.text: May be confused with Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Menetrier disease is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Usually increased acid secretion
 
  • Menetrier disease is characterized by gross hypertrophy of the gastric mucosal folds, protein-losing gastropathy, and hypochlorhydria.
  • This disease is caused by the overexpression of TGF- alpha, which increases the growth of mucous cells.
  • The increased number of mucous cells leads to giant rugal folds.
  • The resulting excessive production of mucous in the stomach causes an increased loss of proteins and chloride from the body.
  • Patients with Menetrier disease usually present with diarrhea, hypoproteinemia, and anemia.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2458.

questions.text: Which antibodies are ordinarily high in primary biliary Cholangitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Antimitochondrial antibodies 

Primary Biliary Cholangitis (PBC)
  • PBC is an autoimmune disease characterized by nonsuppurative, inflammatory destruction of small and medium-sized intrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Large intrahepatic ducts and the extrahepatic biliary tree are not involved.
  • Disease of middle-aged women, with a female predominance of 9:1.
  • Antimitochondrial antibodies are the most characteristic laboratory finding in PBC.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2627.

questions.text: Which is an exception to Large bowel Colonic Diarrhea associations?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Large Volume stool 

Large Volume stool: In large bowel colonic diarrhea, the stool volume is typically reduced due to impaired water reabsorption in the colon.

Features of Large bowel colonic diarrhea :
  • Urgency: There is a sudden and strong urge to have a bowel movement.
  • Tenesmus: The feeling of incomplete evacuation and persistent desire to pass stool, even after bowel movements.
  • Mucus: Presence of mucus in the stool.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 298, 299.

questions.text: Congenital Hypertrophy of Retinal Pigment Epithelium (CHRPE) is associated with which of the Gastrointestinal Polyposis syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Gardner's syndrome 
 
  • Congenital hypertrophy of retinal pigment epithelium (CHRPE) presents with pigmented ocular fundus and is usually associated with familial adenomatous polyposis, and Gardner's syndrome is a subtype of familial adenomatous polyposis (FAP), a gastrointestinal polyposis syndrome caused by mutations in the APC gene.
  • CHRPE is often found in individuals with Gardner's syndrome, making it a significant clinical feature in the diagnosis of this gastrointestinal polyposis syndrome.



Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1356.

questions.text: Which is the best provocative test for diagnosis of Gastrinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Secretin injection test 
 
  • Gastrinoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor that produces excess gastrin, a hormone stimulating stomach acid production.
  • The secretin injection test is used to diagnose gastrinoma by injecting secretin and measuring gastrin levels in the blood afterward.
  • Secretin is a hormone released by the pancreas to regulate stomach acid production in response to food intake.
  • The most sensitive and specific gastrin provocative test for the diagnosis of gastrinoma is the secretin study. An increase in gastrin of ≥120 pg within 15 min of secretin injection has a sensitivity and specificity of >90% for Gastrinoma in ZES. 

Other options:
  • Infusion test: Measures pancreatic function
  • ACTH stimulation test: Assesses adrenal gland function
  • Steroid assay: Measures steroid levels in the blood.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2454.

questions.text: Chronic liver disease can be associated with which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Alpha-1 Antitrypsin deficiency 
 
  • Alpha-1 antitrypsin (AAT) is a protein that helps to protect the lungs from damage.
  • People with alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency do not produce enough AAT, which can lead to damage to the lungs and liver.
  • Chronic liver disease is a condition in which the liver is damaged over a long period of time. It can be caused by a number of factors, including alcohol abuse, hepatitis, and alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.

Other options:
  • Hepatitis A: Viral infection that can cause acute liver inflammation.
  • Chronic malaria: Can cause liver damage, but it is not as common as alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency.
  • Infectious mononucleosis: Viral infection that can cause inflammation of the lymph nodes, but it does not typically affect the liver.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2591, 2624.

questions.text: Celiac disease has which of the following vitamin deficiencies as uncommon?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4:  Vitamin B12
 
  • Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder that damages the small intestine when gluten is ingested.
  • Gluten is a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye.
  • The damaged small intestine is unable to absorb certain nutrients properly, leading to various deficiencies.
  • In celiac disease, it is uncommon to have a deficiency in Vitamin B12. Vitamin B12 deficiency is more frequently associated with other gastrointestinal disorders that affect the absorption of this vitamin.
  • Vit B12 absorption mainly happens in Ileum, which is unaffected in Celiac disease. Celiac diseases predominantly affects Duodenum followed by jejunum. Jejunum is the principal site of Folate absorption.

The other common vitamin deficiencies associated with celiac disease include:
 
  1. Vitamin D
  2. Folic Acid (Vitamin B9)
  3. Vitamin A



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2460.

questions.text: Which medication is prescribed for constipating-related irritable bowel syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Lubiprostone
