Lubiprostone is a chloride channel activator. It promotes the secretion of water and chloride into the bowel and improves bowel movements. It is effective in the treatment of constipation predominant IBS.

Other options:
 
  • Cholestyramine resin – used in the treatment of diarrhea-predominant IBS.
  • Alosetron, a 5 HT3 receptor antagonist used in the treatment of IBS relieves pain and abdominal discomfort. It causes constipation in IBS patients with diarrhea alternating with constipation.
  • Rifaximin is a RNA synthesis inhibitor approved for use in diarrhea-predominant IBS.

IBS management:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2496.

questions.text: An individual receiving ketoconazole treatment for a fungus develops gastroesophageal reflux illness (GERD). Which medication from the list below shouldn't be given to him?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Cisapride
 
  • Cisapride is a prokinetic agent. Its prokinetic action is exerted mainly through 5-HT4 agonism aided by weak 5-HT3 antagonism.
  • It enhances gastrointestinal motility and is often used to treat conditions like GERD and gastroparesis.
  • However, cisapride has a potential interaction with ketoconazole, which can lead to an increased risk of life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias (specifically, QT prolongation).
  • Due to this risk, cisapride should not be given to individuals who are taking ketoconazole or other medications that can prolong the QT interval.
  • Metoclopromide and Domperidone may also cause QTc prolongation but its frequency and severity is much less Cisapride

Drugs causing QT prolongation: 





Prokinetics :





Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 715, 716.

questions.text: Which of the following vitamin deficiencies occurs most frequently in short bowel syndrome with ileal resection?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Vitamin B12 (Cyanocobalamin)
 
  • Short bowel syndrome is a condition that occurs when a significant portion of the small intestine is surgically removed or non-functional, leading to malabsorption of nutrients.
  • The ileum, the last part of the small intestine, is essential for the absorption of vitamin B12.
  • In cases of ileal resection, the absorption of vitamin B12 is impaired, resulting in a deficiency of this vitamin.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to various symptoms and complications, including megaloblastic anemia, neurological issues, and gastrointestinal problems.
  • Absorption of Fat soluble vitamins are also impaired




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2465, 2466.

questions.text: The most typical vitamin deficiency associated with short bowel syndrome is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Vitamin B12
 
  • Short bowel syndrome is a condition that occurs when a significant portion of the small intestine is surgically removed or non-functional, leading to malabsorption of nutrients.
  • The ileum, the last part of the small intestine, is essential for the absorption of vitamin B12.
  • In cases of ileal resection, the absorption of vitamin B12 is impaired, resulting in a deficiency of this vitamin.
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to various symptoms and complications, including megaloblastic anemia, neurological issues, and gastrointestinal problems.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2465, 2466.

questions.text: A man comes in with a history of hematemesis involving 500 ml of blood. Spleen is detectable on inspection 5 cm below the left costal border. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Portal Hypertension
 
  • Portal hypertension: Increased pressure in the portal vein, which carries blood from the intestines to the liver.
  • When portal hypertension is present, it can lead to the development of varices (dilated veins) in the esophagus and stomach, which are prone to bleeding.
  • Hematemesis (vomiting of blood) is a common symptom in patients with portal hypertension and ruptured esophageal or gastric varices.
  • The detectable spleen below the left costal border is known as splenomegaly and is often associated with portal hypertension.

Causes of portal HTN :



Varices:




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2629.

questions.text: Earliest sign/symptom of GB carcinoma?
questions.solution:
• Patients may be asymptomatic at the time of diagnosis.
  • Symptoms, if present, are usually undistinguished from those of Benign GB disease such as biliary colic or cholecystitis, particularly in older patients.
  • Jaundice & anemia are late features and a palpable mass is a very late sign.


The earliest symptom is typically colicky pain (biliary colic), usually in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen. This pain may result from intermittent obstruction of the bile duct or inflammation associated with gallbladder stones, a common coexisting condition.


Other options:
 
  1. Jaundice:
    • Occurs later in the disease due to biliary obstruction from tumor growth or metastasis.
  2. Palpable mass:
    • A palpable mass indicates significant tumor growth or advanced disease.
  3. Ascites:
    • A late manifestation, often due to peritoneal spread or advanced-stage disease.

Significance:
 

Early diagnosis of gallbladder carcinoma is challenging because of its vague symptoms. Patients with risk factors (e.g., gallstones, porcelain gallbladder, or chronic cholecystitis) presenting with persistent or unusual colicky pain should be evaluated for GBC.



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1258.

questions.text:
Patient is referred with necrotizing acute pancreatitis with collection on CECT. Abdomen patient is on vasopressor with BP=90/60 mmHg. What are the initial things you will do? 
(a) Laparotomy and Necrosectomy 
(b) MRI to visualize the pancreatic ducts 
(c) Percutaneous aspiration of fluid under image guidance 
(d) IV antibiotics
questions.solution:
• Step up approach is used in management of infected necrosis.
  • Percutaneous drainage is done under the guidance of pigtail catheter along with minimally invasive retroperitoneal debridement.
  • Open necrosectomy has high mortality rate. Once infection has been demonstrated, IV antibiotics should be given.
  • Because of their penetration into the pancreas and spectrum coverage, carbapenems are the first option of treatment.
 

  • (c) Percutaneous aspiration of fluid under image guidance:

    • This is performed to confirm infection in the pancreatic or peripancreatic collection by obtaining fluid for culture and sensitivity.
    • It is a minimally invasive approach suitable for critically ill patients.
 

  • (d) IV antibiotics:

    • If infection is confirmed or highly suspected, empiric broad-spectrum antibiotics are initiated to control sepsis. Common choices include carbapenems (e.g., meropenem) for their coverage against gram-negative bacteria and anaerobes.



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1538-1540.

choices.text: Most of the cases of CA-stomach are hereditary
Intestinal variety is caused by CDH1 gene mutation
Depth of invasion has no prognostic value

questions.text: Which of the following is the correct statement related to CA-stomach?
questions.solution:
1. Hereditary cases (Option 1):

    • Most cases of gastric carcinoma are sporadic, not hereditary. However, hereditary diffuse gastric cancer (HDGC) is a subtype associated with CDH1 gene mutations.
    • Sporadic gastric cancers are often linked to environmental factors like H. pylori infection, diet, and smoking.

  2. E-Cadherin loss (Option 2):

    • The diffuse variety of gastric cancer is associated with the loss of E-Cadherin, a protein encoded by the CDH1 gene. This leads to loss of cell adhesion and increased invasiveness.
    • Diffuse gastric cancer typically presents as poorly cohesive cells, often signet-ring cells, and is not associated with gland formation.

  3. Intestinal variety and CDH1 mutation (Option 3):

    • The intestinal type of gastric cancer is associated with chronic H. pylori infection, atrophic gastritis, and intestinal metaplasia, not primarily CDH1 mutations.

  4. Depth of invasion and prognosis (Option 4):

    • The depth of invasion is a critical prognostic factor in gastric cancer. Tumors that invade deeper layers (e.g., serosa) are associated with a poorer prognosis.



Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st edition, Page no 1219-1222.

questions.text: A patient completed triple drug regimen for H.Pylori. Which investigation will be best to assess treatment response?
questions.solution:
For treatment follow up, Breath urease test is the most sensitive test.
 

The urea breath test (UBT) is the most reliable, non-invasive method to assess the eradication of H. pylori after treatment.

  • High Sensitivity and Specificity: UBT detects active infection by measuring urease activity, an enzyme produced by H. pylori.
  • Non-Invasive: Unlike endoscopic biopsy, it does not require an invasive procedure.
  • Timing: It is recommended 4–6 weeks after completing therapy to allow clearance of dead bacteria and to avoid false-negative results due to residual antibiotics or proton pump inhibitors (PPIs).

Other options:
 

  1. Biopsy urease test:

    • Requires endoscopy and is invasive.
    • May produce false negatives if sampling is inadequate or if the patient is on PPIs or antibiotics.

  2. Upper GI endoscopy:

    • Primarily used for diagnosing complications like ulcers or malignancy, not for treatment response monitoring.

  3. Serology:

    • Detects antibodies to H. pylori, but cannot differentiate between active and past infection.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 1279-1281.

questions.text: An IT Engineer patient present with complaints of hematemesis and melena. He has a history of epigastric pain intermittently for a long period of time. He takes alcohol occasionally. He is currently taking aspirin for his arthritis.What is the cause of the patient’s symptoms?
questions.solution:
The patient with a history of intermittent gastric pain with:
  • Consumption of alcohol
  • NSAID intake and
  • A stressful lifestyle (IT engineer)
The patient develops hematemesis and melena, features of upper GI bleeding. In light of multiple risk factors and clinical presentation, the patient most likely has peptic ulcer disease.
Peptic ulcers are the most common cause of upper GI bleeding and UGIB is the most common complication of peptic ulcer disease.

Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 1153, 1206.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient presented with vague RUQ pain and weight loss. The AST and ALT levels are normal, ALP levels are 200 and direct bilirubin is 1 mg. The AFP levels are raised. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient with a history of alcohol dependence, unintentional weight loss, normal transaminases and raised AFP most likely has hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC), which is the most common cause of a primary liver malignancy in adults.
The features are as follows:
  • More commonly seen in males
  • Peak age group is 7th decade of life
  • Risk factors for HCC are:
    • Cirrhosis and associated chronic liver damage due to:
      • Chronic infection by hepatitis B or C virus (HBV or HCV)
      • Alcohol abuse
      • Metabolic syndrome
      • Hemochromatosis.
Management:
  • Very early HCC: Ablation
  • Early HCC:
    • Single nodule: Resected
    • Multiple nodules over 3 cm: Ablation or transplantation are considered.
  • Intermediate-stage HCC: Chemoembolization.
    • Transarterial chemoembolization (TACE) is used for multinodular lesions.
Reference: Sabiston Textbook of Surgery, 21st Edition, Page. No- 681.

questions.text: 40 y old man visits Gastromedicine OPD with 2-3 episodes of blood in stools. Patient was evaluated and diagnosed to have ulcerative colitis. What would be the initial line of management?
questions.solution:
5- AminoSalycyclic acid is the first line drug used in management of mild to moderate Ulcerative Colitis.

  • Ulcerative colitis is an inflammatory bowel disease resulting in superficial erosions confined to the mucosa and submucosa of the colon. It starts from the rectum and extends approximately in a continuous manner. The clinical features includes abdominal pain diarrhea rectal bleeding tenesmus and passage of mucus other symptoms includes anorexia nausea vomiting fever and weight loss.
  • Glucocorticoids are indicated in moderate to severe disease.
  • Surgery is indicated in patients who do not improve after medical management or those with toxic mega colon or perforation or malignancy and growth retardation, extra intestinal disease.
  • Azathioprine and Cyclosporin are used as steroid sparing agents.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2263, 2273.

questions.text: An obese man with history of right upper quadrant pain comes to your OPD after his AST/ALT levels were mildly elevated. You order an USG which shows Grade 2 steatosis. He gives history of consuming 2-3 drinks per week. How would you manage him?
questions.solution:
The given history of Obesity + <5 drinks per week +elevated AST and ALT is suggestive of Non alcoholic Fatty liver disease.
First line management for NAFLD is Lifestyle modifications and weight loss and Vitamin E. 
Non alcoholic fat liver disease is associated with diabetes and obesity the fatty change may also be caused due to the effect of toxins proteins malnutrition dyslipidemia and anorexia. Play all my sin methotrexate, doxycycline  is other drugs causing hepatitis steatosis.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2622.

questions.text: A male patient complains of loss of appetite and dysphagia. He lost around significant amount weight in the last few months. The clinician suspects an esophageal condition. Which of the following is the gold standard investigation method in this patient?
questions.solution:
A male patient with progressive dysphagia, loss of appetite, and significant weight loss raises strong suspicion of esophageal carcinoma.

In such a scenario, the gold standard investigation for diagnosis is Upper GI endoscopy (esophagogastroduodenoscopy, EGD).

During endoscopy:

  • The esophagus is directly visualized to locate the lesion.

  • Biopsy samples can be taken for histopathological confirmation, which is essential for diagnosis.

    Other options:

  • Esophageal manometry:
    Measures esophageal motility and sphincter pressures — used in motility disorders like achalasia cardia, not malignancy.

  • Barium study:
    Can show “rat-tail” or “apple-core” narrowing suggestive of carcinoma, but it is not confirmatory — it’s only a screening tool.

  • CECT (Contrast-Enhanced CT):
    Useful for staging (extent of spread, lymph node involvement, metastasis) after diagnosis, not for the initial confirmation.

choices.text: Start IV pantoprazole and antiemetics stabilise the patient with IV fluids, electrolyte correction
Order a liver biopsy to assess fibrosis

questions.text: What is the first line of management in a chronic alcoholic having chronic liver disease, presenting with altered mental status and Hematemesis?
questions.solution:
The management of esophageal variceal bleeding involves:
Resuscitation with IV fluids, airway protection(intubation to protect airway and prevent aspiration), and oxygen
Blood transfusion to maintain Hb between 7-9g/dL
Antibiotic prophylaxis with ceftriaxone before endoscopy .
An attempt at hemostasis with octreotide or terlipressin or vasopressin
Upper GI endoscopy within 12 hours after fluid resuscitation to confirm the source of the bleed
Endoscopic variceal band ligation or sclerotherapy
In case, of failure or rebleeding - Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS)

Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of surgery, 28th Edition, Page No 1168,1204.

questions.text: In comparison to Ulcerative colitis, Crohns disease is associated with
questions.solution:
• Patients with Crohns are less likely to produce Hematochezia in comparison to patients with Ulcerative Colitis.
  • Rest of the statements are seen more with Ulcerative colitis.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2476-2478.

questions.text:
A patient presents with severe vomiting and diarrhea and has orthostatic hypotension. What metabolic abnormalities would you expect in this patient?
A. Hypokalemia
B. Hypochloremia
C. Metabolic alkalosis
D. Respiratory alkalosis
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario describes a patient with a history of vomiting and diarrhea, now presenting with orthostatic hypotension, indicating dehydration and extracellular fluid volume contraction. This triggers activation of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS).

As aldosterone levels rise, it leads to increased excretion of hydrogen (H?) and potassium (K?) in the distal tubule of the kidneys, resulting in hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis. The alkalosis is further aggravated by angiotensin II, which stimulates the Na?-H? exchanger in the proximal convoluted tubule, increasing the reabsorption of sodium (Na?) and bicarbonate (HCO??).

Hypochloremia arises from the loss of hydrochloric acid (HCl) due to vomiting and is perpetuated by renal chloride (Cl?) loss, which accompanies increased bicarbonate reabsorption.

In metabolic alkalosis, the body‘s compensatory response is respiratory acidosis, not respiratory alkalosis. This occurs through hypoventilation, which leads to an increase in arterial carbon dioxide (PaCO?) levels.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 365 .

questions.text: A 29-year-old male patient presents to the OPD with a 10-year history of coarse facial features and progressive enlargement of the hands and feet. Laboratory evaluation revealed elevated IGF-1 and non-suppressible growth hormone levels after the 75 g glucose challenge test. A diagnosis of acromegaly is made. Which of the following drugs is preferred for the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Lanreotide depot formulation is effective in managing acromegaly.

Acromegaly typically results from a growth hormone (GH)-secreting somatotroph adenoma, leading to increased GH and insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1) levels. This excess causes acral bone overgrowth. Common physical signs include frontal bossing, enlarged hands and feet, mandibular enlargement with prognathism, and wider spacing between lower incisor teeth. Soft tissue swelling manifests as increased heel pad thickness, tight rings, coarse facial features, and a large, fleshy nose.

Cardiovascular complications are significant in acromegaly, often presenting as cardiomyopathy, arrhythmias, left ventricular hypertrophy, diastolic dysfunction, and hypertension.

Other clinical features include obstructive sleep apnea and diabetes mellitus.

Diagnosis involves measuring serum IGF-1 levels and performing a GH suppression test with oral glucose. In acromegaly, GH levels do not decrease in response to a glucose load.

Surgical management is preferred, with transsphenoidal surgery being the standard treatment for GH-secreting adenomas. Medical therapy includes long-acting somatostatin receptor ligands (SRLs) such as depot formulations of octreotide and lanreotide, or oral octreotide capsules. Additionally, pegvisomant, a GH receptor antagonist, is another effective treatment that blocks GH actions.

Other options:

  • Ketoconazole 

    • Used in Cushing’s disease (blocks steroid synthesis), not in acromegaly.

  • Terlipressin 

    • V1 receptor agonist, used in variceal bleed & hepatorenal syndrome, not acromegaly.

  • Leuprolide 

    • GnRH agonist, used in prostate cancer, endometriosis, fibroids, not acromegaly.

questions.text: Elective splenectomy is preferred in which of the following conditions? G6PD deficiency- Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency
questions.solution:
Elective splenectomy is indicated for patients with hereditary spherocytosis.

Hereditary spherocytosis is a hereditary hemolytic anemia that is inherited in an autosomal dominant manner. It is caused by mutations in red blood cell surface proteins, such as spectrin and ankyrin, which result in unstable cell membranes and subsequent hemolysis.

This condition can manifest at a young age with symptoms like severe jaundice and fatigue. Patients often experience unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, which increases the risk of developing gallstones.

Laboratory findings typically reveal normocytic anemia and unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia. A peripheral blood smear will display large, spherical red blood cells lacking central pallor. Diagnosis can be confirmed through the acid glycerol lysis test and the eosin-5'-maleimide (EMA)-binding test.

Currently, there is no specific treatment other than splenectomy. However, due to potential adverse effects, it is usually recommended only for severe cases and in moderate cases after the child has reached puberty. Post-splenectomy care should include appropriate antibiotic and vaccine prophylaxis.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a component of Child-Pugh scoring?
questions.solution:
Child-Pugh scoring is used to assess prognosis in chronic liver disease and cirrhosis.
It includes five parameters:

  1. Bilirubin

  2. Albumin

  3. Prothrombin time (or INR)

  4. Ascites

  5. Hepatic encephalopathy

  • While bilirubin, albumin, and PT/INR are part of standard liver function tests (LFTs) individually, the term “liver function tests” as a whole (including AST, ALT, ALP, GGT, etc.) is NOT a component of the Child-Pugh score.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presents with jerky movements of her extremities for 1 week. She has typical hand movements(wing beating tremor aka flapping tremor). She also complains of pain in multiple joints. Vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination reveals jaundice. Which of the following is the gold standard for diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with wing-beating tremor, joint pain, and jaundice, suggesting Wilson’s disease (copper accumulation disorder).

  • Genetic testing for mutations in the ATP7B gene is considered the gold standard for diagnosis.

  • It can confirm the disease even before clinical manifestations appear and is definitive.

Other options:

  • Serum ferritin: Elevated in iron overload disorders, not Wilson’s disease.

  • Urinary copper: Useful for diagnosis and monitoring therapy but not the gold standard.

  • Liver biopsy: Can measure hepatic copper and supports diagnosis, but it is invasive and now largely replaced by genetic confirmation when available.



Reference
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition - Page NO 2984-2030

questions.text: A female patient with celiac disease is recommended a gluten-free diet. Which among the following can she consume?
questions.solution:
Celiac disease is an autoimmune disorder triggered by gluten, a protein found in wheat, barley, and rye.

  • Rice: Naturally gluten-free; safe for patients with celiac disease.

  • Oats: Pure oats are gluten-free, but cross-contamination with wheat is common; only certified gluten-free oats are recommended.

  • Barley: Contains gluten; must be avoided.

  • Wheat: Contains gluten; must be avoided.

Thus, among the given options, rice is safe for a gluten-free diet.



Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 2251

questions.text: Following gastrectomy, the patient is most likely to have which of the following?
questions.solution:
• Gastrectomy removes parietal cells → ↓ intrinsic factor → impaired absorption of Vitamin B12 in terminal ileum → megaloblastic anemia.

    Why not the other options?

  1. Gastric ulcer

  • After gastrectomy, the stomach is largely or completely removed.

  • Patient may develop marginal ulcers at the anastomotic site, but not typical gastric ulcers.

  1. Constipation

  • Not a classical complication. Post-gastrectomy problems are more commonly dumping syndrome, diarrhea, and malabsorption, not constipation.

  1. Folic acid deficiency

  • Folic acid is absorbed in the jejunum, which remains intact after gastrectomy.

  • Hence, deficiency is not typical unless there is generalized malnutrition.


Reference:Ganongs review of medical physiology 26th edition page no 470,478

questions.text: A man was working in a field and he suddenly collapsed on a hot summer afternoon. On examination, there were no physical signs of dehydration but radial pulse was present. His serum electrolytes level was normal. The doctor found that the body temperature was 106 degrees Fahrenheit. Which of the following should be given as first aid in this case?
questions.solution:
The man is experiencing heat stroke, which is a medical emergency characterized by:

  • Very high body temperature (>104°F or >40°C)

  • Altered mental status or collapse

  • No signs of dehydration may still be present

  • Normal electrolytes do not rule out heat stroke

    First Aid Management of Heat Stroke:

  • Immediate cooling is the priority

  • Methods include:

    • Covering with cool damp sheets

    • Spraying with water and using fans

    • Ice packs to groin, neck, and axilla

    • Immersion in cold water (if feasible and safe)

      Incorrect Options:

  • Inject epinephrine: Used for anaphylaxis, not for heat stroke

  • Start CPR: Not required unless patient is unresponsive with no pulse

  • Cover with hot damp sheets: Will worsen hyperthermia

    Key Point:

In classic heat stroke, especially in elderly or outdoor workers, the first aid is rapid body cooling, ideally by cool damp sheets or cold water immersion, to prevent multi-organ failure.


Reference: Essentials of Forensic medicine and toxicology 33rd edition page no 310

choices.text: 4 mg/dL, unconjugated bilirubin 2.1mg/dl, conjugated bilirubin is 0.3mg/dl. Serum AST and ALT levels are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 20-year-old male presented with a 1-week history of yellow skin and sclerae but is otherwise asymptomatic. He gives a history of viral infection for 10 days which resolved 2 days back. There is a history of a similar episode of icterus 2 years back for a period of 2 weeks. On further questioning, he adds that he used to have long basketball practice hours 2 years back and he used to be physically drained during that period. The current serum bilirubin is 2.4 mg/dL, unconjugated bilirubin 2.1mg/dl, conjugated bilirubin is 0.3mg/dl. Serum AST and ALT levels are normal. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Young male with intermittent jaundice

  • Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia (2.1 mg/dL of 2.4 total)

  • Normal liver enzymes (AST/ALT)

  • Precipitated by stress/physical exertion or infection

  • Past similar self-limiting episode

  • Asymptomatic otherwise
    Gilbert Syndrome – Highlights:

  • Common benign hereditary condition (↓ activity of UDP-glucuronosyltransferase)

  • Causes mild, intermittent unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia

  • Often triggered by:

    • Stress

    • Fasting

    • Illness

    • Strenuous exercise

  • No liver damage

  • No specific treatment needed

    Why others are incorrect:

  • Rotor Syndrome: Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, no black liver, rare

  • Dubin-Johnson Syndrome: Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia, black liver pigment

  • Crigler-Najjar Syndrome Type I: Severe, presents in infancy, very high unconjugated bilirubin (>20 mg/dL), risk of kernicterus


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 277,278,2345

questions.text: It was discovered that a 50-year-old smoker and hypertensive had non-small cell lung cancer with brain metastases. He is taking hydrochlorothiazide and enalapril to treat his hypertension. Upon examination, he had blood pressure of 150/90 mm Hg, blood sugar of 112 mg/dL, serum sodium of 120 mg/dL, urinary sodium of 110 mg/dL, serum creatinine of 0.8 mg/dL, serum osmolarity of 255 mOsm/L, urine osmolarity of 350 mOsm/L, and urinary K+ of 9 mg/dL. What of the following is most likely to be the reason for his hyponatremia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: SIADH

SIADH is a condition characterized by excessive release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH), also known as vasopressin, resulting in water retention and dilutional hyponatremia.

The key findings supporting SIADH in this case are:
  1. Serum sodium of 120 mg/dL: The low serum sodium level indicates hyponatremia.
  2. Urinary sodium of 110 mg/dL: In SIADH, the kidneys retain sodium, leading to increased urinary sodium excretion.
  3. Normal serum creatinine: Normal kidney function suggests that the hyponatremia is not due to impaired renal clearance.
  4. Euvolemic status: The absence of volume overload or depletion suggests a normal fluid balance.
  5. Normal serum osmolarity: A low serum osmolarity is expected in SIADH due to water retention without dilutional changes in other solutes.
 
  • Cerebral salt wasting (option 1) is a condition characterized by excessive renal sodium loss due to brain injury or intracranial pathology. It is typically associated with  hypovolemia, which are not consistent with the patient's presentation.
 
  • Diuretic-induced hyponatremia (option 2) is possible when diuretics, such as hydrochlorothiazide, cause excessive urinary sodium and water loss. However, the patient's urinary sodium level is not consistent with this scenario.
 
  • Pseudohyponatremia (option 4) refers to a laboratory artifact where the measured serum sodium level appears low due to abnormal levels of lipids or proteins in the blood. The patient's clinical presentation and laboratory findings are not suggestive of pseudohyponatremia.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 723, 2924, 2925.

questions.text: TSH is raised in a female patient and the free T4 level is below normal.What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Primary hypothyroidism
 
  • Primary hypothyroidism refers to a condition in which the thyroid gland is unable to produce an adequate amount of thyroid hormones.
  • This results in elevated TSH levels as the pituitary gland releases more TSH in an attempt to stimulate the thyroid gland.
  • However, the thyroid gland fails to produce enough free T4 (thyroxine), leading to low levels of free T4 in the blood.It is not subclinical as free T4 level is below normal.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2933-2936.

questions.text: What does high calcium intake lead to?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Milk-Alkali syndrome

High calcium intake can lead to the development of Milk-Alkali Syndrome. This condition occurs due to excessive consumption of calcium-containing products, such as milk or calcium supplements, combined with excessive intake of absorbable alkali (such as antacids containing calcium carbonate). The syndrome is characterized by the triad of hypercalcemia (high levels of calcium in the blood), metabolic alkalosis (high pH of the blood), and kidney dysfunction.

The other options listed are not directly associated with high calcium intake.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3173.

choices.text: Start antithyroid drugs, and do urgent MRI brain
Start antithyroid drugs and wait for symptoms to resolve

questions.text: A young woman had high FT4 and TSH level of 8.5 IU/l and hyperthyroidism symptoms. Bitemporal hemianopia is discovered upon closer inspection. What will be the next line of action?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Start antithyroid drugs, and do an urgent MRI brain.
 
  • Bitemporal hemianopia with hyperthyroidism (elevated TSH and T4) is highly suggestive of Central hyperthyroidism due to TSH-secreting adenoma. MRI should be done to confirm the diagnosis of pituitary adenoma. 
 
  • Patients usually present with thyroid goiter and hyperthyroidism, reflecting chronic overproduction of TSH.
  • Diagnosis is based on demonstrating elevated serum free T4 levels, inappropriately normal or high TSH secretion, and MRI evidence of a pituitary adenoma.
  • Elevated free glycoprotein hormone α subunits are seen in many patients.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2917, 2918.

questions.text:
A 16-year-old female patient was admitted with primary amenorrhea. Her mother stated that when she was 12 years old, she first began to develop breasts.
A doctor gave her OCPs two years ago, but they had no impact. She played football and was of average height. Examination revealed minimal pubic hair (Tanner's stage 1) and well-developed breasts (Tanner's stage 5). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Androgen insensitivity syndrome

Most likely diagnosis in a 16-year old girl who presents with primary amenorrhea, normal sexual development, normal breasts (Tanner stage 5) but minimal pubic hair (Tanner stage I) is androgen insensitivity syndrome.

Androgen Insensitivity Syndrome: Because the testes produce normal amounts of mullerian-inhibiting factor (MlF), also known as mullerian-inhibiting substance (MIS) or anti-mullerian hormone/factor (AMH/AMF), affected individuals do not have fallopian tubes, a uterus, or a proximal (upper) vagina.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3002, 3003.

questions.text: What other research might you suggest in galactorrhoea-amenorrhea disorders other than serum prolactin?
questions.solution:
Apart from prolactin, TSH should be advised in a patient of galactorrhea-amenorrhea syndrome. 
 
  • Basal, fasting morning PRL levels (normally <20 μg/L) should be measured to assess hypersecretion. Both false-positive and false-negative results may be encountered.
 
  • Galactorrhea and Amenorrhea are commonly associated with hyperprolactinemia caused by many conditions.
 
  • Hypothyroidism should be excluded by measuring TSH and T4 levels.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2909.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman has several lytic bone lesions, a fractured clavicle, and second and third metatarsal periosteal resorption. Which diagnosis is most likely
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Hyperparathyroidism
 
  • Hyperparathyroidism is a condition characterized by excessive secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) from the parathyroid glands, leading to increased bone resorption and thus increased levels of calcium in the blood (hypercalcemia). It's classical symptoms is explained by bones, stones, groans and psychiatric overtones. 
  • This can result in various bone abnormalities and manifestations, including osteoporosis, bone pain, fractures, and periosteal resorption.
  • The presence of lytic bone lesions, fractured clavicle, and periosteal resorption of the metatarsals suggests a significant bone pathology.
  • Hyperparathyroidism can cause bone resorption, leading to the development of lytic lesions and increased risk of fractures.
  • Additionally, periosteal resorption is a characteristic finding in hyperparathyroidism, where the outer layer of bone (periosteum) becomes thickened and shows evidence of increased bone remodeling.








Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3175, 3176.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient had spade-like fingers, frontal bossing, an expanded jaw, and an enlarged nasal bone. Which of the subsequent tests will you perform to make a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  IGF1
  • The clinical presentation of spade-like fingers, frontal bossing, an expanded jaw, and an enlarged nasal bone are characteristic features of Acromegaly.
  • It is a hormonal disorder caused by the excessive production of GH in adulthood, usually due to a pituitary adenoma which leads to increased production of IGF1, which is a growth factor that mediates the effects of GH on tissues.
 
  • Measuring IGF1 levels is an important diagnostic test for acromegaly. Elevated levels of IGF1 in the blood are indicative of excessive GH production.
  • However, the diagnosis of acromegaly requires additional confirmatory testing, such as an oral glucose tolerance test (OGTT) and measurement of GH levels.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2912.

questions.text: For two days, a patient has been exhibiting escalating muscle weakness. Examining the limb reveals it to be flaccid. Which investigation should be carried out first?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Serum potassium

The presenting symptoms of escalating muscle weakness and flaccid limb raise concerns about potential electrolyte abnormalities, specifically hypokalemia (low serum potassium levels). Hypokalemia can cause muscle weakness and affect muscle function, leading to flaccid paralysis.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 350, 3530.

questions.text: The image below is of a thyroid scan. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Toxic adenoma

The photo shows a hot nodule








Reference: Bailey & Love’s Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 854, 868.
Grainger & Allison’s Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1634, 1635.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of glucocorticoid deficiency?
questions.solution:
Diabetes is NOT a feature of Glucocorticoid deficiency as glucocorticoids cause hyperglycemia. Rest all are features of Glucocorticoid deficiency.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2972.

questions.text: A diabetic and hypertensive patient on multiple medications developed septicemia. The creatinine level in the blood is 5.7 mg/dl. Which of the following medications should be discontinued?
questions.solution:
Metformin should be stopped in this case.

Contraindications of Metflormin:
 
  • Serum creatinine >1.5 mg/dL (men) >1.4 mg/dL (women)
  • eGFR < 30 ml/min
  • CHE
  • Radiographic contrast studies
  • Hospitalized patients
  • Acidosis


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3110.

questions.text:
A diabetic woman who was morbidly obese was on failed metformin therapy. She has had pancreatitis and has a family history of bladder cancer.
The patient is unwilling to receive injections. Which of the following options would be best for lowering her glucose levels?
questions.solution:
Orally administered canagliflozin is a Sodium-Glucose Cotransporter 2 Inhibitor and also causes weight loss. 
 
  • Sitagliptin raises the risk of acute pancreatitis
  • use of Pioglitazone is linked to a slight elevated risk of bladder cancer  and
  • Liraglutide is administered subcutaneously by injections

Canagliflozin is the preferred medication for the clinical scenario at hand. It also helps in weight reduction in obese diabetic patients.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3110.

questions.text: One of the two patients with atherosclerosis has diabetes, whereas the other does not. Diabetic patients are 100 times more likely than non-diabetics to have:
questions.solution:
• The incidence of lower limb ischemia is increased 100 times in patients with diabetes due to the hardened and narrowed arteries caused by high levels of sugar present in the bloodstream.
 
  • The narrowing of the arteries reduces the amount of blood that flows to the lower limbs, thereby increasing the risk of decreased oxygen levels to the limbs and leading to tissue damage.
 
  • The high blood sugar levels also make the blood more viscous, causing it to flow more slowly and resulting in greater chance of a blockage and lower limb ischemia.
  • Other complications are also increased but not 100 times as limb ischemia


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3127.

questions.text: What conditions are related to these two images?
questions.solution:
The lower leg's anterior and lateral surfaces were found to have an inflammatory, indurated plaque with a deep pink or purple color and a "orange skin" appearance.

This may point to the presence of pretibial myxedema, a condition that is seen in patients with Grave's disease (hyperthyroidism).
 
  • In 5% of Graves' disease patients, thyroid dermopathy develops, nearly invariably alongside moderate or severe ophthalmopathy.
 
  • Skin alterations can occur at other areas as well, especially following trauma, despite the fact that they are most common over the anterior and lateral portions of the lower leg (hence the term pretibial myxedema).
 
  • The typical lesion is an indurated, non-inflamed plaque with a "orange skin" look and a deep pink or purple tint. The illness can occasionally spread across the entire lower leg and foot, imitating elephantiasis, and nodules may become involved.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2939.

questions.text: Which of the following results in the following skin changes?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Diabetes mellitus

The presented lesions are indurated, annular, yellowish brown plaques on the shin that are very suggestive of necrosis lipoidica diabeticorum.
 
  • They have an atrophic center and ectatic blood vessels that are visible through the thinner skin (seen in diabetes mellitus).
  • Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum is a rare disorder that primarily affects young women with diabetes.
  • This typically starts as an erythematous plaque or papule in the pretibial region and progresses to larger, darker lesions with uneven edges, atrophic cores, and central ulceration. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3128.

questions.text: A 20-year-old average-weight female complains of oligomenorrhoea along with facial hair. An initial investigation reveals elevated free testosterone levels. On ultrasound, the ovaries were normal. Which of the following could be a likely etiology?
questions.solution:
Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome (PCOS) is the most likely etiology in a 20-year-old average-weight female with complaints of oligomenorrhea (irregular menstrual cycle) and facial hirsutism (excessive facial hair) with raised free testosterone levels (suggesting hyperandrogenism) and normal appearance of ovaries on ultrasound.
She meets two out of the three Rotterdam criteria for PCOS and hence, it's the most likely diagnosis. 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3036.
Shaw’s Textbook of Gynaecology, 17th edition, Page no 314, 315.

questions.text: A diabetic patient, age 55, comes with brief vision impairment that lasts for two to three days until it is abruptly erased. Which test from the list below would be most effective in determining his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The above scenario signifies Amaurosis fugax i.e transient vision loss can be sign of Hyperhomocysteinemia.
 
  • Hyperhomocysteinemia refers to increased total plasma concentration of homocysteine with or without an increase in free homocysteine(disulfide form).
  • Homocysteine can act as an atherogenic and thrombophilic agent, and increased total plasma homocysteine has been associated with an increased risk for coronary, cerebrovascular, and peripheral arterial disease as well as for deep-vein thrombosis.
 
  • Classic homocystinuria, the most common (frequency 1:450,000), results from reduced activity of cystathionine β-synthase, the pyridoxal phosphate–dependent enzyme that condenses homocysteine with serine to form cystathionine.
  • Most patients present between 3 and 5 years of age with dislocated optic lenses and intellectual disability (in about half of cases). Some patients develop a marfanoid habitus and radiologic evidence of osteoporosis.
 
  • Life-threatening vascular complications (affecting coronary, renal, and cerebral arteries) can occur during the first decade of life and are the major cause of morbidity and mortality.
  • Classic homocystinuria can be diagnosed with analysis of plasma amino acids, showing elevated methionine and presence of free homocystine. Total plasma homocysteine is also extremely elevated (usually >100 μM).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3271, 3272.

questions.text: Pick the option that is not true about treatment with iodine.
questions.solution:
Iodine is not contraindicated in hyperthyroidism. Although use of iodine in hyperthyroidism is controversial, studies have suggested that iodine can worsen the condition in some cases, and it is not recommended for use except in extreme cases.

  • Iodine supplements are generally only used after other treatments, such as antithyroid medications and surgery, have failed to adequately control the symptoms.
  • In these cases, high doses of iodine can be used to temporarily shut down the thyroid, allowing time for other treatments to take effect and to alleviate symptoms.
  • Iodide can be used in Thyrotoxicosis also. Stable iodide (5 drops SSKI every 6 h) is given to block thyroid hormone synthesis via the Wolff-Chaikoff effect.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2941, 2942.

questions.text: The most prevalent kind of young-onset diabetes (MODY) is characterised by the following genetic mutation:
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Hepatocyte nuclear factor-1.
HNF-1 alpha is the most common form of Monogenic diasbetes.

Specific type of diabetes (Monogenic or MODY):
Genetic defects of beta cell function characterized by mutations in:

1. Hepatocyte nuclear transcription factor 4 alpha (MODY 1)
2. Glucokinase (MODY 2)
3. HNF-1 alpha(MODY 3) - most common
4. Insulin promoter factor-1 (IPF-1; MODY 4)
5. HNF-1 beta (MODY 5)
6. NeuroD1 (MODY 6)
7. Mitochondrial DNA



Reference: Williams Textbook of Endocrinology, 14th edition, Page no 1396.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3095.

questions.text: Which prolactin concentration would clearly indicate prolactinoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 200 mg/ml

A prolactin concentration of 200 ng/mL (or 2000 mIU/L) would be more indicative of a prolactinoma.

Prolactinomas are typically associated with significantly elevated prolactin levels above the normal range, and a concentration of 200 ng/mL is generally considered high.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2910.

questions.text: What is the replacement dose of hydrocortisone (mg/day) for Chronic Adrenal Insufficiency?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 4. 20 mg/day.
 
  • Glucocorticoid replacement for the treatment of chronic adrenal insufficiency should be administered at a dose that replaces the physiologic daily cortisol production, which is usually achieved by the oral administration of 15–25 mg hydrocortisone in two to three divided doses.
 
  • Pregnancy may require an increase in hydrocortisone dose by 50% during the last trimester. In all patients, at least one-half of the daily dose should be administered in the morning. 

Therefore, among the given options 20 mg/day will be the most appropriate answer.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2972.

questions.text: What is the first sign of third cranial nerve involvement in a person with diabetes mellitus?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Normal light reflex.
 
  • Acquired oculomotor nerve palsy can have various causes, and if a patient presents with specific symptoms such as ophthalmoplegia, ptosis, and mydriasis, it is important to rule out a compressive etiology such as an intracranial aneurysm.
  • The pupillary fibers within the oculomotor nerve are located peripherally and have better collateral blood supply, making them more susceptible to compression. The most common cause in such cases is a posterior communicating artery aneurysm.
  • However, if a patient has a complete or incomplete oculomotor palsy without pupil involvement (pupil-sparing 3rd nerve palsy), it is more likely to be related to ischemic processes, although compression and inflammation should still be considered as potential causes.
  • Pupillary fibers, being more peripheral, are less vulnerable to ischemia.
  • Diabetes is an ischemic rather than a compressive pathology and hence pupil sparing occurs.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3125.
Kanski's Clinical Ophthalmology, 9th edition, Page 799.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is most commonly linked to congenital adrenal hyperplasia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 2. Female pseudohermaphroditism
 
  • Congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) most often appears as female pseudohermaphroditism, with the most common enzyme deficiency being 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  • A female pseudohermaphrodite is a genetically typical female (46, XX) whose external genitalia resemble those of a male.
 
  • Children with 21-hydroxylase deficiency typically present between 10 and 14 days of age with a range of symptoms resulting from aldosterone deficiency, cortisol deficiency, and androgen excess.
  • Aldosterone deficiency leads to salt-wasting crises, characterized by hyponatremia, hyperkalemia, hypotension, and metabolic acidosis. Cortisol deficiency results in symptoms such as hypoglycemia, hyperpigmentation, weight loss, weakness, anorexia, vomiting, and shock.
 
  • Androgen excess in 21-hydroxylase deficiency causes virilization in females, leading to female pseudohermaphroditism, and precocious puberty in males. In females, virilization is typically noticeable at birth, while in males, it becomes apparent by 2 to 3 years of age. Without treatment, severe complications such as shock, cardiac arrhythmias, and death may occur within days or weeks.

Other options:
 
  • Option 1: Male pseudohermaphroditism is seen in CAH due to 17α-hydroxylase deficiency, which leads to incomplete virilization. This is the second most common enzyme deficiency in CAH.
  • Option 3: True hermaphroditism, now called ovotesticular disorder of sex development (DSD), involves the presence of both ovarian and testicular tissue and is not related to CAH.
  • Option 4: 46 XY intersex (now termed 46 XY DSD) involves under-virilization of the genitalia. Adrenal causes include lipoid adrenal hyperplasia, 3β-hydroxysteroid dehydrogenase deficiency, and 17-hydroxylase/17,20-lyase deficiency, but not 21-hydroxylase deficiency.




Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 2973, 2974, 2977, 3025.

choices.text: Increases the metabolism of oral hypoglycemic drugs

questions.text: Niacin therapy is not recommended for people with diabetes because:
questions.solution:
Niacin is known to increase blood glucose levels - hence, caution is to be exercised if using Niacin in any patient with Diabetes. 

Niacin induces insulin resistance and also decreases glucose-stimulated insulin secretion, which may result in severe hyperglycemia.





Reference: Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 613.

questions.text: Which of these is not associated with Thymoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: SIADH 

About 40% of thymomas present with symptoms stemming from impingement on mediastinal structures. Another 30% to 45% are detected in the course of evaluating patients with myasthenia gravis. 

In addition to myasthenia gravis, other associated autoimmune disorders include:
  1. Hypogammaglobulinemia
  2. Pure red cell aplasia
  3. Graves disease
  4. Pernicious anemia
  5. Dermatomyositis
  6. Polymyositis and
  7. Cushing syndrome


Reference: Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10th edition, Page no 633.

questions.text: Low calcium and high phosphate are observed in the case of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Primary Hypoparathyroidism
 
  • Hypoparathyroidism is a condition characterized by insufficient production or secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH) by the parathyroid glands.PTH plays a crucial role in regulating calcium and phosphate levels in the body.
  • In hypoparathyroidism, the low or absent levels of PTH result in decreased calcium reabsorption from the kidneys and reduced release of calcium from bones.
  • As a result, blood calcium levels tend to be low (hypocalcemia), while phosphate levels in the blood tend to be high (hyperphosphatemia).
 
  • Hyperparathyroidism, on the other hand, is characterized by excessive production of PTH by the parathyroid glands. In this condition, blood calcium levels tend to be high (hypercalcemia), and phosphate levels may be normal or low.
  • Hyperthyroidism (overactive thyroid) and hypothyroidism (underactive thyroid) primarily affect thyroid hormone levels and do not directly cause low calcium and high phosphate levels.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3163, 3185-3187.

questions.text: The following statement about pseudohypoparathyroidism is false:
questions.solution:
1. Decrease serum PTH  is the False statement about pseudohypoparathyroidism.

PSEUDOHYPOPARATHYROIDISM
 
  • PHP refers to a group of distinct inherited disorders. Patients affected by PHP type Ia (PHP1A) develop symptoms and signs of hypocalcemia in association with distinctive skeletal and developmental defects, referred to as Albright’s hereditary osteodystrophy (AHO). The hypocalcemia is due to a deficient PTH response in the proximal renal tubules.
  • Patients affected by PHP type Ib (PHP1B) also present with hypocalcemia and hyperphosphatemia but less frequently with obvious AHO features.
  • In response to the hypocalcemia observed in either disorder, PTH levels increase, leading to parathyroid hyperplasia and, in some cases, to autonomous PTH secretion.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3188, 3189.

questions.text: A patient reports hypoglycemia-related symptoms. Investigations show elevated insulin levels and lowered blood glucose. The results of the C-peptide assay indicate normal levels of C-peptide. The following is the likely cause:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Accidental exogenous insulin administration
 
  • Elevated insulin levels and lowered blood glucose indicate the presence of exogenous insulin in the body.
  • C-peptide levels, which reflect endogenous insulin production, are normal.
  • This scenario suggests that the patient has inadvertently received additional insulin, leading to hypoglycemia-related symptoms.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3132, 3133.

questions.text: Select the condition that is associated with peripheral artery disease, coronary heart disease and stroke.
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Insulin deficiency
 
  • All the above complications are seen in Diabetes mellitus which is characterised by either Insulin deficiency (Type 1 DM) or Insulin resistance (Type 2 DM)
 
  • Type 1 DM is the result of interactions of genetic, environmental, and immunologic factors that ultimately lead to immune-mediated destruction of the pancreatic beta cells and insulin deficiency.

Macrovascular complications of Diabetes include:
  1. Coronary heart disease
  2. Peripheral arterial disease
  3. Cerebrovascular disease


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3099, 3120.

choices.text: Pseudohyponatremia is associated with low plasma osmolality
Hyponatremia associated with hyperglycemia has high plasma osmolality

questions.text: The following statement about hyponatremia is false:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Pseudohyponatremia is associated with low plasma osmolality 

Pseudohyponatremia refers to a laboratory artifact where the measured sodium level appears low due to an abnormal distribution of plasma water, typically caused by high lipid or protein content in the blood. However, the plasma osmolality remains normal in pseudohyponatremia. Therefore, statement 1 is false.
 
  • Statement 2 is true. Hyponatremia associated with hyperglycemia can occur in conditions like diabetic ketoacidosis, where the high glucose levels draw water into the extracellular space, leading to dilutional hyponatremia. In this case, the plasma osmolality is high.
  • Statement 3 is true. Hyponatremia associated with syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone secretion (SIADH) is characterized by excessive retention of water, leading to dilutional hyponatremia. It typically occurs in normovolemic or hypervolemic states.
  • Statement 4 is true. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) can enhance the effects of vasopressin (antidiuretic hormone), leading to increased water reabsorption in the kidneys and potential development of hyponatremia.
 
  1. Hyponatremia:
    • Hypovolemic hyponatremia: Decreased sodium, decreased extracellular fluid volume, increased urine osmolality.
    • Euvolemic hyponatremia (e.g., SIADH): Decreased sodium, normal extracellular fluid volume, increased urine osmolality.
    • Hypervolemic hyponatremia (e.g., heart failure): Decreased sodium, increased extracellular fluid volume, decreased urine osmolality.
    • Hyponatremia associated with hyperglycemia (e.g., diabetic ketoacidosis): Decreased sodium, normal or increased extracellular fluid volume, increased plasma osmolality.
  2. Pseudohyponatremia:
    • Pseudohyponatremia due to hyperlipidemia: Decreased measured sodium, normal plasma osmolality.
    • Pseudohyponatremia due to hyperproteinemia: Decreased measured sodium, normal plasma osmolality:





Note: In pseudohyponatremia, the measured sodium level is decreased, but the true sodium concentration is normal.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 341-343.

questions.text: Males with hypergonadotropic hypogonadism are all of the following, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options, Kallman's syndrome (option 3) is a cause of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism while Viral orchitis, Klinefelter's syndrome and Noonan are causes of Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism. Kallman syndrome has also anosmia. 

Causes of Hypogonadism: 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3014, 3020.

questions.text: The most typical reason for male hypogonadotropic hypogonadism is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Amongst the given options, only Kallman's syndrome (option 3) is a cause of hypogonadotropic hypogonadism leading to delayed puberty. It also has anosmia. 

Viral orchitis, Klinefelter's syndrome and Radiotherapy to testis are causes of Hypergonadotropic Hypogonadism. (Elevated LH/FSH, low Sex hormones).





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3014, 3020.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Graves disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Common in Males

Graves is four times more common in females than males.



Trick-
Autoimmune diseases are more common in females



Reference: Williams Textbook of Endocrinology, 14th edition, Page no 369, 370.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2938.

questions.text: True hermaphroditism karyotype:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: 46 XX OVO TESTIS.

True hermaphroditism: Condition where an individual possesses both ovarian and testicular tissues, making them intersex. [both XX (female) and XY (male)].

The karyotype "46 XX" indicates that the individual has 46 chromosomes, including two X sex chromosomes.
"Ovotestis:" Presence of both ovarian and testicular tissues in the same gonad.







Reference: Williams Textbook of Endocrinology, 14th edition, Page no 868.

choices.text: Normal person after waking up in morning cortical awakening response

questions.text: Select from the options, where there is elevated ACTH and cortisol levels in the morning in comparison the levels of those hormones in the evening in a human being
questions.solution:
• Corticotropin releasing hormone (CRH) is a hormone naturally produced by the hypothalamus in higher levels of CNS control. This hormone has the ability to stimulate the production of ACTH in the pituitary gland. ACTH is secreted from the pituitary in irregular bursts throughout the day, and the plasma cortisol level varies accordingly.
  • The circadian rhythm is controlled by the suprachiasmatic nucleus of the hypothalamus which causes the highest levels of ACTH secretion to occur before waking up in the morning and diminish late in the afternoon and early evening.
  • Stressors such as physical trauma, exercise, and mental stress can increase ACTH and cortisol secretion in response to the stressor.

Other options:-
 
  • Option 1: In Addison's disease, there is a deficiency of mineralocorticoids and glucocorticoids Cushing's syndrome is characterized by an overproduction of cortisol.
  • Option 2: In normal person after giving dexamethasone the ACTH will be supressed that will lead to decrease in cortisol level.
  • Option 4: Cushing's syndrome is characterized by an overproduction of cortisol. Excess ACTH secretion is the primary cause of Cushing's syndrome and is characterized by an increase of both ACTH and cortisol in the blood. But the diurnal variation won't be there.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2959-2962.
Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 13th edition, page no 977, 979, 980.

questions.text: Pick the one not included in metabolic syndrome, as per NCEP-ARP III
questions.solution:
• The metabolic syndrome is a group of metabolic and cardiovascular health risks that occur together and increase the risk of developing serious health conditions such as diabetes and heart diseases.
  • The main features of the metabolic syndrome are central obesity, high triglycerides, low levels of high-density lipoprotein (HDL) cholesterol, high blood sugar, and hypertension.
  • People with these risk factors have a significantly higher risk of developing chronic diseases, such as stroke, heart attack, and type 2 diabetes, compared to people without these risk factors.
  • Therefore, diagnosing and treating these abnormalities early are important for preventing related diseases.


Metabolic syndrome criteria: 






Reference: Williams Textbook of Endocrinology, 14th edition, Page no 1608.

questions.text: What is Addison's disease most commonly associated with?
questions.solution:
Addison's disease is commonly associated with autoimmune adrenalitis.
 
  • In fact, it is the most common cause of Addison's disease in the world.
  • The most common cause of Addison's disease in India is tuberculosis.
     
  • Adrenocortical carcinoma patients display symptoms of Cushing's syndrome, which is an excess of adrenocortical hormones.
  • Hypernephroma and thyroid medullary cancer are not related to Addison's illness.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2970.

questions.text: Choose which is not a symptom of pituitary apoplexy.
questions.solution:
Hypertension is NOT a feature of Pituitary Apoplexy, instead hypotensive shock occurs due to Adrenal insufficiency.
 
  • Pituitary apoplexy is a sudden hemorrhage into the pituitary gland that can be caused by a preexisting adenoma, postpartum syndrome, diabetes, hypertension, sickle cell anemia, or shock.
 
  • Symptoms can include severe headache, diplopia, ophthalmoplegia, hypotension, loss of consciousness, and life-threatening hypotension due to ACTH and cortisol deficiency.
 
  • Diagnosis is usually confirmed with a computed tomography or MRI scan.
 
  • Treatment usually involves high-dose glucocorticoids, but those with significant visual loss, cranial nerve palsy, or loss of consciousness may require urgent surgical decompression.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2897, 2898.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a symptom in ACTH deficiency?
questions.solution:
• ACTH deficiencies occur when the body is unable to produce adequate amounts of the hormone ACTH (adrenocorticotropic hormone).
  • This lack of production can be caused by pituitary problems, genetic factors, or the administration of exogenous glucocorticoids. When ACTH levels are decreased, the production of cortisol and aldosterone decreases in turn, which can lead to adrenal atrophy due to the lack of ACTH stimulation.
  • Signs and symptoms of ACTH deficiency are similar to those of Addison's disease and include fatigue, weakness, weight loss, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.
  • However, the serum sodium and potassium levels are usually more normal in secondary adrenal insufficiency compared to Addison's disease and there is no presence of hyperpigmentation.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2971, 2972.

questions.text:
Patient feels warm and is fatigued; they are not gaining weight. o/e the patient has a staring expression and B/L proptosis. Examination will reveal?
1. Low TSH and High T3/T4
2. High TSH and High T3
3. High TSH and Low free T3
4. Normal TSH and High T3
questions.solution:
•  Thyrotoxicosis is over-functioning of the thyroid gland.
  • It can cause weight loss, despite an enhanced appetite due its increased metabolic rate, as well as hyperactivity, nervousness and irritability, tremor, hyperreflexia, muscle wasting, proximal myopathy, sinus tachycardia, palpitations, widened pulse pressure, aortic systolic murmurs, heat intolerance, palmar erythema, onycholysis, pruritus, urticaria, diffuse hyperpigmentation, fine hair texture, diarrhea, oligomenorrhea and amenorrhea, impaired sexual function, gynecomastia and osteopenia.
  • Depending on the individual, the thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH) level may be suppressed, while both total and unbound thyroid hormone levels are increased. In rare cases, there may only be an increase in total triiodothyronine (T3) levels (T3 toxicosis) or an increase in total thyroxine (T4) levels (T4 toxicosis).




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2939, 2940.

questions.text: Patient had low TSH, however after administering TRH, TSH increased. likely reason?
questions.solution:
• Central Hypothyroidism is a condition of thyroid hormone deficiency caused by a disorder of the pituitary, hypothalamus or the hypothalamic-pituitary portal circulation, resulting in low levels of thyroid stimulating hormone (TSH), thyrotropin-releasing hormone (TRH), or both.
  • Possible causes of TRH deficiency include diseases of the hypothalamus such as benign and malignant tumors, radiation for certain malignancies, infiltrative lesions, infections, traumatic brain injury and stroke.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2932, 2933.

questions.text: A patient is suffering from weight gain and lassitude. What could be the cause if tests revealed elevated TSH and low T4?
questions.solution:
Hashimoto’s disease is the possible diagnosis in this scenario.

Increased TSH with low T4 -> Hypothyroidism
  • Graves disease -> Hyperthyroidism (Most common cause)
  • Hashimoto -> Increased TSH with low T4
  • Pituitary adenoma -> TSH secreting adenoma shows increased TSH, T3, T4
  • Hypoparathyroidism ->No increased TSH or low T4

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2933, 2936.

questions.text: Except for__________, all of the following result in secondary hyperparathyroidism.
questions.solution:
Parathyroid adenoma will result in primary hyperparathyroidism.

Causes of secondary hyperparathyroidism ie hyperparathyroidism due to other underlying diseases:
  • i. Chronic Renal Failure
  • ii. Malabsorption syndrome
  • iii. Vitamin D deficiency
  • iv. Medullary carcinoma thyroid



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3172-3174.

questions.text: Phosphate in urine in excess leads to osteomalacia. Lab findings include low serum phosphate levels, Normal PTH and Normal Vitamin D level. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The diagnosis most likely associated with excess phosphate in urine leading to osteomalacia is Vitamin D resistance.
  • This condition, also known as hereditary vitamin D-resistant rickets (HVDRR), leads to problems with phosphate and calcium metabolism, contributing to weakened bones and osteomalacia despite normal or elevated levels of vitamin D.

Laboratory findings of Vitamin D-resistant rickets:
  • Raised alkaline phosphatase (ALP)
  • Hypophosphatemia
  • Hyperphosphaturia
  • Normal or mild decreased 1, 25 (OH) D3
  • Normal PTH level



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3162, 3168.

questions.text: A patient with known diabetes and hypertension was discovered on the side of the road in the morning, unconscious, with a pulse rate of 120 beats per minute and a bilateral plantar extensor response. What should we do as soon as possible?
questions.solution:
It is critical to check the blood glucose measurements of the patient since they are diabetic, before intervening, as a way of ruling out a hypoglycemic coma.

Clinical features of Hypoglycemia:
  • Neuroglycopenic manifestations of hypoglycemia are the direct result of central nervous system glucose deprivation.
  • These features include behavioral changes, confusion, fatigue, seizure, loss of consciousness, cardiac arrhythmias, and, if hypoglycemia is severe, death.
  • Neurogenic (or autonomic) manifestations of hypoglycemia result from the perception of physiologic changes caused by the central nervous system–mediated sympathoadrenal discharge that is triggered by hypoglycemia.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3129, 3130.

choices.text: 5 kg baby delivered five years prior, and the numerous blood transfusions that followed. After giving birth, she never started her period again, and she also experienced lactation problems.

questions.text:
A 39-year-old lady complains of being tired and lethargic when she visits the medicine office. She recalls having a 3.5 kg baby delivered five years prior, and the numerous blood transfusions that followed. After giving birth, she never started her period again, and she also experienced lactation problems.
Which diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Sheehan syndrome.
  • The most likely diagnosis in this case is Sheehan syndrome, also known as postpartum pituitary necrosis.
  • Sheehan syndrome is characterized by pituitary gland damage due to severe postpartum hemorrhage, leading to hormonal imbalances and symptoms such as fatigue, amenorrhea, and lactation problems.
  • The most common hormone deficiency in Sheehan syndrome is hypothyroidism (thyroid gland does not produce enough thyroid hormone).
  • The patient's symptoms of tiredness, lethargy, and lack of menstruation are consistent with hypothyroidism. The fact that she had a large baby and needed multiple blood transfusions during childbirth suggests that she may have had Sheehan syndrome.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2890.

questions.text: A female patient with altered sensorium was taken to the emergency room. Upon assessment, the patient's blood pressure was 88/67 mm Hg and her pulse was 60 beats per minute. 34°C was the rectal temperature. Menorrhagia, dry skin, and constipation had a history of being related. Which diagnosis is most likely?
questions.solution:
Myxedema coma is a potentially life-threatening condition that can occur in patients with hypothyroidism, typically elderly people.
 
  • It is characterized by altered sensorium, hypotension, bradycardia, hypothermia and other symptoms of hypothyroidism. Patent also had history of menorrhagia, drynskin, constipation.
 
  • It is usually fatal despite intensive treatment and is usually triggered by factors that affect respiration, such as certain drugs, pneumonia, heart failure and other medical problems.
 
  • Exposure to cold may also be a factor. Hypoventilation, hypoxia, hypercapnia and hypoglycemia all play major roles in the development of myxedema coma.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2934, 2937.

questions.text:
A diabetic female patient who had previously eaten outside food was admitted with frequent vomiting.
BP is 90/60 mmHg. pH: 7.52. HCO3-  is 26.
PaCO2: 20+. Na-123, Potassium-3.2, and Chloride-67 meq/l are the electrolytes. What is the reason behind her ABG results?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Persistent vomiting.

The arterial blood gas (ABG) results show:
  1. pH: 7.52, indicating alkalosis as the pH is above the normal range (7.35-7.45).
  2. HCO3-: 26 mEq/L, showing elevated bicarbonate levels, which is a sign of metabolic alkalosis.
  3. PaCO2: 20+ mmHg, suggesting possible respiratory compensation for the metabolic alkalosis.
  • Based on the ABG results and low electrolyte levels, the most likely reason for her condition is persistent vomiting, leading to metabolic alkalosis. 
  • Vomiting causes loss of hydrochloric acid from the stomach, resulting in an alkalotic state.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 361, 365.

choices.text: William syndrome consists of precocious puberty, mental retardation and obesity
In absence of sunlight daily requirement of vitamin D is 400-600 IU
1-alpha hydroxylation of vitamin D occurs in kidney
25-alpha hydroxylation of vitamin D occurs in liver

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false?
questions.solution:
Williams syndrome is a developmental disorder that affects many parts of the body. This condition is characterized by mild to moderate intellectual disability or learning problems, unique personality characteristics, distinctive facial features, and heart and blood vessel (cardiovascular) problems.
"Vitamin D is hydroxylated twice, once in the liver and then again in the kidney to produce the hormone 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol. 7-dehydrocholesterol is converted to cholecalciferol in the skin on exposure to sunlight. Cholecalciferol is then converted to 25-hydroxy-cholecalciferol in the liver by 25-hydroxylation. 25-hydroxycholeecalciferol is then converted to 1,25-dihydroxycholecalciferol, the active form of vitamin D, in the kidney by I-hydroxylation.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3166-3169.

choices.text: Low plasma rennin activity that is not stimulated by volume depletion
Hyperaldosteronism, i.e. increased aldosterone secretion which is not suppressed by volume expansion

questions.text: Which of the following does not meet the criteria for primary hyperaldosteronism?
questions.solution:
Primary hyperaldosteronism is associated with metabolic alkalosis and not metabolic acidosis.

Criteria for Diagnosis of Primary Hyperaldosteronism include:

•Diastolic hypertension without edema.
•Hypersecretion of aldosterone that does not suppress appropriately in response to volume expansion
•Low plasma rennin levels.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2964-2966.

choices.text: Serum sodium can be as low as 125 mEq/L
Urine sodium is usually normal or slightly low
Vaptans are new FDA approved drugs for its treatment
Water loading test can be used for diagnosis

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about SIADH?
questions.solution:
SIADH is typically characterized by high urinary sodium (Increased rate of excretion of sodium). SIADH is associated low serum sodium levels (<135 meq/L). Vaptans are new FDA approved agents for treatment of SIADH. Patients with SIADH excrete <90% of the water load within four hours and do not produce urine osmolality <100 mOsm/kg. Serum and urine osmolalities are measured .This is known as water loading test.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 342, 2924.

questions.text:
At what point is diabetes mellitus diagnosed?
1. Fasting blood glucose is \(\geq\)100 mg/dL and post prandial glucose is \(\geq\)140 mg/dL
2. Fasting blood glucose \(\geq\)125 mg/dL and post prandial glucose is \(\geq\)199 mg/mL
3. Level of plasma insulin is \(\geq\)6 IU/dL
4. HbA1C level is > 6.5%
questions.solution:
Glycosylated Haemoglobin (HbA1C) values of> 6.5% represents an independent criteria/or diagnosis of Diabetes Mellitus in accordance with the criteria set by the American Diabetic Association, 2024.

Criteria for diagnosis of Diabetes mellitus (Any one of the following):





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3095.

questions.text: Thomas Addison made the first mention of Addison's illness. There are still several reports about it coming in from throughout the globe. Which of the following causes of Addison's disease is more prevalent in India?
questions.solution:
• Most common cause of Addison disease in India is tuberculous adrenalitis.
 
  • The commonest cause of adrenal insufficiency (Addison s disease) in developing countries like India is Tuberculosis, followed by autoimmune disorders.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2970, 2971.

choices.text: A parathyroid hormone-related protein is responsible for causing hypercalcemia in cancer patients
The unionised fraction of calcium in the plasma is an important determinant of PTH secretion

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true?
questions.solution:
Circulating ionized calcium acts directly on the parathyroid gland and acts in a negative feedback fashion to regulate the secretion of PTH. Hypercalcemia is  a common metabolic complication of cancer parathyroid hormone related protein produced by tumour cells( Paraneoplastic syndrome).
Magnesium is required to maintain normal parathyroid secretory responses. Impaired PTH release along with diminished target responses to PTH account for the hypocalcaemia that occasionally occurs in magnesium deficiency.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3170-3172.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl who was evaluated for her short height was found to have an enlarged pituitary gland. Her T4 was decreased, and her TSH was increased. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
With long standing hypothyroidism, thyrotroph hyperplasia can result in expansion of sella turcica and the enlargement of the pituitary gland. This may mimic pituitary tumour.
In long standing hypothyroidism, the negative feedback of thyroid hormones on hypothalamus is lost. This results in increase secretion of thyrotropin releasing hormone (TRH) from the hypothalamus. This in turn causes hyperplasia and proliferation of the thyrotrophic cells of the pituitary.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2933, 2935.
