questions.text: An elderly female presents with the nasal blockade and nasal discharge with black debris. Blood sugar was raised and urine is positive for ketones. Best treatment for the patient would be:
questions.solution:
Best treatment for the patient is amphotericin B

The peri-orbital region and vision impairment are involved in the mucormycosis that this diabetic patient most certainly has, according to the most recent research. All kinds of Mucormycosis are most frequently treated with intravenous (iv) Amphotericin B. Another antifungal used is Posaconazole. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1682-1685.

questions.text: The following is not true about Hashimoto's thyroiditis:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Examination shows reduced TSH level.
 
  1. Hashimoto's thyroiditis: An autoimmune disorder, where the body's immune system mistakenly attacks the thyroid gland.
  2. Oncocytic metaplasia is a characteristic feature of Hashimoto's thyroiditis but not pathognomonic (definitive) for the condition. It is a histological finding of large cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm.
  3. Hashimoto's thyroiditis can present with hyperthyroidism during the early phases of the disease. This is known as "Hashitoxicosis" or "painless thyroiditis".
  4. Examination reveals elevated TSH level due to reduced thyroid hormone production as the feedback inhibition is removed. 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2935, 2936.

choices.text: Most common site is the para-aortic sympathetic chain
Vascular invasion may occur in benign lesions

questions.text: The following statement is correct regarding pheochromocytoma:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Vascular invasion may occur in benign lesions.
 
  • Pheochromocytoma is a rare neuroendocrine tumor.
  • It originates from chromaffin cells in the adrenal medulla or sympathetic ganglia.
  • Most commonly, pheochromocytomas arise in the adrenal medulla.
  • While usually benign, they can exhibit vascular invasion, mimicking malignant characteristics.
  • Pheochromocytoma is associated with multiple endocrine neoplasia type 2 (MEN-2), not MEN-1.
  • Approximately 10% of cases are malignant, not 40%.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2976, 2977, 2979.

questions.text: Which of these is true regarding a disturbance in thyroid function?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: There is increased cholesterol in hypothyroidism.
 
  • Thyroid hormones regulate metabolism. Hypothyroidism results from insufficient thyroid hormone production, causing a slowed metabolism, weight gain, fatigue, and reduced heart rate.
  • In hypothyroidism, there is often weight gain and increased cholesterol levels.
  • Hypothyroidism may cause constipation, but not diarrhea.
  • Palpitations and tachycardia are characteristic of hyperthyroidism, not hypothyroidism.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2935, 2936.

questions.text: Most virulent form of Medullary carcinoma thyroid is seen in which type of MEN syndrome:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: MEN - 2B
 
  • Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid (MCT) is a thyroid cancer arising from C-cells.
  • MCT can be linked to multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndromes, genetic disorders causing tumors in multiple endocrine glands.
  • MEN-2B is the most virulent form of MCT, characterized by MCT, pheochromocytoma, and mucosal neuromas.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2988, 2989.

questions.text: Primary Adrenal Insufficiency causes all of the following, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Increased protein breakdown 
 
  • Addison's disease is a primary adrenal insufficiency in which the adrenal is unable to secrete adequate amounts of cortisol (glucocorticoid), aldosterone (mineralocorticoid), and sex hormones. The most common cause of Addison's disease is autoimmune adrenalitis. 
  • Symptoms include:
  1. Low blood pressure
  2. Decrease in extracellular fluid (ECF)
  3. Decreased sodium-potassium ratio  due to reduced aldosterone levels.
  • However, increased protein breakdown (D) is not a typical symptom of primary adrenal insufficiency. People with Addison's disease may actually have increased protein levels in their blood as their bodies try to conserve protein.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2971, 2972.

questions.text: The syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone (SIADH) has which of the following characteristics?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Hypertension
 
  • Syndrome of inappropriate antidiuretic hormone ADH release (SIADH) is a condition where there is an unsuppressed release of antidiuretic hormone (ADH) from the pituitary gland or nonpituitary sources or its continued action on vasopressin receptors.
 
  • Clinical features of SIADH:
    • Hyponatremia (low blood sodium levels)
    • Decreased urination
    • Confusion
    • Fatigue
    • Weakness
    • Muscle cramps
    • High blood pressure- due to increased blood volume 

The other given clinical features are more classic of pheochromocytoma.

Laboratory findings of SIADH :





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 342, 2924.

questions.text: Where is CDKN1B gene mutation implicated ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: MEN-4
 
  • CDKN1B gene mutation is linked to Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 4 (MEN-4), a rare genetic disorder.
  • MEN-4 results from mutations in the CDKN1B gene, which codes for the p27 protein involved in regulating cell division.
  • These mutations can disrupt p27's normal function, leading to uncontrolled cell growth and tumor development in various endocrine glands.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2984, 2990.

questions.text: What is suggested by early morning hyperglycemia with decreased blood glucose of 2.00 AM ?
questions.solution:
Option is 3: Somogyi effect 
 
  • Early morning hyperglycemia with decreased blood glucose of 2.00 AM suggests the Somogyi effect.
  • The Somogyi effect is also known as "rebound hyperglycemia" in diabetes management.
  • It occurs when the body responds to nighttime hypoglycemia by releasing counterregulatory hormones, leading to elevated blood sugar levels in the morning.

Other options:
  • Insufficient insulin would lead to persistent high blood sugar levels, not the specific pattern seen in the Somogyi effect.
  • The Dawn Phenomenon is a separate phenomenon involving mild morning blood sugar elevation due to natural hormonal release for waking up.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3811.

questions.text: What is the likely cause of no increase in the osmolarity of urine , In a patient who has been given an administration of exogenous vasopressin ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Renal Hyposensitivity to ADH 
 
  • Exogenous vasopressin, also known as ADH (antidiuretic hormone), is naturally produced by the pituitary gland and regulates water retention in the kidneys.
  • When ADH is released,prompts the kidneys to reabsorb more water, leading to increased urine osmolarity.
  • If a patient is given exogenous vasopressin, or synthetic ADH, and  osmolarity of their urine does not increase, it indicates renal hyposensitivity to ADH (Nephrogenic DI). This means that the kidneys are not responding to ADH as they should, and are not reabsorbing as much water as they should.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2921, 2922.

questions.text: Mainstay of treatment of Nephrogenic Diabetes Insipidus is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Thiazide/Amiloride diruetics and salt restriction 

Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (DI) results due to resistance to the antidiuretic action of AVP (arginine vasopressin) leading to the production of large amounts of dilute urine and dehydration.

NDI mainstay treatment:
  • Thiazide and Amiloride diuretics increase water reabsorption by the kidneys, reducing urine output.
  • Salt restriction helps to further conserve water and prevent excessive loss in the urine.
  • Thiazides are used in nephrogenic diabetes insipidus due to their paradoxical anti-diuretic action. These are the first-line drugs used in the treatment of Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. 
  • The treatment of choice in a Lithium-associated nephrogenic diabetes insipidus is Amiloride.
  • Loop diuretic acts on the N+ K+ 2Cl- symporter, but is not given in diabetes insipidus as it can worsen the condition.

Water deprivation test analysis :





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2922.

questions.text: Which of the following is not related with hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Elevated Cholesterol is a feature of Hypothyroidism, NOT Low Cholesterol.
 
  • A normal TSH level excludes primary (but not secondary) hypothyroidism. If the TSH is elevated, a free or unbound T4 level (FT4 ) is needed to confirm the presence of clinical hypothyroidism.
  • T3 is also low in majority of hypothyroid patients.
 
  • Other abnormal laboratory findings in hypothyroidism may include increased creatine phosphokinase, elevated cholesterol and triglycerides, and anemia (usually normocytic or macrocytic).

Evaluation for Hypothyroidism: 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2935, 2936.

choices.text: Sleep EEG studies have shown disruption in REM sleep
SPECT studies have reduced blood flow to the thalamus

questions.text: Which of the following is true for fibromyalgia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: SPECT studies have reduced blood flow to the thalamus 
 
  • Fibromyalgia is characterized by chronic widespread musculoskeletal pain and tenderness. It is more common in females. 
  • Patients with fibromyalgia have an increased prevalence of other syndromes associated with pain and fatigue, including chronic fatigue syndrome, chronic headaches, irritable bowel syndrome, interstitial cystitis/ painful bladder syndrome, and pelvic pain syndromes.
  • Anti-polymer antibody may be seen in 50% of patients. 
  • Single-photon emission computed tomography (SPECT) studies done on fibromyalgia patients show hypoperfusion of the thalamus.
Other options:
 
  • Sleep EEG studies have shown disruption in non-REM sleep, not REM sleep.
  • Cortisol levels in fibromyalgia patients are typically within the normal range.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2868-2870.

questions.text: The emergence of hyperthyroidism after supplementary iodine treatment to people with endemic iodine deficient goitre is termed as:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Jod-Basedow effect
 
  • The Jod-Basedow effect is due to overactivation of the thyroid gland or autonomous nodules within the gland after iodine repletion without adequate feedback control from the pituitary gland.
  • This phenomenon does not occur in individuals with normal thyroid gland.
  • In iodine-deficient areas, the thyroid gland cannot produce enough hormones due to the lack of iodine. When excess iodine is introduced suddenly, it causes the thyroid to produce and release more hormones, leading to hyperthyroidism.

Other options:
 
  • Wolff-Chaikoff effect: Opposite phenomenon, where a transient inhibition of thyroid hormone synthesis occurs in response to a large amount of iodine exposure.
  • Thyrotoxicosis factitia: Hyperthyroidism caused by the ingestion of excess thyroid hormone.
  •  De Quervain's thyroiditis: Inflammation of the thyroid gland, leading to transient hyperthyroidism followed by hypothyroidism.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2938, 2945.

questions.text: Which option best describes the lowest detection limit for third generation TSH assays?
questions.solution:
Serum TSH is the initial screening test for primary thyroid dysfunction. TSH is a glycoprotein hormone produced by the pituitary gland. It stimulates the thyroid gland to secrete thyroid hormones, which regulate tissue metabolism.

TSH assays are named historically by “generation”; third generation assays are widely used and have a detection limit of 0.01 mIU/L, as compared to first (1 mIU/L) and second generation assays (0.1–0.2 mIU/L).



Reference: Papaleontiou, Maria, and Anne R Cappola. “Thyroid-Stimulating Hormone in the Evaluation of Subclinical Hypothyroidism.” JAMA vol. 316,15 (2016): 1592-1593. doi:10.1001/jama.2016.9534. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5450818/

questions.text: Which of the following has the least likelihood of being connected to gynecomastia?
questions.solution:
• Gynecomastia is a medical condition characterized by the enlargement of male breast tissue. It is caused by an imbalance in the hormones estrogen and testosterone.
  • The condition is often associated with increased levels of estrogen or decreased levels of testosterone in males. Out of the given options, prolactinoma has the least likelihood of being connected to gynecomastia.
  • Prolactinoma is a noncancerous tumor of the pituitary gland that produces high levels of prolactin hormone. Prolactin stimulates milk production in females and can cause breast enlargement and lactation in males. However, the likelihood of prolactinoma causing gynecomastia is lower compared to the other options.
  • Adrenal tumors can produce excess estrogen or androgen hormones, leading to gynecomastia.
  • hCG-secreting tumors can also cause gynecomastia as they stimulate the production of estrogen. Estrogen-secreting tumors can also cause gynecomastia directly by increasing estrogen levels in the body.
 
  • Therefore, based on the above information, option 1, which is prolactinoma, has the least likelihood of being connected to gynecomastia.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2909, 2910, 2967.

questions.text: Except for____, all of the following agents may be used to treat Chronic Hypocalcemia.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Etidronate
 
  • Etidronate is not used for the management of hypocalcemia. It is a bisphosphonate primarily used to treat hypercalcemia.
  • The main goal in managing hypoparathyroidism is to restore the balance of calcium and phosphate in the body.

Other options:
 
  • The mainstay of treatment involves calcium and vitamin D supplements.
  • Thiazide diuretics can be prescribed along with a low-sodium diet to enhance urinary calcium reabsorption.
  • Other underlying conditions contributing to hypocalcemia should also be addressed during the management process.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition, Page no 2936.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Stipulated ribs
Stipulated ribs are not seen in hypothyroidism.

They are small, bony projections that can be seen on the 12th rib in people with certain conditions, such as Marfan syndrome and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome.

Other options:
 
  • Option 1- Wormian bones: Small, irregular bones that can be seen on the skull
  • Option 3-  Beaking of the vertebra: Tips of the vertebrae become enlarged and pointed. It is also known as bullet shaped vertebra
  • Option 4- Epiphyseal dysgenesis: Growth plates of the bones are affected, which can lead to short stature and other skeletal abnormalities.



Reference: Gutch, Manish et al. “Skeletal manifestations of juvenile hypothyroidism and the impact of treatment on skeletal system.” Indian journal of endocrinology and metabolism vol. 17,Suppl 1 (2013): S181-3. doi:10.4103/2230-8210.119565. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3830298/

questions.text: A patient presented with a pituitary tumour with consequent overproduction of GH. He was planned for surgery but it was not possible to remove the entire tumour mass. What drug should be given to such patient to get maximum benefit?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of of pituitary tumor producing growth hormone will produce Acromegaly. The first line treatment of acromegaly is Octreotide.

It is a synthetic somatostatin analogue. 
 
  • The patient has a pituitary tumor causing overproduction of Growth Hormone (GH), leading to conditions such as acromegaly or gigantism.
  • Since surgery could not completely remove the tumor, pharmacological therapy is essential to control excess GH production.
  • Octreotide, a somatostatin analog, is highly effective at inhibiting GH secretion. It acts by binding to somatostatin receptors on the pituitary tumor, reducing both GH and Insulin-like Growth Factor-1 (IGF-1) levels, providing significant symptomatic relief and biochemical control.

Other options: 
 

  1. Bromocriptine: A dopamine agonist, sometimes used for GH-secreting tumors, but it is less effective compared to somatostatin analogs like octreotide. It is more commonly used for prolactinomas.

  2. Cabergoline: Another dopamine agonist, more potent than bromocriptine, but its role in GH-secreting tumors is secondary. It may be used if somatostatin analogs are not tolerated or as an adjunct.

  3. Goserelin: A gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist, used primarily for conditions like prostate cancer or endometriosis, with no role in treating GH-secreting pituitary tumors.



 

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 260, 264.

Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 781, 932.

questions.text: A 40 years old patient presented with widening of teeth gaps, protrusion of chin, prominence of frontal bone, excessive sweating, impaired glucose tolerance and enlargement of the feet and hand. Which of the following is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of acromegaly.
Among the given options, Pegvisomant is a growth hormone receptor antagonist used to treat this condition. 

Other options:
 
  • Option 2- Octreotide is a synthetic analogue of somatostatin. It is used as first line in treatment of acromegaly. 
  • Option 3- Cabergoline is a D2 receptor agonist. It is used in treatment of hyperprolactinemia. 
  • Option 4- Bromocriptine is D2 receptor agonist used as a first line drug in treatment of hyperprolactinemia. 


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 260, 261.

choices.text: Intravenous fluid bolus in first hour with regular insulin after that
Intravenous fluid in first hour with long-acting insulin after that

questions.text: A known case of diabetes mellitus presented to the Emergency department with complaints of nausea, vomiting and abdominal pain. She is having altered sensorium. Attendants said that she never took medications regularly. General examination shoed that she is dehydrated. She was having tachycardia and systolic BP was 92 mm Hg. Her serum glucose was more than 500 mg/dl. Urine showed presence of sugar and ketone bodies. Best step in managing such a case:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario goes in favor of diabetic ketoacidosis and the next best step in management will be intravenous fluids with regular insulin. 
 

The patient is presenting with diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), a life-threatening complication of diabetes mellitus characterized by hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis.

  1. Symptoms: Nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, altered sensorium.
  2. Signs: Dehydration, tachycardia, hypotension.
  3. Laboratory:
    • Serum glucose >500 mg/dL (severe hyperglycemia).
    • Urine positive for sugar and ketones (ketonuria indicates ketosis).
    • Likely metabolic acidosis (though pH is not provided).

Management of  Diabetic Ketoacidosis:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 361, 1682, 3114-3116.

questions.text: A 45 year old lady presented with the complaints of amenorrhoea and galactorrhoea. Her urinary pregnancy test was positive. MRI of brain revealed a large pituitary mass. She was advised surgery but she refused. Which drug is best for managing such a case ?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of prolactinoma and the drug of choice for prolactinoma in a pregnant female is bromocriptine. 
 
  • Prolactinomas are the most common type of pituitary tumor and cause elevated prolactin levels, leading to symptoms like amenorrhoea (absence of menstruation), galactorrhoea (milky discharge from the breasts), and infertility.
  • Bromocriptine is a dopamine agonist that works by stimulating dopamine receptors in the pituitary gland. This inhibits the secretion of prolactin and can reduce the size of the prolactinoma, helping normalize prolactin levels and relieve symptoms like galactorrhoea and amenorrhoea.

Other options:
 

  1. Leuprolide: This is a gonadotropin-releasing hormone (GnRH) agonist. It is used to manage conditions like endometriosis and prostate cancer, but it is not effective for treating prolactinoma.

  2. Octreotide: This is a somatostatin analog, used primarily for acromegaly (growth hormone-secreting pituitary tumors) and certain types of carcinoid tumors. It is not effective in treating prolactinoma.

  3. Clozapine: This is an antipsychotic medication, and while it can cause increased prolactin levels, it is not used to treat prolactinomas. In fact, antipsychotics like clozapine can exacerbate symptoms of hyperprolactinemia.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2302, 2303, 2309-2311.

questions.text:
Which of the following are associated with MEN-2A syndrome? 
(i) Parathyroid hyperplasia 
(ii) Medullary ca-thyroid
(iii) Cafe-au-lait-spots
(iv) Optic nerve glioma
questions.solution:
• MEN 2A syndrome is a genetic disorder that affects the endocrine glands and causes a type of thyroid cancer called medullary thyroid cancer, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid gland cancer.
  • It may also cause benign (noncancerous) tumors in the parathyroid glands and adrenal glands.

Other options:
 
  • Cafe-au-lait spots (iii): These are associated with neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), not MEN-2A.
  • Optic nerve glioma (iv): Also a feature of NF1, not MEN-2A.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2984.

choices.text: Pain on passive movement of the calf

questions.text: A patient came with a deep ulcer on the foot as shown in the image. Which among the following is most likely to be associated with this condition ?
questions.solution:
The given image shows an ulcer at a pressure point- typical of a neuropathic ulcer. Neuropathic foot ulcers form as a result of a loss of peripheral sensation and are typically seen in individuals with Diabetes Mellitus. 


Reference: Schwartz’s Principles of Surgery, 11th Edition, Page no 290,951,958 .

choices.text: The threshold of plasma osmolality is lowered transiently and no treatment is require
She has DI and require DDAVP life long
She has DI and require DDAVP for a few weeks and stop after that

questions.text: A 14-year old girl underwent resection of a large pituitary lesion, and developed polyuria. Urine osmolarity was seen to be 100 mOsm and serum Na+ was 155 mEq/ L. Which is correct about the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The scenario is suggesting central diabetes insipidus in a neurosurgical patient.
The diagnosis is made by the presence of the classic triad (as seen in this patient) of:
  • Polyuria
  • Hypernatremia as evidenced by raised serum Na+ levels
  • Dilute urine as evidenced by low urine osmolality
* Management principles:
  1. If the duration of diabetes insipidus is quite transient, it is acceptable to treat this simply with fluid replacement, parenterally or orally.
  2. However, most patients who develop diabetes insipidus require desmopressin 0.5 to 2 μg subcutaneously, intramuscularly, or intravenously for life.
  3. Periodic drug discontinuation allows for assessing whether or not it is still required. Thus, the best answer would be to give a trial of desmopressin and continue monitoring the patient for a few weeks.
Thiazides have a role in the management of nephrogenic DI. (option D)

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2920, 2921.

questions.text: 19y old male known case of Type I DM missed his dose of insulin, patient now comes to the ER with features of Diabetic Ketoacidosis. RBS-525. What is the next line of management?
questions.solution:
Patient is diagnosed with Diabetic Ketoacidosis. Mainstay of treatment in DKA is IV fluids followed by IV insulin after 1 hour.
DKA is diagnosed by
GRBS >200,
pH <7.3
Bicarb <18
+/- Urine Ketone bodies.
Anion gap >10

Reference: Raghupathy P. Diabetic ketoacidosis in children and adolescents. Indian J Endocrinol Metab. 2015 Apr;19(Suppl 1):S55-7. doi: 10.4103/2230-8210.155403. PMID: 25941653; PMCID: PMC4413392.

questions.text: 45 y old female known case of Rheumatoid arthritis who was on steroid replacement. She suddenly stopped her medicines after Googling the side effects of steroids on internet. She came to ER with history of sudden onset Giddiness. BP-80/50mmhg GRBS- 65. Which of the following is the next best management?
questions.solution:
The history and sudden stoppage of steroids with hypotension and hypoglycemia is suggestive of Addisonian crisis.
The DOC is Adrenal Insufficency is IV hydrocortisone sixth hourly along with IV fluids and correction of electrolytes.
Adrenal insufficency features- Hyponatremia, Hyperkalemia, Hypotension, Hypoglycemia.

Reference: 
Rathbun KM, Singhal M. Addisonian Crisis. [Updated 2023 Jul 4]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK441933/

questions.text: Identify the condition
questions.solution:
Mandibular enlargement +Prognathism with Jaw Malocclusion is suggestive of Acromegaly.
Before fusion of growth plate leads to Gigantism.
Screening test- IGF-1 levels
Confirmatory test-75g OGTT.



Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2914.

questions.text: 55y old female came known case of Hyperthyoidism, came with sudden onset Palpiations and diagnosed to have thyrotoxic crisis. Which of the following drugs is not used in management of the same?
questions.solution:
NSAIDS and Aspirin is CI in patients with thyroid storm as they interfere with protein binding and further worsen the condition. Drugs used in Thyrotoxic crisis - PTU is preferred drug as it inhibits thyroid hormone synthesis and also reduces peripheral conversion of T4 to T3.
Other drugs used -Lugol"s iodine -Wolf Chaikoff effect,
Propanolol and Glucocorticoids reduced peripheral T4 to T3 conversion, the active form.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2941.

choices.text: Increases Osteoclastic activity and reduces renal excretion of calcium

questions.text: How does PTH increase blood Calcium levels?
questions.solution:
PTH increases Plasma Calcium levels by Increasing the Osteoclastic activity leading to increased bone resorption. It also acts by  decreasing the renal excretion of calcium and increased reabsorption of calcium by renal tubules and  Decreased Phosphate reabsorption.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No: 3175, 3176.

questions.text: 40 y old female with history of Adrenalectomy two years back now came with Hyperpigmentation of her palms associated with Visual Field defects. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of Nelson Syndrome.
Nelson Syndome is characterised by Hyperpigmentation, Excessive ACTH secretion and Coritcotroph adenoma causing visual field defects with a history of adrenalectomy.

Nelson's syndrome (NS) is an uncommon disease occurring as a complication of bilateral adrenalectomy (BLA) in patients with persistent Cushing's disease (CD) due to an adrenocorticotropin-producing pituitary tumor. The first reports of this syndrome were done in the 50s, although its pathophysiology is still not understood. Every year, between 1.8 and 2.6 cases are thought to occur per million people. It is characterized by hyperpigmentation, elevated adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) plasma levels, and typical signs and symptoms related to pituitary adenomas, such as visual deficits due to optic pathway compression or decreased hormone production from the adenohypophysis.

Reference: Torres-Ríos JA, Romero-Luna G, Meraz Soto JM, Zavala-Romero L, Aguirre Maqueda ML, Rodríguez Camacho A, Moreno Jiménez S. Nelson's Syndrome: A Narrative Review. Cureus. 2023 May 16;15(5):e39114. doi: 10.7759/cureus.39114. PMID: 37332454; PMCID: PMC10272858.

questions.text: 30y old female comes with history of weight loss, irregular menstrual cycles and anxiety. On examination- HR-125bpm. Which of the following is the next investigation?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of weight loss, anxiety and tachycardia is suggestive of Hyperthyroidism.
The next test would be to send for TSH followed by Free T3 and T4 levels.
Other tests useful in diagnosis are - TSH receptor antibody, Anti TPO , USG neck to look for nodules, CT and MRI to look for orbitopathy.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No: 2940.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in diagnosis of Metabolic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Metabolic Syndrome is present if three or more of the following five criteria are met .
  • Central Obesity- Waist Circumfernce of >102cm in male or 88cm in females 
  • Triglyceride >150mg/dl
  • Low HDL - <40 in males and 50mg/dl in females
  • BP >130 /85mmhg
  • Fasting Plasma Glucose >100mg/dl 
  • Previously diagnosed Type II DM
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No: 3152, 3154.

questions.text: All the following investigations should be done in a 42y old male newly diagnosed with Type II DM except?
questions.solution:
The following tests should be done in newly diagnosed diabetic patient to screen for microvascular and macrovascular complications. -HBA1C, ECG, Fundoscopy ,Urine ACR, Monofilament test, BP screening.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition, Page No 3104.

questions.text: 65y old male known case of diabetes came with Giddiness. On examination BP-160/95mmhg. What would be the appropriate treatment after lifestyle modifications?
questions.solution:
Newly diagnosed Hypertensive patient with history of T2DM, the best line of treatment wound be Amlodipine along with lifestyle modifications.
Prazosin wound be contraindicated in this patient due to his history of dizziness as it can cause orthostatic hypotension.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2082.

questions.text: Identify the condition
questions.solution:
The given image is suggestive of Acanthosis Nigricans. It is strongly associated with Hyperinsulinemia with insulin resistance. Elevated circulating fatty acids are considered to be major factor in development of insulin resistance.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 19th Edition, Page No- 2857.

questions.text: A male patient, chronic smoker presented with cough and skin hyperpigmentation. During further evaluation, he is found to have high ACTH levels that remained high even after administration of high-dose dexamethasone. What is the underlying cause of this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with features suggestive of Cushing’s syndrome:

  • Skin hyperpigmentation: Due to high ACTH, which stimulates melanocyte-stimulating hormone (MSH)

  • Chronic smoker and cough: Raises suspicion for lung tumor

High-dose dexamethasone suppression test (HDDST):

  • Pituitary adenoma (Cushing’s disease): ACTH levels suppress with high-dose dexamethasone

  • Ectopic ACTH secretion (e.g., small cell lung carcinoma, bronchial carcinoid): ACTH levels do not suppress, indicating ACTH production outside the pituitary

Other options:

  • Pituitary adenoma: Typically shows partial suppression on high-dose dexamethasone

  • Adrenal cortical adenoma: Causes low ACTH due to negative feedback

  • Exogenous steroids: ACTH and cortisol are usually suppressed

questions.text: A 10-year-old child with a known case of type 1 DM presents with confusion. The blood glucose level is 353 mg/dl and pH-7.0. What is the metabolic abnormality?
questions.solution:
• Patient: Type 1 DM, presents with confusion

  • Labs: Blood glucose 353 mg/dL, pH 7.0

Interpretation:

  1. Normal blood pH: 7.35–7.45

    • pH 7.0 → severe acidemia

  2. Hyperglycemia in type 1 DM → suggests diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)

    • DKA → accumulation of ketone bodies → metabolic acidosis

  3. Other options:

    • Metabolic alkalosis → high pH, not seen here

    • Respiratory alkalosis → high pH, low CO, usually due to hyperventilation

    • Respiratory acidosis → low pH, high CO, usually due to hypoventilation

questions.text: Which of the following is the best method to detect HbA1c?
questions.solution:
• HbA1c reflects the glycated fraction of hemoglobin, indicating average blood glucose over the past 2–3 months.

  • Ion-exchange chromatography is considered the gold standard because it:

    • Separates hemoglobin based on charge differences between glycated and non-glycated forms

    • Provides accurate and reproducible quantification of HbA1c

  • Other methods:

    • Electrophoresis: Can separate hemoglobin variants but is less precise for HbA1c quantification

    • Immunoassay: Uses antibodies against glycated hemoglobin; good for routine labs, but slightly less precise than ion-exchange chromatography

    • Affinity chromatography: Uses boronate affinity for glycated hemoglobin; useful but less widely used as standard

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the diagnostic criteria for diabetic ketoacidosis
questions.solution:
To establish the diagnosis of DKA, three of the following components should be present:
1) elevated plasma glucose (>250 mg/dL),
2) the presence of ketones (in serum or urine), and
3) presence of acidosis (serum bicarbonate <18 mEq/L and/or arterial pH <7.30)
4) anion gap [calculated as Sodium - (chloride + bicarbonate)]should be elevated.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3115.

questions.text: Identify the following condition
questions.solution:
• The given image is suggestive of hypercortisolism- Cushing's syndrome
  • Cushings disease is specifically Cushing's syndrome which occurs due to Pitutary corticotrope adenoma.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2959-2965.

choices.text: Normal or low calcium low phosphorus levels

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding nutritional rickets?
questions.solution:
• Initially, low calcium levels in the blood stimulate increased PTH secretion from the parathyroid glands that results in bone resorption and increased reabsorption of calcium and increased excretion of phosphorus in the kidneys.
  • Hence blood calcium levels can be low to normal with low phosphorus evels and high ALP due to increased bone resorption activity.
  • Due to increased PTH secretion there is low urine calcium excretion and high urinary phosphate excretion are seen.
Reference: Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 9th Edition, Page No 113.

questions.text:
A 9 year boy comes with sexual maturity rating 5, height for age > chronological age, hyperpigmentation and short stature. His blood pressure measured 200/110mmHg.
Which of the following enzymes deficiency is responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
• 11 Beta hydroxylase deficiency is a variant of congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH) causing increased aldosterone and testosterone activity with reduced cortisol levels.
  • The given clinical scenario of precocious puberty(SMR grading of 5 in a 9 year old boy) with height age> chronological age with short stature and increased blood pressure 180/110 suggests 11 beta hydroxylase deficient variant of CAH.
Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st Edition, Page No 2972,2976-77.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman presented with complaints of bone pain and abdominal cramps. Her family says she has a history of abnormal behavior. The consultant doctor arrived at a provisional diagnosis based on the clinical features. Which of the following would be the best investigation to arrive at a definitive diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features presented are indicative of primary hyperparathyroidism. The most common cause of primary hyperparathyroidism is parathyroid adenoma, and diagnosis of this condition often involves a Tc99m sestamibi scan.

Clinical Features of Hyperparathyroidism:
1. Bones:
Pathological fractures
Subperiosteal bone resorption, particularly affecting the radial aspect of the 2nd and 3rd digits
Salt-and-pepper skull
Osteitis fibrosa cystica, also known as Von Recklinghausen's disease
2. Stones:
Multiple and recurrent renal stones, which are the most common manifestation
Nephrocalcinosis
3. Abdominal Groans:
Colicky abdominal pain due to pancreatitis
4. Psychiatric Overtones:
Elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) levels can lead to central nervous system depression and various psychiatric symptoms
5. Band Keratopathy
6. Features of Hypercalcemia:
Vomiting
Confusion
ECG changes, such as increased PR interval and shortened QT interval

Nuclear medicine scanning with radiolabeled Sestamibi is a commonly used technique for this diagnosis. Sestamibi accumulates in parathyroid adenomas and is taken up by both thyroid and parathyroid tissues; however, it typically washes out from normal thyroid tissue within an hour. It remains in abnormal parathyroid tissue, making it one of the most accurate and reliable methods for imaging the parathyroid glands.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most common cause of mortality in diabetic ketoacidosis?
questions.solution:
Cerebral Edema in Diabetic Ketoacidosis:
Leading Cause of Mortality: Cerebral edema is a significant cause of mortality in patients with DKA, particularly in children.

Pathophysiology:

High blood glucose levels create an osmolar gradient that causes a shift of water from the intracellular fluid (ICF) to the extracellular fluid (ECF).
This leads to cell volume contraction.
Treatment with insulin and intravenous fluids can quickly reduce effective osmolarity, causing a reversal of the fluid shift and potentially resulting in cerebral edema.

Other Complications of Diabetic Ketoacidosis:
1. Cerebral Edema: Particularly concerning in children.
2. Cardiac Arrhythmias: Resulting from electrolyte imbalances, especially potassium.
3. Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): A serious lung condition that can develop.
4. Venous Thrombosis: Increased risk of blood clots.
5. Acute Gastric Dilation: Distension of the stomach.
6. Acute Kidney Injury: Due to dehydration and other metabolic factors.
7. Intestinal Necrosis: Compromised blood flow can lead to bowel tissue death.
8. Acute Pancreatitis: Inflammation of the pancreas can occur.
9. Mucormycosis: A rare but serious fungal infection that can arise in immunocompromised patients.

questions.text: What disorder occurs if the marked region of the adrenal gland is affected?
questions.solution:
The provided image illustrates a cross-section of the adrenal gland, which plays a crucial role in the development of Cushing's disease, characterized by an overproduction of adrenocorticoids from the adrenal cortex.



Cushing's syndrome refers to a collection of clinical symptoms that arise from prolonged exposure to excessive glucocorticoids, regardless of the cause. In contrast, Cushing's disease specifically denotes Cushing's syndrome that results from a pituitary corticotrope adenoma.

questions.text: The most common cause of Cushing's disease in a 60-year-old male is ACTH-Adrenocorticotropic hormone
questions.solution:
The most prevalent cause of Cushing's disease in a 60-year-old male is a pituitary microadenoma.

Cortisol production is elevated due to the secretion of adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH) from the pituitary gland in the brain. The condition known as hypercortisolemia (overproduction of cortisol) leads to Cushing's syndrome, which commonly occurs when a pituitary adenoma (a benign tumor) produces an excess of ACTH.

This excess ACTH stimulates cortisol production, leading to levels that can be approximately three times higher than normal.

So, 

  • Cushing’s syndrome = clinical state of hypercortisolism (can be ACTH-dependent or independent).

  • Cushing’s disease = specifically due to pituitary ACTH-secreting adenoma.

    • In most cases: pituitary microadenoma (<10 mm) is the cause.

  • Other causes:

    • Ectopic ACTH syndrome → commonly due to small-cell lung cancer or bronchial carcinoid.

    • Adrenal tumors → cause ACTH-independent Cushing’s (high cortisol, suppressed ACTH).

In a 60-year-old male, small-cell lung cancer with ectopic ACTH is possible, but the most common cause of Cushing’s disease overall = pituitary microadenoma.

questions.text: A patient presents with complaints of sudden onset headache, palpitation, and profuse sweating. The patient has had multiple similar episodes in the past. During these episodes, the patient's blood pressure is elevated. A 24-hour urinary metanephrine is elevated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for this patient is pheochromocytoma.

Pheochromocytoma is a rare tumor of the sympathetic nervous system that originates in the adrenal medulla. Patients typically present with a classic triad of symptoms: palpitations, headaches, and profuse sweating. Additionally, they may experience hypertension and cardiac arrhythmias. These symptoms result from an excess of catecholamines secreted by the tumor.

Other Options:
Option B: Addison's Disease

This condition is characterized by primary adrenal insufficiency, where the adrenal glands fail to secrete adequate amounts of cortisol (a glucocorticoid) and aldosterone (a mineralocorticoid). Symptoms include fatigue, weight loss, anorexia, low blood pressure, postural hypotension, hypoglycemia, nausea, vomiting, abdominal pain, salt craving, hyponatremia, and hyperkalemia.

Option C: Renal Artery Stenosis

This condition is a relatively common finding in older patients with chronic essential hypertension. However, it is clinically significant (leading to renovascular hypertension) only if the stenosis exceeds 75% in both renal arteries or is at least 50% with post-stenotic dilatation.
The two major causes of bilateral renal artery stenosis are:
Atherosclerosis (most common), affecting patients over 45 years of age.
Fibromuscular Dysplasia, which most frequently affects women under 50 years of age.

Option D: Hyperthyroidism

This condition presents with symptoms including heat intolerance, sweating, tachycardia, palpitations, weight loss with increased appetite, diarrhea, and oligomenorrhea. Clinical findings may include exophthalmos, tremors, and myopathy.

questions.text: Which of the following parameters is used to assess recovery in patient with DKA?
questions.solution: IN a DKA patient anion gap is used to assess improvement and recovery of patient from DK serum anion gap is usually high in patients with DKA. As the patient recovers from DKA, there is less production of keto acids, thus leading to normalisation of the anion gap. Ref - Harrison principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition page 2871

questions.text:
A patient presents with polyuria, polydipsia, lethargy and abdominal pain. She also gives a history of mood disorders and recurrent kidney stones.
Which of the following investigations would not be useful in arriving at a diagnosis?
questions.solution: clinical scenario of recurrent kidney stones, mood disorder and features of hypercalcemia (polyuria, polydipsia) is suggestive of primary hyperparathyroidism. Angiography of renal arteries is not a useful investigation for hyperparathyroidism. USG neck- localise abnormal parathyroid glands. DEXA- Demonstration of skeletal involvement in Primary Hyperparathyroidism. Ref- Harrison Principle of Internal Medicine 19th Edition Page 313

choices.text: Of the following, the next best step in the management of this patient is to:
Order a thyroid radionuclide uptake and scan

questions.text: A 40-year-old female patient presents with cold intolerance, dry skin, constipation, and on examination slow ankle jerk with a TSH level of 15 IU/L and low T3, and T4. Of the following, the next best step in the management of this patient is to:
questions.solution:
This patient has clinical features of hypothyroidism:

  • Cold intolerance, dry skin, constipation

  • Slow ankle jerk – a classical sign

  • TSH = 15 IU/L (elevated)

  • Low T3 and T4 = Overt primary hypothyroidism

    Why option 4 is correct:

  • The elevated TSH with low free T4 confirms primary hypothyroidism.

  • No further diagnostic testing is necessary at this point.

  • The next step is to initiate levothyroxine replacement therapy.

    Why other options are incorrect:

  1. TBG levels – useful in evaluating total T4 abnormalities when free T4 is normal; not indicated here.

  2. Radionuclide scan – used for evaluating thyrotoxicosis, not hypothyroidism.

  3. Thyroid ultrasound – helps in evaluating nodules or goiters, not necessary unless a palpable nodule is present.


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 2701

questions.text: ___ excreted in the urine are used as a screening test for pheochromocytoma.
questions.solution:
• Pheochromocytoma is a catecholamine-secreting tumor (usually of the adrenal medulla) that produces epinephrine, norepinephrine, and dopamine.

  • These catecholamines are metabolized to:

    • Metanephrines (normetanephrine and metanephrine)

    • Vanillylmandelic acid (VMA)

  • Urinary metanephrines and VMA are measured as screening and diagnostic markers for pheochromocytoma.

    Why not the others?

  • 1. Glucose – Screen for diabetes, not pheochromocytoma.

  • 2. Albumin – Seen in kidney disease, not pheochromocytoma.

  • 4. 5-HIAA – Used to screen for carcinoid tumors, not pheochromocytoma.
     

    Pheochromocytoma is a rare catecholamine-secreting tumor that arises from chromaffin cells, most commonly in the adrenal medulla. It can be part of familial syndromes such as MEN type 2A and 2B, Von Hippel-Lindau (VHL) disease, Neurofibromatosis type 1 (NF1), and mutations in the succinate dehydrogenase (SDH) complex genes.

    The classic clinical triad includes episodic headache, palpitations, and profuse sweating. These episodes are often associated with paroxysmal hypertension, though sustained hypertension may also occur. Other symptoms can include tremors, anxiety, pallor, chest pain, and hyperglycemia.

    The screening test of choice is plasma free metanephrines due to its high sensitivity. For confirmation, a 24-hour urinary collection for metanephrines and vanillylmandelic acid (VMA) is done.

    Clonidine suppression testing may be used to distinguish between true tumor-related catecholamine excess and other causes of sympathetic overactivity. Once biochemically confirmed, imaging such as MRI or CT is used to localize the tumor. For extra-adrenal or metastatic disease, MIBG scintigraphy or PET scans may be useful.

    Management begins with pre-operative alpha-adrenergic blockade, typically with phenoxybenzamine, to prevent intraoperative hypertensive crises.

    Beta-blockers may be added only after adequate alpha-blockade if the patient has persistent tachycardia. The definitive treatment is surgical excision, usually laparoscopic adrenalectomy. Postoperative monitoring is essential, as recurrence or metastatic disease can occur.


Reference: Harper's illustrated Biochemistry 30th edition page no 488-489

choices.text: Urine protein levels range from 30 mg/d to 300 mg/d
It is an independent risk factor for cardiovascular morbidity in diabetic patients
It is the earliest marker of diabetic nephropathy
It is detected by routine dipstick method

questions.text: Which of the following medications is incorrect about microalbuminuria?
questions.solution:
• Microalbuminuria cannot  be detected using routine dipstick tests as they are insensitive to low levels of albumin in urine.
 
  • Routine dipstick methods typically detect higher concentrations of protein, and may not be sensitive enough to detect microalbuminuria, but some specialized dipstick tests or laboratory tests may be able to detect.
 
  • Microalbuminuria is beneath detection by urinary dipstick protein analysis. Any detectable albuminuria on dipstick is called overt proteinuria and when detected at the highest level on the strip is consistent with Nephrotic range proteinuria.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2282.

questions.text: What does this crystal from a urine analysis stand for?
questions.solution:
Calcium oxalate crystals have a distinctive 'X' mark and are square in shape. They are typically described as “Envelope shaped” stones.
  • Struvite stones resemble the lid of a coffin.
  • Uric acid crystals can form rosettes and are frequently needle-shaped.
  • Hexagonal crystals make up cystine.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2370.

choices.text: High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis

questions.text: A CKD patient complains of vomiting. His ABG reports are as follows: pH = 7.40, pCO2 = 40, HCO3 = 23, Na = 145, chloride = 100. The findings point to:
questions.solution:
High anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis.

The clinical history is crucial in this case even though the ABG appears to be entirely normal.
  • Patients with CKD typically exhibit significant ion gap metabolic acidosis. In light of it, the patient has started to vomit (which is the state of alkalosis). The ABG in this condition has returned to normal due to both opposing illnesses.
  • The patient therefore has severe anion gap metabolic acidosis together with metabolic alkalosis.

The likely diagnosis is high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) alongside metabolic alkalosis.

Interpretation of the ABG:'
  • Step 1:The pH of 7.4 is within the normal range.  
  • Step 2: The plasma bicarbonate level is 23 mEq/L, which is also normal. At this point, we can exclude options A and C, as this clinical situation does not indicate a straightforward acid-base disorder.  
  • Step 3: Calculating the anion gap:  

Anion gap = [Na+] - ([Cl-] + [HCO3-])  
= 145 - (100 + 23)  
= 22 mEq/L  

A high anion gap confirms the presence of an acid-base disorder, ruling out option A. A high anion gap suggests metabolic acidosis. However, the normal bicarbonate levels indicate that metabolic alkalosis is also present in this patient.

This can be further validated by calculating the delta gap:  
 
  • Delta gap = (AAG - HCO3-)  
  • In this case, Delta gap = (22 - 10) - (24 - 23) = 11 mEq/L.  
  • A delta gap of +6 suggests that metabolic alkalosis exists alongside HAGMA.
  • If the delta gap is significantly positive (> +6), it indicates metabolic alkalosis due to a greater rise in the anion gap compared to the fall in bicarbonate. Conversely, if the delta gap is significantly negative (<6), hyperchloremic acidosis is typically present, as the rise in the anion gap is less than the fall in bicarbonate.

Alternatively, we can use the delta ratio:  
  • Delta ratio = Increase in Anion Gap / Decrease in HCO3-.  
  • This ratio is useful when assessing high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) to determine if it is a 'pure' HAGMA or if there is coexisting normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA) or metabolic alkalosis.  

Delta ratio values:  

1-2 indicates HAGMA,  
1 indicates NAGMA + HAGMA,  
2 indicates HAGMA + metabolic alkalosis.  

In this case, the delta ratio is 12/1 = 12. Thus, the acid-base disorder in this scenario is HAGMA with metabolic alkalosis.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text: What is the best KDIGO criteria marker for distinguishing renal from pre-renal acute kidney injury?
questions.solution:
Urine Na  x serum creatinine /Serum Na x  Urine creatinine is the best marker in KDIGO criteria to differentiate renal from pre-renal acute kidney injury. This is the formula for fractional excretion of sodium (FeNa).

In AKI, there is abrupt loss of kidney function, resulting in retention of urea and other nitrogenous waste products and dysregulation of extracellular volume and electrolytes.

The term AKI has largely replaced acute renal failure (ARF).


Difference between Pre-renal and Intrinsic Renal AKI:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2303, 2305.

questions.text: Which is the most sensitive indicator of renal tubular function?
questions.solution:
Specific gravity of urine is the most sensitive marker of renal tubular function.

The ability of the kidneys to concentrate, specifically renal tubular function, is measured by urinary specific gravity. Better indices of general renal health and GFR are the serum creatinine levels and clearance.

The best indicator of glomerular function is the GFR.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2305, 2357.

questions.text: In which of the following situations is a normal anion gap metabolic acidosis not seen?
questions.solution:
Salicylate poisoning leads to high anion-gap metabolic acidosis.
 
  • Proximal renal tubular acidosis (RIA), pancreatitis and diarrhea lead to normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.
 
  • Salicylates have a direct effect on the respiratory center in the brain leading to hyperventilation.
 
  • The body responds to hyperventilation by having the kidneys produce more bicarbonate and excrete more potassium which leads to an elevated anion gap metabolic acidosis.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 361, 364.

questions.text: The acid base status of a patient reveals a pH=7.45, pO2=105mm and pCO2=30 mmHg, HCO3-: 20. The patient has partially compensated. Identify the disorder?
questions.solution:
Respiratory alkalosis is a condition in which the blood pH increases due to increased elimination of carbon dioxide from the body. It is caused by hyperventilation. When there is an increase in the amount of carbon dioxide eliminated, the pH of the blood will rise to 7.45 (a slight alkaline reading) and the PCO2 level will decrease to 30mmHg. The overall change is slightly alkaline, and the respiratory change is also alkaline. Therefore, the diagnosis is respiratory alkalosis.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text: A little youngster has acute pyelonephritis. What is the most precise urinary finding?
questions.solution:
• WBC casts are specific urinary findings in acute pyelonephritis, a urinary tract infection that can affect the kidneys.
  • This type of cast is a collection of white blood cells (WBCs) that form within the renal tubules of the affected kidney. These casts indicate that the infection is not just affecting the bladder, but has spread to the kidneys and is causing inflammation.
  • They can be seen under a microscope and are often seen in cases of severe infection.







Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2304.

questions.text: A patient has a three-day history of vomiting. Upon investigation, dehydration was discovered. After additional testing, it was discovered that the patient had elevated creatinine, a pH of 7.22, a pCO2 of 24 mm Hg, an HCO3 of 9 mEq, a Na+ of 138 mEq/L, and a K+ of 3.4 mEq/L. Decide which acid-base imbalance this patient has:
questions.solution:
On examining the values it appears to be a case of Metabolic acidosis
  • pH decreased (Normal= 7.35-7.45) = Acidosis
  • Normal=40–45 mm Hg. Here, pCO2 dropped. A lower pCO2 will attempt to raise pH. The mechanism must thus be a secondary compensatory one.
 
  • According to compensation formula for Metabolic alkalosis, Paco2 = [HCO3–] + 15.
  • Here in this question, PaCO2 value should be 9+15 = 24 (22-26) +- 2. It signifies there is full respiratory compensation.
  • Therefore, it is a case of Metabolic acidosis with respiratory compensation.
 

As a result, the main factor contributing to the Acid-Base imbalance must be a drop in serum bicarbonate levels, or metabolic acidosis.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same
 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text: Determine the base deficit in a patient weighing 75 kg with a pH of 6.96, a pCO2 of 30, and an HCO3-- level of 6 mEq/L:
questions.solution:
The base deficit in the patient turns out to be around 500 mEq.

It can be calculated using:

Total bicarbonate deficit= 0.3 x weight (kg) x base deficit (Standard Base deficit)

Base deficit= 0.4 x Weight (in Kg) x [24- (Sr. bicarbonate)]

Here, BE= 0.4 x 75 x [24-6] = 540 m.eq which is approximately near 500 m.eq



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 360.

questions.text: A patient with lung cancer had a 16.4 mmol/L serum calcium level when they were first seen. What will be the initial management action be?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. IV fluids and furosemide

I.V. fluids and diuretics are the first-line treatments for managing hypercalcemia in an emergency.

Even though IV bisphosphonates are the preferred medication for treating malignant hypercalcemia, their activity doesn't begin for at least 3–4 days, thus they are useless in an urgent situation.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3173, 3183.

questions.text: 8 months after receiving a kidney transplant, an older man with nephropathy presents. Which of the following could be the cause of a viral infection?
questions.solution:
• BK polyoma virus is transmitted through respiratory fluids or urine, since infected individuals periodically excrete virus in the urine. It then disseminates to the kidneys and urinary tract where it persists for the life of the individual.
  • Typically, this is in the setting of kidney transplantation or multi-organ transplantation.
  • BK virus is a latent polyomavirus that lies dormant in the kidney and urothelial tract and can be activated in the setting of immunosuppression. Reactivation of BK, if left untreated, will lead to progressive fibrosis and loss of the graft within 1 year in most cases.
 
  • Presentation in these immunocompromised individuals is much more severe.
  • Clinical manifestations include renal dysfunction (seen by a progressive rise in serum creatinine), and an abnormal urinalysis revealing renal tubular cells and inflammatory cells (Decoy cells).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2330.

questions.text: In contrast-induced nephropathy, which of the following is a sign of renal impairment?
questions.solution:
Contrast nephropathy leads to a rise in serum creatinine within 24-48 hours, peak within 3-5 days, and resolution within 5-7 days.

Iodinated contrast agents, which are commonly used in cardiovascular and CT imaging, are a leading cause of AKI (Acute Kidney Injury). 

The risk of AKI, also known as "contrast nephropathy," is negligible in people with normal renal function, but it rises dramatically in people with chronic kidney disease, particularly diabetic nephropathy.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2300.

questions.text: A patient's laboratory tests revealed pH = 7.3, HCO3- = 15 meq/l and pCO2 = 35 mm Hg. What is the probable primary acid base imbalance?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Metabolic acidosis

Normal range: PH= 7.35-7.45 , pCO2= 40-44mmHg , HCO3=22-28mmol/ml.

Here it is a state of acidosis, with low bicarbonate and low pCO2 which means something in the metabolism was causing acidosis which is now being compensated by CO2 washout by the body via lungs. So, its Metabolic acidosis.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text: Which of the following kidney stones is caused by laxative abuse?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Ammonium urate
 
  • Ammonium urate stones are most likely to be seen in patients with laxative abuse. 
  • Loss of potassium and sodium in laxative abuse causes intracellular acidosis, which increases the production of ammonia in urine. Dehydration and sodium loss further exacerbate hypokalemia and reduces the urinary volume, resulting in hyperuricemia. Highly concentrated uric acid and ammonia promote the formation of ammonium urate stones. 
  • These are also associated with inflammatory bowel disease, chronic diarrhea, ileostomy, recurrent urinary tract infection and recurrent uric acid stone formation. 



Reference: Campbell Walsh Wein Urology, 12th edition, Page no 2032.

questions.text: What is the causes of hypokalemic metabolic alkalosis with hypertension?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Liddle syndrome

The other options are incorrect because:
  1. Bartter syndrome: Bartter syndrome is characterized by excessive renal sodium and chloride excretion, leading to volume depletion, potassium wasting, metabolic alkalosis, and secondary hyperaldosteronism. However, Bartter syndrome is not typically associated with hypertension.
  2. Gitelman syndrome: Gitelman syndrome also involves excessive renal excretion of sodium and chloride, resulting in volume depletion, potassium wasting, metabolic alkalosis, and secondary hyperaldosteronism. However, Gitelman syndrome is not commonly associated with hypertension.
  3. Renal tubular acidosis (RTA): While some forms of RTA can cause hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis, they are not typically associated with hypertension. RTA involves impaired renal tubular acidification, leading to an inability to excrete acid and maintain normal acid-base balance.







Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 349, 350.

questions.text: Plasma urea/ creatinine ratio of 20:1 may be seen in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Pre-renal failure
A plasma urea/creatinine ratio of 20:1 may be seen in pre-renal failure.

Pre-renal failure refers to a condition where there is reduced blood flow to the kidneys, leading to decreased filtration of waste products. This can be caused by factors such as dehydration, hypovolemia (low blood volume), or decreased cardiac output. In pre-renal failure, the kidneys try to conserve water and sodium, resulting in increased reabsorption of urea in the renal tubules and a higher urea/creatinine ratio.
 
  • Rhabdomyolysis (Option 1) is a condition characterized by the breakdown of muscle tissue, which can lead to an increase in creatinine levels, but the urea/creatinine ratio is typically not significantly elevated.
 
  • Ureteric calculi (Option 2) refers to kidney stones that have migrated into the ureter. While it can cause obstruction and kidney dysfunction, it does not typically result in a markedly elevated urea/creatinine ratio.
 
  • Chronic glomerulonephritis (Option 4) is a condition involving inflammation and damage to the glomeruli of the kidneys. It can lead to impaired renal function, but the urea/creatinine ratio may not be as high as in pre-renal failure. Please note that the plasma/urine creatinine ratio is useful in distinguishing between pre-renal and intrinsic renal causes of AKI. A ratio of less than 20:1 suggests pre-renal AKI, while a ratio greater than 20:1 is indicative of intrinsic renal disease.

Difference between Pre-renal and Intrinsic Renal AKI:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2303.

questions.text: Pre-renal azotemia is not characterized by:
questions.solution:
Urinary sodium concentration > 40 meq/l is seen in Intrinsic renal AKI.


Difference between Pre-renal and Intrinsic Renal AKI:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2303, 2306.

questions.text: Maltese cross in urine is seen in
questions.solution:
• The nephropathy of Fabry’s disease typically presents in the third decade as mild to moderate proteinuria, sometimes with microscopic hematuria or nephrotic syndrome. 
  • Urine examination in Fabry disease may reveal oval fat bodies and birefringent glycolipid globules under polarised light showing a Maltese cross appearance.



NOTE: Maltese cross crystals are observed in urine in Fabry disease, nephrotic syndrome, and other conditions like short range shot gun wound and babesiosis.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2345, 2346.

questions.text: A patient with renal failure and anemia comes. Serum Protein Electrophoresis is shown below. What's the diagnosis
questions.solution:
The large spike in the gamma region (M Spike) points toward a diagnosis of Multiple Myeloma.

Renal Failure and anemia are a part of end-organ damage (CRAB criteria of Multiple Myeloma).
In nephrotic syndrome, alpha-2 region spike is seen.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 868, 871.

choices.text: High AG metabolic acidosis with metabolic Alkalosis
High AG metabolic acidosis with normal metabolic Alkalosis

questions.text: What is the  likely abnormality in a patient with renal failure who develops vomiting in ICU and ABG performed shows pH = 7.40. PaCO2 = 40, HCO3 = 24, Anion gap = 21?
questions.solution:
The likely metabolic abnormality in this patient is high anion gap metabolic acidosis with metabolic alkalosis. 
 
  • Patients with renal failure may have metabolic acidosis and associated vomiting in this patient may cause metabolic alkalosis. However, the parameters of arterial blood gas analysis appear to be normal. This disparity raises the suspicion of a mixed acid-base disorder. 
  • When metabolic acidosis and metabolic alkalosis coexist in the same patient, pH may be in the normal range. In such cases, the presence of an elevated anion gap denotes the presence of metabolic acidosis. 
  • AG is high, which points to high AG metabolic acidosis. 
  • In high anion gap metabolic acidosis, excess H+ ions are buffered by bicarbonate and the bicarbonate level falls. The fall in HCO3- is expected to be equal to the rise in anion gap. The difference between the rise in anion gap and the fall in HCO3- (delta gap) is zero in simple HAGMA. 
  • Associated vomiting in this patient results in loss of acid and hence the fall of bicarbonate level is less compared to the rise in the anion gap. A delta gap of more than +6 indicates the presence of additional metabolic alkalosis. 
    In this case, the delta gap is 10, which points to metabolic alkalosis in addition to high AG metabolic acidosis. 
  • Delta gap = (Actual anion gap - Normal anion gap) -(Normal bicarbonate - Actual bicarbonate) 
Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same
 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359-361.

questions.text: Renal feed for CKD patients
questions.solution:
A low-volume diet is preferred to prevent toxic protein degradation byproduct accumulation, sodium and volume overload, hyperkalemia, and hyperphosphatemia.
 
In order to reduce the patient's risk of malnutrition and wasting associated with ESRD, a high-calorie feed is preferred.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2313, 2317.

questions.text:
Renopulmonary syndrome includes
a. Good pasture syndrome
b. Leptospira
c. Hantavirus
d. Wegener's granulomatosis
questions.solution:
All of the given options produce renopulmonary symptoms. 

Pulmonary renal syndrome is a potentially life-threatening condition defined as the combination of diffuse alveolar haemorrhage (DAH) and rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN).
 
  • Leptospirosis: The classic presentation, often referred to as Weil’s syndrome, encompasses the triad of hemorrhage, jaundice, and acute kidney injury. Patients die of septic shock with multiorgan failure and/or severe bleeding complications that most commonly involve the lungs (pulmonary hemorrhage).
  • Hantavirus infection: Hantavirus pulmonary syndrome causes myocardial depression and increased pulmonary vascular permeability.
 

  • Differential diagnoses of pulmonary renal syndrome

    ANCA-associated vasculitis Granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA)
    Microscopic polyangiitis (MPA)
    Eosinophilic granulomatosis with polyangiitis (EGPA)
    Anti-GBM disease Anti-GBM disease (Good Pasture syndrome)
    ANCA-negative vasculitis IgA disease
    Cryoglobulinaemia
    Drug-induced vasculitis Cocaine
    d-penicillamine
    Autoimmune connective tissue disease Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
    Polymyositis
    Diabetes mellitus
    Mixed connective tissue disease (MCTD)
    Systemic sclerosis



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 980, 1420.
Boyle, Niamh et al. “Pulmonary renal syndrome: a clinical review.” Breathe (Sheffield, England) vol. 18,4 (2022): 220208. doi:10.1183/20734735.0208-2022. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC9973488/

questions.text: The lab reports of a patient given below pH=7.2 HCO3- =10 mEq/L PCO2 = 35 mm Hg This exemplifies which of the following disorder
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Metabolic acidosis.
  • In this case: pH = 7.2 (Normal: 7.35-7.45, below 7.35 is considered acidic), blood is too acidic HCO3- (bicarbonate) = 10 mEq/L (Normal range: 22-26 mEq/L).
  • The bicarbonate level is also low, which is another sign of metabolic acidosis.
  • PaCO2 (partial pressure of carbon dioxide) = 35 mm Hg (normal range: 35-45 mm Hg), The PaCO2 is normal, which means that the respiratory system is not contributing to the acidosis.
Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359, 360.

questions.text: A patient with deafness, hematuria and CKD. Light microscopy of urine is normal. Maternal Uncle has similar disease. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Alport syndrome presents with triad of deafness (SNHL), hematuria, and anterior lenticonus. It also lead to Chronic Kidney disease.
 
  • Classically, patients with Alport’s syndrome develop hematuria, thinning and splitting of the GBMs, and mild proteinuria (<1–2 g/24 h), which appears late in the course, followed by chronic glomerulosclerosis leading to renal failure in association with sensorineural deafness.
  • Some patients develop lenticonus of the anterior lens capsule, “dot and fleck” retinopathy, and rarely, leiomyomatosis.
  • Approximately 85% of patients with Alport’s syndrome have an X-linked inheritance of mutationsin the α5(IV) collagen chain on chromosome Xq22–24.

Other options: 
 
  • Thin basement membrane disease does not include deafness or chronic kidney disease.
  • Goodpasture syndrome and PSGN are ruled out by conventional light microscopy.
  • Initially, kidney biopsy specimens examined through light microscopy may be normal in alport syndrome.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2346, 2347.

questions.text: Tachypnea and mental confusion was found in a man aged 55, with ph = 7.0 and blood glucose 350 mg/dl. Name the acid base from the following
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Metabolic acidosis

The given information points to metabolic acidosis based on the following factors:
  1. Tachypnea: Refers to rapid breathing and is a compensatory mechanism to eliminate excess CO2 (acid) from the body in response to acidosis.
  2. Mental confusion: Acidosis can lead to central nervous system (CNS) depression, resulting in symptoms like confusion.

pH 7.0 (Normal: 7.35-7.45) is low indicating acidosis. Blood glucose = 350 mg/dl: Elevated blood glucose levels can lead to diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA), which is a type of metabolic acidosis commonly seen in uncontrolled diabetes.

Trick:- ROMS for pH and pCO2
Respiratory Opposite 
Metabolic Same




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 359-361.

questions.text: A 51-year-old patient arrived at the clinic complaining of hematuria. He was found to have normal blood pressure and pedal edema. Investigations showed the patient had a creatinine level of 9 mg% and no glycosuria. The electron microscopy is shown below. Which of the following investigations should be carried out in order to determine the cause of the disease?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Anti GBM Antibodies
 

  • Anti-GBM antibodies specifically targets the alpha 3 chain of type IV collagen found in the glomerular basement membrane (GBM).
  • In Goodpasture disease, these antibodies cause inflammation in the lungs and kidneys, resulting in a condition known as Rapidly Progressive Glomerulonephritis (RPGN). This can lead to pulmonary hemorrhage in the lungs, as well as to a particular appearance of the kidneys which is called “flea bitten kidneys” upon physical examination.
 
  • Under a microscope, cells called crescents are found in the kidney tissue. Immunofluorescence shows linear patterns of GBM fluorescence for IgG and complement, and electron microscopy reveals ruptures in the GBM.
 
  • Treatment typically involves a combination of plasmapheresis and immunosuppression.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2338, 2339.

questions.text: What is the most critical manifestation of CKD?
questions.solution:
Hyperkalemia is is the most critical manifestation of Chronic kidney disease.
  • It may lead to life threatening cardiac arrythmia and Diastolic arrest.
  • K+ >5.0 mEq/L
  • Acute reduction is required at levels >7.0 mEq/L
  • ECG - Tall peaked T waves

TREATMENT:
 
i. IV Calcium - most rapid and effective way to antagonize myocardial toxic effect
ii. IV Insulin
iii. Beta2 adrenergic agonist
iv. Hemodialysis if hyperkalemia is persistent or severe




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2313, 2316.

questions.text:
What is HAGMA seen with?
a. DKA
b. Lactic acidosis
c. Ethylene glycol poisoning
d. Renal Tubular Acidosis
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. a,b,c are correct
RTA shows Normal AG metabolic acidosis (NAGMA)

Causes of HAGMA: [Mnemonic: MUDPILES]

1. Methanol
2. Uremia
3. Diabetic ketoacidosis
4. Phenformin, Paraldehyde
5. INH, Iron
6. Lactic acid
7. Ethanol, Ethylene glycol
8. Salicylates



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 361.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with dull agonising back discomfort and sterile pyuria. A radiograph is displayed. What cause is most likely?
questions.solution:
• Often seen on plain radiography, a putty kidney is a pattern of renal calcification linked to renal TB.
  • The calcification, which represents calcified caseous tissue, is typically very uniform and ground glass-like.
  • A lobar pattern of calcification, in which dense calcific rims outline the margin of deformed renal lobes, must be distinguished from putty calcification.
  • When it comes to autonephrectomy, lobar calcification is an end-stage look.
  • A patient with abdominal pain and sterile pyuria, with the given x-ray showing diffuse alveolar calcification in the right renal region point towards a diagnosis of a putty kidney. 
  • The putty kidney is a characteristic finding of genitourinary tuberculosis (TB), specifically renal TB. The given image shows a homogenous and ground-glass-like calcification of the kidney appearing like putty.
  • It is caused by the dissemination of the organism through the bloodstream and is thus always a secondary TB. There is either reinfection or reactivation of old TB. 
  • Genitourinary TB is a cause of sterile pyuria.
  • Diagnosis is confirmed with a tuberculin test, or at least 3 consecutive early-morning specimens of urine are examined for acid-fast bacilli. They are stained with a Ziehl-Neelsen stain and subsequently cultured. 
  • CT is the most sensitive modality and is the preferred means of visualizing renal calcifications.
CT urography is done to assess the various stages of renal TB and its manifestations, which are as follows: 

Early:
• Papillary necrosis
Progressive:
• Multifocal strictures
• Generalized or focal hydronephrosis
• Mural thickening and enhancement
• Poorly enhancing renal parenchyma
End-stage:
• Progressive hydronephrosis
• Amorphous dystrophic calcification that involves the entire kidney - putty kidney 

 
  • Treatment involves short-course therapy with antitubercular drugs like pyrazinamide, isoniazid, and rifampicin. Partial nephrectomy, nephrectomy, or reconstructive surgery is often done. 



Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1045, 1046.
Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 748.

choices.text: A rare complication of rapid and aggressive sodium correction

questions.text: An elderly woman experienced uncontrollable vomiting for seven days, along with fluid loss in the stools, decreased food intake, and sensorium changes. She is sent to the hospital, where fluid loss is treated with quick fluids and hyponatremia is treated with electrolyte correction. The patient began to experience quadriplegia and mutism during the course of treatment. What is the correct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical features and the history of the patient indicate that he may be suffering from Central Pontine Myelinolysis (CPM), a disorder due to sudden and rapid correction of chronic hyponatremia, also known as Osmotic Demyelination Syndrome (ODS).
 
  • CPM is the result of a decrease in the amount of salt in the cells surrounding the brainstem, leading to damage of the myelin sheath, which is the protective covering of the nerve cells in the brain.
 
  • Symptoms of CPM include visual disturbances, paralysis, dysphagia, and speech disturbances.
 
  • Treatment includes prompt replacement of fluids and electrolytes.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 344.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a complication of massive blood transfusion?
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia is NOT a complication of massive blood transfusion.

Following are the complications of massive transfusion:
  • Decreased body temperature
  • Acidosis
  • Coagulopathy
  • Raised K+
  • Decreased Mg2+ and Ca2+
  • Air embolism
  • Citrate toxicity


Reference: Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 22.
