questions.text: A woman complains of having abdominal pain. The CECT reveals bilateral papillary necrosis. Which of the following tests should not be performed to find out what caused her papillary necrosis?
questions.solution:
Urine acidification test is mainly done to diagnose RTA (Renal tubular acidosis), NOT the cause of papillary necrosis.

• Though TB is not a major cause but it can cause papillary necrosis, diagnosed by urine RT-PCR.
• Bacterial culture is done for UTI.
• Sickle cell disease can be diagnosed by Sickling test.

Common causes of Renal Papillary Necrosis:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2282, 2348, 2362.

questions.text: What is a patient's urine analysis most likely to show if they have hematuria and hypercalciuria?
questions.solution:
• Urine analysis of a patient with hematuria and hypercalciuria is most likely to reveal isomorphic RBCs.
  • Hypercalciuria is a cause of non-glomerular hematuria.
  • RBCs from a non-glomerular source more closely resemble peripheral blood on microscopy, with isomorphic RBCs and absence of casts.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2280, 2304.

questions.text: What is the least likely scenario in which peripheral eosinophilia and renal failure could occur?
questions.solution:
Peripheral eosinophilia with renal failure is least likely in Polyarteritis nodosa.


Causes of Eosinophiluria: (>1% of urinary Leukocytes as Eosinophils)-
 
  1. Acute interstitial nephritis
  2. Acute rejection of renal allograft
  3. Acute glomerulonephritis (RPGN, PSGN)
  4. Chronic pyelonephritis
  5. Cholesterol embolization of kidney (atheroembolic renal failure)
  6. Bladder cancer
  7. Obstructive uropathy



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2279, 2281, 2304.

questions.text: Which of the following fruit juices can help prevent UTI if consumed on a regular basis?
questions.solution:
Regular drinking of cranberry juice can prevent UTI.
 
  • Cranberry juice is traditionally used for prophylaxis and treatment of UTI.
  • Cranberry juice contains proanthocyanidins that block adherence of pathogens to uroepithelial cells in vitro.
  • Non-antimicrobial prevention is increasingly being studied. Lactobacillus probiotics are one appealing approach to UTI prevention, but there is a paucity of data to support this strategy. Similarly, studies of cranberry products for UTI prevention have produced mixed results.


Reference: Jepson, R G et al. “Cranberries for treating urinary tract infections.” The Cochrane database of systematic reviews vol. 1998,2 (2000): CD001322. doi:10.1002/14651858.CD001322. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7025796/

Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1078.

questions.text: A Hepatitis C patient has hematuria, proteinuria, and hypocomplementemia (2 g/day). What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Most probable diagnosis in this case is MPGN.

Type 1 MPGN has following features:
    • presence of subendothelial deposits of immune complexes associated with activation of the classical complement pathway.
    • persistent hepatitis C
    • exhibits hypo-complimentemia with proteinuria and hematuria.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2336, 2340, 2341.

questions.text: Which of the following is not indicated in a patient with cystinuria and multiple renal stones?
questions.solution:
All are indicated in a patient with cystinuria with multiple renal stones except cysteamine.

Treatment modality of patient with cystinuria with multiple renal stones:
    • increase in urine volume (increase fluid intake)
    • alkalinization of urine
    • penicillamine
    • tiopronin



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3274.

questions.text: Which of the following advice is not given top a 35 years old female patient with recurrent renal stone?
questions.solution:
Advice not given to a 35 year old female patient with recurrent renal stone is restricted calcium intake.

Including a source of calcium at every meal may help reduce the formation of oxalate stones because calcium binds to oxalate in food and stops it from being absorbed by the body.

Increased sodium intake has shown to increase renal stones therefore decreasing sodium intake is advised. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2365, 2372.

questions.text: A 28-year-old man has anterior lenticonus and ESRD now. His maternal uncle also died of a similar illness. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis is Alport's syndrome.

This given clinical picture is a typical clinical picture of Alport's syndrome

Triad seen in Alport's syndrome:
  1. hereditary nephritis
  2. sensorineural deafness
  3. ocular abnormalities(anterior lenticonus)
 
  • Classically, patients with Alport’s syndrome develop hematuria, thinning and splitting of the GBMs, and mild proteinuria (<1–2 g/24 h), which appears late in the course, followed by chronic glomerulosclerosis leading to renal failure in association with sensorineural deafness.
  • Some patients develop lenticonus of the anterior lens capsule, “dot and fleck” retinopathy, and rarely, leiomyomatosis.
  • Approximately 85% of patients with Alport’s syndrome have an X-linked inheritance of mutationsin the α5(IV) collagen chain on chromosome Xq22–24.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2346, 2347.

questions.text: A patient presents with pain in the Metatarsophalangeal (MTP) joints and is a known case of chronic renal failure. This is due to the accumulation of :
questions.solution:
This is due to accumulation of uric acid.

Gout is a disorder of purine metabolism characterized by hyperuricemia, deposition of monosodium urate-monohydrate crystals in joints and peri-articular tissues recurrent attacks of acute synovitis.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2279, 2863.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about type 1 renal tubular acidosis?
questions.solution:
All are true about type-1 renal tubular acidosis except 3. sodium bicarbonate requirement > 4mg/day

Treatment modality of type-1 RTA:
 
  • Early initiation of alkali replacement at doses equivalent to 1-3 mmol/kg per day of bicarbonate in divided doses will usually correct the acidosis, hypokalemia, and hypocitraturia, maintaining growth and preventing bone disease in early-onset dRTA.
  • Citrate is generally tolerated better than sodium bicarbonate and can be given as the potassium or sodium salt. depending on the severity of hypokalemia.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2291-2294.

questions.text: A male adolescent appears with hypercalciuria, nephrocalcinosis, metabolic alkalosis, and hypokalemia. He has normal blood pressure. It is highly likely that:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Bartter Syndrome
 
  • The case involves a male adolescent with hypercalciuria, nephrocalcinosis, metabolic alkalosis, and hypokalemia.
  • These symptoms, along with normal blood pressure, are highly suggestive of Bartter Syndrome.
  • Bartter Syndrome is a rare genetic disorder affecting kidney salt reabsorption, leading to potassium, chloride, and sodium loss in the urine, resulting in hypokalemia and metabolic alkalosis.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2286, 2287, 2293.

questions.text: In dialysis patients, what trace element is linked to the risk of osteomalacia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Aluminium
 
  • In dialysis patients, there is a risk of developing osteomalacia.
  • Osteomalacia is a softening of the bones that can cause pain, weakness, and fractures. It is caused by a deficiency of vitamin D, which is needed for the bones to absorb calcium.
  • Aluminium toxicity is linked to the development of osteomalacia in dialysis patients.
  • Excess aluminium accumulation can occur in these patients due to the use of aluminium-containing phosphate binders or exposure to aluminium in the dialysis process.
  • Prolonged exposure to high levels of aluminium in the dialysis fluid can lead to the accumulation of aluminium in the bones, causing osteomalacia



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2307, 2308.

questions.text: All of the following are caused by primary adrenal insufficiency, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Elevated plasma volume 
 
  • Addison's disease is a primary adrenal insufficiency in which the adrenal is unable to secrete adequate amounts of cortisol (glucocorticoid), aldosterone (mineralocorticoid), and sex hormones. The most common cause of Addison's disease is autoimmune adrenalitis. 
  • The key symptoms include:
         A. Increased urine output
         B. Weight loss with edema,
         C. Decreased urine osmolarity
  • There is decreased retention of sodium and water in the body, which leads to a decrease in plasma volume

Clinical features of Addison’s disease:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2971, 2972.

questions.text: Anuria in clinical practice is defined as:
questions.solution:
• Anuria is a medical condition in which the body produces little or no urine.
  • In clinical practice, anuria is defined as a urine output of less than 50 ml per day.
  • Anuria is a serious condition that can lead to the buildup of toxins in the body and can be caused by a variety of factors such as kidney failure, dehydration, and certain medications.
  • Oliguria is defined as <400 mL/24 h.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2279, 2302.

questions.text: Which of the following best defines Microscopic Hematuria as:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: 3 or More RBC/HPF
 
  • Microscopic hematuria : Presence of RBCs in the urine, visible only under a microscope.
  • It is defined as the presence of 3 or more RBCs per high-power field (HPF) on microscopic examination of the urine.
  • Microscopic hematuria is a common finding and can be caused by various conditions like urinary tract infections, kidney stones, and kidney disease.
  • In contrast, gross hematuria refers to visible blood in the urine.

Other options:
 
  • Macroscopic hematuria: Presence of 5 or more RBCs/HPF.
  • Severe hematuria: 25 or more RBCs/HPF and 50 or more RBCs/HPF.



Reference: Bolenz, Christian et al. “The Investigation of Hematuria.” Deutsches Arzteblatt international vol. 115,48 (2018): 801-807. doi:10.3238/arztebl.2018.0801. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6365675/

questions.text: Distal renal tubular acidosis is associated with:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Calcium stones 
 
  • The clinical features of RTA-1 or distal RTA include diarrhea and renal stones with metabolic acidosis, alkaline urine, hypokalemia, positive urine anion gap, and hypercalciuria.
  • RTA-1 occurs due to defective urinary acidification in the cortical collecting tubule due to ineffective H+ ion secretion by the alpha-intercalated cells. This leads to the formation of alkaline urine. The decreased H+ secretion also leads to inadequate HCO3- regeneration in the alpha-intercalated cells thus leading to metabolic acidosis.
 
  • In this condition, calcium phosphate and oxalate stones are formed in the distal convoluting tubules(DCT).
  • Acidemia leads to hypercalcemia and then hypercalciuria. There is also hypocitraturia as acidemia induces increased cell citrate utilization. Normally, citrate in the urine binds to calcium and increases its solubility. In the absence of citrate in the urine, calcium begins to precipitate. This leads to nephrocalcinosis and calcium phosphate and oxalate stones.
     






Reference: Brenner and Rector's The Kidney, 10th edition, Page no 2384.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th edition, Page no 2172.

questions.text: An exception to low Renin Hypertension is seen in all of the following ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Renovascular hypertension 
 
  • Renal artery stenosis (RAS) is the narrowing of one or both renal arteries, causing high blood pressure, but not low renin levels.
  • Renovascular Hypertension is the exception to the typical pattern of low Renin Hypertension.
  • Renovascular hypertension is high blood pressure caused by narrowed or blocked renal arteries supplying blood to the kidneys.
  • The reduced blood flow triggers the kidneys to produce more renin, resulting in elevated renin levels.
  • In contrast to other conditions associated with low renin levels, Renovascular Hypertension presents with high renin levels due to the narrowed renal arteries.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2088, 2089.

questions.text: Which of the following is an exception to Dent's disease characteristics?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Distal Renal Tubule defect 
 
  • Dent's disease is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by inactivating mutation in CLN5, a chloride transpoter expressed in endosomes of the proximal tubule (Dent disease 1) or OCRL gene mutation (Dent disease 2).
  • Seen more commonly in males.
 
The clinical diagnosis of Dent's disease is based on the presence of all three of the following criteria:
 
  1. LMW proteinuria (elevation of urinary excretion of β2-microglobulin, Clara cell protein and/or RBP by at least 5-fold above the upper limit of normality)
  2. Hypercalciuria (> 4 mg/kg in a 24 h-hour collection or > 0.25 mg Ca2+ per mg creatinine on a spot sample)
  3. At least one of the following: nephrocalcinosis, kidney stones, hematuria, hypophosphataemia, or renal insufficiency


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2292, 2293.

questions.text: The cause of Dialysis disequilibrium is-
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Reverse Urea effect 
 
  • Dialysis disequilibrium is a condition seen in dialysis patients due to rapid changes in urea and other solute levels in the blood during dialysis.
  • The most common cause of dialysis disequilibrium is the "reverse urea effect",where blood urea levels drop too quickly.
  • Rapid drop in blood urea creates concentration gradient, driving water into brain cells, causing cerebral edema (brain swelling).
  • Symptoms of dialysis disequilibrium include headache, nausea, vomiting, and confusion.
 
  • When DDS is suspected, strong consideration should be given to discontinuing the dialysis treatment.
  • Management of DDS is supportive, as with any other patient with acute neurologic deterioration and suspected raised intracranial pressure and cerebral edema. Maintain the airway and consider hyperventilation.
  • In addition, the cerebral edema can be treated by increasing plasma osmolality with mannitol or hypertonic saline to reduce the osmotic gradient between the blood and brain

Other options:
  • Hypertension, aluminium toxicity, and amyloid deposition are potential complications of dialysis but are not responsible for causing dialysis disequilibrium.


Reference: Mistry, Kirtida. “Dialysis disequilibrium syndrome prevention and management.” International journal of nephrology and renovascular disease vol. 12 69-77. 30 Apr. 2019, doi:10.2147/IJNRD.S165925. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6503314/

questions.text: A 30-year-old man arrives with hypertension and widespread edema. A urine examination reveals microscopic hematuria and sub nephrotic proteinuria (2 gm).He has anti-hepatitis C antibodies and his serum complement levels have dropped. The following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Cryoglobulinemia

Clinical features of chronic hepatitis C are similar to those described above for chronic hepatitis B. Generally, fatigue is the most common symptom; jaundice is rare. Immune complex–mediated extrahepatic complications of chronic hepatitis C are less common than in chronic hepatitis B (despite the fact that assays for immune complexes are often positive in patients with chronic hepatitis C), with the exception of essential mixed cryoglobulinemia, which is linked to cutaneous vasculitis and membranoproliferative glomerulonephritis as well as lymphoproliferative disorders such as B-cell lymphoma and unexplained monoclonal gammopathy.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2334-2336; 2604

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman arrives with hypertension, skin ulceration, and generalized edema. A urine examination reveals microscopic hematuria and sub nephrotic proteinuria (2 gm). She tests positive for hepatitis C and has lower serum complement levels. It is highly likely that:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Essential Mixed Cryoglobulinemia
 
  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of mixed cryoglobulinemia, which is strongly associated with hepatitis C.
  • Cryoglobulinemia means the presence of cryoglobulins (immunoglobulins that precipitate at temperatures less than 37°C) in the serum.
  • Deposition of these immune complexes leads to cutaneous vasculitis (skin ulcers, purpura), arthritis, peripheral neuropathy, and glomerulonephritis.
  • The presence of a measurable amount of cryoglobulin (cryocrit) with low C4 complement levels is the laboratory hallmark of cryoglobulinemia.
  • Membranoproliferative Glomerulonephritis (MPGN) and Focal Segmental Glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) can also cause glomerulonephritis, but they are not typically associated with cryoglobulinemia or hepatitis C infection


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2334-2336; 2604

choices.text: Failure to acidify urine to a pH<5
Associated with increased risk of urinary stones

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding Type I Renal Tubular Acidosis (RTA)?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Associated with Hyperkalemia
 
  • RTA type I (distal RTA) is seen in autoimmune diseases like Sjogren's syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, systemic sclerosis, medullary sponge kidney disease, cirrhosis, drugs like amphotericin B, lithium, etc.
  • The patients develop hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis with alkaline urine (urinary pH >5.5). 
  • Type I RTA is associated with an increased risk of urinary stones due to the precipitation of certain minerals in the urine .The increased risk of urinary stones is related to the alkalinization of urine.
  • Treatment for Type I RTA involves alkali replacement as bicarbonate to help correct the metabolic acidosis

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 351 .

choices.text: Serotoxin has no role in the pathogenesis

questions.text: What is the least accurate statement concerning hemolytic uremic syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Serotoxin has no role in the pathogenesis 
 
  • Hemolytic uremic syndrome (HUS) : Triad of microangiopathic hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and acute kidney injury.
  • The most common cause of HUS is infection with Shiga toxin-producing E.coli (STEC), often following ingestion of contaminated food, particularly undercooked ground beef or raw vegetables.
  • Shiga toxin from STEC damages blood vessel endothelial cells, causing microthrombi and organ damage, especially in the kidneys (HUS pathogenesis).
Other options:
  • A. HUS is commonly associated with a preceding infection, often hemorrhagic colitis caused by STEC.
  • B. HUS is often self-limited, meaning it tends to resolve on its own in many cases, especially in children. However, some cases can be severe and require medical intervention.
  • C. Fever is usually mild or absent in HUS, and it is not a prominent symptom.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2285, 2286, 2348.

questions.text: Except for ________, all of the following conditions are linked to type 1 cryoglobulinemia.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Strongly Positive Rheumatoid factor
 
  • Type 1 cryoglobulinemia is specifically linked to monoclonal gammopathies, including monoclonal IgM paraprotein (Option B).
  • Hyperviscosity (Option A) can occur due to increased levels of cryoglobulins in the blood, leading to blood flow issues.
  • In type 1 cryoglobulinemia, complement levels (Option C) are typically normal, unlike in type 2 and type 3 cryoglobulinemia, where complement levels are reduced.
  • Rheumatoid factor is an antibody that is produced in people with rheumatoid arthritis. However, it is not typically associated with type 1 cryoglobulinemia.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2340,2341 .

questions.text:
A chronic smoker presented with difficulty in breathing. His artificial blood gas analysis revealed a pH of 7.2, PO2 of 70 mm Hg,
PCO2 of 80 mm Hg and HCO3 of 34 mEq. Most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
The given blood gas analysis suggests a diagnosis of respiratory acidosis due to elevated levels of pCO2 and an acidic pH. 
 

The patient’s arterial blood gas (ABG) findings are consistent with chronic respiratory acidosis with partial metabolic compensation. Here's the analysis:

  • pH of 7.2: Indicates acidemia (normal pH: 7.35–7.45).
  • PCO2 of 80 mm Hg: Significantly elevated, pointing to hypercapnia due to hypoventilation, which is the hallmark of respiratory acidosis.
  • HCO3 of 34 mEq/L: Elevated, reflecting renal compensation (attempt to counteract the acidosis by retaining bicarbonate).
  • PO2 of 70 mm Hg: Decreased, suggesting hypoxemia, commonly seen in chronic respiratory disorders.


Likely cause: The patient's history of chronic smoking points to chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) or another chronic respiratory condition that causes impaired gas exchange and CO2 retention, leading to respiratory acidosis.

Other options:

  1. Respiratory alkalosis: Characterized by high pH and low PCO2, opposite of the findings here.
  2. Metabolic alkalosis: High pH and elevated HCO3, not consistent with the patient’s acidemia.
  3. Metabolic acidosis: Low pH with decreased HCO3, which is not the case here.

Thus, the patient’s findings are best explained by respiratory acidosis due to chronic respiratory disease.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 359-361.

questions.text: Alkalinization of urine leads to increased excretion of?
questions.solution:
Weakly acidic drugs (pH 5-8) ionize more & are thus reabsorbed less in alkaline medium leading to their increased excretion. E.g- Barbiturates, sulfonamides, chlorpropamide and NSAIDs.
 
  • Urine alkalinization increases the excretion of weak acidic drugs by enhancing their ionization.
  • When urine pH is increased (made more alkaline), weak acids lose a proton, becoming ionized. Ionized drugs are less lipophilic and cannot easily diffuse back across the renal tubule, so they are excreted more readily.

Examples of weak acidic drugs:
  • Salicylates (e.g., aspirin)
  • Barbiturates
  • Methotrexate
  • Phenobarbital



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 63.

questions.text: High anion gap is found in
questions.solution:
Normal Anion gap = 8-10 mEq/L.

Causes of High anion gap metabolic acidosis- [Mnemonic: MUDPILES]
  • M: Methanol
  • U: Uremia
  • D: Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA)
  • P: Phenformin, Paraldehyde
  • I: INH, iron
  • L: Lactic acid
  • E: Ethanol, ethylene glycol
  • S: Salicylates.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 360.

questions.text: A 60 year old patient came with a H/O-Hyponatremia. He was treated with large volumes of hypertonic fluids over 23 hours followed by which the patient develops quadriparesis. What is the most likely cause for this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This is a typical history of sudden correction of hyponatremia, leading to central pontine myelinolysis, a common complication associated with the treatment of hyponataemia.
 
  • Central pontine myelinolysis is demyelination without inflammation at the base of the pons with relative sparing of axons and nerve cells.
  • It typically presents as a devastating condition such as quadriplegia and pseudobulbar palsy.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 344, 347, 2273, 3408, 3435, 3554.

questions.text: Usually patients of CKD develop hyperkalemia. Patients refractory to pharmacological measures are treated with hemodialysis. But, dialysis in these patients may lead to headache, nausea, vomiting, CNS disturbances and even convulsions, called Dialysis Disequilibrium Syndrome. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
The dialysis disequilibrium syndrome (DDS) is characterized by a range of neurologic symptoms that affect patients on hemodialysis, particularly when they are first started on dialysis.

As Hemodialysis rapidly removes small solutes such as urea leading to rapid decline in the blood urea.
This decline in patients who have marked azotemia acutely and significantly lowers plasma osmolality, thereby creating a transient osmotic gradient between plasma and brain cells. This gradient leads to water shift into neurons that produces cerebral edema.
  • Among patients who develop DDS, we initially review the delivered dialysis prescription and quickly initiate sodium modeling.
  • If clinical improvement is not noted within 30 minutes, the patient is taken off dialysis.
  • Among patients with persistent severe DDS (such as seizures, encephalopathy, or coma) despite the use of sodium modeling - a trial of hypertonic saline or mannitol may be given to prevent further osmotic shifts and tackle the development of cerebral edema.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2323.

questions.text: 55y old patient with history of sudden onset facial puffiness and pedal edema with reduced urine output came to Casulty. Patient was evaluated and diagnosed to have Rapidly progressive Renal Failure (RPRF). Patient was found to have Cresentric Glomerular Nephritis which is Pauci Immune. Which of the following Antibodies are involved?
questions.solution:
Anti Neutrophil Cytoplasmic Antibody is the MC antibody associated with Pauci-Immune Cresentric Glomerulonephritis. Immune complex deposition(Type II) examples include- Lupus, IgA nephropathy, HSP, Post Infectious GN.
Pauci Immune (Type III) include - ANCA associated, Granulomatosis with Polyangitis, MPA.
Anti GBM antibody -Type I - Good pasture disease.

Reference: Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of disease, 9th Edition, Page. No- 909, 910.

questions.text: Identify the protein raised on SPEP in Nephrotic syndrome
questions.solution:
Alpha 2 globulin has relatively large size compared to others , hence its not lost in urine as it is unable to pass through glomeruli hence it is very prominent in SPEP of Nephrotic syndrome patient.



Reference: Chew ST, Fitzwilliam J, Indridason OS, Kovalik EC. Role of urine and serum protein electrophoresis in evaluation of nephrotic-range proteinuria. Am J Kidney Dis. 1999 Jul;34(1):135-9. doi: 10.1016/s0272-6386(99)70119-8. PMID: 10401027.

questions.text: Which among the following is not an indication for emergency Hemodialysis?
questions.solution:
K+ -6 is not an indication for Dialysis. Refractory Hyperkalemia or K+ >6.5 is an indication for Hemodialysis.


Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No- 355.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a complication of hypokalemia
questions.solution:
Complications of hypokalemia include:
  • (1) cardiac - tachyarrhythmias, qt prolongation
  • (2) GI- intestinal pseudo-obstruction and constipation,
  • (3) renal- Prolonged hypokalemia can precipitate acute kidney injury, Hypokalemic polyuria due to central polydipsia and an AVP-resistant renal concentrating defect, mimicking nephrogenic diabetes insipidus, interstitial nephritis
  • (4) musculoskeletal system -hypokalemia induces hyperpolarization, compromising the muscle's ability to depolarize and contract effectively leading to weakness and paralysis. Rhabdomyolysis
  • (5) respiratory failure due to paralysis of respiratory muscle
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 349-351.

questions.text: A 40 year old male who is a known case of chronic kidney disease presented with history of recurrent kidney stones, altered sensorium and abdominal pain. On evaluation he had low serum calcium levels with elevated parathyroid hormone. What could be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The above history is suggestive of renal osteodystrophy. it is a complex condition caused by the inability to maintain normal calcium and phosphorus levels in the blood.
  • In chronic kidney disease, vitamin D is not converted into its active form. Hence calcium absorption in the intestine is impaired, thus causing decrease, calcium levels.
  • This decrease in calcium level stimulates the parathyroid gland to secrete PTH in order to increase calcium absorption. This elevated PTH known as secondary hyperparathyroidism causes increased bone resorption to release calcium and phosphate into the bloodstream, leading to bone pain and fragility, and contributing to the formation of kidney stones due to the elevated phosphate and calcium levels in the urine.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2313-2316.

questions.text: Interpret the ABG findings pH 7.3 pCO2 50 HCO3 24
questions.solution:
pH being <7.35 is suggestive of acidosis and pco2 being >45 is suggestive of a respiratory cause of acidosis

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 359-368.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs are beneficial in preventing microalbuminuria and progression of renal damage?
questions.solution:
The following drugs are beneficial in preventing microalbuminuria
  • Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors / Angiotensin receptor blockers - These medications appear to slow the rate of decline of kidney function by reducing the intraglomerular hyperfiltration and hypertension.
  • Finerenone - It is a non steroidal mineralocorticoid receptor antagonist which decreases proteinuria.
  • SGLT-2 inhibitors - These drugs inhibit sodium-glucose cotransporter type 2 in the proximal convoluted tubule. By increasing Nacl delivery to the thick ascending limb, gliflozins trigger tubuloglomerular feedback and thereby increase preglomerular vascular resistance and decrease glomerular hypertension. This contributes to the effectiveness of gliflozins to prevent diabetic kidney disease.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2316, 2319.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication to start corticosteroids in a patient with IgA vasculitis?
questions.solution:
Indications for steroids in IgA vasculitis/Henoch Schonlein Purpura are as follows
- Intractable abdominal pain.
-gastrointestinal bleed
-Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis/ cresentic glomerulonephritis.

Patients usually present with  - Palpable Purpura +Arthralgia + GI manifestations like abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhoea, intestinal perforation.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2814.

questions.text: All are true about Renal tubular acidosis in children except?
questions.solution:
• Type IV is associated with Metabolic acidosis with Hyperkalemia. Other RTAs are associated with Hypokalemia.
  • Below is an important table of differences between different RTAs



Reference: Ghai Essential Pediatrics, 9th Edition, Page No 493-495.

questions.text: A 35y old male with history of sore throat was treated with course of oral antibiotics. Patient now came to the OPD with facial puffiness and periorbital edema. URE showed esopinophilia and WBC casts. The most likely diagnosis is
questions.solution:
• The above clinical scenario with history of Antibiotic use followed by renal injury is suggestive of Acute interstitial Nephritis secondary to drug intake.
  • Drugs causing AIN- Methicillin, Pencillin, NSAID, PPI, Diuretics Anti epileptics.
  • URE- May show urinary eosinophila with WBC casts.
  • Treatment- Stop the drug and supportive.
  • Hemodialysis in severe cases.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 2357-2359.

choices.text: High anion gap metabolic with respiratory acidosis

questions.text: ABG findings of a person presenting with abdominal pain and vomiting are as follows. pH 7.30, HCO3-18, Na 135, K+ 5, Cl- 92. Blood glucose is 490 mg/dL. What is the interpretation?
questions.solution:
• As the pH in the given ABG is less than 7.35 it is acidotic with and bicarb of 18 is suggestive of metabolic acidosis.
  • The anion gap of the given ABG is 135- (92+18)=25 which is greater than 12 and is suggestive of high anion gap metabolic acidosis.

Anion gap is given by the following formula Anion gap = Serum [Na+ – (Cl– + HCO3–)]




Reference: Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 359, 367.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease has the following laboratory reports. Calculate the anion gap in this patient having Na+: 145 mEq/L, K+: 4 mEq/L, Cl-: 90 mEq/L, HCO-: 20 mEq/L.
questions.solution:
The anion gap in this patient is 35 mEq/L.

The anion gap is calculated as Na+ - [Cl(-) + HCO-]. In this patient, the anion gap will be calculated as: 145 — (90 + 20) = 145 – 110 = 35 mEq/L. 
K+ conc is not considered while calculating anion gap
 
  • Anion gap is representative of unmeasured anions which are normally present in the plasma, such as anionic proteins (albumin), phosphate, sulfate, and organic anions.
  • When acid anions such as acetoacetate and lactate accumulate in the extracellular fluid, the anion gap increases, causing a high anion gap metabolic acidosis.
  • A decrease in anion gap can occur due to an increase in abnormal cations (such as lithium, immunoglobulins), reduction in plasma albumin (nephrotic syndrome) or hyperviscosity and hyperlipidemia.


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 360.

questions.text:
A female with nephrotic syndrome underwent a renal biopsy. Which of the following statements is not correct?
A. FSGS is not diagnosed by a percutaneous renal biopsy.
B. Patient should be observed for 24 hours following biopsy.
C. Dark red clots in the urine following a biopsy indicate a hematoma.
D. Patients with features of systemic amyloidosis and renal involvement should undergo renal biopsy.
questions.solution:
Patients undergoing a percutaneous kidney biopsy are observed for a 24-hour period (statement 2) in the hospital. If any major complication occurs, it is likely to happen during this period, and thus likely to be identified and treated early. Bleeding and hematoma formation are relatively common complications of kidney biopsy and can present as frank hematuria or dark red clots in the urine (statement 3).

Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS) is a pathological diagnosis, so obtaining a tissue sample from kidney biopsy is necessary (statement 1). On light microscopy, there are focal (affecting only some of the glomeruli) and segmental (affecting only part of the glomerulus) lesions. There is a collapse of capillary loops, an increase in the matrix, and deposition of plasma proteins.

In patients with features of systemic

Amyloidosis (statement 4), rectal or gingival tissues can be biopsied for the confirmation of the diagnosis. Examination of abdominal fat pat aspirates can also be used for confirmation of systemic amyloidosis.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2342 .

questions.text: A patient with rapidly progressive renal failure (RPRF) presents with crescentic glomerulonephritis and following pattern on immunofluorescence. Which of the following antibody is the causative agent?
questions.solution:
Rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis (RPGN) is a clinical entity with features of nephritic syndrome and rapid loss of renal function. It is a syndrome associated with severe glomerular injury with necrosis and the formation of crescents.
Anti-GBM antibody-mediated disease (Type I) is characterized by linear
GBM deposits of IgG and C3 on immunofluorescence and includes renal limited disease and Goodpasture's disease. Here, the antibodies are produced against a peptide present in the noncollagenous domain of the a3 chain of collagen IV of the GBM.
Immune complex deposition (Type II) is characterized by granular deposits of antibodies and complement on immunofluorescence and can be a complication of any of the immune complex nephritides which include:
• Postinfectious glomerulonephritis
• Lupus nephritis
• IgA nephropathy
• Henoch-Schönlein purpura
Pauci-immune (Type III) exhibits no characteristic immunoglobulin or complement deposits on immunofluorescence. It includes
• ANCA-associated
• Granulomatosis with polyangiitis
• Microscopic polyangiitis.
Robbins & Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 9e • pages 907-912

questions.text: A patient with history mitral valve replacement complaints of reduced urination. Urine analysis reveals proteinuria and hematuria. A renal biopsy shows crescent formation, with a few embolic and septic abscesses. Which of the following primary conditions could have led to his renal findings?
questions.solution:
Endocarditis-associated glomerulonephritis is mostly associated with subacute bacterial endocarditis that has gone untreated for a long time as it allows for the formation of antigen-antibody complexes. Acute bacterial endocarditis on the other hand is picked up clinically and is usually treated aggressively thus not allowing for the kidney disease to progress.
Patients commonly present with oliguria, acute kidney injury or rapidly progressive glomerulonephritis. Grossly, the kidney will show a flea-bitten appearance with multiple abscesses. Biopsy shows crescents.
Immunofluorescence shows IgM, IgG, and C3.
Treatment is treating the underlying endocarditis, and monitoring the patient for improvement in kidney function.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition • page 2337

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with brown-colored urine, flank pain, and fatigue for the last 3 days. He has 2+ proteinuria with >20 red cells/HPF and dysmorphic red blood cells. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The child presents with hematuria (brown-colored urine), flank pain, and proteinuria, along with dysmorphic RBCs in urine, which are characteristic of glomerular origin of bleeding.

  • The acute presentation 3 days after a possible streptococcal infection fits the classic scenario of post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis (PSGN).

  • Other supportive features may include mild edema, hypertension, and elevated ASO titers.

Other options:

  • Minimal change disease: Usually presents with nephrotic syndrome (massive proteinuria, hypoalbuminemia, edema), not hematuria.

  • Bladder calculi: Can cause hematuria but usually pain is localized and not associated with dysmorphic RBCs or glomerular proteinuria.

  • Urinary tract infection: May cause pyuria and hematuria, but RBCs are usually not dysmorphic, and there is often bacteriuria with fever.



Reference
Nelson textbook of pediatrics 21st edition - Page no 2723

questions.text: Hypokalemia is seen in all of the following conditions, except?
questions.solution:
• RTA Type 1 (distal): Causes hypokalemia due to impaired H secretion and secondary K loss.

  • RTA Type 2 (proximal): Also associated with hypokalemia due to increased distal K excretion.

  • Ureterosigmoidostomy: Leads to potassium wasting, causing hypokalemia.

  • RTA Type 4 (hyperkalemic RTA): Characterized by hyperkalemia, not hypokalemia, due to hypoaldosteronism or aldosterone resistance.

So, hypokalemia is not seen in RTA type 4.


Reference
Brenner and Rector's The Kidney (10th Edition, Page 2383).

questions.text: A female weighing 40 kg has a serum sodium level of 120 mEq/L. Calculate the sodium deficit for a desired sodium concentration of 140 mEq/L.
questions.solution:
In this instance, the sodium shortage is 400 mEq. The formula for calculating it is as follows: sodium deficit (mEq) = total body water (TBW) x (sodium concentration desired - sodium concentration current).

Whereas

For men, TBW is equal to 0.6 times body weight in kilos.

= 0.5 times a woman's body weight in kilos Thus, in this instance: Sodium deficit = 0.5 x 40 x (140 - 120) = 0.5. x 40 x 20 = 400 mEq

Rapid sodium correction of 4-6 mEq/L should be achieved in the first 6 hours of therapy for patients with acute hyponatremia.

The rate of correction should be
comparatively slow in chronic hyponatremia: <6-8 MEq/L in the first 24 h and <6 mEq/L each subsequent 24h, so as to avoid osmotic demyelination syndrome.

Reference:Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page no 345

questions.text: What will the patient's adjusted reticulocyte count be if their absolute reticulocyte count is 9% and their hemoglobin level is 5?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: 3

To calculate the patient's adjusted reticulocyte count, we need to use the corrected reticulocyte count formula. The formula is as follows:
Adjusted Reticulocyte Count = (Reticulocyte Percentage x Patient's Hemoglobin Level) / Normal Hemoglobin Level
In this case, the patient's absolute reticulocyte count is 9%, and their hemoglobin level is 5.
Here, if the normal hemoglobin level is 15, the patient's adjusted reticulocyte count would be 3.




 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 435.

questions.text: Medical care was provided for a little girl who had been identified as having acute promyelocytic leukemia (APML). On the third day of her treatment, she developed tachypnea and fever. Bilateral pulmonary infiltrates were seen on a chest X-ray. Which of the following drugs should be given next?
questions.solution:
Patients with APML receiving treatment with ATRA or arsenic may develop Differentiation syndrome, a potentially fatal consequence.

It results from modifications in cytokine secretion and adhesion molecule differentiation brought on by ATRA in APML cells.

Fever, weight increase of more than 5 kg, peripheral edoema, hypotension, abrupt renal failure, and interstitial lung infiltrates are the hallmarks of DS.

Early detection of DS can greatly reduce morbidity and death when paired with a course of dexamethasone treatment.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 818.

questions.text: How much platelet count is needed following a transfusion in a patient with thrombocytopenia in order to undergo an invasive procedure?
questions.solution:
The target platelet count in a patient with thrombocytopenia after transfusion undergoing an invasive procedure is 50000. 
 
  • In an otherwise healthy patient, surgery can be safely performed if platelet counts are above 50,000/mm³.
  • The risk of bleeding significantly increases when platelet counts fall below this threshold.
  • Platelet transfusions can help manage thrombocytopenia, raising the platelet count by approximately 10,000/mm³ for each unit transfused.
 
  • Thrombocytopenia is defined as a platelet count lower than normal and can result from conditions such as immune thrombocytopenic purpura (ITP), drug-induced thrombocytopenia, rheumatological diseases (like SLE and rheumatoid arthritis), pregnancy, and chronic liver disease. If a patient presents with a low platelet count, the first step is to repeat the test and examine the peripheral blood smear.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 963, 964, 967, 968.

choices.text: Observe for a change in colour of the urine
Stop BT and wait for patient to get normal and start

questions.text:
The patient has a history of iron overload that has been previously treated with chelating drugs and is a known case of thalassemia major.
She has a background of cardiac arrhythmia as well. She has now come for BT. The patient complained of back pain during BT and appeared very apprehensive.
What is the next treatment?
questions.solution:
During blood transfusion, whenever an adverse reaction is suspected, the transfusion should be stopped and reported to the blood bank for investigation.

Adverse reactions to transfused blood components can occur despite multiple tests, inspections, and checks. Fortunately, the most common reactions are not life threatening, although serious reactions can present with mild symptoms and signs. Some reactions can be reduced or prevented by modified blood components. 
 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 888-896.

questions.text: <strong>What is the proper sequence for blood sampling?
questions.solution:
Correct order of blood sampling:
Identification of patient; Verification of patient's profile; Sampling; Labeling at bedside.

  • Requisition forms are filled accordingly, Patient's profile is verified, Later the patient is identified and samples are collected by laboratory personnel/ health care staff and labeled appropriately.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in the emergency management of acute hyperkalemia?
questions.solution:
• Intravenous magnesium sulfate is not used in the emergency management of acute hyperkalemia.
  • Intravenous calcium stabilizes the myocardium.  Without affecting the resting membrane potential, calcium increases the action potential threshold and decreases excitability. Calcium restores the depolarization blockage caused by hyperkalemia by restoring the difference between resting and threshold potentials.
  • Salbutamol(Beta 2 agonist) as well as insulin cause intracellular shift of potassium, thus decreasing its plasma levels. 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 355.

choices.text: CML only occurs after 50 years of age
CLL can occur before 10 years of age
ALL in before 1 year has a poor prognosis
Hairy Cell Leukemia has rare splenomegaly and has good prognosis in less than 50 years

questions.text: Which of the following statements about leukemia is correct?
questions.solution:
Acute lymphoblastic leukemia (ALL) in patients under one year of age has a poor prognosis because their young age makes it difficult to tolerate the intensive chemotherapy and radiation treatments needed to treat the disease. 

ALL(Acute Lymphoblastic Leukemia) prognostic factors



Response to steroids/ Minimal Residual Disease Negativity/Positivity i.e. response to therapy is
considered the most important prognostic factor.

Other options
  • Option 1 is incorrect - CML can occur at any age but commonly occurs >50 years of age
  • Option 2 is incorrect - CLL is a disease of the elderly and only occurs beyond 50 years of age
  • Option 4 is incorrect - Hairy cell leukemia commonly has massive Splenomegaly

questions.text: Among the following what is not seen in massive acute blood loss?
questions.solution:
Decrease in PCV and not increase will be seen in massive acute blood loss.
 

  1. Reticulocyte count: In response to acute blood loss, the body increases red blood cell production, leading to a rise in reticulocytes (immature red blood cells) within a few days.

  2. PCV (Packed Cell Volume): After acute blood loss, the PCV (hematocrit) usually decreases because blood volume is reduced, leading to a lower proportion of red blood cells relative to plasma.

  3. MCV (Mean Corpuscular Volume): The MCV can increase slightly in response to reticulocytosis since reticulocytes are larger than mature red blood cells.

  4. Neutrophils: Neutrophils often increase in acute blood loss due to the body's stress response.

Thus, an increase in PCV is not typical of massive acute blood loss.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 776, 792.

questions.text:
A condition known as hypereosinophilic syndrome involves the heart, neurological system, or bone marrow and is defined by an increased eosinophil count in the blood for at least six months without any apparent explanation. What eosinophil count is required for diagnosis?
1. >500/mm3
2. >1000/ mm3
3. >1500/ mm3
4. >2000/ mm3
questions.solution:
Diagnostic criteria for hypereosinophilic syndrome:
  • Persistent eosinophilia > 1500/cu mm
  • Increased marrow eosinophils
  • Myeloblasts <20% in blood or marrow.

Other similar conditions must be excluded before concluding diagnosis.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 864.

questions.text: How should RBC be transfused?
questions.solution:
Packed RBCs after removal from refrigerator (in blood bank) should be transfused within 4 hours. The cannula diameter for transfusion of blood in adults should be 18-20 gauge.

The 30-minute rule states that red blood cell (RBC) units left out of controlled temperature storage for more than 30 minutes should not be returned to storage for reissue; the 4-hour rule states that transfusion of RBC units should be completed within 4 hours of their removal from controlled temperature storage,



Reference: Brunskill, Susan et al. “What is the maximum time that a unit of red blood cells can be safely left out of controlled temperature storage?.” Transfusion medicine reviews vol. 26,3 (2012): 209-223.e3. doi:10.1016/j.tmrv.2011.09.005. URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22119493/

choices.text: Translocation between long arm of chromosome 9 and short arm of chromosome 22
Protein tyrosine kinase inhibitors are used in treatment

questions.text: Which statement regarding CML in children is correct?
questions.solution:
Option (2) is the correct statement among the given options.

Protein tyrosine kinase inhibitors (eg Imatinib/Dasatinib) are used in the treatment of CML.

Imatinib therapy regulates blood counts and significantly reduces the risk of progression to the accelerated phase and blast crisis, which pose the greatest risk to the patient. 

However, it is not a cure for the disease. 

Option (1) is incorrect.
CML occurs due to translocation t(9;22)(q34;q11.2) i.e. translocation between the long arm of chromosome 9 and the long arm of chromosome 22.

Option (3) is incorrect.
CML commonly presents in the chronic phase. Blast crisis at presentation is in only 1-2% of the cases. 

Option (4) is incorrect. 
ALL(70-80%) is the most common leukemia in children followed by AML(10-15). CML accounts for only about 5-7% of cases of leukemia in children. 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 818-827.

In iron deficiency, hemosiderin and ferritin decrease; supply of iron to the apotransferrin decreases resulting in decrease in transferrin saturation <16%.

In the First stage of iron deficiency reduction in storage iron is seen as fall in serum ferritin 

 

IDA is preceded by a stage of latent iron deficiency and its most prevalent in india.

questions.text: Pick the correct option regarding treatment of CLL.
Which of the subsequent conditions can lead to dactylitis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Sickle Cell Anemia

Dactylitis, also known as "sausage digit," refers to painful swelling and inflammation involving an entire finger or toe. It is commonly associated with Sickle cell disease due to irreversible sickling of RBCs leading to Acute painful episodes.

Among the options provided:
  1. Hemophilia: Hemophilia is a bleeding disorder characterized by impaired blood clotting. It does not typically cause dactylitis.
  2. Von Willebrand disease: Von Willebrand disease is another bleeding disorder caused by a deficiency or dysfunction of von Willebrand factor. It is not commonly associated with dactylitis.
  3. Measles: Measles is a viral infection characterized by fever, rash, and respiratory symptoms. It does not typically cause dactylitis.
  • Sickle Cell Anemia: Sickle Cell Anemia is a genetic blood disorder characterized by the presence of abnormal hemoglobin, leading to the formation of sickle-shaped red blood cells.
  • Dactylitis is a well-known manifestation of sickle cell disease and can occur due to vaso-occlusion and infarction in the small blood vessels of the fingers or toes.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 758-760.

  • Vitamin K deficiency, Hemophilia A and B are disorders of Coagulation pathway. Hence, they are NOT associated with mucosal bleeding.

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl has a history of weakness and sluggishness that can be easily aggravated. The Hemoglobin value is 7.0, the MCV is 70, the MCH is 20 pg/cell, and the red cell distribution width (RDW) is 20 on the complete blood count (CBC). The following cause is most likely:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Iron deficiency anemia.
 
  • The above clinical scenario in an adolescent young girl presenting with anemia is highly suggestive of IDA due to increased demand.
  • A high RDW and low MCV suggests iron deficiency.
  • In this case, the low hemoglobin level (7.0 g/dL) and the low mean corpuscular volume (MCV) of 70 fL indicate a microcytic anemia.

Close differential of IDA is Thalassemia minor/trait which has similar presentation and lab parameters

questions.text: Which of the following is a primary indicator for polycythemia vera diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Presence of JAK-2 mutation
 
  • Polycythemia vera is a myeloproliferative neoplasm characterized by the overproduction of red blood cells in the bone marrow.
  • The JAK-2 (Janus kinase 2) mutation is a primary driver of polycythemia vera and is found in the majority of patients with the condition.
  • It leads to the constitutive activation of the JAK-STAT signaling pathway, resulting in uncontrolled cell proliferation.








Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 803, 804.

choices.text: Normal pH can not rule out acid base disorder
Choose another site if Allen test is abnormal
Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood

questions.text: What is not true regarding ABG sampling?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: 3. Add 0.5 ml Heparin to the syringe before taking blood
Syringe should be flushed with heparin and not added/loaded.
 
  • Normal pH, HCO3, and PCO2 levels may not indicate absence of an acid-base imbalance: This statement is true. While normal values of pH, bicarbonate (HCO3), and partial pressure of carbon dioxide (PCO2) may suggest a balanced acid-base state, they do not guarantee the absence of an acid-base imbalance. There are different types of acid-base disorders, such as respiratory acidosis/alkalosis and metabolic acidosis/alkalosis, which can exist even with normal pH, HCO3, and PCO2 values. Additional parameters and the evaluation of compensatory mechanisms are required to make an accurate assessment of acid-base balance.
  • A different site should be tried if modified Allen's test is negative: This statement is true. The modified Allen's test is performed to assess collateral circulation in the hand before arterial puncture. If the modified Allen's test is negative (indicating inadequate collateral circulation), it is recommended to try a different arterial site for blood sampling to avoid potential complications, such as hand ischemia.
  • Radial artery is the preferred site: This statement is true. The radial artery is commonly preferred for arterial blood gas (ABG) sampling due to its accessibility and lower risk of complications compared to other sites. It is easily palpable and provides a relatively comfortable experience for patients.



Reference: Trulock EP III. Arterial Blood Gases. In: Walker HK, Hall WD, Hurst JW, editors. Clinical Methods: The History, Physical, and Laboratory Examinations. 3rd edition. Boston: Butterworths; 1990. Chapter 49. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK371/

WHO Guidelines on Drawing Blood: Best Practices in Phlebotomy. Geneva: World Health Organization; 2010. Annex I, Modified Allen test. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK138652/

questions.text: A 20-year-old female arrived with an Hb of 9 g/dL, an MCV of 55, and a RBC count of 4.5 million per mm3. There is no history of blood transfusions. What will be the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient in question has:
  • low MCV indicating microcytic anemia (excludes Megaloblastic anemia) and
  • has never required blood transfusion (excludes Thalassemia major).

This patient may therefore have either an lron deficiency anemia or Thalassemia minor. Microcytic anemia with a normal RBC count favours a diagnosis of Thalassemia minor over iron deficiency anemia.




In this question, MENTZER INDEX (MCV/RBC count) = 55/ 4.5= 12.2 (<13).  Therefore, it points more towards Thalassemia minor/trait than IDA.

Next step in this patient would be HPLC to confirm the diagnosis.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 750, 753.

questions.text: A preoperative coagulation test was performed on a 25-year-old woman with a history of abortion. Her lab results are as follows: PT = 15/14(Control), aPTT = 45/35(control), platelet count = 2.5 lac/mm3. What ailment does she probably have?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Anti-phospholipid syndrome
 
  • The patient in the question has a prolonged aPTT and a normal PT, which is consistent with a lupus anticoagulant. The patient also has a history of abortion, which is a risk factor for APS.
  • Anti-phospholipid syndrome is an autoimmune disorder where the body produces antibodies against phospholipids, leading to a paradoxical increase in blood clotting, despite the name.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2750.

questions.text: The following lab results were obtained from a 60-year-old woman with a history of rheumatoid arthritis: Hb 4.5 g/dL, platelet count 2Lac/mm3, TLC 6000/mm3, serum ferritin 300 mg/L, and TIBC 280 ng/L. Which diagnosis is most probable amongst the following given options?
questions.solution:
Anemia of chronic disease is associated with:
  • decreased serum iron
  • decreased TIBC
  • decreased % saturation
  • normal or increased serum ferritin levels.
 
  • It is characterized by block in delivery of iron from the reticuloendothelial system to the erythroid progenitors due to upregulation of Hepcidin thus inhibiting Ferroportin.
  • On the other hand low serum iron with increased TIBC indicate Iron deficiency anemia.

Diagnosis of Hypoproliferative anemia: 



In this table, Inflammatory cause signifies Anemia of Chronic Disease



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 751, 753.

questions.text: What is the disease for which the NESTROFT test is used in screening?
questions.solution:
• NESTROFT (Naked Eye Single Tube Red Cell Osmotic Fragility Test) is used in screening of Beta-thalassemia.
  • The principle of NESTROFT is based on the limit of hypotonicity, which the red cell can withstand.
  • Positive test is due to the reduced osmotic fragility of red cells.
  • NESTROFT is also positive in other conditions, which are associated with decreased red cell osmotic fragility such as Hereditary spherocytosis, liver disease and hemoglobinopathies.

Hereditary Spherocytosis:
 
  • Hereditary spherocytosis is a condition where red blood cells are sphere-shaped due to defects in membrane proteins.
  • Osmotic fragility testing is indeed used here because spherocytes are more prone to lysis in hypotonic solutions.
  • However, the standard osmotic fragility test (OFT) is performed, not NESTROFT.
  • NESTROFT is specifically tailored for detecting red cell resistance to lysis, characteristic of beta-thalassemia.




Reference: Piplani, Sanjay et al. “NESTROFT - A Valuable, Cost Effective Screening Test for Beta Thalassemia Trait in North Indian Punjabi Population.” Journal of clinical and diagnostic research : JCDR vol. 7,12 (2013): 2784-687. doi:10.7860/JCDR/2013/6834.3759. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3919310/

questions.text: Which of the following may not require chemotherapy and just observation maybe recommended?
questions.solution:
Neuroblastoma may not require treatment sometimes- just observation. Although all four of the above malignancies should be treated, neuroblastoma especially low risk NB may experience spontaneous regression. Therefore, neuroblastoma is the best answer.

Treatment of newly diagnosed low-risk Neuroblastoma includes:
 
  • Observation alone for infants younger than 6 months who have small adrenal tumors or for infants who do not have signs or symptoms of neuroblastoma
  • Surgery for infants younger than age 1 year with symptoms but have favorable histology and meet other low-risk criteria.

Reference: Essential Pediatrics by OP Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 612.

Now presents with pallor, on examination hepatosplenomegaly. Hemoglobin was 3.8 gm/dl, MCV=68, MCH=19. Peripheral smear showed erythroid hyperplasia. Diagnosis is:

Features of beta-thalassemia major are:

  • Hb 3.8 gm/dl, MCV = 68, MCH = 19
  • Peripheral smear: Schistocytes
  • Bone marrow examination show erythroid hyperplasia.

Beta-Thalassemia:

questions.text: Aplastic anemia, Pancreatic exocrine insufficiency, small height, with skeletal anomalies point to the diagnosis of:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 4: Shwachman-Diamond syndrome.

Shwachman-Diamond syndrome (SDS) is a rare genetic disorder characterized by:
 
  • Aplastic anemia (condition where the bone marrow fails to produce enough blood cells).
  • Pancreatic exocrine insufficiency (pancreas does not produce enough digestive enzymes).
  • Short stature.
  • Skeletal anomalies (abnormalities in the bones).




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 794.

questions.text: Which of the characteristics is NOT present in DIC?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Hyperfibrinogenemia.
 
  • Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC) is a life-threatening disorder involving abnormal blood clotting, excessive bleeding, widespread microvascular thrombosis, and potential organ damage.
 
  • Hyperfibrinogenemia is not a characteristic of DIC; instead, fibrinogen levels are typically decreased due to its consumption during clot formation.
  • D- dimer and Fibrin Degraded Products are a marker of DIC. 

Classic features of DIC:

choices.text: Platelets bear the antigens of ABO system
Platelet products usually do not contain donor plasma

questions.text: What is incorrect about platelet transfusions?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Platelets carry the Rh antigen.
 
  • Platelets do not express Rh antigens, they contain small numbers of intact red blood cells or fragments, which can lead to alloimmunization in the recipient. Alloimmunization to the RhD antigen may occur when platelets obtained from RhD-positive donors are transfused to RhD-negative recipients.
 
  • Platelets express ABO antigens and are collected in plasma, which contains ABO antibodies as would be consistent with the donor ABO group. Platelet ABO antigens that are incompatible with recipient ABO antibodies may have accelerated clearance from circulation and result in lower count increments. ABO antibodies that are passively transferred from donor plasma may result in hemolysis of recipient red blood cells.
 
  • Platelet products may contain some donor plasma, but the amount is usually very small. To minimize the risk of transfusion reactions, platelet products are usually prepared by a process called apheresis, which separates platelets from the donor's blood and returns the rest of the blood components back to the donor. 



Reference: Dunbar, Nancy M. “Does ABO and RhD matching matter for platelet transfusion?.” Hematology. American Society of Hematology. Education Program vol. 2020,1 (2020): 512-517. doi:10.1182/hematology.2020000135. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7727583/

questions.text: What is the shelf life of blood in a blood bank in CPDA buffer:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: 35 days 
 
  • Blood stored in a blood bank is preserved using CPDA buffer to maintain its viability and prevent clotting for transfusions.
  • The blood's shelf life in CPDA buffer extends up to 35 days, allowing it to be safely used for transfusions during this period after its collection.
  • Beyond the 35-day mark, the blood may undergo changes in its cellular and biochemical properties, making it unsuitable for transfusions.

The recommended storage for different blood components are as follows:  





Reference: Wintrobe's Clinical Hematology, 13th edition, Page no 550.
Moore, G L et al. “Some properties of blood stored in anticoagulant CPDA-1 solution. A brief summary.” Transfusion vol. 21,2 (1981): 135-7. doi:10.1046/j.1537-2995.1981.21281178147.x, URL: https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/7222197/

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics of multiple myeloma is least common?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Hyperviscosity syndrome 
 
  • Multiple myeloma is a plasma cell dyscrasia in which there is an unregulated proliferation of plasma cells.
  • The proliferating cells stimulate osteoclastic activity and suppress osteoblastic activity, leading to the formation of multiple lytic bone lesions. 
  • Common symptoms include bone pain due to bone involvement and lytic lesions.
  • Anemia is a frequent feature, and it can be normocytic (normal-sized red blood cells) and normochromic (normal hemoglobin content).
  • Multiple myeloma compromises the immune system, leading to increased susceptibility to bacterial infections.
  • Hyperviscosity syndrome is a rare complication, characterized by increased blood viscosity due to high levels of abnormal proteins.
  • Hyperviscosity is more common with Walderstorm macroglobulinemia. 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 869-871.

choices.text: Increased fibrinogen, increased antithrombin III, increased thrombin-antithrombin III complexes
Increased FDP, decreased PT, increased antithrombin III
Increased FDP, prolonged PT, decreased thrombin-antithrombin complexes

questions.text: The observation made in DIC is as follows:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Increased FDP, prolonged PT, reduced Platelets 
 
  • Disseminated intravascular coagulation refers to the widespread intravascular clot formation, commonly due to sepsis, trauma, and obstetric complications.
  • These patients present with petechiae, ecchymoses, and oozing from venipuncture sites. 
  • Schistocytes may be present on peripheral smears. 
 
  • Deranged clotting parameters are seen and fibrin degradation products such as D-dimers are elevated
  • Fibrin degradation products (FDP) are produced as a result of fibrinolysis (the breakdown of blood clots) and are increased in DIC.
  • The prothrombin time (PT) is prolonged in DIC due to the depletion of clotting factors, leading to impaired blood clotting.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 915-917.

questions.text: Thrombocytopenia (Platelet count 50,000) and fragmented RBCs in a peripheral smear are symptoms of pregnancy in a 25-year-old woman. Which of the following differential diagnoses is least likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Evan's syndrome 
 
  • Thrombocytopenia (low platelet count) and fragmented red blood cells (schistocytes) in a peripheral smear can occur in various medical conditions, including certain pregnancy-related complications.
  • Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP), Disseminated Intravascular Coagulation (DIC), and HELLP syndrome are conditions that can cause thrombocytopenia and the presence of fragmented RBCs.
  • Evan's syndrome, although a condition with autoimmune hemolytic anemia and immune thrombocytopenia, is less likely to be the cause in this case.




Algorithm for Thrombocytopenia:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 905, 907.

questions.text:
A child presented to the OPD with complaints of abdominal pain, vomiting and oliguria for the last 8 days. On examination, he was found to be dehydrated. Serum potassium and uric acid was raised. Peripheral smear showed the presence of
lymphoblasts. Immediate management of such a patient would be:
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with laboratory investigations are suggestive of Tumor lysis syndrome. 

The next best step of management will be aggressive hydration. 

Cairo-Bishop criteria is used to assess severity of TLS.

MANAGEMENT OF TLS:

Prevention:
 
  • Identify high-risk patients: Those with high tumor burden (e.g., Burkitt lymphoma, acute leukemia), rapidly proliferating tumors, or pre-existing kidney dysfunction.
  • Hydration:
    • Aggressive intravenous hydration (e.g., 3 L/m²/day) to maintain adequate urine output (>100 mL/m²/hour) and promote renal clearance of uric acid, phosphate, and potassium.
    • Avoid potassium-containing fluids.
  • Allopurinol:
    • A xanthine oxidase inhibitor to reduce the formation of uric acid from purines.
    • Dose: 300 mg/day, started 1–2 days before chemotherapy.
  • Rasburicase (recombinant urate oxidase):
    • Converts uric acid to allantoin (water-soluble and excretable).
    • Used in patients with high uric acid levels or at high risk of TLS.
    • Dose: 0.1–0.2 mg/kg IV once daily.
  • Electrolyte monitoring:
    • Frequent monitoring of potassium, phosphate, calcium, uric acid, and creatinine (every 6–12 hours in high-risk patients).

Treatment:
 
  • Hyperkalemia:
    • Immediate interventions if potassium >6.0 mmol/L or with ECG changes (e.g., peaked T waves, widened QRS).
    • Measures include:
      • Calcium gluconate (stabilizes myocardium).
      • Insulin with glucose or β-agonists (shifts potassium into cells).
      • Sodium bicarbonate (if acidosis is present).
      • Potassium binders or dialysis for refractory cases.
  • Hyperphosphatemia:
    • Restrict dietary phosphate intake.
    • Administer oral phosphate binders (e.g., sevelamer).
    • Dialysis if severe and unresponsive.
  • Hypocalcemia:
    • Treat only if symptomatic (e.g., tetany, arrhythmias) to avoid calcium-phosphate precipitation.
    • Administer IV calcium gluconate cautiously.
  • Hyperuricemia:
    • Rasburicase (preferred for rapid uric acid reduction).
    • Allopurinol to prevent further uric acid formation.
  • Acute Kidney Injury:
    • Optimize hydration and treat metabolic disturbances.
    • Initiate renal replacement therapy (dialysis) in severe cases.

Indication of Dialysis in TLS:
 
  • Severe hyperkalemia refractory to treatment.
  • Symptomatic hypocalcemia.
  • Severe hyperphosphatemia.
  • Volume overload or uncontrolled AKI.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 573, 574.

questions.text: A lady was some medications for some time. Now she is complaining of bleeding tendencies. Which vitamin deficiency is more likely in such a case?
questions.solution:
The most likely vitamin which is deficient in the given clinical scenario is vitamin K manifesting as bleeding tendencies.

questions.text: The two co-enzymes of riboflavin are FMN and FAD. Which of the following is used for evaluation of riboflavin activity?
questions.solution:
Among the given options, glutathione reductase is used for evaluation of riboflavin activity. 

Option 1- Transketolase is used for evaluation of vitamin B1-thiamine's activity.
