questions.text: What is the Corrected reticulocyte count, if Hb=5, reticulocyte =9% ?
questions.solution:
Corrected reticulocyte count= Reticulocyte % × (Patient Hb/Normal Hb)
Normal Hb= 15g/dl.

Here, in this question,
Corrected reticulocyte count=9 x (5/15) = 3%.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 435.

questions.text: At what Serum Iron levels is desferoxamine indicated in a patient recieving transfusion.?
questions.solution:
IV desferoxamine is indicated when serum Iron levels are greater than 500mcg/dl in cases of iron toxicity. Desferoxamine can be given IV, IM, SC but not orally.

*Extra EDge: 
 

Deferoxamine (DFO or DFOA) is FDA approved to treat iron overload, either acute or chronic. The definition of iron overload is serial ferritin levels above 800 to 3000 ng/mL. The FDA has not approved deferoxamine as first-line therapy for hereditary hemochromatosis unless there is a contraindication to phlebotomy. Clinicians can also use deferoxamine as an off-label treatment for aluminum toxicity in chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.

Transfusion-related iron overload occurs in patients that require frequent transfusions throughout their life. These patients include those affected by Thalassemia, Sickle cell disease, myelodysplastic syndromes, ineffective hematopoiesis, and other inherited anemic disorders. In this population, chelation should begin two years after transfusions start, serum ferritin levels greater than 1000 mcg/L, or when liver iron concentration (LIC) is greater than 3 mg Fe/g.

Another indication for iron chelation is a cardiac T2* <20 milliseconds found on cardiac magnetic resonance. Cardiac MRIs can measure proton relaxation times (T2*) in the cardiac nuclei. Excess iron within these cells speeds up the rate of proton relaxation. This reduced cardiac T2* time is associated with cardiomyopathy, dramatically increasing mortality. Chelation therapy improves overall survival in these patients and should not be delayed.

The use of deferoxamine in acute ingestion of iron is an indication when patients present with systemic toxicity, hemodynamic instability, lethargy, persistent vomiting, metabolic acidosis, or toxic serum iron levels. Iron levels >500 mcg/dL are considered hazardous, and chelation should be initiated. Signs and symptoms of systemic toxicity include coagulopathy, cardiomyopathy, and hepatic and renal failure. Acute iron toxicity progresses through five clinical stages, with the most deadly consequences occurring within the first four days. Thus, rapid progression through these stages is another indicator that chelation may be necessary. 



Reference: Velasquez J, Wray AA. Deferoxamine. [Updated 2023 May 22]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK557654/

questions.text: Match the following blood products with their corresponding shelf life.
questions.solution: Reference: Harrison principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page No 885-886.

questions.text: Which of the following are seen in iron deficiency anemia?A. Reduced serum iron levelB. Reduced transferrin saturationC. Increased total iron binding capacityD. Reduced ferritin level
questions.solution:
Iron deficiency anemia (IDA) is characterized by reduced serum iron levels, decreased transferrin saturation, increased total iron-binding capacity (TIBC), and lowered ferritin levels.

**Serum Iron Level**: This represents the amount of circulating iron bound to transferrin. In IDA, as the body‘s iron stores become depleted, the serum iron level decreases.

**Total Iron-Binding Capacity (TIBC)**: TIBC is an indirect measure of the circulating levels of transferrin, the protein responsible for iron transport. In IDA, there is more free transferrin available (not bound to iron) in the bloodstream, resulting in an increase in TIBC.


The normal range for transferrin saturation is 25-50%. In states of iron deficiency, transferrin saturation is low. A transferrin saturation greater than 50% indicates a significant amount of iron being delivered to tissues, which can lead to tissue iron overload, as seen in conditions like hemochromatosis.

**Serum Ferritin**: This is the most useful laboratory test for assessing iron stores in the body. When iron stores are depleted, serum ferritin levels decrease. Serum ferritin levels below 15 pg/L are indicative of completely absent iron stores.
 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 749-750 .

choices.text: TPE removes anti-ADAMTS13 autoantibodies and thereby increases the ADAMTS protease activity

questions.text: Total plasma exchange is done in thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura. How does TPE help in the management of TTP?
questions.solution:
Thrombotic Thrombocytopenic Purpura (TTP) is a type of thrombotic microangiopathy that can be either inherited or acquired spontaneously. It is characterized by a deficiency or the presence of antibodies against the enzyme ADAMTS13, which plays a crucial role in cleaving von Willebrand factor (vWF) multimers. When ADAMTS13 is deficient or inhibited, these vWFmultimers are not properly cleaved, leading to increased platelet adhesion and aggregation. This results in the formation of platelet thrombi and fibrin deposits in the microcirculation.

These thrombi cause a range of clinical features known as the classic pentad of TTP:
1. Microangiopathichemolyticanemia (MAHA)
2. Thrombocytopenia
3. Renal failure
4. Neurologic symptoms
5. Fever

The formation of platelet thrombi narrows blood vessels, creating shearing forces that damage red blood cells as they pass through, leading to microangiopathichemolyticanemia. The same thrombi contribute to microvascular occlusion, causing organ damage such as renal failure and neurological symptoms. On a peripheral blood smear, fragmented red blood cells, known as schistocytes or helmet cells, can be seen.

Therapeutic plasma exchange (TPE) is the cornerstone of TTP treatment. TPE helps remove autoantibodies against ADAMTS13, allowing the enzyme to function properly and degrade the vWFmultimers. TPE is continued until the platelet count normalizes and signs of hemolysis have been absent for at least two days. Glucocorticoids are often used as an adjunct therapy to TPE, and the addition of rituximab early in treatment has been shown to reduce the duration of the disease and the risk of relapses.

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 907,908 .

questions.text: A 45 year old male presents with complaints of weakness, fatigue, and recurrent infections, he also gives history of exposure to radiation for management of gastric malignancy in the past. On evaluation he was found to have spleenomegaly. Lab investigations reveal anaemia, leukopenia, thrombocytopenia and Bone marrow studies show marked hypocellularity. What is the likely diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Aplastic anemia refers to the syndrome of chronic primary hematopoietic failure from injury leading to diminished or absent hematopoietic precursors in the bone marrow and attendant pancytopenia. The most common etiology, idiopathic, accounts for 65%. Fanconi anemia is the most common hereditary cause. It presents in the late first decade with pancytopenia, organ hypoplasia, and bone defects including abnormal radii, absent thumbs, and short stature. Seronegative hepatitis is responsible for 5% to 10% of total cases. Telomerase defects are found in 5% to 10% of adult-onset aplastic anemia. Other causes being exposure to toxins such as benzene, chloramphenicol, drugs like phenytoin, radiotherapy, viral infections such as parvovirus infection , EBV infection. The diagnostic criteria for aplastic anemia are the following: the presence of bone marrow hypocellularity and 2 or more cytopenias (reticulopodia less than 1% or less than 40,000/microliter, neutropenia less than 500/microliter, or thrombocytopenia less than 20,000/microliter).
Wintrobe's Clinical Hematology 14th Edition • Page no: 993

questions.text: A 70 year old male presents with a fracture of femur following trivial fall. He was extensively evaluated and found to have the following findings on X-ray of the skull. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario in the background of a trivial fall is suggestive of multiple myeloma.
Multiple myelomas: Malignant neoplasm of plasma cells characterized by:
• Presence of monoclonal immunoglobulin or light chains in the serum and urine
• Bone destruction (lytic lesions)
• Disease of older adults, with a peak age of incidence of 65 to 70 years
Signs and symptoms
• Hypercalcemia
• Pathologic fractures/lytic bone lesions
• Renal failure
• Anemia
• Radiography: Punched-out lytic lesions on X-ray
• Electrophoresis: Monoclonal elevation of one immunoglobulin
• Urinalysis: Free kappa and lambda light chains (Bence Jones proteins)
• Bone marrow biopsy: 10 to 20%plasma cells (normal is < 5%)
• Peripheral smear: Rouleaux formation (High level of M proteins in myeloma causes red cells in the peripheral blood smears to stick to one another in linear arrays, a finding referred to as rouleaux formation).
Robbins and Cotran Pathologic Basis of Disease, 10e • Page no: 609, 607, 610, 611, 263, 260

questions.text: Which of the following chemotherapeutic agents is known to cause flagellate dermatitis?
questions.solution:
Bleomycin causes cutaneous toxicities like erythema, ulceration, and flagellate dermatitis. The most serious adverse reaction to bleomycin is pulmonary toxicity, which may progress to life-threatening pulmonary fibrosis.
Flagellate dermatitis is a rare skin condition that causes a distinctive whip-like pattern of linear or curvilinear streaks and plaques on the skin. It's characterized by hyperpigmentation and erythema.
Goodman & Gillman's The Pharmacological Basis Of Therapeutics - 13th Edition •
Page no 1182

questions.text:
A 30 y old patient who was in a road traffic accident and sustained an open fracture of the femur one hour ago was transfused with 4 units of PRBC. Two hours later, he develops hypotension, hypoxia, dyspnea, and bilateral interstitial infiltrates on chest X-ray.
What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI).
TRALI is a sudden onset of respiratory failure resulting from the transfusion of donor fresh frozen plasma and platelets that contain high-titer of anti-HLA antibodies. These antibodies bind recipient leukocytes and aggregate in the pulmonary vasculature, releasing mediators that increase capillary permeability. The recipient develops symptoms of hypotension, fever, hypoxia and signs of noncardiogenic pulmonary edema, including bilateral interstitial infiltrates visible on the chest x-ray.
Treatment is supportive, and patients usually recover without sequelae. The incidence of TRALI has been reduced by choosing males and nulliparous women as donors. Ref - Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 891-894

questions.text: What is the most common type of Anemia in a 65 y old male?
questions.solution: The most common cause of anaemia in a 65 year old male is iron deficiency anaemia. Ion deficiency, anaemia is the most common cause of anaemia in India across all age groups. Iron deficiency anaemia is usually classically described as microcytic, hypochromic anaemia, but it can also be normocytic normochromic in early stages. It presents with fatigue, koilonychia. Atrophic tongue . Lab - low levels of iron and ferrritin and increased TIBC. Ref - Harrison 20th edition page 683

questions.text: A 70-year-old man presented with back pain for the past 3 months. On examination, he has pallor, and gamma globulins are elevated. Liver function tests are normal. X-ray spine shows multiple lytic lesions. Which of the following cells are involved in the pathogenesis of this patient's condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with features suggestive of multiple myeloma:

  • Age >60 years

  • Back pain due to lytic bone lesions

  • Pallor from anemia

  • Elevated gamma globulins (monoclonal protein spike)

  • Multiple lytic lesions on X-ray

Pathogenesis:

  • Multiple myeloma is a malignancy of plasma cells.

  • Malignant plasma cells proliferate in the bone marrow, produce monoclonal immunoglobulins (M protein), and secrete factors (like IL-6) that stimulate osteoclasts → bone resorption → lytic lesions.

  • Other cell types (lymphocytes, monocytes, histiocytes) are not primarily involved in the malignant process, though they may participate in the immune environment.

Other options:

  • Lymphocytes: Precursors of plasma cells; B-cell malignancies (like CLL) involve lymphocytes.

  • Monocytes: Part of innate immunity; not central in myeloma.

  • Histiocytes: Tissue macrophages; involved in storage disorders or histiocytosis, not multiple myeloma.


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 21st edition Page no 869-871

questions.text: An elderly woman presented with symptoms of confusion, thirst, and abdominal pain. On examination, she had pallor and thoracic spine tenderness. Her lab investigations showed the following findings. An X-ray of her skull is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Elderly woman: Multiple myeloma typically affects individuals >60 years of age.

  • Confusion, thirst, abdominal pain: Classic symptoms of hypercalcemia.

  • Thoracic spine tenderness and pallor: Suggests bone involvement (e.g., lytic lesions, pathological fractures) and anemia (due to marrow infiltration).

  • Skull X-ray: Shows multiple punched-out osteolytic lesions, a hallmark of multiple myeloma.

    Why Not the Others:

  • Primary hyperparathyroidism:

    • Causes subperiosteal bone resorption and brown tumors, not classical punched-out skull lesions.

    • Usually shows osteopenia and salt-and-pepper appearance in the skull, not discrete lytic lesions.

  • Milk-alkali syndrome:

    • Hypercalcemia due to excess intake of calcium and absorbable alkali.

    • No bone lesions or anemia; usually occurs in people taking calcium supplements or antacids excessively.

  • Metastatic breast cancer:

    • Can cause osteolytic lesions, but typically in multiple bones—especially spine, pelvis, and ribs.

    • Skull lesions can occur but are usually not as punched-out and discrete as in multiple myeloma.
       

  • Clinical Features of MULTIPLE MYELOMA:

    • C – hyperCalcemia: Confusion, weakness, thirst, constipation.

    • R – Renal failure: Due to light chain cast nephropathy.

    • A – Anemia: Fatigue, pallor; marrow infiltration.

    • B – Bone lesions: Lytic lesions, bone pain, pathological fractures.

  • Radiological Findings:

    • Skull X-ray: Multiple “punched-out” lytic lesions.

    • Lytic lesions in spine, ribs, pelvis, and long bones.

  • Laboratory Findings:

    • Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP): Monoclonal spike.

    • Urine: Bence Jones proteins (free light chains).

    • Bone marrow biopsy: >10% clonal plasma cells.

  • Diagnosis:

    • Based on CRAB criteria (Calcium ↑, Renal failure, Anemia, Bone lesions).

    • Confirmed with bone marrow biopsy + monoclonal protein evidence.

  • Treatment:

    • Chemotherapy, immunomodulatory drugs (lenalidomide), proteasome inhibitors (bortezomib), stem cell transplant in selected cases.


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 793-799

questions.text: A 68-year-old male came to the physician with complaints of chronic back pain and easy fatigability and past history of multiple urinary tract infections in the last 3 months. His ESR is elevated and X-ray of his skull is shown below. Which of the following investigations is useful for diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Elderly male (68 years)

  • Chronic back pain → due to vertebral lytic lesions

  • Easy fatigability → anemia

  • Recurrent UTIs → possible immunosuppression/hypercalciuria

  • Elevated ESR

  • Skull X-ray (classically shows “punched-out lesions”)

    Why Serum Electrophoresis?

  • It detects M protein (monoclonal spike) in blood

  • Most sensitive screening test for multiple myeloma

  • Confirmatory test: Bone marrow biopsy showing >10% plasma cells

    Incorrect Options:

  • PET scan: Detects metabolically active lesions, not first-line for MM diagnosis

  • MRI brain: Not helpful unless there’s CNS involvement

  • CT head with contrast: Won’t show the systemic nature or monoclonal protein

    Key Diagnostic Tests in Suspected Multiple Myeloma:

  • Serum protein electrophoresis (SPEP)

  • Urine Bence-Jones protein (UPEP)

  • Bone marrow aspiration/biopsy

  • Skeletal survey (X-rays of skull, spine, pelvis)

    Mnemonic: CRAB features of Multiple Myeloma:

  • C – HyperCalcemia

  • R – Renal dysfunction

  • A – Anemia

  • B – Bone lesions (lytic)



Reference:DM Vasudevan textbook of biochemistry page no 330

questions.text: A 50-year-old man presents to you with features of anemia, fever, and recurrent nosebleeds. On examination there is hepatosplenomegaly, Lab investigations revealed: Hb = 6 g/dL, TLC count = 40,000/ cu.mm with 10% blasts and platelet count = 12,000/cu.mm. On further investigation, t(8;21) was detected in the blasts. What Is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Anemia, fever, bleeding → suggest bone marrow failure

  • Hepatosplenomegaly → infiltration

  • 10% blasts in peripheral blood

  • Low hemoglobin (6 g/dL)

  • Low platelet count (12,000/cu.mm)

  • TLC = 40,000/cu.mm → leukocytosis

  • Cytogenetic abnormality t(8;21)

    Diagnosis: AML with t(8;21)

  • t(8;21) is a specific chromosomal translocation seen in AML (particularly M2 subtype)

  • Indicates favorable prognosis

  • Myeloblasts typically found in peripheral smear and bone marrow

  • AML diagnosis is made when ≥20% blasts in bone marrow or blood OR if specific genetic abnormalities like t(8;21) are present, even if blasts <20%

    Why others are incorrect:

  • Aleukemic leukemia: Leukemia without blasts in peripheral smear (this case has 10% blasts)

  • ALL (Acute lymphoblastic leukemia): Common in children, t(8;21) not associated

  • Preleukemia (Myelodysplastic syndrome): Less blasts, no specific translocations like t(8;21), occurs before transformation to leukemia



Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 395,740

choices.text: Stop levetiracetam and start on a different antiepileptic
Discontinue the drug as he is seizure free
Slowly taper the drug over next 6 months
Continue levetiracetam since a 5-year seizure free interval is needed

questions.text: A patient who has a history of epilepsy, is currently taking levetiracetam 1 gm BD. He has been seizure-free for two years, but the drug use caused him to become agitated and angry, which interfered with his day-to-day activities. Which should be the next best step?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 3. Slowly taper the drug over next 6 months
Levetiracetam is a broad spectrum anti seizure medication whose mechanism of action involves modulation of neurotransmitter release by binding to synaptic vesicle glycoprotein 2A.
  • Levetiracetam can cause neuropsychiatric side effects such as agitation and anger in some individuals.
  • Since the patient’s quality of life is significantly affected by these side effects, discontinuing levetiracetam and switching to another antiepileptic drug with a different mechanism of action may be necessary.
 
  • The mood changes seen in this patient are likely a result of an adverse effect of levetiracetam. Abrupt discontinuation of the medication could lead to rebound seizures. Therefore, the optimal management approach is to gradually taper the drug over the next 6 months.
 

Adverse effects of levetiracetam include:

  • Somnolence
  • Asthenia
  • Ataxia
  • Dizziness
  • Mood and behavioral changes
  • Psychotic reactions (rare)


Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 447, 449.
Katzung Basic and Clinical Pharmacology, 13th edition, Page no 407.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in myasthenia gravis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Absent DTRs
 
  • Deep tendon reflexes (DTRs) are usually preserved in myasthenia gravis.
  • However, if the weakness is severe, it may be difficult to elicit DTRs due to inadequate muscle response.
Myasthenia gravis is an acquired autoimmune disorder where autoantibodies act against the nicotinic post synaptic receptors causing blockade of neuromuscular transmission which results in symmetric proximal predominant weakness of limbs along with occular and bulbar symptoms








Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3510, 3511.

questions.text: Which of the following complications after a stroke doesn't require medical intervention?
questions.solution:
Correct option: Neglect (Option 4) > Spasticity (Option 2)
Controversial Question

Neglect is a common feature of stroke that often does not require treatment.
While neglect can indicate a poor prognosis, most patients show recovery without intervention within 1 to 6 months.

Other options:
 
  • Fever (Option 1) is harmful in stroke patients and needs to be addressed.
  • Dysphagia (Option 3) presents a significant risk of aspiration and should not be ignored.
  • Spasticity (Option 2) can be managed with medications such as baclofen or tizanidine, as untreated spasticity can have a negative psychosocial impact on patients.
 
  • Neglect can result from damage to the cortical-limbic-reticular network, which is responsible for directing attention and integrating the localization and identification of stimuli. Although neglect is linked to poorer outcomes and slower recovery, severe cases are uncommon beyond 6 months. Recovery is typically rapid in the first two weeks, regardless of which side the stroke affects, and by three months, patients may still experience some residual visual neglect. Treatment options for neglect depend on its underlying mechanisms; for instance, patients with underaroused right hemispheres may struggle to process sensory inputs.
 
  • Spasticity occurs in fewer than 20% of stroke patients, and those with bilateral weakness from hypoxic injury are more likely to exhibit signs of spasticity. Symptoms such as exaggerated cutaneous and autonomic reflexes and involuntary spasms can be quite disabling. Physical therapies like slow stretching and daily passive exercises can help alleviate spasticity and prevent contractures. Medications like baclofen, tizanidine, and clonidine are effective in reducing clonus and extensor spasms.



Reference: Bradley’s Neurology in Clinical Practice, 7th Edition, Page no 829, 830, 832-845.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man had a history of fall and along with one episode of vomiting following which he had certain memory disturbances. On evaluation at a nearby hospital he was found to have anterograde amnesia. which of the following structures are most likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 2. Hippocampus
Anterograde amnesia is the inability to create new memories after an event that caused amnesia, leading to a partial or complete inability to recall the recent past , while long term memories from before the event remain intact. 

Anterograde amnesia can occur from damage caused to the structures involving the Papez circuit.




Reference: Bradley  Neurology in clinical practice, 8th edition, Chapter 7 page 63

questions.text: Where is hypertensive haemorrhage most commonly seen?
questions.solution:
• Hypertensive ICH usually results from spontaneous rupture of a small penetrating artery deep in the brain.
  • The most common sites are the basal ganglia (especially the putamen), thalamus, cerebellum, and pons.
  • The small arteries in these areas seem most prone to hypertension-induced vascular injury.
 
  • ICH accounts for ~10% of all strokes, and ~35–45% of patients die within the first month. Incidence rates are particularly high in Asians and blacks.
  • Hypertension, coagulopathy, sympathomimetic drugs (cocaine, methamphetamine), and cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) cause most of these hemorrhages.



Transaxial NCCT Brain showing Hypertensive basal ganglia hemorrhage



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3349.

choices.text: Put a handkerchief in his mouth and restrain him by holding hands and legs
Take him away from the train, give him medicine with small sips of water and wait for seizure to resolve
Take him away from the train, give him medicine with small sips of water and raise his legs and wait for seizure to resolve
Take him away from the train, make him lie down and call for the hospital

questions.text: While waiting for the train, a passenger started having seizures at the train station. It was discovered that he wears a wristband identifying him as an epilepsy patient who has a medication in his pocket. What are your next actions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Take him away from the train, make him lie down and call for the hospital

Take him away from the train, make him lie down, and call for medical assistance or the hospital.
If someone is having a seizure, the following steps can be taken:
  1. Ensure the person's safety: Move the individual away from any potential dangers or hazards, such as sharp objects or traffic.
  2. Support their head and protect them: Cushion their head with something soft to prevent injury during the seizure. It is important not to restrain the person or put anything in their mouth.
  3. Clear the area: Create space around the person by moving objects and people away. This helps prevent accidental contact during the seizure.
  4. Time the seizure: Note the start time of the seizure. If the seizure lasts longer than five minutes or if the person has difficulty breathing, it is crucial to call for emergency medical assistance immediately.
  5. After the seizure: Once the seizure ends, check the person's responsiveness and breathing. If they are not responsive or are having difficulty breathing, perform CPR if you are trained to do so or wait for medical professionals to arrive.
  6. Nothing should be administered in the mouth during active seizure episode as it may lead to aspiration of contents.



Reference: First Aid for Seizures, CDC guidelines (2024), URL: https://www.cdc.gov/epilepsy/first-aid-for-seizures/index.html

questions.text: Which of the following diseases saw the first reduction in a single neurotransmitter's levels?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Parkinson's disease

Parkinson's disease was the first among the diseases that have reduction in a single neurotransmitter's levels.
It is caused due to degeneration  of dopaminergic neurons in the Substantia nigra.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3387.

questions.text: A 15 year old boy presented with headache vomiting and altered sensorium. On probing his parents gave a history of recent URTI after swimming at a near by pond.  He was diagnosed to have meningitis and he succumbed to his illness on day five.  What is the most likely etiological agent among the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Naegleria fowleri
 
  • Naegleria fowleri is a free-living amoeba that can cause a rare but severe infection of the central nervous system called primary amebic meningoencephalitis (PAM).
  • It is commonly associated with warm freshwater environments such as lakes and hot springs. Infections occur when contaminated water enters the nasal passages and allows the amoeba to reach the brain.
  • The symptoms of Naegleria fowleri infection typically include a severe headache, high fever, neck stiffness, and often purulent nasal discharge.
  • The infection progresses rapidly and can lead to coma and death within a few days.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1718, 1719.

questions.text: The H-reflex can be used to diagnose
questions.solution:
The H-reflex (or Hoffmann's reflex) is used primarily to diagnose S1 radiculopathy.
 
  • An H-reflex is a spinal reflex that involves both sensory and motor fibers. It's a sensitive test that can be used to assess radiculopathy.
  • During an H-reflex test, the tibial nerve in the popliteal fossa is stimulated to elicit a monosynaptic S1 reflex response.
  • It assesses the integrity of the S1 nerve root by measuring the electrical response of the muscle following stimulation of the sensory nerve.
  • In evaluating radiculopathy, a unilateral absent H reflex or a side-to-side latency difference greater than 2.0 ms supports a diagnosis of an S1 radiculopathy




Reference: Alrowayeh, Hesham N, and Mohamed A Sabbahi. “H-reflex amplitude asymmetry is an earlier sign of nerve root involvement than latency in patients with S1 radiculopathy.” BMC research notes vol. 4 102. 5 Apr. 2011, doi:10.1186/1756-0500-4-102. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3078869/

questions.text: What is the time frame for thrombolysis in a stroke patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: 4.5 hours
  • Thrombolysis, or the administration of clot-dissolving medication, is a treatment option for acute ischemic stroke.
  • The recommended time window for thrombolysis is within 4.5 hours from the onset of stroke symptoms.
  • Initiating thrombolysis within this time frame can help improve blood flow to the affected area of the brain and potentially minimize long-term disability.

NOTE: Current recommendations state IV rTPA efficacy to extend from 4.5 hours to 6 hours.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3337.

questions.text: Which is the most specific sign of metabolic encephalopathy?
questions.solution:
Although asterixis on the motor examination is vague, it typically points to a toxic or metabolic cause of the delirium.

It is a disorder of motor control, defined as sudden, brief, arrhythmic lapses of sustained posture due to involuntary interruption in muscle contraction.
This condition involves a specific form of negative myoclonus, characterized by momentary loss of muscle tone in agonist muscles, followed by a compensatory jerk involving antagonistic muscles
 
  • Bilateral asterixis is a sure symptom of metabolic encephalopathy or drug intoxication in a sleepy and disoriented patient.
  • However, Most common symptom of Metabolic encephalopathy is Delirium.
Other symptoms include:
  • Hallucinations
  • Involuntary movements (tremors)
  • Seizures
  • Difficulty breathing
  • Loss of consciousness
  • Nausea
  • Fatigue and difficulty sleeping (insomnia)
  • Depression 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 186.
Agarwal, R, and R Baid. “Asterixis.” Journal of postgraduate medicine vol. 62,2 (2016): 115-7. doi:10.4103/0022-3859.180572. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4944342/

questions.text: In which of the following aphasias naming and fluency are impaired?
questions.solution:
Broca's aphasia:
Preserved comprehension (except grammar) with impaired naming and fluency. 
Brocas aphasia is caused  due to damage to the inferior frontal lobe of the brain's dominant hemisphere, made up of Brodmann areas 44 and 45. 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 196, 197.

questions.text: A 9-year-old child complained of having trouble combing his hair and climbing stairs. on examination bilateral calves were enlarged. His mother also gave a history that the child has been toe walking since a few days. What comes next in the diagnostic process?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Creatine kinase levels

The above mentioned clinical features points to a diagnosis of Proximal myopathy most probably associated with Duchenne Muscular dystrophy (DMD).

Clinical features include: 
  • Proximal muscles, especially of the lower extremities, are prominently involved.
  • This becomes evident in DMD very early; boys with DMD have difficulty climbing stairs and never run well.
  • As the disease progresses, weakness becomes more generalized. Hypertrophy of muscles, particularly in the calves, is an early and prominent finding.

 
  • The initial preferred muscle enzyme to evaluate when assessing myopathies is Creatine Kinase (CK) levels.
  • The CK leaks from the muscle fibre to the serum as a result of muscle damage.
  • CK is the most sensitive measure of muscle damage. The MM isoenzyme predominates in skeletal muscle, whereas CK-myocardial bound (CK-MB) is the marker for cardiac muscle.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3520, 3521.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of benign intracranial hypertension?
questions.solution:
Graves disease exhibits proptosis. Benign intracranial hypertension does not exhibit it.

Benign Intracranial Hypertension:  (a.k.a Pseudotumor cerebri)
  • Adult idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) is a rare condition of unknown cause, which results in raised intracranial pressure (ICP).
  •  Young obese women are most commonly affected, although rarely it may occur in men.
  • Patients first experience headaches, diplopia (typically from CN VI palsy), and unaltered mental status.
  • A diagnosis of IIH requires CSF opening pressure greater than 250 mmCSF



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 116.

choices.text: Breath holding is not required for the procedure
The bevel of the needle face upwards while inserting the needle

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about the procedure done with the following needle?
questions.solution:
Platelets below 50,000 is a contraindication to Lumbar Puncture.


Contraindications of LP:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Chapter S9 (Technique of Lumbar Puncture).

choices.text: Give loading dose of aspirin and clopidogrel

questions.text:
A 60 years old female patient has left sided weakness since 1 hour and left sided face weakness with BP, 160/100 mm Hg.
What is the best next step if the CT scan is normal?
questions.solution:
The first step in such patients is NCCT head to rule out hemorrhagic stroke.

As CT head is normal in the question, it is suggestive of non-hemorrhagic stroke and Window period for thrombolysis is <4.5 hour so this patient can be considered for thrombolysis with Alteplase/Tenecteplase.
Thrombolytic agent, recombinant t-PA can be use between 3-4.5 hours after the onset of stroke.

The preferred drug is alteplase and it's dose is 0.9 mg/kg. 

Management of Acute Stroke:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3336, 3337.

questions.text:
A 53-year-old man with a recent history of CVA is hospitalized. He is drowsy and not responding to commands. The CT image is displayed as in the figure.
What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient has low GCS  and NCCT of the head shows a large wedge shaped infarct in left MCA territory with significant midline shift. In such a scenario,  decompressive neurosurgery will be the next best step of management in order to prevent impending brain herniation. 
 
  • Decompressive craniectomy is a neurosurgical procedure that reduces increased intracranial pressure in the presence of space-occupying brain lesions or brain swelling due to stroke.
  • Cerebral edema is a potential complication in 5-10% of patients with strokes, leading to obtundation and brain herniation. The severity of edema is highest on the second or third day after the stroke and can last for around 10 days.
  • Medical management may not be successful in case of significant edema or infarcts involving the cerebellum.

 
  • Decompressive surgery is recommended for patients who are less than 60 years old and experience deterioration within 48 hours, despite receiving medical therapy.
  • Hypodensity on head CT within the first 6 hours of stroke onset, involving > one-third of the MCA territory, early midline shift, and a diffusion-weighted imaging volume on MRI within 6 hours >80 mL are predictors of severe cerebral edema. 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3337.

questions.text: A patient with a headache visits the emergency room and claims it is the worst headache he has ever had. What is the next course of treatment?
questions.solution:
“The worst headache I've ever had” is a  symptom of a subarachnoid haemorrhage.

CT of the brain should be the next step for diagnosis.
 
  • The hallmark of aneurysmal rupture is blood in the CSF. More than 95% of cases have enough blood to be visualized on a high-quality noncontrast CT scan obtained within 72 h.
 
  • The extent and location of subarachnoid blood on a noncontrast CT scan help locate the underlying aneurysm, identify the cause of any neurologic deficit, and predict the occurrence of vasospasm.
 
  • If the scan fails to establish the diagnosis of SAH and no mass lesion or obstructive hydrocephalus is found, a lumbar puncture should be performed to establish the presence of subarachnoid blood. Lysis of the red blood cells and subsequent conversion of hemoglobin to bilirubin stains the spinal fluid yellow within 6–12 h. This xanthochromic spinal fluid peaks in intensity at 48 h and lasts for 1–4 weeks, depending on the amount of subarachnoid blood.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3354, 3355.

questions.text: A patient with fever and a headache arrives at the emergency room. On examination, he has stiffness in his neck. A CSF analysis was performed The opening pressure was increased, proteins were mild, glucose was normal, and lymphocytes were increased. What is the most likely organism responsible for this?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. Coxsackie virus
 
  • The presence of chronic headaches and stiff neck signify meningitis, according to medical history.
  • Elevated opening pressure, slightly increased proteins, normal glucose, and increased lymphocytes in the CSF assay results are strongly suggestive of viral (Coxsackie virus) meningitis.
Meningitis accompanied by normal glucose levels strongly suggests viral meningitis.


CSF findings in Meningitis:
 
Appearance Opening Pressure mmHg WBC (cell/\(\mu\)L) Protein (mg/dl) Glucose (mg/dL)
Normal Clear 90-180 < 8 15-45 50-80
Bacterial Meningitis Turbid Elevated > 1000-2000 >200 <40
Viral meningitis Clear Normal <300; Lymphocytic predominance <200 Normal
Fungal Meningitis Clear Normal-elevated <500 >200 Normal-Low



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 946.

questions.text: Which sort of spinocerebellar ataxia is most prevalent in India?
questions.solution:
Spinocerebellar ataxia (SCA) is a group of inherited neurological disorders that cause problems with coordination and balance. These disorders are caused by changes in certain genes that control the movement of proteins, which are essential for proper functioning of the brain and nerves.
 
  • SCA2 is the most common form of SCA in India, caused by a mutation of a protein called ataxin-2. This protein is responsible for the functioning of nerve cells and for the proper formation of connections between nerve cells in the brain and spine.
 
  • Individuals with SCA2 experience difficulty with balance, coordination of movements, and speech. They may also experience muscle weakness and involuntary twitching of the body.
 
  • Treatment of SCA2 usually involves medications to improve coordination and maintain muscle strength, as well as physical and occupational therapy.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3424.

questions.text: Which structure is most likely to be compressed in a posterior intercommunicating artery aneurysm?
questions.solution:
An aneurysm of the posterior cerebral artery (PCA) or Posterior communicating artery is likely to affect the oculomotor nerve due to its close proximity to the artery. The oculomotor nerve is responsible for controlling the medial and lateral movement of the eye, as well as pupil size and shape.

Aneurysms can cause damage to the oculomotor nerve, resulting in ocular motor dysfunction including ophthalmoplegia (paralysis of eye muscles), impaired vision and abnormal pupil responses. 



Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 931, 937.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 229.

questions.text: A patient has hypotonia and unilateral ptosis in the same eye. After receiving an IV shot, his symptoms vanished for a breif duration. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Clinical findings of unilateral ptosis and hypotonia in the eye with improvement after an IV injection (most probably
edrophonium) indicates Myasthenia gravis.

Clinical features of Myasthenia Gravis:

Muscle weakness and fatiguability are its defining characteristics.

• Weakness may worsen late in the day or after prolonged use (fatigue), although it may also become better after rest or sleep.
• There is a recognizable pattern to how muscular weakness is distributed.

Early on in the course of MG, the cranial muscles (lids and extraocular muscles) are frequently affected.
Ptosis and diplopia are frequent early complaints.

• The patient's attempt to grin is met with a "snarling" face due to facial weakness.
• Chewing weakness is most obvious after exerting a lot of effort, like when chewing meat.

Speech timbre: nasal (due to weakness of palate) Dissonant "mushy" quality (due ot tongue weakness)
• Difficulty swallowing due to pharyngeal, tongue, or palate paralysis, resulting in aspiration or nasal regurgitation.

The edrophonium (Tensilon) test is sometimes of value in distinguishing botulism (usually a negative result) from myasthenia gravis (usually a positive result), which was performed in the question.




Reference: Ophthalmology by Yanoff and Duker, 5th edition, Page no 1275.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3510, 3511.

questions.text: Pseudotumor Cerebri is usually seen in:
questions.solution:
• Pseudotumor cerebri, also known as idiopathic intracranial hypertension, is a neurological disorder characterized by increased pressure in the cranial cavity which can result in severe headaches, blurred or double vision, or even vision loss.
 
  • It is most commonly seen in obese women between the ages of 20 and 45. This is because increased pressure in the brain is more likely to occur in those with a higher amount of intra-abdominal fat, which pushes up on the diaphragm and therefore increases pressure on the cranial cavity.
 
  • Age also plays a role because it is more common in this age range among women.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 116.

questions.text: Since two years ago, a 60-year-movements old's have been gradually slowing down. She moves in a rectangular, slow wave jerking fashion and exhibits rigidity. The likelihood of a diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Progressive supranuclear palsy (PSP) is a neurological disorder that affects movement and causes stiffness, decreased movement, and an inability to control eye movements. The cause of PSP is unknown. It typically affects individuals over the age of 60 and its symptoms are progressive.

Clinical features and progression: 
 
  • Clinically, PSP-RS begins with falls and executive or subtle personality changes (such as mental rigidity, impulsivity, or apathy).
  • Shortly thereafter, a progressive oculomotor syndrome ensues that begins with square wave jerks, followed by slowed saccades (vertical worse than horizontal) before resulting in progressive supranuclear ophthalmoparesis.
  • Dysarthria, dysphagia, and symmetric axial rigidity can be prominent features that emerge at any point in the illness. A stiff, unstable posture with hyperextension of the neck and a slow, jerky, toppling gait are characteristic.
  • Frequent unexplained and sometimes spectacular falls are common secondary to a combination of axial rigidity, inability to look down, and impaired judgment.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3380.

questions.text:
Symptoms of a 56-year-old male include a unilateral headache, diplopia, and fever. He found it challenging to chew. ESR was higher and the brain MRI results were normal.
What is the treatment advisable?
questions.solution:
• This individual is likely to be suffering from temporal (giant cell) arteritis, which is an inflammatory disorder often affecting the large  arteries, usually those found in the head, including those leading to the eyes and the temples.

 
  • In order to confirm the diagnosis, the patient's erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) must be persistently high along with normal results on magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) scans. As this condition is highly serious and can cause permanent damage to the arteries, treatment needs to start before confirmation of the diagnosis.

 
  • The initial treatment plan consists of high-dose prednisolone or corticosteroid therapy which helps reduce the inflammation in the arteries. This can help to slow or stop the progression of the condition and possibly reverse any damage caused.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2812.

choices.text: Amyloid Angiopathy is associated with Small Vessel Disease
Alzheimer's Disease is associated with Amyloid Angiopathy
Alzheimer's Disease is related to small vessel Disease
Alzheimer's Disease is not related to small vessel Disease

questions.text: All are true EXCEPT
questions.solution:
It has been seen that deposition of amyloid is aggravated in patients with cerebral small-vessel disease, especially in apolipoprotein E4 carriers, providing evidence for pathophysiological synergy between these three biological factors
 
  • The accumulation of Aβ in cerebral arterioles is termed amyloid angiopathy. Thus, amyloid angiopathy is a small vessel disease whi is also seen in patients with Alzheimer's disease.
  • In Alzheimer's disease Microscopically, there are widespread neuritic plaques containing amyloid beta (Aβ), neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) composed of hyperphosphorylated tau filaments, and Aβ accumulation in blood vessel walls in cortex and leptomeninges (amyloid angiopathy).
  • Also, in many patients with AD, amyloid angiopathy can lead to microhemorrhages, large lobar hemorrhages, ischemic infarctions most often in the subcortical white matter, or in rare cases an inflammatory leukoencephalopathy.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3349, 3370-3372.

questions.text: Which of the following matches is incorrect?
questions.solution:
• Moya Moya disease is a progressive neurological disorder which is characterized by narrowing or blockage of the blood vessels leading to the brain.
  • Moyamoya disease is a poorly understood occlusive disease involving large intracranial arteries, especially the distal internal carotid artery and the stem of the MCA and ACA. Vascular inflammation is absent.
  • The lenticulostriate arteries develop a rich collateral circulation around the occlusive lesion, which gives the impression of a “puff of smoke” (moyamoya in Japanese) on conventional x-ray angiography.
  • It is most commonly diagnosed in children and is associated with the narrowing and occlusion of the circle of Willis and arteries that feed it, as well as the presence of abnormal and collateral vessels within the brain.
  • It is not associated with aortic aneurysms, which are conditions where a weakened area in the aorta bulges out, forming a balloon-like structure, and can be life-threatening if the aneurysm ruptures.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3343.

questions.text: A 42-year-old lady from a dry state who had consumed rye for an extended period of time complained of exhaustion, nausea, and weakness in both lower limbs. She eventually loses the ability to walk altogether. What is the most probable reason?
questions.solution:
• The reason for developing this illness is consuming Lathyrus sativus (Khesari dal), which contains the ODAP/BOAA toxin.
  • It produces pyramidal tract injury, which manifests as paralysis with evidence of higher motor neuron damage in the lower limbs and a lack of strength in or inability to move those limbs.
  • Ingestion of legumes containing the toxin occurs despite an awareness of the means to detoxify Lathyrus.
  • Drought conditions can lead to shortages of both fuel and water, preventing the necessary detoxification steps from being taken, particularly in impoverished countries.
  • When certain legumes from the genus Lathyrus are consumed, it can lead to a neurological disorder known as neurolathyrism in humans.

Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, page no 759.

choices.text: Due to occlusion of right posterior inferior cerebellar artery
Due to occlusion of left posterior inferior cerebellar artery
Due to occlusion of anterior inferior cerebellar artery

questions.text: A 59-year-old male patient complains of right-sided palatal paralysis and loss of sensation on face. Horner's syndrome, nystagmus, vertigo, ataxia, and dysphagia are discovered during examination. The patient is unable to stand on his own two feet. What causes this manifestation the most frequently?
questions.solution:
The given symptoms are compliant with a case of Lateral Medullary Syndrome, most common cause of which is the occlusion of Vertebral artery > posterior inferior cerebellar artery.

 

Symptoms of Lateral Medullary Syndrome:

  • Contralateral sensory deficits from the body
  • Ipsilateral Cerebellar signs like Ataxia
  • Ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation from the face
  • Ipsilateral palatal, pharyngeal and laryngeal hemiparesis.
  • Ipsilateral Horner Syndrome.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3329.

questions.text: A patient with altered sensorium arrives at the emergency room. The test that could be done at last is:
questions.solution:
• For patients with altered sensorium, it is generally recommended that an imaging study be performed prior to lumbar puncture to exclude the causes of raised ICP (large intracranial mass lesion) and to prevent herniation. “Lumbar puncture is performed less frequently  for coma diagnosis because neuroimaging effectively excludes intracerebral & extensive subarachnoid hemorrhage. 
 
  • The metabolic aberrations commonly encountered in clinical practice are usually revealed by measurement of electrolytes, glucose, calcium, magnesium, osmolarity, and renal (blood urea nitrogen) and hepatic (NH3) function.
 
  • Lumbar puncture should be performed if no cause is readily apparent, as examination of the CSF remains indispensable in the diagnosis of various forms of meningitis and encephalitis.


NOTE: An imaging study should be performed prior to lumbar puncture to exclude a large intracranial mass lesion, which could lead to herniation with lumbar puncture.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 187.

questions.text: Cerebellar lesion cannot produce:
questions.solution:
A cerebellar lesion can produce all of the given symptoms except Resting tremors. 

Resting tremors are seen in case of damage to Basal Ganglia like in Parkinson's disease.

However, cerebellar damage may result in intention tremors.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3280, 3400.

questions.text: A and B were instructed to create a square from the empty and filled circles, respectively. A drew a square that isn't really a square. What could be the potential reason?
questions.solution:
Image A shows the phenomenon of past-pointing and intentional tremor while joining the empty and filled circles, seen in case of cerebellar lesions. 




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3280, 3400.

questions.text: A 7-year-old kid arrives with a right-sided hemangioma and left-sided focal convulsions. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Sturge-Weber syndrome, or encephalotrigeminal angiomatosis, is a phakomatosis characterized by facial port wine stains and pial angiomas. 

  • The diagnosis is usually obvious on account of a congenital facial cutaneous capillary malformation (also known as port wine stain or facial nevus flammeus). This feature is almost always present and usually involves the ophthalmic division (V1) of the trigeminal nerve ; if this territory is not involved, Sturge-Weber syndrome is unlikely.
 
  • In ~5%, it has intracranial involvement present without associated cutaneous nevus. In the majority of cases (~70%) the nevus is unilateral and ipsilateral to the intracranial abnormality. 
 
  • The most common clinical manifestation is with childhood focal seizures, present in 71-89% of cases, which is often refractory to medical therapy. These usually begin in the first few years of life and are often associated with developmental delay and hemispheric symptoms including hemiplegia/hemiparesis and hemianopsia.
 
  • Approximately a third of patients have choroidal or scleral angiomatous involvement, which may be complicated by retinal detachment, buphthalmos or glaucoma. 




Reference: Essential Pediatrics by OP Ghai, 9th edition, Page no 558, 559.

questions.text: What is the first indication of cord compression in a case of thoracic spine tuberculosis?
questions.solution:
The first signs of spinal cord compression in thoracic spine tuberculosis are usually pain, weakness, and numbness in the upper and lower extremities. These symptoms may progress over time, leading to paraplegia.

Other symptoms of spinal cord compression include: 
  • Loss of bladder and bowel control 
  • Loss of sensation in the limbs and trunk 
  • Difficulty walking 
  • Tightness in the lower limbs 
  • Loss of dexterity and weakness in hand grip 
  • Loss of balance and spasticity in legs 



Reference: Garg, Ravindra Kumar, and Dilip Singh Somvanshi. “Spinal tuberculosis: a review.” The journal of spinal cord medicine vol. 34,5 (2011): 440-54. doi:10.1179/2045772311Y.0000000023. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3184481/

questions.text: A patient using ATT on a regular basis had tubercular meningitis. At the end of one month of consistent drug use, the patient's condition has deteriorated despite good drug compliance. Which of the following inquiries is not necessary for an emergency assessment?
questions.solution:
CSF examination in this case is not required in emergency evaluation.
 
  • Blood cultures should be acquired right away when there is a suspicion of bacterial meningitis, and supplementary dexamethasone therapy should also be started.
  • NCCT followed by MRI and LFT will be useful for immediate diagnosis or status of the patient.
  • However CSF analysis will not provide with any new information after 1 month of ATT.



Reference: Davis, Angharad et al. “Treatment of Tuberculous Meningitis and Its Complications in Adults.” Current treatment options in neurology vol. 20,3 5. 28 Feb. 2018, doi:10.1007/s11940-018-0490-9. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5830467/

questions.text: Which medication was recently approved by the FDA for the treatment of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome?
questions.solution:
Recently approved drug by FDA for treatment of Lennox-Gastaut syndrome is Rufinamide.

  • Rufinamide is an anticonvulsant medication that is used to treat Lennox-Gastaut syndrome and other seizure disorders in combination with other medications and therapy. 
  • On November 14, 2008, the US Food and Drug Administration approved rufinamide as an adjunctive treatment for seizures associated with Lennox-Gastaut syndrome in children 4 years of age and older, as well as adults.



Other drugs used in Lennox-Gestaut syndrome: 

  1. Clobazam
  2. Felbamate
  3. Lamotrigine
  4. Topiramate
  5. Cannabidiol



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3307, 3312, 3319.

choices.text: One dose of low molecular weight heparin subcutaneously followed by dual antiplatelet therapy

questions.text: A patient with aortic valve disease who also had right hemiparesis was admitted. What steps will you take to stop further strokes?
questions.solution:
• Aspirin is the only antiplatelet agent that has been shown to be effective in the acute treatment of ischemic stroke; however, there are several antiplatelet agents that have been shown to be effective in the secondary prevention of stroke.
 
  • Two large trials, the International Stroke Trial (IST) and the Chinese Acute Stroke Trial (CAST), found that the use of aspirin within 48 h of stroke onset reduced both stroke recurrence risk and mortality.

  • Numerous clinical trials have failed to demonstrate any benefit of routine anticoagulation in the primary treatment of atherothrombotic cerebral ischemia and have also shown an increase in the risk of brain and systemic hemorrhage. Therefore, the routine use of heparin or other anticoagulants for patients with atherothrombotic stroke is not warranted.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3338.

questions.text: Except for____________all exhibit coarse tongue tremors.
questions.solution:
Thyrotoxicosis leads to fine tongue tremors, not the coarse tongue tremors.

Causes of coarse tremors include:

  • Alcoholism
  • Drug addiction
  • Anxiety Disorder
  • Tongue Paralysis
  • Parkinsonism

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2939.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with right hemiparesis and 2.5 hours of speech loss presented to emergency. BP is 180/100. What is the best course of action for managing this patient moving forward?
questions.solution:
The next best step in the management of this patient is go for NCCT Brain.

  • Following the clinical diagnosis of stroke, a sequential process of evaluation and treatment should ensue. The first objective is to prevent or reverse brain injury.
  • Attend to the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs) and, if hypoglycemia or hyperglycemia is detected, treat it.
  • Perform an emergency noncontrast head CT scan to distinguish between ischemic and hemorrhagic stroke.



Management of Acute Stroke: 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3336, 3337.

questions.text: A 32-year-old Bengali woman presented with a 48-hour fever, a history of meaningless chatter, and two occurrences of tonic-clonic seizures that occurred back-to-back on the way to the hospital. She also had bizarre behaviour and memory disturbances. Before, she had been fine. Which medication from the list below can be administered while the other investigations are ongoing?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 4. IV acyclovir

The above clinical scenario with meaningless chatter, GTCS, abnormal behaviour and memory disturbances point the diagnosis towards HSV (viral) encephalitis.
 
  • The patient with encephalitis commonly has an altered level of consciousness (confusion, behavioral abnormalities), or a depressed level of consciousness ranging from mild lethargy to coma, and evidence of either focal or diffuse neurologic signs and symptoms.
  • Patients with encephalitis may have hallucinations, agitation, personality change, behavioral disorders, and, at times, a frankly psychotic state.
 
  • HSV encephalitis should be considered when clinical features suggest involvement of the inferomedial frontotemporal regions of the brain, including prominent olfactory or gustatory hallucinations, anosmia, unusual or bizarre behavior or personality alterations, or memory disturbance.
  • HSV encephalitis should always be suspected in patients with signs and symptoms consistent with acute encephalitis with focal findings on clinical examination, neuroimaging studies, or EEG.
 
  • Diagnosis: The diagnostic procedure of choice in these patients is CSF PCR analysis for HSV. A positive CSF PCR establishes the diagnosis.
 
  • Treatment: Acyclovir is of benefit in the treatment of HSV and should be started empirically in patients with suspected viral encephalitis, especially if focal features are present, while awaiting viral diagnostic studies.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1094, 1097.

choices.text: Sequential nerve demyelination followed by inflammatory myopathy during course of disease
Cranial nerves are involved more commonly than peripheral nerve
Diaphragmatic atony due to prolonged intubation may cause it

questions.text: What is true regarding the critical illness myoneuropathy?
questions.solution:
Diaphragmatic atony due to prolonged intubation may cause critical illness myoneuropathy.
 
  • Critical illness polyneuropathy (CIP) or critical illness myopathy (CIM) are the most common causes of weakness in critically ill patients in the ICU due to prolonged neuromuscular blockade. 
  • Both CIM and CIP develop as a complication of sepsis and multiple organ failure. They usually present as an inability to wean a patient from a ventilator.
 
  • Serum creatine kinase (CK) levels are usually normal; an elevated serum CK level indicates CIM rather than CIP.
  • In CIP, nerve conduction studies show that motor and sensory studies are absent or have significantly reduced amplitudes, whereas sensory studies are relatively preserved in CIM.
 
  • Improvement takes weeks in mild cases and months in severe cases. Over 50% of patients have reported complete recovery.
  • In more severe cases, however, recovery may be incomplete or may not occur at all.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3490.

questions.text: A patient fell unconscious two hours ago after experiencing a sudden, acute headache which he describes as the worst headache of life. He later became conscious but has neck rigidity and photophobia. What should be done after that?
questions.solution:
Most probable diagnosis in this case is subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).
 
  • In SAH, sudden loss of consciousness may be preceded by a brief moment of excruciating headache, but most patients first complain of headache upon regaining consciousness.
 
  • The patient often calls the headache “the worst headache of my life”; however, the most important characteristic is sudden onset.
 
  • NCCT head should be done in this case to confirm the diagnosis. On CT scans, subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) appears as a high-attenuating, amorphous substance that fills the normally dark, CSF-filled subarachnoid spaces around the brain. The normally black subarachnoid cisterns and sulci may appear white in acute hemorrhage.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3354, 3355.

questions.text: An elderly patient with hypertension who developed a sudden onset headache, nausea, and neck stiffness but no localised neurological deficit. What will be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An elderly, hypertensive patient presented with sudden onset headache, vomiting, neck rigidity without focal neurological deficit, diagnosis in this case is subarachnoid hemorrhage.

NCCT is done to confirm diagnosis.

Subarachnoid Hemorrhage
 
  • MC cause: Trauma >Spontaneous rupture of Berry aneurysm
  • Clinical Features: Sudden transient loss of consciousness, Complaint of Severe headache in 45% of cases and is more commonly on regaining consciousness. Neck stiffness and vomiting without Focal neurological deficit and Sudden headache in the absence of focal neurological deficit is the hallmark sign.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3354.

choices.text: Replacement of stylet prior to removal of needle

questions.text: Which of the following is not an effective strategy to decrease the risk of post-puncture dural headache?
questions.solution:
Supplementation, of fluid does not prevent post-dura/ puncture headache (PDPH). 

Techniques for prevention of Post-dural Puncture Headache are: 

Use of atraumatic pencil-point spinal needle, Direction of bevel insertion parallel to the longitudinal dural fibers for cutting needles, smaller needle size, replacement of stylet before withdrawing the spinal needle, Ultrasound guided neuraxial blocks, lesser number of lumbar puncture attempts.

POST DURAL PUNCTURE HEADACHE:

  • May follow lumbar puncture, spinal anesthesia, wet epidural tap (in which epidural needle pierced dura).
  • Onset 12-72hrs and last for 1-2 weeks.
  • Aggravated by sitting and relieved by lying down.
  • Incidence increases with the larger needle, cutting point (in comparison to pencil point) needle, young age, females, pregnancy.
  • Prevention by thinner needle 

Management: 

  1. Supine position
  2. IV fluids
  3. Caffeine and analgesia
  4. Epidural blood patch 



Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 8th edition, Page no 1712.
Morgan and Mikhail's Clinical Anesthesiology, 5th edition, Page no 969.

questions.text:
A patient with a history of alcoholism is brought to the emergency room by his wife. Due to religious obligations, the person has abstained from alcohol for the past two days.
The participant reported feeling queasy, nauseated, and dizzy. He began having seizures on the second day, which later turned into widespread tonic-clonic seizures (GTCS).
Which of the following would be the most effective medication to treat the patient's seizure?
questions.solution:
The seizures in this patient and above clinical features are suggestive of Delirium tremens, due to acute alcohol withdrawal.

  • Delirium tremens (DTs), where the withdrawal includes delirium (mental confusion, agitation, and fluctuating levels of consciousness) associated with a tremor, seizure and autonomic overactivity (e.g., marked increases in pulse, blood pressure, and respirations).
  • Diazepam would can be used to manage the seizure of the patient. 
 
  • Although most depressants are effective, benzodiazepines have the most supportive data for use in this situation, combining a high level of safety and low cost.
  • To treat mild-moderate, uncomplicated alcohol withdrawal, either long acting benzodiazepines like chlordiazepoxide or diazepam or short-acting ones like lorazepam can be taken.
  • Chlordiazepoxide is favoured over diazepam for this purpose.
  • Liver disease is associated frequently with alcohol use. 
Benzodiazepines safe in Liver disease-
LOve The liver
L- Lorazepam
O- Oxazepam
T- Temazepam




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3561.

questions.text: What is a cognitive remediation used for?
questions.solution:
Cognitive remediation is used for cognitive restructuring. 

  • Cognitive remediation therapy (CRT), also known as cognitive enhancement therapy (CET), is a type of cognitive rehabilitation therapy developed at Kings College in London with the goal of enhancing neurocognitive skills like executive functioning, planning, flexibility, attention, and working memory.
 
  • These skills all contribute to social functioning.




Reference: Fan, Qing et al. “The Application of Cognitive Remediation Therapy in The Treatment of Mental Disorders.” Shanghai archives of psychiatry vol. 29,6 (2017): 373-375. doi:10.11919/j.issn.1002-0829.217079. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5925589/

questions.text: An older, hypertensive patient is experiencing sudden onset headache, vomiting, and neck rigidity without a specific neurological abnormality. What is the correct diagnosis?
questions.solution:
An elderly, hypertensive patient presented with sudden onset headache, vomiting, neck rigidity without focal neurological deficit, diagnosis in this case is subarachnoid hemorrhage.

Features of SAH would include- 

1. Sudden, severe headache
2. Stiff neck
3. Nausea and vomiting
4. Decreased alertness, confusion
5. Seizures
6. Vision changes, such as blurred or double vision
7. Loss of consciousness
8. Facial weakness
9. Weakness or numbness in an arm or leg
10. Difficulty speaking or understanding speech



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3354.

questions.text: Which part of the brain is most likely to experience atrophy in Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Temporoparietal

  • In Alzheimer's disease, the part of the brain most likely to experience atrophy is the temporoparietal region.
  • This area is involved in cognitive functions such as memory, language, and spatial orientation, which are commonly affected in Alzheimer's disease.
 
  • In typical amnestic AD, brain atrophy begins in the medial temporal lobes before spreading to the inferior temporal, lateral, medial parietal, and dorsolateral frontal cortices.
  • The pattern of binding is largely consistent with Braak neuropathologic staging of NFTs, with early retention in medial temporal regions, followed by spread into temporoparietal and cingulate cortices, dorsolateral prefrontal regions, and, ultimately, primary sensory and motor areas.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3370, 3371.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is bumping into things and is experiencing acute onset amnesia. Upon assessment, she displayed normal comprehension, fluency of speaking, and alertness. Additional testing found difficulties identifying the fingers, right-left confusion, impaired arithmetic skills, and impaired writing (acalculia). MRI results showed leptomeningeal augmentation and foci of increased cortical and subcortical T2 signals. The following is the likely cause:
questions.solution:
• Gerstman syndrome is a neurological disorder caused by damage to the dominant hemisphere of the Parietal lobe which results in symptoms including difficulty with simple arithmetic, difficulty with writing, difficulty naming individual fingers, and difficulty telling the difference between the right and left side of the body.
 
  • It is commonly associated with damage to the inferior parietal lobule, specifically the angular gyrus of the dominant parietal lobe. 


Principal features of Gerstman syndrome:
 
  1. Acalculia
  2. Alexia
  3. Finger agnosia
  4. Right-left confusion



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3326.

questions.text: A glass factory worker presented with complaints of numbness in hands and feet, generalized weakness and constipation. Radiograph showed linear lines on metaphyses of knee and wrist joints. How will you diagnose this patient?
questions.solution:
The above clinical features are suggestive of exposure to lead. 

Main causes for the pathology of lead is that it interferes with the activity of an essential enzyme called Delta aminolevulinic acid dehydratase, which is important in the biosynthesis of heme, the cofactor found in hemoglobin.

  • Lead also inhibits the enzyme ferrochelatase, another enzyme involved in the formation of heme.
  • Ferrochelatase catalyzes the joining of protoporphyrin and Fe2+ plus to form heme.
  • Another effect of lead's interference with heme synthesis is the buildup of heme precursors, such as aminolevulinic acid, which may be directly or indirectly harmful to neurons and which are excreted in urine.

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3580.

Correct Option is 4: Subarachnoid hemorrhage

choices.text: Level of needle insertion should be L1-L2 vertebral junction
The bevel end of needle should face up
Needle should be inserted in a slightly cephalad direction
Legs should be straightened for CSF pressure measurement

questions.text: Which of these is not true about lumbar puncture?
questions.solution:
• LP in adults is done at the level of L3-L4 because spinal cord ends at a level above that.
  • This is followed so that the Spinal cord is not injured during Puncture with LP needle. Rest all other options are correct.
 
  • The midline approach relies on the ability of patients and assistants to minimize lumbar lordosis and allow access to the subarachnoid space between adjacent spinous processes, usually at the L2-L3, L3-L4, or the L4-L5 space.
  • The spinal cord ends at the level of L1-L2 and so needle insertion above this level should be avoided.


Reference: Miller's Anesthesia, 9th edition, Page no 1428,1429.

questions.text: Which of the following characteristics makes it easier to tell seizures as compared to syncope?
questions.solution:
The characteristic that makes it easier to distinguish seizures from syncope is Urinary incontinence (option 3).

Here's why:

  • Seizures often involve involuntary movements, loss of motor control, and autonomic disturbances like urinary incontinence. It's not uncommon for someone to lose bladder control during a seizure, particularly in generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

  • Syncope, on the other hand, typically involves a transient loss of consciousness due to a sudden drop in blood flow to the brain, but urinary incontinence is much less common in syncope.

Let's quickly review the other options:

  1. Loss of consciousness: Both seizures and syncope involve a loss of consciousness, so this is not a distinguishing factor.
  2. Injury due to fall: Both seizures and syncope can result in a fall and injury, though the mechanisms differ (seizures due to uncontrolled movement, syncope due to collapse from a sudden drop in blood pressure). This doesn't reliably distinguish between the two.
  3. Urinary incontinence: As explained above, this is more commonly seen in seizures than syncope, making it a helpful distinguishing feature.
  4. Physical weakness with clear sensorium: This is more suggestive of syncope, as people usually regain full awareness shortly after syncope. In seizures, the postictal state (after the seizure) often involves confusion or altered consciousness.

So, urinary incontinence is the key feature that points more toward seizures than syncope.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3315.

questions.text: Which of the following modes of treatment has demonstrated the best seizure-free duration in medically untreatable seizures?
questions.solution:
The most effective treatment for medically intractable seizures that shows best seizure-free period includes Resective epilepsy surgery. 
 
  • Advances in presurgical evaluation and microsurgical techniques have led to a steady increase in the success of epilepsy surgery. For example, ~70% of well-selected patients treated with temporal lobectomy will become seizure free, and another 15–25% will have at least a 90% reduction in seizure frequency.
  • Marked improvement is also usually seen in patients treated with hemispherectomy for catastrophic seizure disorders due to large hemispheric abnormalities.
  • Postoperatively, patients generally need to remain on antiseizure drug therapy, but the marked reduction of seizures following resective surgery can have a very beneficial effect on quality of life.

Additional treatments that may improve seizure control include corticosteroids, antiepileptic drugs, and gamma ray radiosurgery. However, these treatments may only reduce seizure frequency or severity, but may not achieve complete seizure freedom.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3321.

questions.text: Which of these is Bilateral Babinski sign a characteristic of?
questions.solution:
• The bilateral Babinski sign is an important sign of pontine haemorrhage due to damage to nerve tracts that run through the pons. This typically presents as an extensor response of the toes (upward) when the sole of the foot is firmly stroked.
  • It is essential for clinicians to be aware of this sign as it can indicate the severity of the pontine haemorrhage and may provide important information on the patient's neurological prognosis.
  • In cases of pontine hemorrhage, the presence of a bilateral Babinski sign should be an alarm for clinicians to consider an urgent intervention such as a surgical evacuation of the hematoma.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 165.
Rao, Gurukanth; Vaibhav, S.; Belle, Jayaprakash. A Case of Resolving Pontine Hemorrhage. APIK Journal of Internal Medicine 12(3):p 186-188, Jul–Sep 2024. | DOI: 10.4103/ajim.ajim_34_22. URL: https://journals.lww.com/joim/fulltext/2024/12030/a_case_of_resolving_pontine_hemorrhage.11.aspx

choices.text: As anti-ACHR is negative you will consider an alternative diagnosis

questions.text: A 50-year-old man complained of ptosis, chewing difficulties, and occasionally had trouble swallowing. No prior instances of vision loss exist. With a finger abduction test at a 60° angle, there is symmetric ptosis and a slight restriction of extraocular muscle movement causing diplopia. Only the orbicularis exhibits a decreasing response in a nerve conduction examination. An ERG pattern was myopathic. Radioimmunoassay for anti-AchR proved ineffective. The following is the most likely diagnosis:
questions.solution:
Generalized myasthenia gravis is the most likely diagnosis. This condition commonly causes ptosis and diplopia as initial complaints and reveals a characteristic pattern of muscle weakness.


Clinical features:
 
  • The distribution of muscle weakness often has a characteristic pattern. The cranial muscles, particularly the lids and extraocular muscles (EOMs), are typically involved early in the course of MG; diplopia and ptosis are common initial complaints.
  • Facial weakness produces a“snarling” expression when the patient attempts to smile.
  • Weakness in chewing is most noticeable after prolonged effort, as in chewing meat
  • Difficulty in swallowing may occur as a result of weakness of the palate, tongue, or pharynx, giving rise to nasal regurgitation or aspiration of liquids or food.

Autoantibodies Associated with MG:
  • Anti-AChR antibodies are detectable in the serum of ~85% of all myasthenic patients but in only ~50% of patients with weakness confined to the ocular muscles.
  • The presence of anti-AChR antibodies is virtually diagnostic of MG, but a negative test does not exclude the disease.
  • The measured level of anti-AChR antibody does not correspond well with the severity of MG in different patients.
  • Antibodies to MuSK are present in ~40% of AChR antibody–negative patients with generalized MG.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3510, 3511.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with NF2 instead of NF1?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Acoustic neuromas.

Acoustic neuromas (option 2) are associated with Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2) rather than Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1).

Features for Neurofibromatosis Type 1 (NF1) and Neurofibromatosis Type 2 (NF2):







Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 703, 707.

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with dementia, incontinence, and ataxia. It is most likely due to:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 4: Normal pressure hydrocephalus
