  • Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus(NPH) is a condition characterized by the accumulation of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the brain's ventricles, leading to enlarged ventricles and increased intracranial pressure.
 
  • The classic triad of symptoms in NPH includes gait disturbance (ataxia), cognitive decline (dementia), and urinary incontinence. "Wet, wacky, wobbly" is a phrase commonly used to describe the classic triad of symptoms
 
  • While Alzheimer's disease and Parkinson's disease are common causes of dementia, they do not typically present with the combination of incontinence and ataxia as seen in NPH.

Steel Richardson syndrome, also known as progressive supranuclear palsy, primarily presents with motor symptoms and is not associated with incontinence.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 175, 194.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with acute left upper limb weakness, mitral stenosis, and atrial fibrillation. The weakness subsided completely in two weeks. The following is the likely cause:
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario points towards the diagnosis of Acute ischemic stroke (AIS) due to cardioembolism from cardiac thrombus in a case of Atrial fibrillation.
 
  • Cardioembolism is responsible for ~20% of all ischemic strokes. Stroke caused by heart disease is primarily due to embolism of thrombotic material forming on the atrial or ventricular wall or the left heart valves. These thrombi then detach and embolize into the arterial circulation. The thrombus may fragment or lyse quickly, producing only a TIA. Alternatively, the arterial occlusion may last longer, producing stroke.
 
  • Atrial fibrillation is the most common cause of cardioembolic AIS.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3339, 3340

questions.text: A 25-year-old develops focal seizures and a sudden onset of fever. The frontal lobe and temporal lobe of the brain are enhanced and hyperintense in the MRI image. The following is the likely cause:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Herpes simplex encephalitis
 
  • Herpes simplex encephalitis (HSE) is a viral infection of the brain caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV).
  • It typically presents with focal neurological symptoms, such as seizures, altered mental status, and fever.
  • The involvement of the frontal and temporal lobes is characteristic of HSE and can be observed in MRI imaging as enhanced and hyperintense regions.
  • IOC- PCR of CSF for HSV 
 
  • Meningococcal meningitis (option 1) is a bacterial infection caused by Neisseria meningitidis and primarily affects the meninges. While it can cause neurological symptoms, the MRI findings described in the scenario are not typically associated with this condition.
  • Japanese encephalitis (option 3) is a viral infection transmitted by mosquitoes and primarily affects the brain. However, the MRI findings mentioned in the scenario are not consistent with Japanese encephalitis.
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV, option 4) is a common viral infection that can affect various organs, including the brain. However, the specific MRI findings described in the scenario are not commonly associated with CMV encephalitis.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1095, 1096.

questions.text: Damage to the brain caused by a head injury in a patient is made worse by
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Hyperglycemia 
 
  • Hyperglycemia, can exacerbate brain damage caused by a head injury.
  • Elevated blood glucose levels can lead to increased inflammation, oxidative stress, and cell death in the brain.
  • It can also impair the brain's ability to regulate cerebral blood flow and worsen cerebral edema (swelling).
  • Hyperglycemia is associated with poorer outcomes and increased mortality in patients with traumatic brain injury.
 
  • Hypothermia (Option 2) is actually used as a therapeutic intervention in some cases of severe head injury to reduce brain metabolism and protect against further damage.
  • Hypocapnia (Option 3), or low levels of carbon dioxide in the blood, can cause cerebral vasoconstriction and decrease cerebral blood flow, potentially leading to ischemia and further brain injury. However, it is not a major factor in worsening brain damage compared to hyperglycemia.
  • Serum osmolality (Option 4) refers to the concentration of solutes in the blood. While severe disturbances in serum osmolality can have adverse effects on brain function, it is not directly implicated in worsening brain damage caused by a head injury.

TBI- Exacerbating and relieving factors:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3456-3458.

questions.text: Which of the subsequent techniques of grading is used to assess the prognosis or outcome following a subarachnoid hemorrhage?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Hess and hunt scale  
 
  • The Hess and Hunt scale is a grading system used to assess the prognosis or outcome following a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).
  • It evaluates the severity of SAH based on the patient's clinical presentation and the amount of blood observed on imaging studies, such as computed tomography (CT) scans.
  • The scale ranges from grade 0 to grade 5, with higher grades indicating a worse prognosis.
  • This scale helps in predicting the risk of complications and guiding the management of SAH patients.


Here's a summary table of commonly used scales in emergency medicine scenarios:






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3354.

questions.text: The likelihood of developing epilepsy following febrile convulsions is significantly increased by all of the following, with the exception of:
questions.solution:
Early age of onset (age <1 year) is a risk factor for recurrence of febrile seizures, NOT Late age of onset.

The other risk factors for such recurrences are as follows:

Major:
  • Age <1 yr
  • Duration of fever <24 hours
  • Fever 38-39°C

Minor:
  • Family history of febrile seizures
  • Family history of epilepsy
  • Complex febrile seizure
  • Male gender
  • Lower serum sodium at the time of presentation



Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 3092, 3093.

questions.text: Several times per day, a youngster has brief moments of vacant staring. The youngster is unresponsive during the entire vacant episode, which starts out abruptly. The youngster is otherwise normal, and there is no history of aura or postictal disorientation to go along with it. The most likely diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Absence seizures 

Absence seizures, also known as petit mal seizures, are a type of generalized seizure characterized by brief episodes of vacant staring and unresponsiveness. These episodes can occur multiple times per day and typically last for a few seconds. The onset of absence seizures is abrupt, and the child may appear to be "daydreaming" during the episode.

Key features of absence seizures include:
 
  • Brief duration: Episodes typically last for a few seconds and resolve spontaneously.
  • Vacant staring: The child appears to be inattentive and unresponsive during the episode, often with a blank facial expression.
  • Abrupt onset and termination: The episodes start and end suddenly, without any warning signs or postictal confusion/disorientation.
  • No aura or postictal period: Unlike other seizure types, absence seizures are not typically preceded by an aura (warning sign) or followed by a postictal period of confusion or disorientation.

Other options: 
 
  • Grand mal seizures (Option 1) are generalized tonic-clonic seizures characterized by loss of consciousness, muscle rigidity, and convulsions.
  • Complex partial seizures (Option 3) involve impaired consciousness with repetitive movements and may have associated aura or postictal confusion.
  • Daydreaming (Option 4) is a normal state of mind characterized by being lost in thoughts but does not involve altered consciousness or staring episodes.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3306, 3307.

questions.text: A youngster was seen with 5,000 CPK value, positive Gower's sign, calf hypertrophy, and lower limb weakness. The following diagnosis is most likely:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Duchenne muscular dystrophy 
 
  • Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is an X-linked recessive disorder characterized by progressive muscle weakness and wasting.
  • It primarily affects boys and typically presents in early childhood.
  • The clinical features described in the question, including elevated CPK levels, positive Gower's sign, calf hypertrophy, and lower limb weakness, are classic findings seen in DMD.

Other options:
 
  • Spinal muscular atrophy (Option 2) is a different neuromuscular disorder characterized by progressive degeneration of the spinal motor neurons, resulting in muscle weakness.
  • Myotonia congenita (Option 3) is a genetic disorder that leads to muscle stiffness and delayed relaxation after contraction.
  • Myotonic dystrophy (Option 4) is a multisystem disorder characterized by myotonia, muscle wasting, and involvement of various organs.







Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3519-3521.

questions.text: Select the one that is not used in Juvenile Myoclonic epilepsy (JME).
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Carbamazepine

JUVENILE MYOCLONIC EPILEPSY (JME):





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3317.

questions.text: A young youngster with a history of seizures and mental impairment arrives at the clinic. On clinical inspection, many hypopigmented macules are seen. What plausible diagnosis is there?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Tuberous sclerosis 
 
  • Tuberous Sclerosis (Bourneville disease) is a genetic disorder characterized by the growth of benign tumors in various organs, including the brain, skin, kidneys, heart, and lungs.
 
  • It is commonly associated with seizures, intellectual disability, and developmental delays.
 
  • The hypopigmented macules, known as ash-leaf spots, are a characteristic feature of Tuberous Sclerosis and can be observed on the skin.Other clinical features may include facial angiofibromas, shagreen patches, and renal angiomyolipomas.

Other options: 
 
  • Neurofibromatosis (Option 2) is characterized by the development of neurofibromas and café-au-lait macules but is not typically associated with seizures and mental impairment.
  • Sturge-Weber Syndrome (Option 3) is characterized by facial port-wine stains and may cause neurological symptoms such as seizures, but it does not commonly present with hypopigmented macules.
  • Linear Epidermal Nevus Syndrome (Option 4) is characterized by linear epidermal nevi but is not typically associated with seizures and mental impairment.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 388.

questions.text: Select the artery thrombosis that can lead to a patient presenting with clinical features of vertigo, nystagmus.
questions.solution:
Obstruction of the superior cerebellar artery (SCA), located more rostrally, tends to produce more ataxia, dysarthria, and nystagmus, with less frequent vertigo, headache, and vomiting occurrences.
Obstruction of SCA causes Lateral superior pontine syndrome (a.k.a syndrome of superior cerebellar artery)
Clinical features of Syndrome of SCA:

On side of lesion
  • Ataxia of limbs and gait, falling to side of lesion: Middle and superior cerebellar peduncles, superior surface of cerebellum, dentate nucleus
  • Dizziness, nausea, vomiting; horizontal nystagmus: Vestibular nucleus
  • Paresis of conjugate gaze (ipsilateral): Pontine contralateral gaze
  • Skew deviation: Uncertain
  • Miosis, ptosis, decreased sweating over face (Horner’s syndrome): Descending sympathetic fibers
  • Tremor: Localization unclear—Dentate nucleus, superior cerebellar peduncle
On side opposite lesion
  • Impaired pain and thermal sense on face, limbs, and trunk: Spinothalamic tract
  • Impaired touch, vibration, and position sense, more in leg than arm (there is a tendency to incongruity of pain and touch deficits): Medial lemniscus (lateral portion)



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3332.

questions.text: Pick the cause when there is no h/o trauma involved in a 45 years old female with sudden onset headache and neck rigidity.
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: SAH , as in the CT scan hemorrhage is seen in the fissures that is the subarachnoid space. 
  • Subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) is a medical emergency that occurs due to bleeding into the subarachnoid space, characterized by a sudden and severe headache, sometimes described as "the worst headache of life."
  • Neck rigidity (stiff neck) is a common symptom of SAH, as the bleeding can irritate the meninges, the protective membranes around the brain and spinal cord.
  • SAH can occur spontaneously, and in many cases, there may be no history of trauma or injury involved.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3355.

questions.text: What is U/L proptosis with B/L sixth nerve palsy?
questions.solution:
Unilateral Proptosis with bilateral abducent Nerve Palsy is seen in cavernous sinus thrombosis.
 

  • It is a condition in which the abducens nerves on both sides of the head become paralyzed, resulting in one eye remaining turned outwards.
  • This is due to compression of the cavernous sinus, a blood-filled channel located in the skull, because of a blood clot.
  • Symptoms include facial pain, double vision and drooping of one of the eyelids.
  • Treatment typically involves anticoagulation therapy to dissolve the clot. In some cases, neurosurgical intervention or radiation therapy may also be helpful.


Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 439.

questions.text: After a 3-day CT revealed an SDH, the patient with h/o RTA presented to the OPD. Fundoscopy revealed B/L papilledema. What is the likelihood of this happening?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 1: Raised ICT
  • Papilledema is a swelling of the optic disc, caused by increased intracranial pressure (ICP), which is the pressure of the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) inside the skull.
  • In the case, the patient has a history of RTA, and a CT scan has revealed an SDH. 
  • SDH is a collection of blood between the dura mater, meninges, and the arachnoid mater. This collection of blood can increase ICP, which can lead to papilledema.

Other options : 
  • Meningitis, Optic neuritis, and Glaucoma are less likely causes, as they are not directly related to the history of RTA and SDH.



Reference: Parsons' Diseases of the Eye, 23rd edition, Page no 323-325.

questions.text: A 74-year-old man with ataxia and urine incontinence was brought to the OPD by his daughter.  He struggles with simple maths calculations and suffers from memory loss. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Normal Pressure Hydrocephalus (NPH) is a form of communicating hydrocephalus, characterized by an enlarged ventricular system and normal opening pressures on lumbar puncture.
  • It is associated with a classic set of symptoms including a triad of dementia, gait disturbance and urinary incontinence.
  • Idiopathic NPH may be caused by decompensated congenital hydrocephalus or impaired absorption of cerebrospinal fluid.
  • Secondary NPH is caused by intraventricular or subarachnoid hemorrhage, acute or chronic meningitis, Paget disease at the skull base or other rare conditions.
  • The most prominent symptom is gait difficulty, which is distinguished from Parkinsonian gait by a wide base, small steps and postural instability.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 175, 194.

questions.text: Seizures are being experienced by a patient. Multiple parenchymal cysts are visible on his CT head.  Which of the following statements about management are correct in this case?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario is neurocysticercosis caused by larvae of T. Solium. 
 
  • The drug of choice for treatment is albendazole. However, steroids are started before initiating albendazole to reduce the incidence of inflammatory reactions to dead and dying parasitic products. 
 
  • For the treatment of patients with brain parenchymal cysticerci, most authorities favor antiparasitic drugs, including Albendazole (15 mg/kg per day for 8–28 days) and/or praziquantel (50–100 mg/kg daily in three divided doses for 15–30 days). A combination of albendazole and praziquantel (50 mg/kg per day) is more effective in patients with more than two cystic lesions.
 
  • For patients with subarachnoid cysts or giant cysticerci, antiinflammatory medications such as glucocorticoids are needed to reduce arachnoiditis and accompanying vasculitis.
 
  • In patients with diffuse cerebral edema and elevated intracranial pressure due to multiple inflamed lesions, glucocorticoids are the mainstay of therapy, and antiparasitic drugs should be avoided



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1792, 1793.

questions.text: Except for_____, all of the following are subcortical dementia types.
questions.solution:
Pick’s disease is fronto temporal dementia which is a type of cortical dementia.

Types of dementia :
  1. Cortical dementia
    1. Alzhiemer’s disease
    2. Motor neuron disease
    3. Pick’s disease
    4. Progressive aphasia
 
  1. Subcortical
    1. Huntington disease
    2. Parkinson’s disease
    3. AIDS dementia
    4. Progressive supranuclear palsy
    5. Wilson disease
 
  1. Mixed
    1. Lewy body dementia
    2. Vascular dementia
    3. Binswanger disease.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 193, 3378, 3379.

choices.text: Acuity of onset and level of consciousness

questions.text: Which of the following distinguishes Alzheimer's disease-related delirium from dementia
questions.solution:
• Delirium refers to presence of altered level of consciousness with cognitive impairment with sudden and acute onset.
  • Dementia stands for loss of cognitive functions in clear consciousness which is a chronic condition.
 
  • Delirium and dementia can be differentiated by the memory disturbance feature; memory disturbance is seen in dementia and not seen in delirium.


Reference: Kaplan and Sadock's Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th edition, Page no 697, 701, 704.

choices.text: Dorsal Column and Lateral tracts are involved

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about SACD?
questions.solution:
Subacute combined degeneration of spinal cord.
 
  • Often referred to as Putnam-Dana syndrome or Lichtheim's disease
  • Dorsal columns and lateral corticospinal tracts degeneration
  • Due to
    • a lack of vitamin B12 and
    • a lack of vitamin E
    • a lack of copper
Clinical features include:

1. Paresthesias, sensory loss
2. Ataxia
3. Loss of ankle jerk
4. Memory loss
5. Reduced vision, central scotoma
6. Sphincter disturbance



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3454.

choices.text: Complete steroids course and then give anti parasite agents

questions.text: A 35-year-old man has been experiencing headaches for the past two months and had a seizure a day ago. AED was started, and the patient is stable. A head MRI reveals several calcified lesions in the parietal lobe as well as cystic lesions with scolex and perilesional edoema. Which statement concerning how this case should be handled is true
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the given clinical scenario is neurocysticercosis caused by larvae of T. Solium. 
 
  • The drug of choice for treatment is albendazole. However, steroids are started before initiating albendazole to reduce the incidence of inflammatory reactions to dead and dying parasitic products. 
 
  • For the treatment of patients with brain parenchymal cysticerci, most authorities favor antiparasitic drugs, including Albendazole (15 mg/kg per day for 8–28 days) and/or praziquantel (50–100 mg/kg daily in three divided doses for 15–30 days). A combination of albendazole and praziquantel (50 mg/kg per day) is more effective in patients with more than two cystic lesions.
 
  • For patients with subarachnoid cysts or giant cysticerci, antiinflammatory medications such as glucocorticoids are needed to reduce arachnoiditis and accompanying vasculitis.
 
  • In patients with diffuse cerebral edema and elevated intracranial pressure due to multiple inflamed lesions, glucocorticoids are the mainstay of therapy, and antiparasitic drugs should be avoided



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1792, 1793.

questions.text:
When a 25-year-old woman's hand is submerged in cold water, she experiences redness followed by digit cyanosis. Which of the following may be the cause of this symptom?
A. Sumatriptan
B. Migraine
C. Cryoglobulinemia
D. Hyperthyroidism
questions.solution:
The patient is experiencing Raynaud's syndrome.

People who suffer from migraines are more likely to develop Raynaud's phenomenon.

Triptans and beta blockers should not be taken because they cause more vasoconstriction.

Along with Raynaud's syndrome, cryoglobulinemia (cold-sensitive antibodies) is related to the condition.

The conditions responsible for this manifestation are:
  • Sumatriptan
  • Migraine
  • Cryoglobulin


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2778.
Bailey & Love's Short Practice of Surgery, 28th edition, Page no 1024.

questions.text: What medication can be used for a cluster headache attack that is acute?
questions.solution:
Cluster headache is a neurologic disorder characterised by recurrent severe headaches on one side of the head, typically around the eye.

It often lasts for 15 minutes to 3 hours, attacks occur in clusters which typically lasts for weeks to months and occasionally more than a year.

Treatment:

  • Cluster headache attacks peak rapidly, and thus a treatment with rapid onset is required. Many patients with acute cluster headache respond very well to oxygen inhalation.
 
  • This should be given as 100% oxygen at 10–12 L/min for 15–20 min.
 
  • It appears that high flow and high oxygen content are important. Sumatriptan 6 mg SC is rapid in onset and will usually shorten an attack to 10–15 min; there is no evidence of tachyphylaxis.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3366.

questions.text:
Multiple TIA events were experienced by an elderly patient with severe MS with atrial fibrillation. Which of the following assertions about stroke prevention in this patient is correct?
(i) Only aspirin is given in prevention of stroke
(ii) Warfarin is used in prevention of stroke
(iii) Dabigatran is not indicated
(iv) Mitral valvotomy is indicated in this case
questions.solution:
• Statements (ii) and (iii) are correct regarding stroke prevention in this patient.
  • Statement (i): Clopidogrel combined with aspirin is more effective than aspirin alone for stroke prevention. Warfarin is superior to antiplatelet therapy for stroke prevention.
 
  • Statement (ii): Warfarin is the recommended anticoagulant for patients with mitral stenosis (MS) and mechanical prosthetic valves.
 
  • Statement (iii): Direct oral anticoagulants (DOACs) such as dabigatran, rivaroxaban, apixaban, and edoxaban are not used for treating moderate to severe MS or in patients with prosthetic heart valves due to limited clinical evidence. DOACs have a lower risk of intracranial hemorrhage than warfarin and are as effective as warfarin for stroke prevention in valvular heart disease (except for moderate to severe mitral stenosis or mechanical heart valves), ischemic stroke or TIA, and atrial fibrillation (AF).
 
  • Statement (iv): Mitral valvotomy is not recommended for stroke prevention in this patient. It is indicated for symptomatic patients (New York Heart Association Functional Class II-IV) with isolated severe mitral stenosis, where the effective orifice area is less than 1.5 cm² in normal-sized adults. It is contraindicated in the presence of left atrial thrombus.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 935, 1906, 1992, 3344.

questions.text: Which of the following medications is the only one that effectively stops the advancement of a patient's impairment in primary progressive multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Multiple sclerosis is an autoimmune demyelinating disorder. Main target in this disease is Myelin Basic Protein (MBP).

OCRELIZUMAB : Used in primary progressive multiple sclerosis (PPMS) management (acts by attacking mature B calls).

  • Ocrelizumab was shown in a phase 3 trial to reduce progression of clinical disability in PPMS by 24%, and also to improve other clinical and MRI markers of inflammatory and degenerative disease activity.
 
  • Ocrelizumab represents the first agent to convincingly modify the course of PPMS.
  • The dosing of ocrelizumab for PPMS is identical as for RMS.
 
  • Siponimod is a selective S1P1 S1P5 receptor modulator that was shown in a single phase 3 study to be superior to placebo in reducing the risk of progression in SPMS patients.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3473.

questions.text: Identify the one which is not useful in the management of GBS:
questions.solution:
Steroids are not useful in the management of GBS.
 
  • Evidences suggest that corticosteroids given alone do not significantly hasten recovery from GBS or affect the longterm outcome.
 
  • Either high-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis (PLEX) can be initiated, as they are equally effective for typical GBS.
 
  • Meta-analysis of randomized clinical trials indicates that treatment reduces the need for mechanical ventilation by nearly half (from 27 to 14% with PLEX) and increases the likelihood of full recovery at 1 year (from 55 to 68%).


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3504.

questions.text: A patient has been taking analgesics on a regular basis for the past two years despite her headache complaints.There is no prior history of photophobia, nausea, or vomiting. However, for the last six months, NSAIDs have not been able to stop the headache from getting worse. The headaches have improved when the medications were stopped. A probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Medication overuse headache.
 
  • Medication overuse headache occurs when a person takes too much medication for headaches. 
  • This can happen when a person takes over-the-counter pain relievers too often, or when a person takes prescription pain relievers more often than prescribed.
 
  • Symptoms: A daily headache that is worse in the morning, and a headache that does not respond to medication. 
  • The headache may also be accompanied by other symptoms, such as nausea, vomiting, and sensitivity to light and noise.
  • In the case of the patient in the question, the patient has been taking analgesics on a regular basis for the past two years. The headaches have improved when the medications were stopped, which suggests that the headaches are caused by medication overuse.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3364.

questions.text: Patient had seizures, had a 24-hour urine output of 650 ml, had a urine osmolality of 1000 mOsm/kg, and had a serum osmolality of 270 mOsm/kg. What electrolyte anomaly can be anticipated after further examination?
questions.solution:
The patient is suffering from hyponatremia.
  • It is a disorder that develops when the blood's sodium content is unacceptably low.
  • The body retains too much water when this condition is present. Because of this, the blood's salt levels are diluted and fall. Nausea, headaches, disorientation, and weariness are symptoms.
  • There may be a need for restricted fluid consumption, medication, and hospitalisation.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 341-344.

questions.text:
A 54-year-old male patient from Madhya Pradesh is experiencing leg stiffness and signs of increasing motor paresis.
What medical history will you review in order to make a diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct option: 1. Diet history
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of Neurolathyrism due to chronic intake of lathyrus sativus (Khesari dal).
 
  • Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. In the humans it is referred to as neurolathyrism because it affects the nervous system
  • Neurolathyrism is a crippling disease of the nervous system characterized by gradually developing spastic paralysis of lower limbs, occurring mostly in adults consuming the pulse, Lathyrus sativus in large quantities. Neurolathyrism is prevalent in parts of Madhya Pradesh, Uttar Pradesh, Bihar and Orissa
 
  • Lathyrus sativus is commonly known as "Khesari dhal". It is known by local names such as Teora dhal, Lak dhal
 
  • Studies have shown that diets containing over 30% of this dhal if taken over a period of 2—6 months will result in neurolathyrism.

Therefore, it is important to elicit dietary history in suspected case of Neurolathyrism.



Reference: Park's Textbook of Preventive and Social Medicine, 27th edition, Page no 759.

questions.text: Find the incorrect statement about ABCD2 score:
questions.solution:
Duration more than 5 min is NOT a component of ABCD2 score 


ABCD2 score for Transient Ischemic Attack (TIA):
 
ABCD2 score Points
Age > 60 years 1
BP = 140/90 mmHg at initial evaluation 1
Clinical features of the TIA
  Speech disturbance without weakness, or
  Unilateral weakness
1
2
Duration of symptoms
  10-59 min, or
  >60 min
1
2
Diabetes mellitus in patient's history 1



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3334.

questions.text: The nature of GCS data is:
questions.solution:
GCS is an example of ordinal data.
It is a qualitative data which can be further graded into mild, moderate and severe based on the severity.






Reference: High-Yield Biostatistics, Epidemiology and Public Health, 4th edition, Page no 2, 3.

questions.text: For seven days, a patient complained of having a headache and fever. When performing a lumbar puncture, it was observed that the opening CSF pressure rose when the jugular vein was compressed and returned to normal when the pressure was released. What does this mean, exactly?
questions.solution:
• Queckenstedt's test can be used to assess whether or not there is a block to the flow of cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) in the spinal canal.
  • During a lumbar puncture, the opening CSF pressure should be increased when the jugular veins are compressed, and normal when the pressure is relieved.
  • If the opening CSF pressure is increased on jugular vein compression and become normal on relieving the pressure on jugular vein, it suggests that there is patent subarachnoid space (no spinal block).



Reference: Pearce, J M S. “Queckenstedt's manoeuvre.” Journal of neurology, neurosurgery, and psychiatry vol. 77,6 (2006): 728. doi:10.1136/jnnp.2005.083618. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2077443/

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman arrived complaining of back pain, disorientation, and constipation.  Her hemoglobin level is 7.3 g/dL, and her platelet count and TLC are both normal. Serum albumin is 2.4 g/dL, total protein is 9.1 g/dL, serum creatinine is 2.6 mg/dL, serum calcium is 13 mg/dL. The vertebrae have lytic lesions. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Multiple Myeloma is the most likely diagnosis. 





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 869-871.

questions.text: Neuromyelitis spectrum disorder can be diagnosed in all of the following EXCEPT?
questions.solution:
• Neuromyelitis optica (NMO; Devic’s disease) is an aggressive inflammatory disorder characterized by recurrent attacks of optic neuritis (ON) and myelitis.
  • The more inclusive term NMO spectrum disorder (NMOSD) was proposed to include individuals with partial forms, and also those with involvement of additional regions in the central nervous system.

Core clinical characteristics of Diagnostic criteria for NMOSD:




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3477.

questions.text:
Ergotamine is taken by an ART-treated HIV patient for migraine. After a few hours, her limbs feel cold, and her lower limbs' distal pulses are absent.
What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Ergotism is the result of chronic ergot poisoning, which is traditionally brought on by consuming the alkaloids made by the fungus Claviceps purpurea.
  • The fungus's ergotamine-ergocristine alkaloids cause vasoconstriction, which leads to dry gangrene.
  • It affects the distal structures that have less blood flow, like the fingers and toes.
  • Desquamation or peeling, weak peripheral pulses, loss of peripheral feeling, edema, and eventually the death and loss of affected tissues are some of the symptoms.
  • Vasodilators are used to treat vasoconstriction.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3584, 3590.

questions.text: The following are excluded from the diagnosis of neuromyelitis spectrum disorders:
questions.solution:
Focal epilepsy is NOT included in diagnostic criteria for NMOSD.

NEUROMYELITIS OPTICA SPECTRUM DISORDERS (NMOSD):
Diagnosis according to AQP4-IgG-seropositive status
• \(\geq\)1 core clinical characteristic
• Positive test for AQP4-IgG
• Exclusion of alternative diagnoses
 
Six core NMOSD clinical characteristics
• Optic neuritis • Acute myelitis
• Area postrema syndrome • Acute brainstem syndrome
• Symptomatic narcolepsy or acute diencephalic clinical syndrome
• Symptomatic cerebral syndrome with NMOSD-typical brain lesions
 
Diagnosis according to AQP4-IgG-seronegative status
• \(\geq\)2 different core clinical characteristics as a result of \(\geq\)1 clinical
   attack and meeting all following requirements:
    • \(\geq\)1 core clinical characteristic must be ON, acute myelitis with
       LETM or area postrema syndrome
    • Dissemination in space (\(\geq\)2 different core clinical characteristics)
    • Fulfilment of additional MRI requirements
• Negative test for AQP4-IgG
• Exclusion of alternative diagnoses

Additional MRI requirements for NMOSD without AQP4-IgG and NMOSD with unknown AQP4-IgG status
 
  1. Acute optic neuritis: requires brain MRI showing (a) normal findings or only nonspecific white matter lesions, OR (b) optic nerve MRI with T2-hyperintense lesion or T1-weighted gadolinium-enhancing lesions extending over \(\geq\)1/2 optic nerve length or involving optic chiasm
  2. Acute myelitis: requires associated intramedullary MRI lesion extending over \(\geq\)3 contiguous segments (LETM) OR \(\geq\)3 contiguous segments of focal spinal cord atrophy in patients with history compatible with acute myelitis
  3. Area postrema syndrome: requires associated dorsal medulla/area postrema lesions
  4. Acute brainstem syndrome: requires associated periependymal brainstem lesions


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3477.

choices.text: Pain in the legs before going to sleep

questions.text: A 30-year-old man's excessive sleep at work is ascribed to night time sleep disruption. Additionally, he recently lost his balance when out with his friends. What more characteristics can be identified that are connected to his condition?
questions.solution:
• A history of falls strongly suggests atonia or paralysis and may be related to narcolepsy.
  • Patient with obstructive sleep apnea typically goes off to sleep during the day without losing postural tone.
  • Both the inability to maintain wakefulness freely and the disorders in management of REM sleep are associated with narcolepsy.
  • Narcolepsy is characterised by paralysis during the sleep-wake transition along with hallucinations.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 208, 209.

questions.text: Limb girdle muscle dystrophies do not include which of the following groups of disorders?
questions.solution:
Calpainopathies, Sarcoglycanopathies, and dysferlinopathies are a few instances of Limb Girdle Dystrophies caused by malfunctioning gene/locus.
 
  • The Limb girdle muscular dystrophies (LGMD) typically manifest with progressive weakness of pelvic and shoulder girdle musculature.
  • Respiratory insufficiency from weakness of diaphragm and cardiomyopathy may occur.
  • However unlike Duchenne dystrophies (Dystrophin) intellectual/unction remains intact.
  • Muscular dystrophies of the Duchenne and Becker types are related with dystrophin gene, and are not limb girdle dystrophies.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3521, 3524.

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
• Aphasia, Apraxia, Acalculia and Agnosia may all be seen in Alzheimer's Dementia.
  • Agnosia in Alzheimer's disease usually presents late in the disease and is not included in the ICD-10 Diagnostic criteria for dementia in
  • Alzheimer's disease with early onset and hence may be selected as the single as the single best answer by exclusion.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3370.

choices.text: Immediately taper off valproate and start lamotrigine
Continue valproate and serial drug monitoring in blood

questions.text: There is a history of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy in a 29-year-old primigravida who is four months pregnant. She has been taking sodium valproate on a consistent basis, but she has just come in to ask for advice on changing her antiepileptic medication. Which advice do you have for her?
questions.solution:
• Continue valproate with serial drug monitoring in the blood of the 4-month old patient having history of juvenile myoclonic epilepsy.
  • Most women with epilepsy who become pregnant will have an uncomplicated gestation and deliver a normal baby.
  • Changes in seizure frequency are attributed to endocrine effects on the CNS, variations in antiepileptic drug pharmacokinetics (such as acceleration of hepatic drug metabolism or effects on plasma protein binding), and changes in medication compliance.
  • Because the potential harm of uncontrolled convulsive seizures on the mother and fetus is considered greater than the teratogenic effects of antiseizure drugs, it is currently recommended that pregnant women be maintained on effective drug therapy.
  • Patients should also take folate (1–4 mg/d), because the antifolate effects of anticonvulsants are thought to play a role in the development of neural tube defects.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3320, 3323.

questions.text: Which drug from the list below is used to treat multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
• Interferon beta is used in multiple sclerosis. Interferon-beta should be considered in patients with Relapsing/Remitting MS (RRMS) and Secondary Progressive MS (SPMS) with superimposed relapses.
  • Interferon-beta reduces the attack rate in MS patients and also improves disease severity measures and disease burden.

 
  • Efficacy in MS probably results from immunomodulatory properties including: (1) downregulating expression of MHC molecules on antigen-presenting cells, (2) reducing proinflammatory and increasing regulatory cytokine levels, (3) inhibiting T-cell proliferation, and (4) limiting the trafficking of inflammatory cells in the CNS.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3472.

questions.text: Which of the following is not approved for the treatment of Relapsing Remitting (RRMS) type of multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
• Mycophenolate mofetil is lymphocyte specific oral immunosuppressant that is presently being studied for its role in multiple sclerosis.
  • Presently mycophenolate is not U.S. FDA approved for use in multiple sclerosis.
  • Hence this drug cannot be recommended for the treatment of multiple sclerosis at present.
 
  • Glatiramer acetate reduces the attack rate (whether measured clinically or by MRI) in RRMS.
  • IFN-β should be considered in patients with either relapsing forms of MS (either RRMS or SPMS with superimposed relapses).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3471, 3472.

questions.text: The only drug reported to be effective in slowing the progression of multiple sclerosis on the Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) is which one of the following?
questions.solution:
• Natalizumab is the only drug found to be beneficial in halting the progression on Expanded Disability Status Scale (EDSS) in multiple sclerosis.
 
  • Natalizumab, a recombinant, humanized antibody, binds to α4β1-integrin and blocks its interaction with VCAM-1. As a result, leukocyte migration into brain tissue is inhibited, reducing inflammation and preventing the formation of lesions.
 
  • Natalizumab is highly effective in reducing the attack rate and significantly improves all measures of disease severity in MS (both clinical and MRI).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3470, 3471.

questions.text: Which of the following clinical signs of demyelinating myelopathy is most unlikely to portend an eventual development into multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
• Oligoclonal bands are variable; but when bands are present, a diagnosis of MS is more likely, thus absence of oligoclonal bands suggests a less likely progression to MS.
  • Progression to MS is more likely with presence of bilateral optic neuritis, poor prognosis and complete cord transection.

Insidious neurologic progression suggestive of MS (PPMS): [Criteria]
1 year of disease progression (retrospectively or prospectively determined)
PLUS
2 out of the 3 following criteria:

• Evidence for dissemination in space in the brain based on ≥1 T2+ lesions in the MS-characteristic periventricular, juxtacortical, or infratentorial regions
• Evidence for dissemination in space in the spinal cord based on ≥2 T2+ lesions in the cord
• Positive CSF (isoelectric focusing evidence of oligoclonal bands and/or elevated IgG index)



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3465, 3466.

questions.text: Of the following illnesses, which one only affects neurons?
questions.solution:
• Spinocerebellar ataxia exclusively affects neurons.
  • Spinocerebellar ataxia (SCA) is a group of inherited brain disorders. It affects cerebellum, a part of the brain vital to coordination of physical movement, and sometimes spinal cord.
  • This inherited condition worsens over time and causes specific problems with coordination, usually affecting eyes.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3423, 3424.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Brown Sequard syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Contralateral dorsal column involvement.

Brown-Séquard syndrome is a spinal cord injury that affects one side of the spinal cord i.e Hemisection of spinal cord, leading to specific features:



Dorsal column involvement is usually on the same side as the lesion, not contralateral. Therefore, that feature is not seen here.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3446, 3447.

questions.text: A 25-year-old lady presented with fever of one-month duration, ataxia and headache. Dilated ventricles with basal exudates were found during brain imaging. Which among the following is the most likely CSF finding?
questions.solution:
• Presence of significant basal exudates, together with dilated ventricles (hydrocephalus) in a young female with prolonged history of fever and headache suggests a diagnosis of tubercular meningitis.
  • Tubercular meningitis is characterized by lymphocytic pleocytosis (Pleocytosis is the presence of both neutrophils and lymphocytes in CSF), low glucose and high proteins within the CSF.
  • CSF pressure is raised in tubercular meningitis.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1109.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about myelopathy is incorrect?
questions.solution:
Jaw jerk is exaggerated in supranuclear lesions that are above the mid pons. It is helpful in localizing the lesion to the brainstem.

Causes of the exaggerated jaw jerk-

•Neurodegenerative diseases
•Pseudobulbar palsy
•Motor neuron disease
•Multiple sclerosis



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3447, 3450.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with gradually worsening lower-limb weakness, spasticity, and recent onset micturition hesitancy. On neurological examination, there is evidence of dorsal myelopathy. An MRI scan of the spine reveals a middorsal intradural contrast-enhancing mass lesion. What ailment does she most likely have?
questions.solution:
Diagnosis in a middle aged female with slowly progressive weakness of lower limbs, spasticity and recent onset hesitancy of micturition with evidence of dorsal myelopathy and mid-dorsal intradural contrast enhancing mass lesion on MRI is meningioma.
  • They are derived from meningomesothelial cells of arachnoid.
  • It mostly occur along the superior sagittal sinus.
  • Most are slow growing and encapsulated.
  • Meningiomas are often located posterior to the thoracic cord or near the foramen magnum, although they can arise from the meninges anywhere along the spinal canal.

MRI of spinal Meningioma



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3448.
Grainger & Allison's Diagnostic Radiology, 7th edition, Page no 1430, 1431.

questions.text: What is a blink reflex used for?
questions.solution:
Blink reflex is used for mid-pontine lesions.
 
  • Corneal blink reflex has its centre @ level of Mid-Pons.
  • So any lesion involving Mid-pons will have abnormal/absent Blink reflex.

A neurophysiological test known as the BRT is used to assess the brainstem reflex circuits.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 186.

questions.text: Except for_____, all of the following are observed in cervical syringomyelia:
questions.solution:
2. hypertrophy of abductor pollicis brevis

In case of cervical syringomyelia muscle wasting is seen in:
  • Lower back
  • Shoulders
  • Arms and hands
And not the hypertrophy of abductor pollicis brevis
 
  • The presentation is a central cord syndrome consisting of a regional dissociated sensory loss (loss of pain and temperature sensation with sparing of touch and vibration) and areflexic weakness in the upper limbs.
  • The sensory deficit has a distribution that is “suspended” over the nape of the neck, shoulders, and upper arms (cape distribution) or in the hands.
  • Most cases begin asymmetrically with unilateral sensory loss in the hands that leads to injuries and burns that are not appreciated by the patient.
 
  • As the cavity enlarges and compresses the long tracts, spasticity and weakness of the legs, bladder and bowel dysfunction, and Horner’s syndrome appear



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3453.

questions.text: A 70-year-old retired military person with good previous medical record complains of bi-temporal headache forlast 3 weeks which is decreased in lying down position. He states that he gets relief by giving pressure over bilateral temples. The patient also complains of loss of appetite with feeling feverish. Diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
Diagnosis is chronic tension headache.
 
  • The term tension-type headache (TTH) is frequently used to refer to a persistent head-pain syndrome characterised by tight, band-like discomfort on both sides of the head.
 
  • The pain typically builds slowly, fluctuates in severity, and may persist more or less continuously for many days. The headache may be episodic or chronic (present >15 days per month). 
 
  • The pain of TTH can generally be managed with simple analgesics such as acetaminophen, aspirin, or NSAIDs. Behavioral approaches including relaxation can also be effective.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3365.

questions.text: What does a thromboembolic event involving gait apraxia show?
questions.solution:
Gait apraxia is seen in thromboembolic episode involving ACA.

Anterior cerebral artery mainly supplies frontal lobe and it's occlusion leads to gait apraxia.

Signs and symptoms: Structures involved [ACA lesion]:
 
  • Paralysis of opposite foot and leg: Motor leg area
  • A lesser degree of paresis of opposite arm: Arm area of cortex or fibers descending to corona radiata
  • Cortical sensory loss over toes, foot, and leg: Sensory area for foot and leg
  • Urinary incontinence: Sensorimotor area in paracentral lobule
  • Contralateral grasp reflex, sucking reflex, gegenhalten (paratonic rigidity): Medial surface of the posterior frontal lobe; likely supplemental motor area
  • Abulia (akinetic mutism), slowness, delay, intermittent interruption, lack of spontaneity, whispering, reflex distraction to sights and sounds: Uncertain localization- probably cingulate gyrus and medial inferior portion of frontal, parietal, and temporal lobes
  • Impairment of gait and stance (gait apraxia): Frontal cortex near leg motor area
  • Dyspraxia of left limbs, tactile aphasia in left limbs: Corpus callosum



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3327.

questions.text: A neurosurgeon dropped his kid to the school then there he saw a child with uncontrollable laughing and precocious puberty. When he again went to the school in  parents teachers meeting, he talked to the father of that boy and advised him to get an MRI done and the diagnosis was confirmed. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Most probable diagnosis is Hypothalamic hamartoma.

Clinical features of children with hypothalamic hamartoma:
  • Central precocious puberty starting before the age of 3 years
  • Seizures, especially laughing spells (gelastic seizures)
 
  • Gelastic seizures are epileptic events characterized by bouts of laughter. Laughter-like vocalization is usually combined with facial contraction in the form of a smile.
 
  • Autonomic features such as flushing, tachycardia, and altered respiration are widely recognized. Conscious state may not be impaired, although this is often difficult to asses particularly in young children.
 
  • Gelastic seizures have been associated classically to hypothalamic hamartomas, although different extrahypothalamic localizations have been described.
 
  • Hypothalamic hamartomas are rare congenital lesions presenting with the classic triad of gelastic epilepsy, precocious puberty and developmental delay.



Reference: Téllez-Zenteno, José F et al. “Gelastic seizures associated with hypothalamic hamartomas. An update in the clinical presentation, diagnosis and treatment.” Neuropsychiatric disease and treatment vol. 4,6 (2008): 1021-31. doi:10.2147/ndt.s2173. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC2646637/

questions.text: A child with seizures is presented to the casualty department. On examination, an oval hypo-pigmented macule was noted on the trunk, along with a sub-normal IQ.  What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Probable diagnosis of child is tuberous sclerosis

Some major clinical features of tuberous sclerosis are:
  • seizure
  • mental retardation
  • adenoma sebaceum (facial angiofibromas) or forehead plaque 
  • non-traumatic ungual or peri-ungual ulcers
  • hypomelanotic macules (Ash leaf macules)
  • shagreen patch
  • multiple retinal nodular hamartomas
  • renal angiomyolipomas
  • cardiac rhabdomyomas etc.

These patients have an increased incidence of subependymal nodules, cortical tubers, and subependymal giant cell astrocytomas (SEGAs).




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 388, 708.

questions.text: A 7 year old girl with falling grades and complaints by a teacher that she is inattentive in class to her parents and has bad school performance. On hyperventilation, her symptoms increased and showed the following EEG findings. Diagnosis is (graph is given):
questions.solution:
Diagnosis is Typical absence seizures.
 
  • The electrophysiologic hallmark of typical absence seizures is a burst of generalized, symmetric, 3-Hz, spike-and-slow-wave discharges that begins and ends suddenly, superimposed on a normal EEG background.
 
  • Periods of spike-and-slow-wave discharges lasting more than a few seconds usually correlate with clinical signs

Some features of absence seizures are:
 
  • do not have an aura
  • starts at 5-8 years of age
  • usually last for few seconds
  • hyperventilation for 3-5 mins can precipitate the seizure
  • accompanied by flutter or upward rolling of eye



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3306, 3315.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true regarding frontotemporal dementia?
questions.solution:
All are true regarding fronto-temporal dementia except: 2. insight present

FTD often begins in the 5th to 7th decades

Features of Fronto-temporal dementia(FTD) are:
 
  • Insight is absent
  • Poor judgement
  • Apathy
  • lack of inhibition
  • weight gain, food obsessions
  • compulsions
  • emotional distance or loss of empathy



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 192, 3378.

questions.text: A stroke with abrupt onset has struck a 65-year-old hypertensive male patient. He has been identified as a patient with a stroke in the superior division of middle cerebral artery distribution following tests. Which of the following clinical characteristics is not possible for this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 3: Wernicke's aphasia.
 
  • Wernicke's aphasia is not possible for this patient with infarct of superior division of middle cerebral artery distribution. 
  • Wernicke's aphasia is typically associated with a lesion in the posterior part of the left temporal lobe, specifically in Wernicke's area, which is responsible for language comprehension. It is supplied by inferior division of MCA.

Other options:
 
  • Option 1: A stroke affecting the middle cerebral artery can lead to visual deficits, including homonymous hemianopia.
  • Option 2: A stroke in the middle cerebral artery distribution can cause weakness or paralysis on the opposite side of the body (contralateral hemiplegia) due to its involvement with the motor cortex.
  • Option 4: Gerstman syndrome: This syndrome is characterized by a combination of four symptoms: agraphia (difficulty writing), acalculia (difficulty with mathematical calculations), finger agnosia (inability to identify fingers), and left-right disorientation. It is typically associated with lesions in the dominant parietal lobe

Distribution of MCA:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3326.

questions.text: What is the most common site of idiopathic Basal ganglia calcification?
questions.solution:
Correct option is 2: Globus Pallidus.

Idiopathic Basal Ganglia Calcification (Fahr's disease) : Rare neurological disorder characterized by abnormal calcium deposition in the brain, particularly in the basal ganglia.
 
  • Calcification is most commonly reported in the globus pallidus.
  • Additional reported sites of calcification include putamen, caudate nucleus, internal capsule, dentate nucleus, thalamus, cerebellum, and cerebral white matter



Reference: Mufaddel, Amir A, and Ghanem A Al-Hassani. “Familial idiopathic basal ganglia calcification (Fahr`s disease).” Neurosciences (Riyadh, Saudi Arabia) vol. 19,3 (2014): 171-7. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4727649/

choices.text: 6 months of steroids +12-24 months maintenance doses

questions.text: The preferred course of treatment for acute sarcoidosis with multiple organ involvement is:
questions.solution:
Correct answer 1
  • The preferred course of treatment of Sarcoidosis is 3-6 months of Steroids tapered gradually followed by a maintenance dose for 12-24 months

Management of Acute Sarcoidosis:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2835, 2836.
Melani, Andrea S et al. “A Comprehensive Review of Sarcoidosis Treatment for Pulmonologists.” Pulmonary therapy vol. 7,2 (2021): 325-344. doi:10.1007/s41030-021-00160-x. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC8589889/

choices.text: Extensors more than flexors in Lower limb
Flexors more than extensors in Upper Limb
Antigravity muscles are affected in upper limb
Antigravity muscles are spared in upper limb

questions.text: As a result of the distribution of weakness in pyramidal tract lesions:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Antigravity muscles are affected in upper limb
 
  • Pyramidal tract lesions result from damage to the corticospinal tracts, responsible for voluntary movement control.
  • Characterized by spasticity, increased muscle tone, and exaggerated reflexes.
  • Presents with weakness on one side of the body (hemiparesis) if the lesion is unilateral.
  • Unilateral or bilateral weakness of the upper limb extensors and lower limb flexors (“pyramidal weakness”) suggests a lesion of the pyramidal tract.
  • Lower limb weakness is greater than upper limb weakness.
  • Distal muscles of the limbs are more affected than proximal muscles.
  • Babinski sign may be present (upward extension of the big toe and fanning of other toes upon foot stimulation).
  • Commonly observed in conditions like stroke, multiple sclerosis, and traumatic brain or spinal cord injuries.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 165, 3280.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about Guillain-Barré syndrome is not true?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Descending
 
  • Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an autoimmune disorder affecting the peripheral nervous system.
  • GBS manifests as a rapidly evolving areflexic motor paralysis with or without sensory disturbance. The usual pattern is an ascending paralysis that may be first noticed as rubbery legs.
  • It is characterized by inflammation and demyelination of nerves, leading to weakness, numbness, and tingling in the limbs.
  • GBS typically follows an ascending pattern; it usually starts in the feet and hands and moves up the body.
  • Cranial nerves can also be affected, leading to issues with facial, eye, and mouth control.
  • GBS is both inflammatory and demyelinating in nature, involving damage to the protective sheath surrounding nerves.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3501.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Tabes Dorsalis is untrue?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Deep tendon reflexes are brisk
 
  • Tabes dorsalis (or syphilitic myelopathy) is a slow degeneration and demyelination of the neural tracts.
  • It is seen in tertiary syphilis.
  • It primarily involves the dorsal columns of the spinal cord and dorsal roots.

Clinical features:
  • Loss of reflexes in lower limbs 
  • Romberg's sign
  • Bilateral Argyll Robertson pupils - accommodation reflex present, pupillary reflex absent 
  • Loss of position sense and vibration
  • Stabbing/pricking pain in the legs - this is fleeting or repetitive
  • Ataxia of the legs and gait disturbances
  • Paresthesias
  • Bladder disturbances 
  • Acute abdominal pain with vomiting - visceral crisis 


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3454.

questions.text: It is usual to see neurodegeneration and iron buildup in the basal ganglia in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Hallervorden-Spatz Disease
 
  • Pantothenate kinase-associated neurodegeneration (PKAN) formerly known as Hallervorden-Spatz disease caused by PANK2 gene mutation is the most common form of Neurodegeneration with Brain Iron Accumulation (NBIA) and is manifested as a combination of dystonia (hyperkinetic), parkinsonism (hypokinetic), and spasticity.
 
  • T2W-MRI shows the characteristic eye of the tiger sign due to iron accumulation in globus pallidus.






Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3409.

questions.text: All of the following are included in the Balint's syndrome triad, except:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Opsoclonus
 
  • Balint's syndrome is a rare neurological disorder that is characterized by three main features:
    • Optic ataxia (inability to reach for or point to objects that are seen in the periphery of the visual field).
    • Simultanagnosia (inability to see multiple objects in a single visual scene).
    • Ocular apraxia (inability to voluntarily move the eyes to a specific location).
 
  • Opsoclonus is a rare movement disorder that is characterized by involuntary, rapid, jerky eye movements. It is not a feature of Balint's syndrome.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3329.

questions.text: Quinn's wheel chair sign is used as a standard Red Flag Sign in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Idiopathic Parkinsonism

Wheelchair sign is seen with levodopa therapy in Parkinsonism / Paralysis agitans patients.
 
  • Usage of levodopa leads to on and off phenomenon.
  • When Levodopa starts acting the akinetic wheelchair bound patient will be in a position to get out of the chair and start pushing it.
  • When the effect weans off the same patient will be restricted to wheelchair.



Reference: Roongroj Bhidayasiri, Jirada Sringean, Stephen G. Reich, Carlo Colosimo,
Red flags phenotyping: A systematic review on clinical features in atypical parkinsonian disorders, Parkinsonism & Related Disorders, Volume 59, 2019, doi: https://doi.org/10.1016/j.parkreldis.2018.10.009. URL: https://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S1353802018304371

questions.text: Which of the following factors is not associated with a substantially greater risk of developing epilepsy after febrile seizures?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Family history of Febrile Seizure
 
  • The high-risk category for developing subsequent epilepsy in a child with febrile seizures includes the factors of:
         A. Complex febrile seizure
         C. Neurodevelopment abnormalities.
         D. Family history of epilepsy
 
  • Febrile seizures are described as seizures that occur in children of the age of 6–60 months with a temperature of 38ºC (100.4°F) or higher, without underlying intracranial infections or prior unprovoked seizures. 
 
  • Epilepsy is a disorder of the brain characterized by a predisposition to generate repeated seizures.

Risk factors for the development of subsequent epilepsy in a child with febrile seizure can be classified into two groups:




Reference: Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics, 21st edition, Page no 3092, 3093.

questions.text: In which of the following - examination would reveal crossing crossing of suture lines?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2 - Subgaleal hemorrhage. 
Among the options listed, only sub-galeal hemorrhage is associated with a clinical examination revealing crossing of cranial sutures.
 
  • Subgaleal hemorrhage is a collection of blood in the subgaleal space - which is between aponeurosis of the scalp and the periosteum of the bone. It occurs as a result of ventouse deliveries due to tears of the emissary veins which connect to the dural venous sinuses. 
  • The subgaleal space is large is not limited by cranial sutures and hence, subgaleal hemorrhages can be large and can easily cross sutures.
  • Since, the subgaleal space is large - subgaleal bleed can be extremely large and profuse and can sometimes lead even to shock and DIC.





Other options

Option 1 -  Cephalhaematoma is a subperiosteal haemorrhage between the skull bone and the periosteum overlying it. Since, periosteum is tightly adherent to the skull bone - therefore, it does not cross the boundary of the skull bone and does not cross the sutures. 

Option 3 - Epidural haematoma is an intracranial haemorrhage between the skull and dura mater. It also does not cross suture lines because the dura is tightly adherent at sutures. 



Reference: DC Dutta Textbook of Obstetrics, 9th edition, Page no 452.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is not true about 'Sham Rage'?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Abolished by Decortication 
 
  • Sham rage is a controversial term used to describe behavior such as biting, clawing, hissing, arching the back and "violent alternating limb movements" produced in animal experiments by removing the cerebral cortex, which is claimed to occur in the absence of any sort of inner experience of rage.
  • The reason for this might be that the removal of the neocortex causes a loss of inhibition of the areas involved in the rage reaction, causing those areas to become hyperactive (due to an uninhibited hypothalamus). 
  • Removal of hypothalamus abolishes the sham rage.
  • Sham rage may be triggered by very mild stimuli such as weak touch. It is also non-goal directed.



Reference: Purves D, Augustine GJ, Fitzpatrick D, et al., editors. Neuroscience. 2nd edition. Sunderland (MA): Sinauer Associates; 2001. The Integration of Emotional Behavior. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK10814/

questions.text: Which is a characteristic of Extrapyramidal Tract Involvement?:
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1:  Increased Muscular Tone 


Extrapyramidal tract controls smooth voluntary movements.

Involvement of extrapyramidal tract leads to:
  • Increased muscular tone
  • Rigid muscles
  • Shuffling gait
  • Trouble walking
  • Tremor
  • Bradykinesia (slowed movements)
  • Dyskinesia (abnormal movements)
  • Paralysis and positive Babinski sign are not related to extrapyramidal tract involvement.
  • Exaggerated deep tendon reflexes are a characteristic of both extrapyramidal tract involvement and pyramidal tract involvement.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3280.

questions.text: Intracranial hemorrhage is mainly due to which cause?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Intracerebral hemorrhage
 
  • Intracranial hemorrhage: This type of hemorrhage involves bleeding directly into the brain tissue itself. It is often caused by the rupture of small arteries or veins within the brain.
  • The increased pressure from the bleeding can compress and damage brain tissue, leading to neurological deficits and other complications.
 
  • Causes of intracerebral hemorrhage: High BP, aneurysm, arteriovenous malformation, trauma, drugs, and clotting disorders.

Symptoms can vary depending on the location and severity of the bleed and may include:
  • Sudden, severe headache
  • Nausea and vomiting
  • Seizures
  • Weakness or paralysis on one side of the body
  • Speech problems
  • Vision problems
  • Any other focal neurological defects

ICH Score (maximum score: 6)





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3349, 3351.

questions.text: The most common form of diabetic neuropathy is -
questions.solution:
The correct answer is option 2, which is "Distal symmetric sensory and motor neuropathy" for the most common form of diabetic neuropathy.

Diabetic Distal Symmetric Sensory and Sensorimotor Polyneuropathy (DSPN) DSPN is the most common form of diabetic neuropathy and manifests as sensory loss beginning in the toes that gradually progresses over time up the legs and into the fingers and arms.
 
  • Diabetic neuropathy is a type of nerve damage that can occur in people with diabetes.
  • It is caused by high blood sugar levels, which can damage the nerves throughout the body.
  • Neuropathy can affect any type of nerve in the body, including sensory, motor, and autonomic nerves.
  • Distal symmetric sensory and motor neuropathy is the most common form of diabetic neuropathy. It affects the nerves in the feet, legs, and hands in a symmetrical pattern, meaning that both sides of the body are affected equally.
  • This type of neuropathy can cause numbness, tingling, and pain in the affected areas.
  • It can also lead to muscle weakness and difficulty with coordination and balance.
  • Autonomic neuropathy is another type of diabetic neuropathy that affects the autonomic nerves, which control functions such as heart rate, blood pressure, digestion, and bladder function. Symptoms of autonomic neuropathy can include dizziness, fainting, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, constipation, and difficulty with urination. Distal motor neuropathy is a less common form of diabetic neuropathy that affects the nerves that control movement and muscle function.
  • It can cause muscle weakness, muscle wasting, and difficulty with movement and coordination.
Therefore, based on the above explanation, option 2 is the correct answer as it describes the most common form of diabetic neuropathy that affects both sensory and motor nerves in a symmetrical pattern.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3488.

choices.text: Caused by Herpes simplex-2 virus in all cases
Is also referred to as "Benign Recurrent Lymphocytic Meningitis"

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about Mollaret's meningitis except:
questions.solution:
• Mollaret's meningitis is a rare type of meningitis that is characterized by recurrent episodes of meningitis that last for 2-5 days and then resolve spontaneously.
  • The exact cause of Mollaret's meningitis is not fully understood, but it is believed to be caused by the herpes simplex virus type 2 (HSV-2) in some cases.
  • However, it is important to note that not all cases of Mollaret's meningitis are caused by HSV-2. It is caused by other viruses as well like Varicella zoster virus and some non-viral etiologies also.
  • Therefore, option 1 is not completely true about Mollaret's meningitis.

Other options: 
  • Option 2 is true, as Mollaret's meningitis is a recurrent type of meningitis that is generally considered benign, as it does not cause any long-term neurological damage.
  • Option 3 is also true, as Mollaret's meningitis is also known as "Benign Recurrent Lymphocytic Meningitis" due to its recurrent and benign nature and CSF lymphocytosis.
  • Option 4 is  true, as Mollaret's meningitis episodes usually resolve spontaneously without treatment, although antiviral drugs may be used to shorten the duration of symptoms during an episode.
 
  • Therefore, the correct option is 1, as Mollaret's meningitis is NOT ALWAYS caused by HSV-2 only.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1107.

questions.text: The effectiveness of ventrolateral cordotomy performed to produce relief of pain from the right leg is because it interrupts the-
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Left Lateral Spinothalamic tract 
 
  • In ventrolateral cordotomy, selected pain-conducting tracts in the spinal cord, i.e. fibers in the lateral spinothalamic pathway, are cut leading to contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation below the level of the lesion.
 
  • In the more recent percutaneous approach, destruction of the lateral spinothalamic at the level of C1-C2 results in a contralateral disruption of painful sensations beyond C4. 

Pain pathway (Lateral Spinothalamic tract):





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 92, 3447.

questions.text: Below which values of cerebral blood flow Cerebral Ischemia to occur ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: 20 ml / 100 g/ minute 
 
  • The normal CBF is 20 ml/100g/min. This means that 20 milliliters of blood flow through every 100 grams of brain tissue every minute.
  • A decrease in the cerebral blood flow below 20 mL/100 g/min causes reversible ischemia.
  • If this state is prolonged for several hours to days, it can lead to infarction. A decrease in CBF to 0 causes the death of the brain tissue within 4–10 min.

Normal cerebral physiologic values:





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3335.

questions.text: Which is an exception to normal pressure spontaneous CSF leaks?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Pseudo tumor Cerebri 
 
  • Normal pressure spontaneous cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) leaks: Leak of CSF from the brain or spine into the surrounding tissues.
  • These leaks usually result in a decrease in CSF pressure, leading to conditions like low-pressure headaches when in an upright position.
 
  • Pseudo tumor cerebri (also known as idiopathic intracranial hypertension) refers to a rise in intracranial pressure in the absence of a structural lesion or hydrocephalus.
  • Pseudo tumor cerebri is not associated with CSF leaks or low-pressure headaches and, therefore, is the exception among the provided options.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 116, 224.

questions.text: Increased levels of what are associated with age related dementia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Homocysteine 
 
  • Homocysteine is an amino acid produced when the body breaks down methionine, another amino acid.
 
  • High homocysteine levels are thought to contribute to the development of dementia by promoting oxidative stress, inflammation, and damage to blood vessels, which can impair brain function and increase the risk of neurodegenerative diseases.
 
  • Reducing elevated homocysteine levels through dietary modifications, lifestyle changes, and supplementation with certain B vitamins (such as folate, vitamin B6, and vitamin B12) has been suggested as a potential strategy to mitigate the risk of age-related cognitive decline and dementia.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 191, 194, 3372.

questions.text: Frequency of symptoms in Parkinsonism are shown to have reduced due to deep Brain Stimulation of which part of the brain ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Subthalamic nucleus 
 
  • Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is a neurosurgical procedure that involves implanting electrodes in specific regions of the brain to modulate neural activity and alleviate symptoms of certain neurological disorders.
  • In the case of Parkinsonism, DBS is often used to target the Subthalamic nucleus (STN) or Globus pallidus interna (GPi)
  • The Subthalamic nucleus, part of the brain's basal ganglia, regulates motor control and movement regulation.
  • Deep brain stimulation of the Subthalamic nucleus can modify abnormal neural activity, reducing Parkinsonian symptoms like tremors, rigidity and bradykinesia (slowness of movement).





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3397.

questions.text: To reduce the frequency of Parkinsonism symptoms, which of the following is the most commonly used site for Deep Brain Stimulation?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Subthalamic Nucleus 
  • Deep brain stimulation (DBS) is a neurosurgical procedure that involves implanting electrodes in specific regions of the brain to modulate neural activity and alleviate symptoms of certain neurological disorders.
  • In the case of Parkinsonism, DBS is often used to target the Subthalamic nucleus (STN) > Globus pallidus interna (GPi)
  • The Subthalamic nucleus, part of the brain's basal ganglia, regulates motor control and movement regulation.
  • Deep brain stimulation of the Subthalamic nucleus can modify abnormal neural activity, reducing Parkinsonian symptoms like tremors, rigidity and bradykinesia (slowness of movement).





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3397.

questions.text: Experimentally, stimulation of which of the following areas of brain is used to control intractable pain ?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Periaqueductal grey matter 
 
  • The periaqueductal gray (PAG) is a small area of gray matter located in the midbrain, near the cerebral aqueduct.
  • Descending pathways from the mesencephalic periaqueductal gray matter inhibit transmission in nociceptive pathways.
  • This descending pathway includes a synapse in the ventromedial medulla (Raphe nucleus) and the release of endogenous opiates. So periaqueductal gray matter releases endogenous opiate, thereby reducing intractable pain.

Other options:
 
  • Mesencephalon, subthalamic nucleus, and medial forebrain bundle, are all structures in the brain that are involved in functions, such as: Movement, cognition, and motivation.
  • However, there is no evidence that stimulation of these structures is effective in controlling pain.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3357.
Sims-Williams, Hugh et al. “Deep brain stimulation of the periaqueductal gray releases endogenous opioids in humans.” NeuroImage vol. 146 (2017): 833-842. doi:10.1016/j.neuroimage.2016.08.038. URL: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC5312788/

questions.text: Which of the following areas of the brain is most resistant to Neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Lateral Geniculate Body 
 
  • Neurofibrillary tangles (NFTs) are a hallmark of Alzheimer's disease.
  • NFTs are composed of tau protein, which is normally found in axons, the long fibers that transmit signals between neurons.
  • The Lateral Geniculate Body in the thalamus  is responsible for relaying visual information from the retina to the cortex.
  • It is not as susceptible to NFT formation as other areas of the brain, such as the hippocampus and entorhinal cortex.
  • The Visual Association area (part of the Occipital lobe) is also vulnerable to Neurofibrillary tangle formation in Alzheimer's disease.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3371, 3372.

questions.text: Wernicke's Korsakoff psychosis does not involve which of the following
questions.solution:
• Wernicke's Korsakoff psychosis is a neurological disorder caused by a deficiency of thiamine (vitamin B1) in the brain. The disorder is characterized by a range of symptoms, including confusion, memory loss, and difficulty with coordination and movement.
  • The correct option is 4. Hippocampus.
  • The hippocampus is a part of the brain that is involved in the formation and retrieval of memories.
  • Other three options (1. Mamillary body, 2. Thalamus, and 3. Periventricular Grey matter) are all areas of the brain that are affected by Wernicke's Korsakoff psychosis.
  • The mamillary bodies are involved in memory and learning, and damage to these structures can result in amnesia.
  • The thalamus is involved in the processing and relaying of sensory information, and damage to this area can lead to problems with sensory perception.
