  • The periventricular grey matter is involved in the regulation of pain and other autonomic functions, and damage to this area can lead to a range of symptoms, including chronic pain and autonomic dysfunction.
 
  • In summary, the correct option is  4. Hippocampus



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3376.
Akhouri S, Kuhn J, Newton EJ. Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome. [Updated 2023 Jun 26]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430729/

questions.text: Which of the following sites is responsible for the amnestic defect in Wernicke's Korsakoff syndrome
questions.solution:
• The thalamus is responsible for the amnestic defect in Wernicke's Korsakoff syndrome.
  • The amnestic defect is a hallmark symptom of Korsakoff's psychosis, which is characterized by severe memory impairment, confabulation, and personality changes.
  • The thalamus is a crucial relay station in the brain that is involved in various functions, including sensory processing, motor control, and memory.
 
  • In Wernicke's Korsakoff syndrome, thiamine deficiency leads to damage to the thalamus, particularly the dorsomedial nucleus, which is responsible for mediating memory function.
  • Damage to the dorsomedial thalamus correlates most closely with the memory loss
  • However, Mammillary body atrophy may also be visible on MRI in the chronic phase
 
  • As a result, patients with Wernicke's Korsakoff syndrome have significant memory impairment, which is a result of damage to the thalamus.
  • Therefore, the most appropriate option is 2. Thalamus > 1. Mamillary body



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3376.
Akhouri S, Kuhn J, Newton EJ. Wernicke-Korsakoff Syndrome. [Updated 2023 Jun 26]. In: StatPearls [Internet]. Treasure Island (FL): StatPearls Publishing; 2024 Jan-. Available from: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK430729/

questions.text: All of the following conditions cause reduction in conduction velocity of nerve except
questions.solution:
• Acute Motor Axonal Neuropathy (AMAN) is a type of Guillain-Barré syndrome that affects the axons and causes demyelination. This results in a decrease in conduction velocity.
 
  • Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Neuropathy (AIDP) is another type of Guillain-Barré syndrome that affects the myelin sheath and causes demyelination. 
 
  • Hereditary Motor Neuropathy (HSMN) is a genetic disorder that affects the motor nerves and causes muscle weakness and wasting. It does not affect the myelin sheath or the axon diameter, so it does not result in a decrease in conduction velocity.
 
  • Multifocal Motor Neuropathy is a rare disorder that affects the motor nerves and causes muscle weakness and wasting. It is characterized by conduction block, which means that nerve impulses are unable to pass through certain areas of the nerve, resulting in a decrease in conduction velocity.
Therefore, the correct option is 3 :Hereditary Motor Neuropathy (HSMN).



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3502, 3503, 3483, 3507.

questions.text: Except what of the following is not classified as 'Small fiber neuropathies' :
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Vitamin B12 deficiency
 
  • Small fiber neuropathies are a group of disorders that affect the small nerve fibers in the body. These nerves are responsible for transmitting pain, temperature, and touch sensations
 
  • Vitamin B12 deficiency can cause a condition called subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord, which can damage the large nerve fibers in the spinal cord (large fiber neuropathy), is responsible for motor function and proprioception.
 
  • A preferential large-fiber sensory loss affecting proprioception and vibration with sparing of small-fiber modalities is present.
 
  • HIV-induced neuropathy, Hansen's disease (leprosy), and Amyloidosis are examples of conditions that can cause small fiber neuropathies.
 



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3496.

questions.text: What is the most probable diagnosis in a young adult with proximal weakness of upper limbs and features of facial palsy and winging of scapula.
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Facio-Scapulo-Humeral Dystrophy 
 
  • Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy is an autosomal dominant condition that generally presents with asymmetric weakness in facial and shoulder girdle muscles.
  • Occasionally, finger and wrist weakness is the first symptom. 
  • The mouth is rounded and appears puckered because of the protruding lips.
  • Upper facial weakness will manifest as an inability to close the eyes completely in sleep. 
  • Scapular winging is prominent, even in infants. 
  • Eventually, proximal muscles get involved and undergo atrophy, and Gowers sign & Trendelenburg gait appear.
  • Lumbar lordosis, foot drop, and kyphoscoliosis are common complications.





Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3527.

questions.text: All of the following statements about Von-Hippel Lindau syndrome are false except :
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Craniospinal hemangioblastomas are common 
 
  • Von Hippel Lindau (VHL) syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition that arises from a mutation affecting the VHL tumor suppressor gene.
  • Characteristic features of VHL include spinal hemangioblastomas, endolymphatic sac tumor, pheochromocytoma, and cystic lesions of the kidneys, pancreas, and liver.
  • In VHL syndrome, multiple tumors are commonly seen, including hemangioblastomas, clear cell renal cell carcinoma, pheochromocytomas, and pancreatic neuroendocrine tumors.
  • The lesions in VHL syndrome can occur more commonly in infratentorial (below the tentorium) regions of the brain like cerebellum.
  • While tumors involving Schwann cells can be seen in VHL syndrome, they are not among the most common tumors associated with this condition.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 2990, 2991.

choices.text: Absent pupillary light reflex and dilated pupils

questions.text: What are the Criteria for Brainstem death?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 2: Absent pupillary light reflex and dilated pupils 

Brainstem death entails testing twice, by two clinicians, to demonstrate the absence of:
  1. Response to pain
  2. Respiratory drive (apnea despite arterial PCO2 ≥ 60 mm Hg )
  3. Pupillary light reflex
  4. Corneal reflex
  5. Vestibulo-ocular reflex
  6. Oculo-cephalic reflex/ Doll’s eye reflex

Other options:
The oculocephalic reflex or doll's eye reflex is used to assess the integrity of the cranial nerves III, VI, and VIII.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 188.

questions.text: A 12-year-old child who has a history of falling frequently and having more difficult walking presents to the outpatient  department. A physical examination indicates nystagmus and an ataxic gait. While the plantar response was "Extensor," it was noticed that all deep tendon reflexes were absent. Which diagnosis is more likely?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Friedreich's Ataxia
 
  • Friedreich's ataxia is the most common form of inherited ataxia and is an autosomal recessive disorder.
  • It is caused by the expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat in the first intron of a gene on chromosome 9q13 that encodes frataxin.
  • This disorder typically occurs in individuals less than 25 years of age.
Clinical features of Friedreich's ataxia include:
  • dysarthria
  • progressive staggering gait
  • frequent falls
  • nystagmus
  • titubation (nodding head and body movements).


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3425, 3426.

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient with complaints of discomfort, weariness, and weakness in both lower limbs arrives at the outpatient clinic. She discusses her childhood experience with paralysis involving both lower limbs, from which she made a good functional recovery. The most likely suspected diagnosis is which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 1: Post-Polio syndrome

Post-Polio Syndrome:
 
  • After an interval of 30-40 years, around 30-40% of persons who survived paralytic poliomyelitis in childhood, experience muscle pain and exacerbation of existing weakness or development of new weakness or paralysis. It is known as post polio syndrome.
 
  • It has been reported only in persons who were infected in the era of wild-type poliovirus circulation.

Risk factors for post polio syndrome include:
 
  • Permanent impairment after recovery from acute polio infection
  • Increasing length of time from acute polio infection
  • Female sex



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 1603.

questions.text: A patient with acute paraplegia caused by a "T3 level" thoracic cord injury was found to have a blood pressure reading of 210/120. What should the initial management be?
questions.solution:
Correct Option is 3: Nifedipine
 
  • Autonomic dysreflexia is a condition that emerges when the spinal cord is injured above the T6 level. 
  • The blood pressure of the patient suddenly rises in response to stimuli like bladder or bowel distension that originates below the level of injury. 
  • It is usually accompanied by a severe headache, bradycardia, and facial flushing, along with pallor, cold skin, and sweating in the lower part of the body. 
 
  • It is treated with vasodilators to manage acute BP elevation. 
  • Nifedipine is a calcium channel blocker that helps to lower blood pressure by relaxing and dilating blood vessels.
  • Clonidine is prophylactically used to reduce hypertension resulting from bladder stimulation.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page no 3433.

questions.text: A patient presented to the Neurology OPD with the complaints of ballistic movements of arm. He had suffered stroke 6 moths back. What could be the probable site of lesion?
questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, presence of ballistic movements of arm points to a diagnosis of hemiballismus and the site of lesion is the subthalamic nucleus. 
 
  • Option 1 - Caudate/putamen are involved in chorea.
  • Option 3- Globus pallidus is involved in athetosis. 
  • Option 4- Substantia nigra is involved in Parkinson's disease. 

Reference: Guyton & Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, 14th edition, Page no 721, 722.

questions.text: An elderly patient presented with tremors, rigidity and bradykinesia. Such a patient can be treated by giving:
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of Parkinson's disease. Among the given options, selegiline is used in the treatment of Parkinson disease. 
 
  • Selegiline is a monoamine oxidase B (MAO-B) inhibitor. It works by inhibiting the breakdown of dopamine in the brain, thus helping to alleviate symptoms of Parkinson's disease, particularly tremors, rigidity, and bradykinesia.

Other options:
 

  • Haloperidol: This is an antipsychotic medication, but it can worsen the symptoms of Parkinson's disease by blocking dopamine receptors in the brain. It is not used to treat Parkinson’s and may actually induce drug-induced parkinsonism.

  • Clozapine: This is an atypical antipsychotic that has a lower risk of extrapyramidal side effects (such as parkinsonism) compared to other antipsychotics. However, it is primarily used for schizophrenia and not for treating Parkinson’s disease.

  • Donepezil: This is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor used for Alzheimer's disease. It increases acetylcholine levels but does not directly address the dopamine deficiency in Parkinson’s disease and would not be an appropriate treatment for this condition.

Thus, Selegiline is the correct choice for treating Parkinsonian symptoms in this case.



Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology by KD Tripathi, 8th edition, Page no 458, 459, 467, 468.

questions.text: A young female presented with severe throbbing headache on the left side. Before the onset of headache, she had nausea, vomiting, phonophobia and photophobia. Drug which can offer her immediate relief?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of classical migraine. Among the given options, Sumatriptan will be the drug of choice to terminate an acute attack.

It acts as an agonist at 5HTIB and 5HT1D receptors. 
 
  • Sumatriptan is a serotonin (5-HT) receptor agonist and is commonly used to abort or relieve acute migraine attacks. It works by constricting blood vessels and inhibiting the release of substances that contribute to the migraine pain. It provides rapid relief and is effective for the symptoms described (headache, nausea, photophobia, etc.).

Other options:
 

  • Propranolol: This is a beta-blocker and is commonly used as a prophylactic treatment for migraines, not for acute relief. It helps prevent future migraine attacks but does not provide immediate relief during an active episode.

  • Topiramate: This is an anticonvulsant medication that is used prophylactically to reduce the frequency of migraines. It is not effective for providing immediate relief during an acute migraine attack.

  • Cyproheptadine: This is an antihistamine with anti-serotonergic properties. While it has some off-label use for migraine prevention in certain cases, it is not a first-line treatment for acute relief of migraines.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 3357, 3359, 3361, 3363.

questions.text: A young male presented to the OPD with complaints of drooping of the left angle of mouth, inability to blow properly and weakness of the facial muscles on the left side. Which of the following cranial nerve/CN might be paralyzed?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Bell's palsy which commonly involves the seventh cranial nerve-facial nerve. 
 

The facial nerve (Cranial Nerve VII) controls the muscles of facial expression, including the muscles responsible for:

  • Raising the eyebrows
  • Closing the eyes tightly
  • Moving the mouth (such as smiling, frowning, and blowing)

The symptoms of drooping of the angle of the mouth, inability to blow properly, and weakness of the facial muscles are indicative of a facial nerve palsy, which can result from conditions such as Bell’s palsy, trauma, or stroke.


Other options:

  • 4th CN (Trochlear Nerve): This nerve controls the superior oblique muscle, which helps in eye movement. It does not affect facial muscles.
  • 5th CN (Trigeminal Nerve): This nerve provides sensation to the face and controls the muscles of mastication (chewing). While it can cause weakness in chewing muscles if affected, it does not cause the facial muscle weakness described in this case.
  • 6th CN (Abducent Nerve): This nerve controls the lateral rectus muscle, responsible for moving the eye laterally. It does not affect the facial muscles.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 229, 3439-3441.

choices.text: Used as monotherapy-not in combination with AChE inhibitors

questions.text: True about Memantine?
questions.solution:
Memantine is a clinically useful drug in many neurological disorders, including Alzheimer's disease( mild to moderate form)
  • The principal mechanism of action of memantine is believed to be the blockade of current flow through channels of N-methyl-d-aspartate (NMDA) glutamate receptors.
 

  • Used as monotherapy-not in combination with AChE inhibitors (Incorrect):

    • Memantine can be used as monotherapy or in combination with acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibitors (e.g., donepezil) for moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease.

  • Dose is 500mg per day (Incorrect):

    • The typical dose of memantine is 10–20 mg per day, not 500 mg.

  • Given intravenously (Incorrect):

    • Memantine is administered orally, either as tablets or oral solution. It is not given intravenously.



Reference: Goodman & Gillman’s The Pharmacological Basis of Therapeutics, 13th edition, Page no 333, 337.

questions.text: Gottron's papules are seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
• DERMATOMYOSITIS—A rare inflammatory disease characterised by typical skin lesions and weakness of proximal group of muscles.
  • Gottron's papules are violaceous flat-topped papules affecting MCP and IP Joints.

Clinical features of Dermatomyositis:

1. CUTANEOUS SIGNS:
 
  • Gottron's papules:
    • Raised, scaly, erythematous or violaceous papules over the knuckles, elbows, knees, or other extensor surfaces.
  • Gottron's sign:
    • Erythematous or violaceous macules or patches over the same extensor areas without raised papules.
  • Heliotrope rash:
    • Violaceous discoloration with or without edema over the eyelids, often accompanied by periorbital edema.
  • Shawl sign:
    • Erythematous or violaceous rash over the upper back, shoulders, or chest, resembling a shawl distribution.
  • V-sign:
    • Rash on the upper chest and neck in a V-shaped distribution.
  • Mechanic's hands:
    • Hyperkeratotic, cracked skin on the lateral and palmar aspects of the fingers, resembling a mechanic’s hands.
  • Photosensitivity:
    • Rashes in sun-exposed areas, aggravated by UV light.

2. MUSCLE WEAKNESS:
 
  • Proximal muscle weakness:
    • Involves the shoulders, hips, and neck flexors, making activities like climbing stairs, rising from a chair, or lifting objects difficult.
    • Typically painless, although mild myalgias may occur.

3. SYSTEMIC FEATURES:
 
  • Interstitial lung disease (ILD):
    • Can occur in up to 30% of patients. Symptoms include cough and dyspnea.
  • Dysphagia:
    • Due to esophageal muscle involvement.
  • Arthritis:
    • Non-erosive polyarthritis is sometimes present.

4. ASSOCIATED FEATURES;
 
  • Dermatomyositis can be a paraneoplastic syndrome, associated with malignancies such as ovarian, lung, pancreatic, or gastric cancer.

5. NAILFOLD ABNORMALITIES;
 
  • Dilated capillary loops or dropouts, periungual erythema, and telangiectasias seen in the nailfold area.



Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 2819, 2820.

questions.text: Positive Tredelenburg test on right side, where is the lesion?
questions.solution:
• The given scenario is suggestive of Superior Gluteal nerve on Left side injury, paralysis of gluteus medius & gluteus minimus muscles of left side is seen.
 
  • When the leg on one side is lifted off the ground, the gluteus medius & minimus  muscles, on opposite supported side, exert traction on hip bone by acting from femur.
 
  • This action results in the slight raising of pelvis on unsupported side, which helps maintain the trunk in upright position
 
  • When the gluteus medius & minimus are paralyzed, the pelvis sinks down on unsupported (normal) side when pt. tries to stand on affected Limb.



Reference: Apley & Solomon's System of Orthopaedics and Trauma, 10th edition, Page no 234, 548.

questions.text: What is the characteristic clinical feature seen in Klumpke's palsy?
questions.solution:
When the ulnar and median nerves get damaged, muscles in the forearm override the action of the lumbricals, causing the hand to look like a claw. So, with Klumpke's palsy, patient’s forearm is stuck in the supinated position, with the wrist extended.
 

Klumpke's palsy is caused by injury to the lower trunk of the brachial plexus (C8 and T1 nerve roots). This affects the ulnar nerve and, to some extent, the median nerve, leading to characteristic symptoms:

  1. Claw hand deformity:

    • Due to paralysis of the intrinsic hand muscles (lumbricals and interossei) innervated by the ulnar and median nerves.
    • Results in hyperextension of the metacarpophalangeal (MCP) joints and flexion of the interphalangeal (IP) joints, especially in the 4th and 5th fingers.

  2. Weakness in hand grip:

    • Paralysis of the flexor muscles of the fingers and intrinsic hand muscles.

  3. Sensory deficits:

    • Loss of sensation along the medial arm, forearm, and hand (ulnar side).

  4. Horner's syndrome (occasionally):

    • If the T1 nerve root involvement extends to the sympathetic fibers, symptoms like ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis may occur.



Reference: BD Chaurasia's Human Anatomy- Volume I, 8th edition, Page no 62, 63, 109, 201.

questions.text: A 78-year old lady was brought to the OPD with complaints of progressive difficulty in daily activities for 6 months, Convulsions and visual hallucinations. The patient is reported to stare calmly and continuously at the sky. The autopsy of the patient revealed Lewy bodies. What is the most probable cause?
questions.solution:
This patient most likely has Lewy body disease, which is the second most common cause of neurodegenerative dementia, after Alzheimer’s disease.
  • One may have even considered PDD (i.e. Parkinson disease dementia) a suitable answer as it is part of the spectrum of Lewy body disease.
  • Based on this premise, and exclusion of other options, Parkinson's disease (PD) has been chosen as the single-best answer.
  • Please note PDD and PD are distinct conditions but approximately 10% of patients with PD develop PDD per year, with the majority of PD patients developing PDD over time.
* Diagnosis: 
  • The key neuropathologic feature in LBD is the presence of Lewy bodies and Lewy neurites throughout specific brainstem nuclei, substantia nigra, amygdala, cingulate gyrus, and, ultimately, the neocortex.
  • Lewy bodies are intraneuronal cytoplasmic inclusions that stain with periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) and ubiquitin but are now identified with antibodies to the presynaptic protein α-synuclein.
  • Lewy bodies are composed of straight neurofilaments 7–20 nm long with surrounding amorphous material and contain epitopes recognized by antibodies against phosphorylated and non-phosphorylated neurofilament proteins, ubiquitin, and α-synuclein.
  • The presence of α-synuclein aggregates in neurons and glia in PDD and DLB molecularly classifies these diseases as synucleinopathies.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3385.

questions.text: A young female presents with cheilitis. On examination, there is pallor, loss of proprioception and touch, absent ankle reflex, UMN type of lower limb weakness. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The female patient with cheilitis, anemia and neurological manifestations likely has vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • Anemia and subacute combined degeneration of the spinal cord are the two major disease manifestations of this nutritional deficiency.
  • Subacute refers to the neurological disease course, while combined refers to the involvement of both the sensory (dorsal column) and motor (lateral corticospinal tract) in addition to the spinocerebellar tracts, and leads to the characteristic findings as seen in this patient.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3454.

questions.text: Which artery is involved in patient with Wallenberg Syndrome?
questions.solution:
Vertebral artery>PICA is involved in Lateral Medullary or Wallenberg syndrome. The following tracts are affected in Lateral Medullary syndrome Nucleus of Trigeminal nerve, Inferior Cerebellar peduncle, Lateral Spinothalamic tract ,IX and X CN ,Vestibular nucleus ,Descending Sympathetic tract.

Reference: Gray’s Anatomy, The Anatomical Basis of Clinical Practice,42nd Edition, Page. No-285, 315.

questions.text: 30y old male was diagnosed to have Associative Visual Agnosia. Which of the following lobe is likely to be affected?
questions.solution:
Agnosia refers to inability to visually identify objects. In Associative visual agnosia, Patient is able to identify objects using other sensory modalities like touch. The lesion is in the Occipito-Temporal Junction which is present in the Inferior Temporal lobe.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No: 201.

questions.text: 14 y old boy from Kerala who went to swim in a freshwater pool with his friends developed history of altered mental status with multiple cranial nerve palsies and reduced vision. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Given history and clinical scenario is suggestive of Primary Amoebic encephalitis. The causative organism is Naegleria Fowleri. The portal of entry by the amoeba is through the olfactory mucosa and the cribriform plate. There is no proven treatment. Amphotericin B is found to be efficacious in many cases.

Reference: Shrestha GS, Parajuli NP, Shrestha PS, Acharya SP, Hamal R, Gajurel B, Khanal K, Marhatta MN. Primary amoebic meningoencephalitis. J Neurosci Rural Pract. 2015 Apr-Jun;6(2):284-6. doi: 10.4103/0976-3147.153244. PMID: 25883507; PMCID: PMC4387838.

questions.text: Which of the following Anti epileptic drugs is the drug of choice for Infantile spasms seen in Tuberous Sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Vigabatrin inhibits GABA reuptake by inhibiting the GABA reuptake transporter. It is the DOC for infantile spasms seen in tuberous Sclerosis.

*Extra Edge: 
Vigabatrin (γ vinyl GABA) It is an inhibitor of GABA-transaminase, the enzyme which degrades GABA. Anticonvulsant action may be due to increase in synaptic GABA concentration. It is effective in many patients with refractory epilepsy, especially CPS with or without generalization, and in infantile spasms. It is approved only for adjuvant medication. Visual field contraction, alteration of colour vision, paresthesias and production of behavioural changes, depression or psychosis has restricted its use to only as a reserve drug.

Reference: Essentials of Medical Pharmacology, K.D. Tripathy 8th Edition, Page No: 448.

questions.text: A male patient who is HIV-positive, presents with persistent headaches, confusion, and fever. Further cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis revealed a positive India ink stain. What is the most likely causative organism?
questions.solution:
This patient is immunocompromised (HIV-positive) and presents with meningitis-like symptoms: persistent headache, confusion, and fever.

Clues from CSF analysis:

  • India ink stain positive: Indicates the presence of encapsulated yeast.

  • Cryptococcus neoformans is the most common opportunistic fungal pathogen causing cryptococcal meningitis in HIV patients.

Other options:

  • Candida: Rarely causes meningitis; usually in neonates or severely immunocompromised.

  • Meningococcus: Causes acute bacterial meningitis, gram-negative diplococci on CSF, not India ink.

  • Coxsackie virus: Causes viral meningitis, CSF viral PCR positive, not India ink.

Key points:

  • Cryptococcal meningitis is common in CD4 <100/mm³ in HIV patients.

  • Clinical features: Headache, fever, altered sensorium, sometimes papilledema.

  • Diagnosis: CSF India ink stain, cryptococcal antigen, culture.

questions.text: A child was brought in the ER with a head injury. He also had a seizure on the way to the hospital. What is the likely percentage of early seizures in such patients?
questions.solution:
Early post-traumatic seizures (PTS) are seizures occurring within 7 days of a head injury.

Key points:

  • Occur more frequently in children and severe head injuries.

  • Incidence: Approximately 10–20%, with 17% being the commonly cited average.

  • Late PTS occur after 7 days and are associated with higher risk of developing post-traumatic epilepsy.

  • Risk factors include:

    • Severe head injury

    • Intracranial hemorrhage

    • Skull fractures

questions.text: The given test is done to check the integrity of which of the following structures?
questions.solution:
• Finger-Nose Test:
Purpose: Assesses upper limb coordination and the functioning of the cerebellum.
Method:
1. The patient is asked to alternately touch their nose and the examiner's moving finger multiple times.
2. The test is designed to evaluate coordination over the full range of motion of the upper limb.
3. Impairment in accuracy, smoothness of movement, or presence of tremor during the test suggests cerebellar dysfunction.
• Heel-Shin Test:
Purpose: Evaluates lower limb coordination and cerebellar function.
Method:
1. The patient lies down and places the heel of one leg on the shin of the other leg just below the knee.
2. They are then asked to slide the heel down the shin to the foot.
3. Patients with cerebellar lesions will have difficulty in accurately performing this action, often experiencing tremor or inability to smoothly trace the shin.
These tests are key in diagnosing cerebellar disorders, as they directly assess motor coordination, precision, and control of movement.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman presents with slurred speech weakness in right arm for 6 hours duration. The weakness gradually became lesser and resolves. She is a known case of diabetes and hypertension. Which of the following is the probable diagnosis of this case?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with sudden neurological deficits—slurred speech and right arm weakness—that developed acutely and resolved gradually within a few hours.

  • Transient Ischaemic Attack (TIA):

    • Sudden onset of focal neurological symptoms

    • Duration <24 hours (usually minutes to a few hours)

    • No permanent neurological deficit

    • Often a warning sign for future stroke

    • Risk factors include diabetes, hypertension, hyperlipidemia

Other options — brief:

  1. Ischaemic stroke: Neurological deficits persist >24 hours and may result in permanent damage.

  2. Compressive neuropathy: Usually gradual onset, localized to a nerve distribution, not sudden and transient.

  3. Diabetic neuropathy: Chronic, progressive, sensory > motor, not sudden focal weakness.

questions.text: A female patient presents with a throbbing unilateral pulsatile headache of severe intensity, which is aggravated by skipping meals. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical features described are classic for migraine:

  • Throbbing, unilateral headache

  • Pulsatile in nature

  • Severe intensity

  • Triggers: skipping meals, stress, hormonal changes, certain foods

  • May be associated with nausea, vomiting, photophobia, or phonophobia.

Other options:

  • Temporal arteritis: Usually in patients >50 years, with scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, and elevated ESR.

  • Trigeminal headache (neuralgia): Sharp, electric shock-like pain in trigeminal nerve distribution.

  • Cluster headache: Severe, unilateral, periorbital, associated with autonomic symptoms (lacrimation, nasal congestion), short duration, multiple attacks daily.

questions.text: What is the best line of management for a patient parenting with sudden onset unilateral LMN facial palsy with normal imaging findings?
questions.solution:
• The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Bell's palsy.
  • Treatment of Bell's palsy involves prednisone 60-80 mg daily during the first 5 days and then tapered over the next 5 days.
  • Acyclovir can also be used in patients who are suspected to have exposure to the herpes virus.
  • Tape or eye masks to depress the upper eyelid during sleep and artificial tears can be used to prevent corneal drying. Most patients recover within a few weeks or months.
Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 3439-3441.

questions.text: which of the following is not a feature of Korsakoff's psychosis?
questions.solution:
• Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome is a neurological disorder caused by the lack of thiamine (vitamin B1).
  • The disorder includes Wernicke encephalopathy and Korsakoff amnesic syndrome which are not different conditions but different stages of the same disease (Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome).
  • Wernicke's encephalopathy represents the "acute" phase of the disorder and Korsakoff's amnesic syndrome represents the disorder progressing to a "chronic" or long-lasting stage.
  • Wernicke's encephalopathy includes ataxia, opthalmoplegia, dementia.
  • Korsakoff's psychosis includes Amnesia, polyneuropathy and confabulation.

Reference: KAPLAN & SADOCK’S Synopsis of Psychiatry, 11th Edition, Page No 632.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a red flag sign is patient presenting with headache?
questions.solution:
Red flag signs-
  1. Tenderness over temporal area- D/d Temporal artertitis, early treatment neccesary to prevent visual loss.
  2. Subacute onset with worsening-Could be indiactive of tumour or expanding hematoma requiring further evaluation.
  3. Age >50 needs to be evaluated as it is most commonly secondary headache hence needs to be evaluated.
Cocaine abuse with headache can lead to Hypertensive Emergencies or strokes but not considered a primary red flag sign.

Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 113.

questions.text: Which of the following are features of lower motor neuron lesions?
questions.solution:
• Fasciculation, hypotonia, and muscle atrophy our features of a LMN lesion.



Reference: Harrison’s Principals of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition, Page No 165-166.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of reversible dementia?
questions.solution:
Lewy body dementia causes irreversible dementia.

Dementia is an acquired deterioration in cognitive abilities that impairs the successful performance of activities of daily living. The most commonly lost cognitive function is episodic memory, that is, the ability to recall events specific in time and place.

Causes of dementia are: Reversible

• Hypothyroidism

* Thiamine deficiency, vitamin B12 deficiency
* Normal pressure hydrocephalus

• Subdural hematoma

• Brain tumor


• Chronic infection

• Autoimmune encephalopathy


Irreversible

*Alzheimer‘s disease

• Huntington‘s disease

• Lewy body dementia


• Vascular dementia

* Creutzfeld-Jacob disease
* Frontotemporal dementia

 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 189-191 .

questions.text: A person comes to the OPD with symptoms of not using his left side and not washing the left side of his body while bathing. On examination, he wasn‘t able to draw the left side of the images. Which of the following is the most likely location of the lesion?
questions.solution:
• The given presentation suggest hemispatial neglect on the left side, likely due to a contralateral (right) parietal lobe lesion. The right hemisphere of the brain directs attention to the entire extrapersonal space, encompassing both the right and left sides.
  • If there is a lesion in the left hemisphere, there is minimal contralesional neglect because the right hemisphere can compensate for both sides.
  • The left hemisphere directs attention only to the contralateral right hemispace. Thus, a lesion in the right hemisphere can lead to severe contralesional hemineglect, as the left hemisphere does not contain ipsilateral attention functions.
Patients with neglect may be unable to dress or groom the left side of their body and may fail to replicate details on the left side of a drawing. Two bedside tests can be used to evaluate neglect:

1. Simultaneous Bilateral Stimulation: When the examiner provides unilateral or simultaneous bilateral stimulation in the visual, auditory, or tactile modalities, patients have no difficulty detecting unilateral stimuli on either side. However, when presented with bilateral stimuli, patients perceive it as coming only from one side, a phenomenon known as extinction.

2. Visual Target Cancellation: The patient fails to detect targets on one-half of the field during target-detection tasks.


Other features of non-dominant parietal lobe lesions include:

- Constructional apraxia
- Visuo-spatial disorientation
- Dressing apraxia


 

Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st edition, Page no 199, 200.

questions.text: Identify the neurological test being performed
questions.solution:
The image displays an extensor plantar response, indicating a positive Babinski sign.

Normally, when the sole of the foot is subjected to uncomfortable or painful cutaneous stimulation, the toes exhibit plantar flexion, sometimes accompanied by flexion withdrawal of the limb. However, if there is an upper motor neuron (UMN) lesion affecting the leg being tested, an extensor plantar response will occur, which is a positive Babinski sign. The minimum extensor response involves at least the extension of the great toe, often accompanied by fanning of the other toes and contraction of the tensor fascia lata. Additional features that may be seen in UMN lesions include spasticity of the leg, pathologically brisk reflexes, and ankle clonus.

 

Reference: Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, 26th edition, Page no 235 .

questions.text: A young patient presents with a severe headache. He has never experienced a headache of this severity before. He has hypertension and nuchal rigidity on examination. Which of the following could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical signs of neck stiffness and an intense headache (unlike any experienced before) indicate a potential diagnosis of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).

SAH occurs when there is bleeding into the subarachnoid space, located between the arachnoid membrane and the pia mater that encases the brain. Diagnosis is often suspected when hyperattenuating material is observed filling the subarachnoid space, typically around the circle of Willis, where most berry aneurysms are found, or in the Sylvian fissure.

Risk Factors:
Young males who experience sudden, severe headaches accompanied by seizures should raise suspicion for an aneurysmal subarachnoid hemorrhage. The leading cause of SAH is head trauma, followed by the rupture of a saccular aneurysm.

Symptoms:
Common symptoms of SAH include:
Severe headache (often described as a thunderclap headache)
Rapid onset vomiting
Confusion or altered consciousness
Seizures
Neck stiffness or pain

choices.text: Ipsilateral upper and lower halves of the face
Contralateral upper and lower halves of the face.

questions.text: Bell's palsy involves
questions.solution:
Bell's palsy affects both the upper and lower halves of the face on the ipsilateral side.



It is characterized as a lower motor neuron lesion of the facial nerve, resulting in idiopathic peripheral facial paralysis or paresis that occurs suddenly.

When a patient attempts to close their eye, the eyeball may turn upward and outward, a phenomenon known as Bell's phenomenon. Common symptoms include decreased tearing, hyperacusis, disturbances in taste, otalgia, weakness of the facial muscles, and difficulty with eyelid closure. When the patient smiles, their face may appear distorted, shifting to the side opposite the affected area, with noticeable flattening of the forehead and nasolabial fold on the side of the paralysis.

Treatment for Bell's palsy typically involves prednisone at a dosage of 60-80 mg daily for the first five days, followed by a taper over the next five days. Additionally, using artificial tears and covering the eye at night can help prevent corneal drying.

questions.text: 30-year-old man presented with excessive fatiguability towards the end of the day that improved with rest. He also gives a history of ptosis and difficulty in speech and swallowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Key clues in the case:

    • Fatigability that worsens with activity and improves with rest → hallmark of myasthenia gravis

    • Ptosis, dysarthria (difficulty in speech), dysphagia (difficulty swallowing) → common bulbar symptoms in MG

  • Other options:

    • SLE → multisystem autoimmune disorder, not characterized by fatigability or ptosis.

    • Lambert-Eaton syndrome → associated with small cell lung carcinoma, weakness improves with activity (opposite of MG).

    • Duchenne muscular dystrophy → childhood onset, progressive proximal muscle weakness, calf pseudohypertrophy, not fatigability with rest.

questions.text: A young male patient presents with ptosis and muscle weakness which reportedly worsens in the evening and improves in the morning. This is relieved by neostigmine. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Based on the given clinical picture, myasthenia gravis is the most likely diagnosis. The patient exhibits symptoms of ptosis, progressive weakness, and excessive fatigability, which improves with rest.

Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune neuromuscular junction disorder characterized by weakness and fatigability of skeletal muscles. This condition results from the autoantibody-mediated destruction of acetylcholine receptors (AChRs) at the post-synaptic membrane. As a consequence, there is a decrease in transmission at the neuromuscular junction, leading to muscle weakness.

The condition is more commonly seen in females than in males and tends to occur during middle age.

Other options:

  • Huntington chorea → involuntary movements + psychiatric symptoms, not fatigability.

  • ALS (Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis) → progressive upper and lower motor neuron signs, not relieved by neostigmine.

  • External ophthalmoplegia → paralysis of extraocular muscles, but not fluctuating weakness or response to neostigmine.

questions.text: In the sagittal section of the brain given below the colored area represents the paracentral lobule. Which of the following structures are affected in a lesion to this area?
questions.solution:
The area highlighted in the image is the paracentral lobule. A lesion in this region affects the perineum and leg.

Key Points:
  • The paracentral lobule is primarily supplied by the A2 segment of the anterior cerebral artery.
  • Lesions in the paracentral lobule can result in several clinical manifestations, including:
  • Weakness and loss of sensation in the contralateral lower limb (resulting in paraplegia).
  • Urinary incontinence due to involvement of the bladder control centers.
  • Fecal incontinence, which may occur due to disrupted control of bowel function.
  • This region plays a crucial role in the motor and sensory representation of the lower limb, as well as in bladder and bowel control.

questions.text: A woman presents with a history of headaches for the past 9 months that worsen in a recumbent position and improves as the day progresses. She also gives a history of taking oral contraceptives. Fundal examination shows papilledema. There are no focal neurological deficits. What is the probable cause of her headaches?
questions.solution:
The female patient experiencing recurring headaches characterized by positional and diurnal variation, along with raised intracranial pressure indicated by papilledema, is likely suffering from pseudotumor cerebri (idiopathic intracranial hypertension).

Risk Factors Include:
Female gender
Obesity
Nalidixic acid
Tetracycline
Vitamin A
Oral contraceptives
Use of or withdrawal from corticosteroids
Evaluation:
To assess the condition, brain imaging is necessary, with MRI being the most commonly used initial diagnostic study. The key feature of idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH) is elevated cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) opening pressure observed during lumbar puncture, even if there are no noticeable fundoscopic changes.

Initial Treatment:
The primary treatment involves administering acetazolamide. Topiramate may also be considered. Additionally, weight loss and discontinuation of any medications contributing to IIH should be undertaken.
 

Other options:

  • Temporal arteritis → usually >50 years, jaw claudication, visual loss, elevated ESR, not related to recumbency.

  • Chronic migraine → throbbing headache, usually unilateral, photophobia, phonophobia, nausea, but not associated with papilledema.

  • Myasthenia gravis → neuromuscular disease, presents with weakness, not headache.

questions.text: A 27 year old primigravida history of hyperemesis gravidarum currently presented with altered sensorium , opthalmoplegia , nystagmus and gait ataxia. What could be the possible diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
Wernicke encephalopathy (WE) is an acute neurological condition characterized by a clinical triad of ophthalmoparesis with nystagmus, ataxia, and confusion. This is a life-threatening illness caused by thiamine deficiency, which primarily affects the peripheral and central nervous systems. Korsakoff syndrome is neuropsychiatric disorder associated with memory disturbances in which there are significant deficits in anterograde and retrograde memory. Immediate memory is maintained, but short-term memory is diminished with intact sensorium. The disorder is associated with patients fabricating stories in the setting of clear consciousness.
High-risk groups for thiamine deficiency are:
• Lactating mothers
• Patients on regular haemodialysis
• Persistent vomiting
• Prolonged gastric aspiration
• People who go on long fasts
• High-risk groups should be treated with direct supplementation of thiamine.
Nelson Textbook of Pediatrics 20th Edition • Page nos 321 and 322

questions.text: A 17 year old girl was diagnosed to have meningitis her CSF findings were as follows what is the possible etiology? CSF appearance clear, cells 200 lymphocyte predominant CSF sugar 60 corresponding blood sugar levels 122mg/dl CSF protien 98mg/dl, CSF ADA- Normal
questions.solution: Lymphocyte predominant with normal sugar and elevated protien levels in CSF is suggestive of viral meningitis. Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition • Page no 999 - 1001

questions.text: 65y old male presents with left sided weakness for the last two hours. NCCT- Normal. His BP is 200/120mmhg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution: In a patient with Ischemic stroke in window period who is candidate for IV thrombolysis , BP should be maintained <185/110mmhg. IF the BP is higher than this Antihypertensives are indicated such as IV Nicardipine to reduce the BP. After the BP is reduced patient can be administered thrombolysis if there are no contraindications for the same. Ref- Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page 3335-3338

choices.text: Acetylcholine receptor and muscle-specific receptor tyrosine kinase antihadiac

questions.text: A 50 year old female presented with bilateral ptosis and double vision. She gives a peculiar history that she remains asymptomatic during morning hours and symptoms appear towards afternoon and progress in severity. Which of the following tests has the highest sensitivity in diagnosing this condition?
questions.solution:
Single-fiber electromyography has the highest sensitivity in the clinical diagnosis of myasthenia gravis.
Single-fiber electromyography (SFEMG) simultaneously records action potentials of two muscle fibers innervated by the same motor axon. The variability in time of the second action potential relative to the first is called
"jitter" and this is increased in myasthenia gravis.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition • Page no. 3234

questions.text: A 55 year old male with fatiguable proximal muscle weakness was found to have an anterior mediastinal mass. One evaluation he was found to have >10% decremental response on repetitive nerve stimulation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Myasthenia gravis is a neuromuscular junction (NMJ) disorder due to autoimmune damage to the postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors at the
NMJ. It is characterized by proximal muscle weakness and fatigue. Weakness increases with usage and muscle movement is difficult at the end of the day. Myasthenia gravis is usually associated with pericarditis Treatment includes Anticholinesterase drugs like Pyridostigmine, immunosuppression, and Thymectomy when associated with a Thymoma.
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 21st Edition • page no. 3509

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic patient consuming alcohol for the last 20 years had his last drink 3 days back. He presents with altered sensorium, disorientation, tremors, and a feeling of insects crawling over his body. Identify the condition
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of delirium tremens. Delirium tremens occurs after 2-4 days of abstinence in a heavy or chronic drinker. It is characterized by autonomic hyperactivity, tremors, delusions, and hallucinations- feeling of insects crawling over the body. It usually resolves spontaneously in 7 days but at times may be fatal due to cardiovascular collapse. Treatment includes Lorazepam + thiamine.
Kaplan & Sadock's Concise Textbook of Clinical Psychiatry 11th Edition • Page no
631, 1410

questions.text: Which of the following is the best next step in managment of a patient diagnosed with Wernicke's encephalopathy who comes to the Emergency department?
questions.solution: Current treatment guidelines for Wernicke's encephalopathy is to give Thiamine 100mg IV before administering IV dextrose containing fluids. Wernicke encephalopathy is characterized by - Global confusion, truncal ataxia, Ophthalmoplegia, Horizontal Nystagmus. Ref- Harrison Principles of Internal Medicine 20th edition Page 2080-2081

questions.text: Which of the following factors is not included in ABCD2 scoring?
questions.solution:
• The ABCD² score is used to predict the risk of stroke after a transient ischemic attack (TIA).

  • Components of ABCD²:

    • A: Age ≥60 years

    • B: Blood pressure ≥140/90 mmHg

    • C: Clinical features of TIA (unilateral weakness, speech disturbance)

    • D: Duration of symptoms (≥60 min, 10–59 min)

    • D: Diabetes mellitus



Reference
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition - Page no 3087

questions.text: Which of the following is least useful in the management of a patient with Thalamic Dejerine syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Among the options provided, Ibuprofen, which is an analgesic (NSAID) is considered the least effective in the management of Thalamic Dejerine Syndrome.
 
  • Thalamic Dejerine Syndrome, also known as Thalamic Pain Syndrome or Central Post-Stroke Pain, is a condition characterized by severe and often chronic pain on one side of the body following damage to the thalamus in the brain, commonly due to a stroke.
 
  • Occlusion of these thalamic and thalamogeniculate branches results in thalamic pain syndrome. It is characterized by C/L hemisensory loss which starts as numbness and progresses to cause severe burning pain in the affected regions.
 
  • Ibuprofen, an analgesic (NSAID), is thought to be the least successful treatment choice for Thalamic Dejerine Syndrome among the ones offered.
 
  • After injury to the thalamus in the brain, usually as a result of a stroke, thalamic dejerine syndrome, also known as thalamic pain syndrome or central post-stroke pain, is a disorder marked by severe and frequently chronic pain on one side of the body.
 
  • Thalamic pain syndrome is brought on by blockage of these thalamic and thalamogeniculate branches. It is typified by C/L hemisensory loss, which begins in the affected areas as numbness and develops into excruciating searing pain.
 
  • A lesion in the thalamus results in a misunderstanding between the cortex and the periphery because the thalamus relays sensory information between the two.


Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th edition, Page no 3072, 3073.

questions.text: A male patient was brought to the emergency room with complaints of headache, vomiting, and blurring of vision after he consumed some locally produced spirit. Which of the following is used for the treatment of his condition?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with headache, vomiting, and visual disturbances after consuming locally produced spirits, suggesting methanol poisoning.

  • Fomepizole is a competitive inhibitor of alcohol dehydrogenase, which prevents the conversion of methanol to toxic metabolites (formaldehyde and formic acid). It is the drug of choice in methanol poisoning.

Other options:

  • Flumazenil: Used to reverse benzodiazepine overdose, not methanol.

  • Diazepam: A benzodiazepine; not used in methanol toxicity.

  • Naloxone: Opioid receptor antagonist; used in opioid overdose, not alcohol poisoning.


Reference
The Essentials Of Forensic Medicine And Toxicology, 33rd edition - Page no: 582-583, 595, 586,631

questions.text: Which of the following autoantibody isotype is involved in the pathogenesis of Acute inflammatory Demyelinating Polyneuropathy (AIDP)?
questions.solution:
• Acute inflammatory demyelinating polyneuropathy (AIDP), the most common form of Guillain-Barré Syndrome (GBS), is an autoimmune demyelinating disorder of peripheral nerves.

  • The pathogenesis involves autoantibodies of the IgG isotype targeting myelin antigens, leading to complement-mediated demyelination and nerve conduction block.

Other options:

  • IgA: More associated with mucosal immunity; not a primary mediator in AIDP.

  • IgM: Often involved in chronic demyelinating neuropathies like anti-MAG neuropathy.

  • IgE: Typically involved in allergic reactions, not autoimmune demyelination.


Reference
Harrison's Principles Of Internal Medicine - 19th Edition - Page nos 2695-2696

questions.text: A patient is brought to the OPD with complaints of speaking nonsensical and made-up words. However, his speech is easy and fluent. His family claims his speech was fine until a few hours back. Which type of aphasia does the patient most likely have?
questions.solution:
• The patient’s speech is fluent, meaning normal rate and melody, but contains nonsensical or made-up words (neologisms).

  • Sudden onset suggests an acute neurological event, likely affecting Wernicke’s area.

  • Fluent aphasia (Wernicke’s aphasia) features:

    • Fluent, effortless speech

    • Poor comprehension

    • Paraphasias (word substitutions) and neologisms

    • Patient usually unaware of deficits

Other options:

  • Anomic aphasia: Difficulty finding words, speech otherwise fluent and meaningful.

  • Motor aphasia (Broca’s aphasia): Non-fluent, effortful speech, good comprehension.

  • Conduction aphasia: Fluent speech, good comprehension, but impaired repetition.



Reference
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition - Pg 159

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with excessive fatiguability towards the end of the day that improved with rest. He also gives a history of ptosis and difficulty in speech and swallowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with fatiguable weakness—worsening towards the end of the day and improving with rest.

  • Classic features include ptosis, dysarthria (difficulty in speech), and dysphagia (difficulty in swallowing).

  • Pathophysiology: Autoantibodies against acetylcholine receptors (AChR) at the neuromuscular junction cause impaired transmission.

  • Other options:

    • Lambert-Eaton syndrome: Weakness improves with activity (opposite pattern), often associated with small cell lung carcinoma.

    • Systemic lupus erythematosus: Multisystem autoimmune disease; muscle weakness is not typically fatiguable in this pattern.

    • Duchenne muscular dystrophy: X-linked, onset in childhood, progressive proximal weakness, not fatiguable.


Reference
Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th Edition - Page NO. 3232-3238, 3244

questions.text: Increased firing of ___ is responsible for the occurrence of scissoring gait.
questions.solution:
• Scissoring gait is commonly seen in spastic cerebral palsy or upper motor neuron lesions.

  • It occurs due to spasticity of the adductor muscles of the thigh.

  • The obturator nerve innervates the adductor group of muscles (adductor longus, brevis, magnus, gracilis, and obturator externus).

  • Increased firing or hypertonicity of these adductors causes the legs to cross over each other while walking, producing the characteristic scissoring gait.

Other options:

  • Inferior gluteal nerve: Innervates gluteus maximus; affects hip extension.

  • Femoral nerve: Innervates quadriceps; affects knee extension.

  • Superior gluteal nerve: Innervates gluteus medius and minimus; affects hip abduction and prevents Trendelenburg gait.



Reference:Nelson's textbook of pediatrics 20th edition Page no 2897

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with acute onset left-sided hemiparesis. The symptoms started 3 hours ago. On examination, blood pressure is 200/100 mm of hg. CT head is shown below. Which of the following should not be done in this patient?
questions.solution:
• The patient has acute left-sided hemiparesis with very high blood pressure and a CT head (showing intracerebral hemorrhage, given the context of hypertension and acute presentation).

  • Thrombolysis is contraindicated in hemorrhagic stroke because it can worsen bleeding.

Other options:

  • Edema management: Needed to reduce intracranial pressure in hemorrhagic stroke.

  • Blood pressure control: Essential to prevent expansion of the hematoma.

  • Clotting factor administration: If the patient was on anticoagulants or has coagulopathy, this is appropriate.



Reference: Bailey's and love short practice of surgery 27th edition page no 333-335

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with complaints of sudden, involuntary, and uncontrollable dance-like movements. He also complains of facing difficulty with his memory. His wife says he has gotten very emotional recently. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with the classic triad of Huntington’s disease:

  • Chorea: Sudden, involuntary, dance-like movements.

  • Cognitive decline: Memory difficulties.

  • Behavioral/psychiatric changes: Emotional lability, irritability.

Other options:

  • Parkinson’s disease: Characterized by bradykinesia, rigidity, resting tremor, not chorea.

  • Friedreich’s ataxia: Presents with gait ataxia, scoliosis, and cardiomyopathy; no chorea.

  • Alzheimer’s disease: Progressive memory loss without choreiform movements.


Reference:Goodman and Gillmans The pharmacological basis of Therapeutics 13th edition page no 335

questions.text: A 37-year-old female complains of recurrent episodes of discomfort, pain, and a sensation of pressure behind her left eye. She has intermittent proptosis, that is reducible. Her symptoms and signs are accentuated when she bends forward. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient presents with intermittent, reducible proptosis that worsens with bending forward. These are classic features of orbital varices.

  • Orbital varices are abnormal, dilated venous channels within the orbit that expand with increased venous pressure (Valsalva maneuver, bending forward, or straining).

  • Symptoms include: intermittent proptosis, orbital pressure, and discomfort.

  • They may thrombose, causing sudden painful proptosis.

Other options:

  • Orbital dermoid cyst: Usually congenital, non-compressible, and painless, often superotemporal; does not fluctuate with posture.

  • Orbital hemangioma: Typically a capillary or cavernous type, non-reducible, slowly progressive proptosis, usually in children.

  • Orbital metastasis: Usually painful, firm, and rapidly progressive; not posture-dependent.

Key point: Fluctuating proptosis that worsens with Valsalva or bending forward is pathognomonic for orbital varices.


Reference:Kanski's clinical opthalmology: A systematic approach 8e page 98

questions.text: If all Extraocular muscles are paralysed ,where would you suspect the lesion?
questions.solution:
• All extraocular muscles are innervated by cranial nerves III (oculomotor), IV (trochlear), and VI (abducens).

  • These cranial nerves originate in the midbrain and pons:

    • CN III: Midbrain (at the level of the superior colliculus)

    • CN IV: Midbrain (dorsal aspect, lower)

    • CN VI: Pons

  • A lesion affecting both the midbrain and pons can paralyze all extraocular muscles.

    Why other options are incorrect:

  • 1. Frontal eye field:

    • Controls voluntary eye movements (saccades), especially to the opposite side.

    • Lesion causes deviation of the eyes to the ipsilateral side but does not paralyze all EOMs.

  • 3. Cerebral surface:

    • May impact cortical control of eye movements, but again will not paralyze all EOMs.

    • Can cause gaze preference or neglect, not full EOM paralysis.

  • 4. Spinal cord:

    • Has no role in innervating extraocular muscles.

    • Lesion here affects body motor/sensory control, not eye movement.

      Topic Discussion: Extraocular Muscle Innervation and Lesions

  • Extraocular Muscles (EOMs):

    • Total 6 muscles:

      • Superior, Inferior, Medial, Lateral Rectus

      • Superior Oblique, Inferior Oblique

    • Innervated by:

      • Oculomotor nerve (CN III): SR, IR, MR, IO, and levator palpebrae

      • Trochlear nerve (CN IV): SO

      • Abducens nerve (CN VI): LR

  • Lesion sites and effects:

    • CN III palsy: Eye is down and out; ptosis, dilated pupil

    • CN IV palsy: Vertical diplopia, worse on looking down (e.g., stairs)

    • CN VI palsy: Medial deviation of the eye (unable to abduct)

  • Lesion of midbrain and pons:

    • Can affect all 3 cranial nerves supplying EOMs.

    • Result: Complete ophthalmoplegia (paralysis of all extraocular muscles)

    • Common causes: Brainstem stroke, tumor, demyelination


Reference:Gray's Anatomy The Anatomical Basis Of Clinical Practice 41st edition page no
671-673

questions.text: A 54-year-old man was brought to the casualty with fever, headache, focal seizures. EEG shows focal temporal lobe spikes. CSF sample analysis shows 50 cells with 90% Lymphocytes and 10% Neutrophils. What would be the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with:

  • Fever, headache, focal seizures

  • EEG: Focal temporal lobe spikes

  • CSF: Lymphocytic pleocytosis (suggesting viral etiology)

These features are classic for Herpes Simplex Virus (HSV) encephalitis, especially HSV-1, which commonly affects the temporal lobes.

HSV Encephalitis – Key Clues:

  • Acute/subacute onset of altered sensorium, seizures, fever

  • Focal neurological signs, especially involving temporal lobe

  • EEG: Temporal lobe spikes or periodic lateralized epileptiform discharges (PLEDs)

  • CSF: ↑ Lymphocytes, mild to moderate protein, normal or slightly ↓ glucose

  • MRI: Hyperintensities in temporal lobes

    Drug of Choice:

  • Acyclovir (IV) is the first-line treatment.

  • It is essential to start empirical acyclovir immediately in suspected HSV encephalitis due to high mortality if untreated.

    Other Options:

  • Ganciclovir – CMV, not HSV

  • Foscarnet – Used for resistant HSV/CMV

  • Valacyclovir – Oral agent, not used in acute severe encephalitis



Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 946

questions.text: A patient comes with a blood pressure of 160/100 mmHg and left-sided facial paralysis and weakness for 8 hours. Her CT is shown below. What would be your next step?
questions.solution:
• Presentation: Sudden-onset hemiparesis and facial weakness

  • BP: 160/100 mmHg

  • Duration: 8 hours

  • CT: Normal (rules out hemorrhage)

  • Diagnosis: Likely ischemic stroke or TIA

  • Time window: Outside thrombolysis window (4.5 hours)

    Explanation (based on key acute stroke management principles):

    Imaging

  • Initial non-contrast CT (NCCT) is used to rule out hemorrhage, not to confirm infarction (early ischemia may not show up for 24–48 hours).

  • This patient's CT is normal, which is not unusual in early ischemic stroke or TIA.

    Time Since Onset

  • At 8 hours, the patient is outside the 4.5-hour window for IV thrombolysis (alteplase).

  • Also outside most mechanical thrombectomy windows unless perfusion mismatch is demonstrated on advanced imaging (not mentioned here).

    Blood Pressure Management

  • Patient's BP: 160/100 mmHg

  • Since thrombolysis is not planned, antihypertensive treatment is not required unless BP >220/120 mmHg.

  • Avoid aggressive BP lowering – overcorrection can worsen cerebral perfusion in the ischemic penumbra.

  • Oral Nifedipine is contraindicated for this reason.

    Next Best Step

  • Supportive care and close monitoring, including serial neuro checks, oxygenation, and glucose control.

  • Start antiplatelets (e.g., aspirin) after ruling out hemorrhage.

  • Workup for etiology (ECG, echocardiography, carotid Doppler, etc.) to prevent recurrence.

    Why Other Options Are Incorrect:

Option Why It’s Incorrect
1. IV labetalol BP <220/120 mmHg, and no end-organ damage—no need to lower BP now.
3. IV thrombolysis Patient is outside 4.5-hour window.
4. Oral nifedipine Sudden BP drop can worsen brain ischemia—contraindicated in acute stroke.
 

In a patient with ischemic stroke who presents outside the thrombolysis window and has moderate BP elevation, the best next step is observation and monitoring. Blood pressure should not be lowered aggressively, and thrombolysis is not an option at 8 hours without advanced imaging supporting intervention.


Reference - Harrisons Principles of Internal Medicine 21st edition Page no 3334-3337

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presented with excessive fatiguability towards the end of the day that improved with rest. He also gives history of ptosis, difficult in speech and swallowing. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The patient presents with fatigability that improves with rest, ptosis, and difficulty in speech and swallowing, which are classic features of myasthenia gravis.

  • Myasthenia gravis is an autoimmune disorder caused by antibodies against postsynaptic acetylcholine receptors at the neuromuscular junction.

  • It is characterized by fluctuating weakness, particularly involving ocular, bulbar, and proximal limb muscles.

  • Symptoms typically worsen at the end of the day or after prolonged activity, and improve with rest.

Why other options are incorrect:

  • Lambert-Eaton syndrome: Weakness improves with activity (opposite pattern), often involves autonomic symptoms, and is commonly associated with paraneoplastic syndromes.

  • Systemic lupus erythematosus: May cause fatigue but not the pattern of fatigable muscle weakness with ptosis and bulbar signs.

Duchenne muscular dystrophy: Typically presents in early childhood, not adulthood, and is marked by progressive rather than fluctuating weakness. Ptosis is not a hallmark feature.
 

Definition
Myasthenia gravis (MG) is an autoimmune disorder characterized by fluctuating skeletal muscle weakness due to autoantibodies directed against components of the postsynaptic membrane at the neuromuscular junction, most commonly the acetylcholine receptor (AChR).

Clinical Manifestations

1. Ocular Involvement

Ptosis and diplopia are the initial presenting symptoms in the majority of patients.

Typically asymmetric and fluctuating.

2. Bulbar and Cranial Muscle Weakness

Dysarthria (nasal speech), dysphagia, and fatigable chewing.

Facial weakness produces a characteristic “myasthenic snarl” when attempting to smile.

3. Limb and Axial Weakness

Predominantly proximal and asymmetric.

Typically worsens with exertion and improves with rest.

4. Reflexes and Sensory Examination

Deep tendon reflexes are preserved.

No sensory deficits are present.

5. Myasthenic Crisis

A life-threatening exacerbation involving respiratory muscle weakness.

Diagnostic Approach

1. Bedside Tests

Ice Pack Test: Temporary improvement in ptosis with application of ice, due to inhibition of acetylcholinesterase.

Edrophonium (Tensilon) Test: Transient improvement in muscle strength following administration of a short-acting acetylcholinesterase inhibitor (used less frequently now due to availability of antibody testing).

2. Serological Testing

Anti-AChR antibodies (positive in ~85% of generalized MG)

3. Electrophysiological Studies

Repetitive nerve stimulation: Demonstrates a characteristic decremental response.

Single-fiber electromyography (SFEMG): Most sensitive test; detects increased jitter.

4. Imaging

Chest CT/MRI to evaluate for thymic pathology.

Management

1. Symptomatic Therapy

Acetylcholinesterase inhibitors: Pyridostigmine is the first-line agent for symptomatic relief.

2. Disease-Modifying Therapy

Corticosteroids: Prednisone is often used for immunosuppression.

Steroid-sparing agents: Azathioprine, mycophenolate mofetil, cyclosporine, tacrolimus, and rituximab.

3. Surgical Management

Thymectomy: Indicated in the presence of thymoma and considered in younger patients with generalized disease—even in the absence of thymoma.

4. Acute Exacerbations / Myasthenic Crisis

Plasmapheresis or IVIG: Used for rapid immunomodulation.

ICU-level care may be required for respiratory support.


Reference: Harrison's principles of internal medicine 20th edition Page no 3232-3238,3244

questions.text: A patient came to casualty complaining of a severe headache. On examination, there was no focal neurological defect. However, neck rigidity was present. The casualty medical officer ordered an emergency CT which revealed the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical and radiological findings are characteristic of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH).
Clinical Clues:

  • Severe sudden-onset headache (often described as "worst headache of life")

  • Neck rigidity suggests meningeal irritation due to blood in the subarachnoid space

  • No focal neurological deficit – early SAH can present without localizing signs

    Radiological Finding:

  • Blood in the basal cisterns on a non-contrast CT is a hallmark of subarachnoid hemorrhage

    • Basal cisterns include suprasellar, interpeduncular, and ambient cisterns.

    • Blood in these areas on CT is considered diagnostic of SAH, especially in the acute phase (within 24–72 hours).

      Why other options are incorrect:

  • Pituitary apoplexy: May present with headache and visual disturbances, but typically shows a hemorrhagic or infarcted pituitary mass on imaging, not blood in the basal cisterns.

  • Subdural hemorrhage: Classically shows crescent-shaped blood collections between the dura and arachnoid, not in the basal cisterns.

  • Pituitary carcinoma: Very rare; typically presents with mass effect, hypopituitarism, or visual field defects. Not associated with acute hemorrhage in basal cisterns.

    Summary:

The presence of acute headache with neck rigidity and blood in the basal cisterns on non-contrast CT points strongly toward subarachnoid hemorrhage, most commonly due to rupture of a cerebral aneurysm.




Reference: Harrison's Principles of Internal Medicine, 20th edition, Page no 2084.

choices.text: He has a long face, large ear, large testis and a cardiac murmur. What is the diagnosis?

questions.text: A young male child was brought for psychiatric evaluation for intellectual disability. On examination, his IQ was 45. He has a long face, large ear, large testis and a cardiac murmur. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Young male with intellectual disability

  • IQ of 45 indicates moderate intellectual disability

  • Long face, large ears, and macroorchidism (large testes) are characteristic physical features

  • Presence of a cardiac murmur, often due to mitral valve prolapse

  • These findings are highly suggestive of Fragile X syndrome

    Genetic Basis:

  • Caused by CGG trinucleotide repeat expansion in the FMR1 gene on the X chromosome

  • Inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern

    Why other options are incorrect:

  1. Cushing's syndrome – Presents with weight gain, moon face, central obesity, not with ID or dysmorphic features

  2. Rett syndrome – Affects girls, with regression in development, hand-wringing movements

  3. Williams syndrome – Features include elfin facies, supravalvular aortic stenosis, and overfriendly behavior, not macroorchidism


Reference:Robin's and cotran pathologic basis of Therapeutics 9e page no 169-170

questions.text: Treatment of Grade 1 Meningioma?
questions.solution:
Grade I meningiomas (WHO Grade I) are the most common type and are benign, slow-growing, and often well-circumscribed.

Treatment Approach:

Grade I Meningioma Management
Symptomatic Surgical excision is the first-line treatment if the tumor is accessible.
Asymptomatic & small Observation with regular MRI scans may be considered.
Incomplete excision Postoperative radiotherapy may be considered.
Inoperable Stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) or conventional radiotherapy.


Other Options:

  • Chemotherapy is ineffective for Grade I meningiomas.

  • Radiotherapy is used postoperatively if resection is incomplete or in higher-grade tumors.

  • Reassurance alone is not sufficient for symptomatic or growing tumors.


Reference:Robbins and cotran pathologic basis of disease 9e page no 1314-1315
